It is good to model mindful behavior for them, even in the little things. They add up!

The Invicta Men's 21446 Pro Diver Analog Display Japanese Quartz Black Watch is very good looking. I love Invicta designs; they are always very handsome and appealing. This watch has a comfortable polyurethane strap which makes it slightly more sporty and casual looking. The face of the watch is great. It is gold plated stainless steel ringed with a cool green to black marker. It is truly unique looking. It has a luminous dial and is water resistant to 330 feet. I doubt anyone would really use this as a pro diver watch. Rather, it seems they are referring to the style and look of this Invicta's men's watch, not its function.I received mine in a navy box instead of the yellow box shown when you look at the watch offered here. Just a heads up.At these prices, Invicta cannot be beat. Having a watch with a nice Japanese Quartz movement, and a stainless steel 18 k ion-plated gold face this lovely is a bargain, if this is to your taste. Great gift!

This London Fog Men's Cromwell Parka Coat has been a success for my adult son who has autism.My main concern was that he have a very warm parka during the cold winters in NY. It had to have a hood, too!My second concern was that it be able to be washed.This parka by London Fog filled the bill in every way.We love the ink blue. It is very attractive.This parka has been nice and durable. It is going into its second year now. Recommended!

I purchased this at a much higher cost at my local pharmacy. I am growing out my hair. I wanted to see if a new shampoo would help gear up my enthusiasm during this awkward "in between" time of having no hairstyle to speak of.The shampoo went on great, with nice suds. However after rinsing, it left my hair dull and somewhat dry. Where were the great conditioning properties of Argan Oil? I didn't notice anything.It actually stripped my hair a bit.I will use up this bottle, however I won't purchase this product again.I also tried a leave in conditioner from the same company. It was ineffective as well,The price for each (where I bought them) was comparable to the prices for Fekkai products. Fekkai is far superior. I cannot recommend this, even at the lower price I note offered by Amazon.

If you are looking forward to the holiday season, and you love crafts, you are going to adore this book, 'Tis the Season to Be Felt-y: Over 40 Handmade Holiday Decorations, by Kathy Sheldon with Amanda Carestio.With super pretty color photos and clear directions, 'Tis the Season is tons of fun. The 40 plus holiday themed projects are well designed by top names in the crafting field. Each one will inspire the reader to try her hand at creating with felt! And it will be worth it, as the decorations you can make are lively, colorful and packed full of festive charm.Felt is one of the easiest materials a crafter can work with.Additionally, the instructions for the projects are a snap to follow.There are plenty of templates at the back of the book the reader will find very useful as well.The materials and tools needed to craft the decorations offered are inexpensive and easy to obtain. You may have a lot of what you need already at home.You are going to want to embrace the appeal of crafting with felt when you look at any and all of the projects.Get ready, get set, and dive in!Check out the "Clove-Filled Orange Ornaments" designed by Mollie Johanson. What a clever and pretty take on the traditional pomander ball. Filled with the sent of cloves, these pretty oranges made of felt and trimmed with green ribbons would be a delightful teacher's gift.Aimee Ray's "Felt Light Up Village" is wonderful, if you want to set a mood as you look forward to this magical season. Her enchanting felt houses will require some simple embroidered embellishing. You will be rewarded for your efforts with a little village, hand made by you, which you can arrange in all sorts of sweet and funky ways as you herald the approach of Christmas.Another project I liked is the very hip "Bird Mobile", designed by Jennifer Jessee. With green felt balls, cheery felt snowflakes and the cutest felt bird this side of the North Pole, you have yourself a mobile to love all winter through, not just during the holiday season.The "Joy to the World Garland" by author Kathy Sheldon is, according to her, "so simple that, if you help cut out the letters(or purchase stick-on felt letters), kids can make it!" It is a lovely large banner that just bursts with the excitement of this festive time of year. Really fun!One of my special favorites is the "Rustic Reindeer" by Suzie Millions. This little free standing reindeer decoration touched my heart and made me smile. He is created by you of different tones of orange felt, with white felt. He has twig antlers and twig legs. When this reindeer peeks out at you,  you will melt. This is the project I want to try first. He is guaranteed to delight my grandchildren and family.There is lots more to make and to love, from tree skirts with bunnies, to felt poinsettia wreaths, to partridges and pear trees! There is even a gingerbread house tissue box cover!'Tis the Season to Be Felty is the successor to Fa la la la Felt: 45 Handmade Holiday Decorations by the same authors. Many of the same designers have contributed to this lovely and fun book.I have never been so excited for the holidays to come since I was a kid. Hand made decorations make for irreplaceable happy memories.I was glad to note that the seasonal cheer offered by the projects in 'Tis the Season to Be Felt-y is primarily non-denominational. It is great that we all can get in the spirit!Join in the fun with 'Tis the Season to Be Felty. Celebrate the wonders of creating with felt! You truly can do this. What is more, you will have a total blast doing it! Lovely craft book!Note: I received this book in exchange for my honest review.

I am very pleased with the purity and high quality of Sabai Wellness' Lavender Essential Oil.This soothing scent is carefully crafted from Lavandula Angustifolia and Lavandula Latifolia. Always look for the Latin names of the flowers, when you are buying essential oils: they indicate that the oils distilled from them are truly legitimate.Lavender oil can be used for many purposes. I like Sabai Wellness Lavender essential oil especially in my diffuser. The fragrance calms me as I drift off to sleep.I also have tried a suggestion from a friend of mine. I added a few drops to a clean washcloth and tossed it in the dryer. My laundry has never smelled so fabulous!Lavender oil is a wonderful essential oil to keep around for quick stress relief. It is like having serenity in a bottle!I carry Sabai Wellness Lavender oil in my purse when I travel. I put a little on my hands and inhale the calming scent when I am in crowded places and becoming bothered by large groups of people. It helps to ground me and give me peace.I have not tried ingesting it yet but many people do. I am considering adding it to my tea (you can even use it to bake with!). Lavender oil is recommended to enhance flavor enjoyment, and also to aid in alleviating digestive complaints.There are tons of ways to use Lavender essential oil!The purity of Sabai's product, this delightful Premium, High End Pure Undiluted French Lavender Essential Oil, is trusted by me.I love this wonderful wonder worker!I was provided with this product in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

This analog watch has a gorgeous high end appearance. Invicta goes all out with presentation.The Invicta Men's 19241 Specialty Analog Display Japanese Quartz Gold Watch arrives double boxed in glamorous yellow, to wow the recipient.  There is an impressive outer box in yellow, and within is found a second yellow colored sueded box. The inner box holds this beautiful man's watch. The effect upon opening, both breathtaking and exciting, is one of luxury and good taste. This is not a flashy, cheap watch. It is a well designed, high end analog watch.What is an analog watch? Simply put, an analog watch is one in which the display is not digital. Look at the face of this watch. The time is indicated by the continuous motion of rotating hands pointing to numbers arrayed on the circular dial. The hour hand's movement is analogous to the path of the Sun across the sky. There you go: that is what an analog watch is.However, there is more to this watch. It also has chronograph functions, with 60 second, 60 minute and 24 hour subdials. It has a luminous band to light up the bezel at night.The case and band are comprised of gold plated stainless steel.The Invicta Men's 109241 has a Japanese quartz movement. The Japapese are second only to the Swiss in this area. They are catching up fast. A Japanese quartz movement denotes high quality timekeeping these days. While researching Japanese quartz movements vis a vis Swiss quartz movements, I learned this online: "Japanese quartz is known for accuracy, and was used as the official timekeeper at many Olympic games". The Japanese quartz movement is a fine, slightly less expensive but close competitor to the Swiss quartz movement. Both are considered supremely accurate. You can be proud to own this Invicta, or to give it. Not only is it good looking, it will be dependable. It is not going to let you down in the time keeping department.This watch is not for the shy. It is very glamorous in design. It is a bold looking, very masculine watch.The sapphire dial with its gold accents is especially beautiful to look at. I love the elegant layout of the 60 second, 60 minute, and 24 hour subdials. They are useful as well as entrancing to look at. The body of the watch, heavily matte gold plated stainless steel, has a elegant and comfortable adjustable bracelet. If you are looking for a gift for the man in your life, look no further! This big gorgeous chunk of a watch, shining brilliant in gold and blue, will be loved by him for years to come. It comes with a guarantee, and is water resistant to over 300 feet. The Invicta Men's 19241 Specialty Analog Display Japanese Quartz Gold Watch is a watch to depend on. A beautiful man's watch for a great price.

I love this mouthwash. You are supposed to use it three times a day.It helps even if you skip a time or two!It is completely natural, with no artificial sweeteners. It has a pleasing taste and doesn't sting your mouth or gums when they are feeling sensitive..It is very effective for preventing gingivitis, which is why I initially purchased it. One of my friends had recommended it to me after her dentist told her about it. When I bought it at my local pharmacy, the pharmacist told me that she has tons of people who buy this from her and swear by it. It has a "following", as has the toothpaste by the same company!The Natural Dentist Antigingivitis Rinse for Gums obviously isn't a substitute for visiting your dentist when you need to.  However, it is definitely a great adjunct your arsenal of products when you are fighting gum disease. Try it.

The Secret Lives of Bats: My Adventures with the World's Most Misunderstood Mammals, is a wonderful book. I have recommended this delightful and informative adventure story to everyone.Merlin Tuttle is a great storyteller and a fount of knowledge on bats. He is open, honest and charming as he relates the remarkable history of his life as a bat enthusiast.Having studied bats for more than fifty years, his passion and love for these creatures is evident. He started Bat Conservation International back in 1982. Tuttle, one of the foremost educators in this field, is a dedicated scientist, and ecologist. He is a heck of a terrific human being.There is no self indulgence  in this charmingly related history of  Merlin Tuttle's lifelong love of bats. Rather it is funny, fun and informative. If you know little about bats you will love learning lots with Tuttle as your teacher! If you like animal stories, such as those by Durrell, Mowat, and Herriot, this book's perspective will pull you right in. If you love adventure, close encounters with danger, tons of fun, and even scares with wild and woolly tales of moonshiners and other offbeat sorts, come along for the ride. This compassionate teacher will open to you all of the beauty and all that is fine about our own species as well as bats. The years it spans add to the flavor of the book, as the author learns from childhood about bats and their nature. You are given amazing, evolving insight into  the secret world  of bats from start to finish.Ultimately you will be moved by the nobility of this book. People seem to bring out the best in each other, united in their fascination with Tuttle's love for bats. It is a delight.This a positive story which is real, fun and true. It is very educational as well. The Secret Lives of Bats: My Adventures with the World's Most Misunderstood Mammals is an upbeat gem from a great nature writer.There is something  enduring about The Secret Lives of Bats which everyone who reads it will adore.Bats are beautiful to me now, thanks to Merlin Tuttle..

To say I like this company is to put it mildly. I think they are one of the leaders in the health and beauty industry. Their focus, to me seems targeted toward the older demographic (which I fit into). However,  the InstaNaturals line is surely great as well, for younger skin.  It is downright perfect for ,my dull, dry, aging skin in particular though! Light up your face by using this lovely night cream! As it says, it "hydrates and plumps skin". My skin has never felt so soft.I would not use this right after exfoliating (it will sting a little if you have sensitive skin like me, but the sting goes away fast). I use this instead after toning, and using serum, at night.  It smooths right on after you deliver it by way of a cleverly designed pump. You don't need much but do add some to your neck and even your decollete. The improvement in even skin tone is almost instantaneous.The scent is not very pretty, however it dissipates rapidly. I can feel the effects of this night cream on the surface of my skin hours after I have applied it. It works through the night very well, lasting through the hours until you wake up refreshed and ready to greet the day with your fresh, pretty and radiant skin! Recommended!Note: I received this night cream in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

Effective and pleasantly scented with oranges, this product by InstaNaturals is a winner! Their Pro-Radiant Skin Brightening Serum is just wonderful for my aging skin. I was surprised to see the orange color of the serum but you don't care about the color after you see the beautiful effects of this treatment on your skin.  When I used this for the first time, I felt an immediate softening of my skin. You do not need to use much as it goes a long way. Orange or not, it pampers your facial skin and prepares it for your night cream, or for moisturizers and makeup.My skin looks more refined since I have been using this serum. I notice that my fine lines are lessening, possibly due to some of the ingredients. I am thrilled about that as I am in my sixties. It is never too late to care for your skin! Let this little wonder worker work its magic for you, too!  I love it!Note: I received this product for free in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

InstaNatural's Vitamin C Facial Toner is a wonderfully refreshing skin toner. I have found that it instantly gives my complexion a wake up call, but without any sting to it. It is comfortably soothing to sensitive skin. However you can tell that your skin is being treated to a pore tightening, cleansing, and refining toner. I am pleased to have this toner to use on the days I am not doing a deep exfoliating cleanse. It is very calming and has the lovely scent of oranges, due to the Vitamin C it contains.Vitamin C Facial Toner is simple to use. I just spray it on a cotton pad and gently pat it off. It leaves my skin clean and clear, ready for day or night serums and moisturizing creams. I like it very much!note: I received this product for free for my honest and unbiased feedback.

What a wonderful and well designed product  LaMagia's Essential Oil Diffuser  is!LaMagia went above and beyond in thinking the design and intention of this diffuser through.I have found this product to be everything I could possibly want in a home essential oil diffuser. I can see it easily being used in a spa, as well.I like the ease of set up and the excellent, high quality sturdiness.The mist from the diffuser can be controlled to your liking, as can the dispersal of the essential oil you choose to use.People are growing more and more aware of alternative ways to reduce the stress and strain of daily living. A diffuser is one way you can do something luxurious and calming for yourself in a fairly inexpensive way.The design of LaMagia's diffuser is really excellent. The cord fits into its own slot in the bottom. A water cup is thoughtfully provided to measure the water used for misting and dispersing. The unit shuts off when the water well is empty, so you don't need to worry about that.The cleaning instructions are clear and easy to follow.The colors are amazing--I wish I could photograph them all! I am mesmerized by them. They are beautiful and relaxing to watch.Essential oil (which is not included) is getting more popular as we all learn more about aromatherapy and alternative medicine. It is worth researching. I have been doing just that because of this lovely diffuser.Do something good for yourself and give yourself the gift of  LaMagia's well made, pretty and sleek diffuser, The peace and tranquility you will get in return will be more than worth it. The LaMiglia diffuser affects in a positive manner your sense of smell, and what you see in your surroundings as well,It is a great investment in well-being!This diffuser would make a delightful wedding gift or birthday present for someone you love.note: I was provided with this product in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

This is the first Proactiv+ product I have tried. However I have a number of friends who swear by this line of products, both for their own beauty regimens, and also for the young adults in the family.I don't have acne but I chose this cream because over time it should  clarify and even out my skin tone. As a woman in her sixties, having great skin tone and having a glowing complexion is a  big priority of mine.So far, here is what I have found.It is not too harsh for my skin ( and I have fair, sensitive skin).It goes on in a very pleasant way and sinks in fast. No residue is left.It really keeps my skin feeling noticeably softer.I think the main ingredients are not only effective for acne (as I have learned from people I am friends with), but possibly act to exfoliate your skin. If not overdone, and it isn't overdone by Proactive+  in their Clarifying Night Cream, your skin should look and feel softer, clearer, less blotchy and prettier in general.It has given me a luminosity I am pleased with.I am proud of my skin and always try to treat it right as I continue to get older. I like Proactiv+ Clarifying Night Cream very much.PS: It smells great!
Nice, if a tiny bit loose. I use them for indoor exercising.

I did a lot of research before I bought this one. I never saw the TV show and had no reference because of that. However, I read a lot about all the exercise DVDs offered and chose this one for several reasons.The levels of difficulty are pretty accessible if you have not been exercising AT ALL but are used to exercise in the past, and don't have too many basic physical things to hold you back from exercise in general.The enthusiasm and encouragement from Bob Harper seems genuine and unforced. I like watching him. He is not annoying or intrusive.You can go at your own pace as you progress, as long as you are able to walk.This DVD is cheerful and gets you going. I am glad to have found it.

The Char-Broil Standard Digital Electric Smoker is a high quality, mindfully designed product. Let it be your partner-in-arms as you try out smoking ribs, pork and other meats. It is fun and almost effortless!I was interested in the Char-Broil Standard Digital Electric Smoker for a couple of reasons.1) We eat out less because of the expense of going out, but we love good food2) We are learning to enjoy cooking as a hobby.When I first considered ordering it, I looked up health concerns, as smoking meats brings up the subject of carcinogens. From what I read online, smoked meat, when eaten in moderation, has negligible ill effects. Just don't over do it.My other worry was whether or not the smoker would give off heat. However it is cool to the touch and therefore safe around children (who should be supervised around it anyway, obviously). Once my mind was put at ease. I was totally gung ho to try it. I have not been disappointed yet!It is easy to use. Set up was a breeze, with no assembly required. It is spacious and nicely designed. It has four racks and holds tons of food at one time!  The Char-Broil Standard Digital Electric Smoker has a useful and efficient digital thermometer, automatic shut off, and easy rolling wheels.If you like to throw parties it is perfect as you can cook for a crowd.I am still trying out different recipes (yes, I watch the Food Network) but eventually I plan to have that big party. I am all for staycations at home these days for economic reasons. This smoker really helps you rediscover the pleasures of decompressing by hanging out with friends, something cool to drink, and some great eats in your own backyard.I am very happy with this standard edition of the Char-Broil Standard Digital Electric Smoker.The only difference with the standard is a) it is black instead of stainless and b) it doesn't have a front window so you can't look inside...You are just going to have to be surprised. ;)I have tried smoked chicken, which came out deliciously. It makes great leftovers for use in salads. I also tried smoked baby back ribs with a rub. I used mesquite wood chips for that and they came out amazing. I love the wood chips and want to try apple next. WoodChar-Broil Mesquite Wood Chips chips are easier to use with this smoker; a great advantage over some of the other smokers where you have to change the chips more often.The Char-Broil Standard Digital Electric Smoker is a wonderful addition for the avid food lover. It would be a thoughtful and much appreciated gift for newlyweds, if they have the room for it. It is pretty, large, and sturdy, with a really nice design. Once you get one, you can't imagine how much enjoyment you will get from the yummy meals you will be making yourself. I love it!

There is a lot of fun and inspiration to be had when you open and learn from Unexpected Findings by Michelle Mach.Ms. Mach creates great projects which include super pretty and inventive findings,  intriguing "stars of the show", which are great fun to try out.Additionally. the author has chosen great contributors to pack some added punch to Unexpected Findings. These contributors are designers Lorelei Eurto, Erin Siegal, Jamie Hogsett, Denise Yesbak Moore, Erin Praiz-Hintz, Andrew Thornton, Molly Shaller, Erin Strother, Barb Switzer, and Cindy Wimmer.Along with the author, these are some of the most beloved designers working in the jewelry field today. It is a treat to have them all together with Ms. Mach.The focus is truly original. The reader is presented with a terrific way to learn a new jewelry style. The author shares her knowledge concerning how to make all sorts of jewelry components from the findings you might have in your jewelry collection. There are fifty projects to linger over and enjoy as you learn. You not only get earrings to try, you get necklaces and bracelets as well, all showcasing findings in a most delightful way.Unexpected Findings is a wonderful book filled with great jewelry designs!The beginning of the book introduces the reader to the many kinds of findings which will be used. After that is a look at how to jazz up those findings. This section really gets right to the point, including adding patina, hole punching, painting and more. It is a great introduction to the direction that Unexpected Findings will be heading.There is a very complete list of other findings and tools before the projects begin.The idea of using findings as a way of making jewelry is a lot of fun.The projects are very pretty and quite fascinating. Michelle Mach has done a fine job designing using findings.There are many styles of jewelry presented, all of which are lovely."Tuesday Night Book Club" by Michelle herself, is a wonderful and charming  leather cord and pendant necklace. Once the reader sees how it is made and understands the techniques used, it is a very fun and easy project, and one you will want to make."Vertebrand" is a great bracelet by Barb Switzer.If you love Swarovki Elements crystals, check this one out. The findings used are spacer bars which, along with the crystals, have a lot of impact.Dalle de Verre, by once again by Ms. Mach, is a really gorgeous seed bead and ball chain connector necklace anyone would want to make. Give it a try! It has variation suggestions also, which many of the projects offer.Another good thing about Unexpected Findings is that the cost of the materials does not seem to be prohibitive. I, and I am sure many other designers, appreciate that!To sum up, Unexpected Findings is a new way of  looking at jewelry design, one which is very welcome and cool.I think that many of the projects are perfectly beautiful, such as Molly Shaller's Tidal Treasures, a delicate aquatic necklace which uses a toggle clasp as a connector.Michelle Mach's bracelet called Gypsy Girl, which cleverly uses snap clasps, is a total thrill. It has pretty colors of teals and magenta, and lots of jangle.It is hard to know where to stop when admiring this excellent book, Unexpected Findings,50+ CLEVER JEWELRY DESIGNS.It is such a original concept, which is presented so well.I totally recommend Unexpected Findings. It is a very appealing, fun, and clever book!

FINE ART WIRE WEAVING, Weaving Techniques for stunning jewelry designs, by Sarah Thompson, is a breathtakingly beautiful introduction to the art of wire weaving.The book isn't just about the beauty of this jewelry however, although it has that in spades. It also delivers a solid, concise learning base for the reader. You can see just from the cover photo alone how amazing fine art wire weaving is, when taught by author Sarah Thompson. Her step-by-step instructions are clear and understandable. The photos of the projects are totally gorgeous.You will be seeing rings, necklaces, earrings, and bracelets. Some are fashioned from wire alone. Some have gems, pearls or crystals as a part of the design, front and center or as accents. Many of the projects have really fine variations. You get your money's worth when you purchase  FINE ART WIRE WEAVING! There is a holistic sensibility to these woven wire designs,  They are classic in form yet have gorgeous leaps of freedom and wildness. Sarah Thompson balances artful tension and control, backed up by her dynamite originality .  FINE ART WIRE WEAVING  is very  complete, containing not only the projects, but lists of materials,tools, ways to fix mistakes (I love her for that!) and other great additions such as instructions with photos on how to make your own findings for your jewelry. There is also a resource section.The projects range from beginner to intermediate to advanced, so don't be afraid of this style of making jewelry. You will be able to make your own chic jewelry right away.There is nothing which isn't exceptional about  FINE ART WIRE WEAVING. I was immediately engaged by it.  Every detail is carefully thought out and explained. The author has translated her own experience and love of creating this style of jewelry into a treasure chest of inspiration for the reader.For example, in the earliest section of projects, for beginners, I found the "Embrace" adjustable ring. As the author says, "This ring is beautiful on its own, but when combined with a splash of balled wire ends and an hint of a swirl, you get a wonderful, yet simple, adjustable ring."  This is an understatement--I was blown away by the smashing artistry of her design! It is a knockout. Even better, as with her other designs, there is no sense that anything is forced. It is so great to see such intact design work, with no unnecessary extras clogging it up. All of the designs flow perfectly.When you reach the intermediate section, take a look at the Petal bracelet. This is an instant classic if I ever saw one. Made up of really cool components linked together, it will stop traffic whenever you wear it. Her variation, a pair of earrings made from the same components but with sexy fringe added, are divine!Speaking of earrings, check out the "Scorpio" earrings while you are at it. If you are like me, you are going to fall flat when you see these. I have never seen earrings so unique and incredible. Learning to make these earrings alone is worth the price of the book. This is great work from an outstanding teacher.Finally, to give you an idea of what you will find in the advanced section, take a look at the "Kayla" pendant. Employing different sizes of crystals, chain and a graceful symmetrical focal, it has a hand made clasp component to complete the elegance. Wear this one to meet the Queen!Or just hang out at home in it. It is perfect, either way.If you are intrigued by the look of woven wire (whether plain or set with gems and pearls) but don't know where to start, this will be a great work book to teach and inspire you. Perhaps you don't believe you have the skills to weave wire but would love to try it. With  FINE ART WIRE WEAVING, you will access the confidence to learn, as well the understanding to make your own woven wire jewelry. Sarah Thompson shares her knowledge with great generosity and flair.She wholeheartedly hands over the "How To" key to fine art woven wire.Classic chic, hip and fun,  Fine Art Wire Weaving  has it all going on!  Sarah Thompson is a wire wonder worker!Her book will entrance you, coax your creativity into full gear, and help you understand how to grow as a jewelry designer at every turn, twist, and swirl.

The Armitron Sport Women's 45/7051CLR Digital Clear Jelly Strap Watch is flat out beautiful! I love watches for their looks as well as their performance, so I am as delighted with the look of this stylish watch as I am happy with its performance.It is a perfect watch to wear when you are swimming laps, as you can time yourself using it. Even better, the dial is very visible in every detail so you won't have to stop or waste time looking at it when you are working out. You can see it easily!It has a jelly strap so you have to expect somewhat of a sticky feel when you are wearing it on a hot summer day. I don't mind it, and it plays a part in the watch's cool look.If it begins to bother you, just jump in the water wearing it--because that is part of the fun of it--you can, with no worries!As a piece of jewelry, this watch will update your sporty style. It is a great wear alone piece, or would goes nicely with a simple sterling bracelet to accentuate and play up the lovely silver face.I am delighted with the Armitron Sport Women's 45/7051CLR Digital Clear Jelly Strap Watch, and recommend it.

Having loved all the Kneipp products for years, I tried the one I had overlooked before: Kneipp "Pure Bliss Bath". The sturdy bottle contains enough for 10 baths. That is a good value for a spa level treatment you can give yourself at home.I specifically turned to Kneipp because I was under the weather from stress and I trust the therapeutic value of their products. I chose the Pure Bliss because the box says. "relaxes body and soul, with natural essential oils."  The Kneipp line has many selections and normally I choose the Spruce & Pine (great in winter!) or the Lavender (great before bed) and recommend both of them as well.This oil is a clear deep tone of red when you first pour it into the cap in order to measure it. Make sure you already have some water filling the tub because it could stain otherwise.It disperses into a lovely pink tone.The scent is very soothing. It took away the headache I had, and calmed me noticeably the first time I used it.Pure Bliss Huile de Bain Instant Plaisir, with Red Poppy and Hemp (also known as Coquelicot (wild corn poppy) and Chanvre if you look the French up), relaxes you for the rest of your day.Who wouldn't love to have the gift of Pure Bliss?Lovely stuff!

L'Occitane has long been offering this version of shea butter. The company had it way before shea butter was accepted by mainstream companies, who then added to their health and beauty lines, either as a stand alone ingredient or combined with other ingredients to make it fragrant or to make it cheaper.However, if you want the best, the most drenchingly moisturizing, the longest lasting skin (and even hair!) moisturizer, use this one. Shea butter comes from the nuts of the African Kante tree. It is a wonderful purveyor of Vitamin A.L'Occitaine's Pure Shea Butter is both organic and Fair Trade Approved.You can layer this product with L'Occitaine's lighter versions (their hand and foot creams which contain less shea, for example) but if you want the heavy hitter, get this: the one, the only, the original, by L'Occitaine.This product is great for dry cracked hands, feet, elbows, lips and, yes, dry hair! I love it  for my very high maintenance skin, and have given as a gift as well. It is worth the price.

For someone coming from iMovie, I found the interface understandable, and much easier to use than Apple. I've done some very basic trimming of videos and minor manipulation of the contents before, but nothing advanced. It was a little rough at first, but I was pretty quickly able to get up to speed and use some of the more advanced features. I'd recommend this for anyone starting out, but from what I can tell, it would also be appropriate for relatively advanced users. I'd give it five stars if the learning curve wasn't so steep. It still seems like more could be done to help out beginners who are new to the product.

I use manuka honey and propolis elixir for my throat in the winter. The nice thing about this is that instead of using them separately (a spoonful of tasty manuka honey and a couple squirts of the foul tasting propolis), they are both together, and the unpleasantness of the propolis is gone.

The Origami case for the Kindle Voyage is a tad bit on the heavy side, which is probably because it uses a lot of magnets--magnets for the cover to work properly and magnets to hold the Kindle in the shell. When it arrived, I was very disappointed, and planned to send it back the next day. I thought Amazon had really messed up with this monstrosity! But, not wanting to use the Kindle naked, I put it on until the replacement arrived.Weeks later, it's still on. I've owned all of the Kindles since the second version (including the DX) and had all of the Amazon cases. This is the best one I've ever had, even though I kind of wonder if I'd been better off going for something a bit more subdued than the greenish yellow "Citron" (I posted this there, but it shows up for some reason as a review for the purple case, which I don't own).There is one reason the case works so well for me: I have always enjoyed reading without holding my books. I set it up on the kitchen table and can read for hours over breakfast, or set it up on the table at a coffee shop while reading and freely taking notes. It's pure pleasure. Up until now, I've been using Kindles in conjunction with my BookGem stand (best book stand ever made), but now I can use that exclusively with my iPad, whose folding cover is slick, but won't let it stand up like the Kindle in portrait mode. I've also discovered that the origami case works wonderfully in bed as well, because it props up on its side at the perfect angle. As for protection, this thing is much more solid than any other Kindle case I've owned.You may not like this if you want to hold your Kindle while reading because of its weight and the weight distribution, though you could easily slip it in and out of its magnetic holster to read it in its birthday suit -- the case is not so heavy until you pick up the feather-weight Kindle and realize that whatever weight Amazon shaved off the device it shifted over to the case. In addition, if you don't like opening the case like a communicator from the old Star Trek shows (this is actually fun every time for me), then go for something else. Finally, I should mention that my fears about the magnets erasing credit cards or computer drives have so far been unnecessary. Between the magnets in my iPad + case and the magnets in this case for the Kindle I may be messing with compasses in the room :)

I've been pleased with Moshi products in the past, and I think this screen protector lives up to Moshi's reputation for excellence, but with one caveat: as so many other reviewers have mentioned, it is shiny.It is quite thick, fits the Kindle perfectly, is completely clear, and there isn't a single bubble. This is what I was looking for with it, so I am quite pleased.  I don't read outside so much, I read inside at an angle that is unaffected by the lights, and I read at night, so the reflectivity isn't a big deal to me; hence, the five stars.However, one of the selling points of the Kindle is it's readability in any lighting conditions, even direct sunlight. Why Moshi would make a product that would completely undermine the Kindle in this way is a mystery to me. Did they not read or view any of the Amazon advertisements over the last few years? Kindle owners who bought the Kindle to read outside had better stay away from this product.

I haven't had much experience with projectors, but judging by the quality of the  Epson PowerLite Home Cinema 3500 1080 Widescreen, HDMI, 3LCD, 2500 Lumens color brightness, 2500 lumens White Brightness, Projector I've been missing out on all this time. I'm coming from the perspective of a 42" flat screen TV, which I was quite pleased with until I turned on the projector. Even against a flat white wall, it beats my TV hands down. It's not just the size, but the crisp resolution and the beautiful colors. I've read in the past about projectors that were criticized for being too dim, and I've certainly used my fair share of them with presentations, but I think Epson has overcome that obstacle here.It seems durable to me, though surprisingly heavy. I think you'll want to be careful if you intend to mount this on a ceiling. This isn't a complaint, by any means, but it must be packed with a lot of stuff for such a small thing to weigh this much. It is easy to set up and use. My only concern is the durability of the light, but I suppose it will outlast any TV I purchase, so I guess that is a relatively minor concern.Normally, when I do reviews, I try to point out the pros and cons of a device. I cannot find any cons at this point -- it has far exceeded my expectations, which might be because I've read so many lukewarm tech blog postings on projectors over the years and/or because Epson has raised the bar with this one. Either way, I doubt anyone will be disappointed by it.

The Incipio Journal Cover for Kindle Voyage, Black is a lot lighter than the official Kindle cover, but it is clearly not the same level of quality, and I don't think it is worth the price. It's true that it doesn't shut off your Kindle when you close the cover, but that isn't a big deal, because the Kindle will automatically shut off anyhow. The elastic bands and the unnecessary thickness bugged me. This doesn't even live up to the Amazon cover for the paperwhite, which is an old item.I'd recommend springing for the official cover. It is heavy, yes, and I am not a big fan of so many magnets, but it really works well -- protecting the device, looking good, and providing a stand. This cover by Incipio barely accomplishes the first objective, so it gets three stars, because there is nothing impressive here.

The Sony AZ1VR/W Action Camera Mini Kit with Live View Remote is a pretty good camera with no particular shortcomings, but when you consider the competition, it might be a difficult choice.PROS- Pretty tough. It gets banged around a bit, but no problems so far.- Water. I haven't tried it, but it says it can handle water, so that is good to know. It isn't, though, for underwater filming.- It's tiny and lightweight. Actually, it's amazing, and this is its strongest feature compared to the GoPro.CONS- The wristband is pretty bulky and the range isn't all that far; I'm not terribly keen on it. Theoretically, you could control 5 of these, but would you? Maybe I need to get some drones.- It's a bit of a pain to move files around. I guess now that so much on smart phones works seamlessly, having to mess around with cables seems antiquated.- Battery. It is very short-lived, but I guess that is the price you pay for the size.- Where is the SD card?SUMMARY- It's pretty good and about what you would expect from Sony at this price. The size and the remote on the wrist seems to be the differentiating factor, and if these are important to you, then you'll want to seriously consider it.

The DeLonghi AC150 Energy Star Air Purifier with Ionizer, 150 Square Feet is a great product and I've got no complaints about it, but you'll want to think about the cost / coverage ratio.HARDWARENo problems so far with it. I loathe LED lights on stuff, because it means you can't use it in your bedroom at night, and they are just annoying. But, DeLonghi wisely gave users the options to turn these off. I wish other manufacturers would do the same with their products. Otherwise, there isn't much to say. It is a little bit stocky, but not terribly bulky. It runs quietly, and it seems to be doing something.THE PROBLEMThe problem is that I cannot figure out if it is working very well. It turns out that 150 square feet is a really, really small space. Perhaps it is our vaulted ceilings that is throwing it off, but I think the only place where it is really going to be able to circulate all of the air might be the bathroom or closets, where it is in a small, closed-off space. For some reason, the Vornado air purifier (175 feet of coverage) we have seems to be a lot more powerful for about the same money.SUMMARYThere is nothing bad to say about the unit itself. In fact, it seems quite nice. It's just that it is terribly underpowered for the price, and I think to cover our condo we'd need 7 or 8 of them. If you've got a small space, this is the unit for you, but if you live in a large space, or have vaulted ceilings, you might want to consider something that is more cost effective.

The Oster Kettle seemed kind of gimmicky with its transparent glass and lights. But, I was interested in it because there was no heating element inside, so I thought it might stay cleaner over time.What I discovered is that when I can see inside, it reminds me to clean it, and now I am a lot more careful to regularly empty the water and wipe it down. I've been pretty happy with this aspect of it, and plan to stick with glass kettles in the future. I could do without the lights, but they don't hurt anything. Maybe if you live in a man-cave or something, you'll appreciate the extra illumination.

The HMDX HX-HP420BK Jam Transit Wireless Headphones, Black seem very well designed for such an inexpensive product. Surprisingly, they even blocked out a significant amount of sound. They are easy to pair through Bluetooth with your music player (I have an iPod). They come pre-charged (not a big deal for me), so you could potentially open the box, pair them, put them on your head, and go out for a run in about 2 minutes! It has a built-in mic, so you can talk on it if you want to take a call. My only complaint, and the reason I gave it 4 stars, is that the headphones don't quite fit my tiny ears. They work OK, but there is pressure on the top of my ears, and they seem to be made for people with a different head shape. More adjust-ability would be welcome.

The Vornado Evap3 Whole Room Evaporative Humidifier is pretty much exactly what you want to have in a humidifier. It has a huge tank for water, it is not unbearably loud (compared to others in this price range), and it has plenty of adjustments to fit your use case.We have it in the living room, but I don't think it is a good idea to put it in the bedroom unless you like the sound of fans when you sleep (actually, I do). At the high settings, the fan noise is definitely noticeable. With a name like "Vornado," you shouldn't expect whisper-quite. (By the way, the name always makes me think of "Sharknado," but I digress.)I should also mention that it is surprisingly easy to fill, and I think it will probably fit easily under most kitchen faucets. I highly recommend this humidifier, and we've been pleased with it for everyday use.

It's great that they are organic, and no doubt the Vitamin C is appreciated, but do they work? I don't know.They tasted a bit medicinal and I can't tell if it worked for the cough or had any more soothing effect than regular candies. They aren't terribly expensive, so you might want to give them a try, and maybe they will be exactly what you need, but I'd keep a bag of the regular cough drops on hand just in case they don't do the job.

The Panasonic "Milano" ER-GS60-S Self-Hair Clipper, Wet/Dry works exactly as expected. It is very lightweight, it cut my hair, and it cleaned up easily when I ran water over it.My only complaint would be that the battery seems a little weak. I expected it to be running strong by the end of my haircut (shaving off two or three inches of hair down to the number 4 setting), but it had grown noticeably weaker. Because of the way it is designed, you can't just plug it into the wall and keep going. It sits in a special stand, but ideally the cord for recharging would be separate from the stand and you could continue using it if the charge drains (my rechargeable razor works this way). It's not a big deal for me (I'll be cutting a lot less hair now that I shaved it all off), but if you have a family with two or three people who will use it, you might want to space out the haircuts.

The Kensington Corner Case is the best case I have ever owned, and I strongly recommend it to anyone looking to protect their iPad. It is also surprisingly inexpensive.I should explain that I have had iPads since the first one came out, and I have tried all sorts of products ranging from Apple's case for the original iPad (I liked it a lot, but later iterations were cheap and of lower quality) to the Kensington KeyFolio keyboard cases (I am not impressed with them). This inexpensive and simple (looking) case stands out from the rest.1. It is flexible.Unlike the hard Belkin cases I usually get, it isn't a rigid shell. Normally, you only find these kinds "softer" (and higher quality) plastic cases for phone-sized products.2. It is shaped to match the iPad Air.No extra case material where the case isn't needed, and the shape sticks out from the device ever so slightly so that buttons don't get accidentally pressed (i kept accidentally shutting off the iPad before when I had it flipped upside down in portrait charging -- no more of that now). It also has a lip that sticks up slightly higher than the screen so that if you lay the iPad flat on the table the screen will actually be resting a millimeter above the surface safe and sound. Worried about the shiny chamfered edges? Worry no more, because the majority of them are now covered.3. It is lightweight and unobtrusive.I barely notice it is on the iPad (I have the smoke case with the space gray iPad -- you'll probably want the clear case if you are a white iPad owner). I also have the Apple smart cover (green), which is now made without the metal hinges, so both the case and the cover now seem to get out of my way. One slight problem with the smart cover is that it used to adhere firmly to the back of the case instead of flapping around like previous smart cover models. However, with this case (as you would expect) the tiny magnets no longer work to hold it flat against the back -- sometimes it stays, and sometimes it doesn't. I think that is the price you have to pay for protection, though.4. It is tough.I hurled my iPad onto the concrete and it was fine. Just kidding! Unlike the hard Belkin cases, I do think if this were dropped from a few feet up onto a hard floor, the device might be more likely to survive unscathed, because there is more "give" in this case.My only recommendation to Kensington for improvement would be to somehow get rid of the ridge running around it (from the joining of the molds in production?), because it could be annoying. I've used the iPad for hours without being bothered in the slightest, but some people are quite sensitive to these "sharp" edges, and will not like it for that reason.[EDIT:] I just realized the Amazon image is quite misleading. Users should know that the Kensington branding is in white (on my smoke-colored case), not the smokey looking color they have shown in the image. I don't care much, but it isn't terribly good looking (can't they come up with a better logo?) , and scratching it off does not seem to be an option. You'll have to do some of Kensington's marketing for them if you want the case -- perhaps a tasteful sticker is in order.

[ Update November 9]An unhelpful review?----------A lot of customers are marking this review as unhelpful. I am sorry to hear that. In my opinion, if you are spending $80 on a product, you want to know a lot of details about the quality of the product in regular use, and as someone who uses bluetooth keyboards paired with the iPad for most of the working day, I feel like I have some helpful advice. However, if you think I am leading customers astray, please mark my review as "unhelpful," but also consider commenting on the review with some advice for how I can improve it.Customer service---------A customer service representative from Kensington commented on this review and kindly offered to replace my keyboards. Clearly, the Kensington customer support is excellent, and the company deserves to be recognized for how it stands behind its products.How did the replacements stand up in my tests, though? I received them, and have changed my rating from one star to three, because I saw a slight improvement (see the original review below for a more comprehensive review of the case).Is the replacement keyboard an improvement?----------Yes. I was sent two replacement keyboards (I have the KeyFolio Pro and KeyFolio Exact models), and one of them was significantly better than the original. The other one was about the same. I originally speculated that it was a bluetooth connectivity issue, but I think I may have been wrong, and it is actually a key sensitivity one. The keys respond well to a deliberate touch directly on the center of each one, but the lighter your touch, and the closer to the edge of the key you get, the less likely it is to recognize the input.Why three stars?----------I can imagine this keyboard working for someone who hunts and pecks, or who types maybe 20 to 30 words a minute. They are more likely to be pressing down firmly on each key. I think the faster you type, the more likely you are to run into unrecognized keys. At 50 or 60 words a minute, a sentence is typically missing all of its punctuation (the question mark is the most difficult to have recognized) and a few letters (it varies, but I'd say anything off the center row away from the middle is probably going to go missing at some point -- I have a lot of missing "t," "a," and "n" characters. Typing at faster speeds ends up as gibberish, in my experience.Why should you trust me?----------Maybe you shouldn't! I don't see other reviewers commenting on this, people have marked my review as "unhelpful," and with four keyboards in front of me at the moment, you might start to think I am the problem here. I did, so I handed a few keyboards over to a friend and asked him to give it a try. Like me, he loved the look of the keyboard, and thought it seemed well-designed.1. He tried the best one of the bunch (one of the four seems more sensitive than the others) and had the same experience I did. In fact, he compared it to the old manual typewriters that required you to press firmly down from directly above each key. Of course, this is much more difficult on this relatively cramped keyboard (a necessary tradeoff for the size).2. I gave him one of the other three and he immediately noticed the difference, and declared that there wasn't much point in using the keyboard if you have to press the backspace key all of the time to correct errors.3. I gave him the Apple bluetooth keyboard (larger, and more expensive, to be sure, but also more sensitive and accurate) and his fingers danced happily across the keyboard without any errors. He also liked the angle of the keyboard, something that you have to produce manually with the Kensington by sticking a book or something underneath.Summary----------It's not a "bad" keyboard. Rather, I think it is a keyboard that is designed for a particular kind of typist that I am not. I grew up with manual typewriters, and I have taken typing classes. I think I was one of the only boys in class back then, but for some reason I really wanted to learn how to type--I even asked for a typewriter for my birthday. I know my way around a keyboard, so I could modify my typing to go back to the manual style, but why? I much prefer to type quickly, comfortably, and with a light touch. I think the keyboard has great potential (it certainly seems well-designed otherwise), and I will keep my eye on future iterations, but this generation is not quite ready for daily use, in my opinion.----------------------------------------[ Original review]I rarely give one-star reviews, but the Kensington KeyFolio Pro with Bluetooth Keyboard and Google Drive Offer for iPad Air (iPad 5) (K97008US) has earned it. I wanted to like it, and was excited to try it out with my iPad Air today, but I simply cannot recommend this to anyone.The case looks to be of high quality, though a little too bulky for my taste. Inserting the iPad Air was easy, and it fit relatively well. I'd prefer a tighter fit myself, but I can live with it. Pairing the keyboard worked fine. I think a dedicated button for connecting is unnecessary, and the spacing / sizing of the keys isn't ideal, but overall I really like the look of the keyboard -- it's thin and rechargeable, which is something I cannot say about Apple's bluetooth keyboard.Why the one-star review?1. The keyboard appears to have a poor bluetooth connection with the iPad. I tested it with my iPad Air and my iPad 3 with the same results. It misses characters. Every few words a character goes missing, and if you are reasonably fast, then expect to have several words each sentence garbled. I am reviewing another Kensington keyboard, and it has the same problem, so I don't think it is simply a dud. It appears to be a systemic problem, and I am surprised not to see more complaints from others. In my opinion, this alone makes it a one-star product, because the selling point here is that you'll have a keyboard and a case all in one. I really wanted this to work, but I am afraid it was a failure, so I am back to the Apple keyboard + Incase Origami, which is now looking very large next to the iPad Air!2. The metal clasp on the case hit my screen! I couldn't believe it, but they made the case with a floppy metal clasp. I should have been much more careful using it, and I deeply regret not reading the other reviews first, because they would have given me the warning I needed. I simply cannot fathom how this part of the case made it through the testing process. The iPad screen is the most delicate part of the device, and to have this flopping around next to it is a recipe for disaster. I'll probably cut mine off just to be on the safe side. The rest of the case is acceptable, in my opinion, but this part of it really needs more thought. If it was the clasp alone I wouldn't think so badly about the product, but in combination with the keyboard problem, I think it makes the product unusable.I am sure there will be users who enjoy the case, and I guess others aren't seeing the bluetooth connectivity problems, so if you want to take a chance with it, go ahead, but I'd suggest keeping a hold of the receipt (so-to-speak) just in case.

I think the Mr. Clean 240279 Magic Eraser Toilet Scrubber Kit takes a lot of the annoyance out of having to clean the toilet.To prepare it, you first need to load the cleaning pads into the container with the blue side facing up (the blue side will connect to the handle, and the white side will clean the toilet bowl). The directions aren't entirely clear about this, so you can look at the photo on the box if it seems confusing.To use it: 1) flush the toilet, 2) pick up a cleaning disk with the handle, 3) clean the toilet, 4) throw the cleaning disk away (into the trash), 5) replace the handle into the assembly. The cleaning disk works well, and the small size makes it easier to clean everything. It smells good, too.Weirdly, though, the cleaning disk wouldn't come off at the end of the process. It's no big deal, I guess. Stick it in the trash and use the trash bag to pull it off. This seems to ruin the whole flow -- what's the point, after all, if you have to touch it to remove the disk? Still, if it would work, it would be a good idea! It gets three stars for that.

The Remington D3020 Volume and Shine Hair Dryer is a powerful hair dryer that is a lot better than previous hair dryers we have had.It has more power than one we bought a few years ago (Vidal Sassoon "Ionizer" VS785). This one is also an ionizer hair dryer and the size is the same, but it is slightly lighter, and so a little easier to hold.It also takes less time to dry hair. With the old Vidal Sassoon it took about 10 minutes (long hair), but with the Remington it only takes about five, even though both have the same wattage.I highly recommend it.

Our dog is not a big fan of Hill's Ideal Balance Chicken and Brown Rice Recipe Adult Small Breed Dog Dry Food Bag, 15-Pound. She refused to eat it for a while. When she finally gave in, she only grudgingly took tiny bites of it and walked around the house spitting the pieces out everywhere. The food might be wonderful, and other dogs might enjoy it, but if ours could write this review, she'd surely give it one-star (I gave it three, because I think she is being too picky).

The Black & Decker Flash Thermal Laminator 9.5-Inch (LAM95) works well with heated lamination. It warms up quickly and performs exactly as expected. I do not know if the cold setting works, because the manufacturer did not include a self-adhesive pouch. In fact, there isn't a lot that comes with this, so you should expect to purchase consumables separately.The corner punch? I tried my best to get that thing to work, but it is totally useless. I cannot imagine how this product made it out the door with a highlighted feature that doesn't work! Other reviewers had the same problem, so I am glad to see that I am not the only one who couldn't figure it out.Fortunately, the laminator appears to be solidly built and affordably priced. I don't imagine I will miss having a corner punch, and if you'd be fine without one as well then I'd recommend you consider purchasing it.

I've had several air purifiers over the years, but the Airocide Air Purifier is easily one of my favorites. I am a sucker for beautifully designed products, and this one is industrial design at its finest.PERFORMANCE---------Does it work?  I have no idea. Unlike conventional filters that need to be regularly cleaned and replaced, it uses some kind of NASA technology involving reaction chambers and so forth. The explanation in the manual is vague and not terribly convincing. Honestly, I do wonder if it works, and I guess only time will tell.SETTINGS---------There are no settings to speak of -- you plug it in and you can choose automatic, low, and high for the fan speeds. I say "fan," but I don't really understand how this air moves out without blades that you would need to clean every once in a while. It is a mystery to me at the moment. Again, I would have appreciated more detailed explanations in the manual.GUARANTEE---------Airocide promises that I will "feel better" after using this for a while. I am not exactly sure what that means, or how they can even make that promise, but if it is true, and they really will stand by their 60-day return policy, I don't think you have anything to lose by giving it a try.VERTICAL?---------One thing to note is that the photos often show the air purifier in a vertical position. As far as I can tell, this is not possible to achieve in real life. You may notice that the only time it happens in the literature or on the Amazon page is when the product has been photoshopped or placed on a special stand. In fact, there is a slight angle to the sides, so I think you will probably need to imagine it in a horizontal position, unless you mount it on a wall or put it on the stand that can be purchased separately.MAINTENANCE---------Finally, a word about the reactors. You have to replace them every year, and they do cost about $100, but this is definitely not out of line with the price of filters that you would have to replace with other high-end air purifiers. It is interesting that "reactors" have to be replaced about the same interval as "filters", but because I have no idea how this thing actually works, I have to take their word for it that I need to change the parts regularly.

UPDATE:A year and a half later and these are still some of the best headphones I have ever owned. I took an international flight yesterday and these made it considerably more pleasant than it would have been otherwise. One minor thing that annoys me is the square sound processing / battery thingy that is placed inconveniently near to the headphone jack. It tries to bang against the iPad / iPod / iPhone screens when using it, and it seems to get in the way a lot more than I would like. Still, it is better than any competing noise-cancelling headphones I have tried and definitely an improvement over the QC15.Comparing the Bose QuietComfort 20i Acoustic Noise Cancelling Headphones to the Bose® QuietComfortÂ® 15 Acoustic Noise CancellingÂ® Headphones, I was surprised to find that I prefer the 20i.The QC15----------I've used the QC15 headphones for several years now on a daily basis to the point that I have even had to replace the leather cups on them because they completely wore out. I cannot say enough good things about the QC15's excellent ability to filter out noise (compared to other leading brands I have owned and tried). They are comfortable to wear for long periods of time and deliver excellent battery life.Yet, the QC15 has its drawbacks.- You cannot use them in a moderately warm room or your head will overheat. I've seen people work out in them, and I honestly cannot comprehend how they endure the heat.- The QC15 also has pretty unimpressive sound if you are an audiophile.- Finally, they are extremely bulky and inconvenient to take anywhere with you.The 20i----------Basically, the i20 has all the benefits of the QC15 in a tiny, portable size. I value the noise cancellation function myself, and I cannot distinguish between the two headphones, even though you would expect the QC15 to do better because it completely covers your ears. It is amazing how well the i20 cancels out the sound, and I could not believe that the uniquely shaped earbuds fit comfortably into my ears. There is no more overheating, and they are much more convenient to carry with me all of the time. I really do not know how they managed to do it, but this is the first in-ear noise canceling that actually works. For iOS users, I can confirm that it works perfectly with Apple devices.Yet, there are some drawbacks.- Just like the QC15, the i20 still does a relatively poor job with sound quality.- Additionally, I find them a little less comfortable for wearing hours on end.Recommendation----------If you are choosing between the 20i and the QC15, you may not be able to distinguish between the two in terms of sound quality or noise cancellation, but when you are wanting to carry the headphones around with you wherever you go, then the 20i is going to be a better choice. In fact, the only situation in which I would recommend the QC15 over the 20i is if you plan to be in one air-conditioned place using the headphones for extended periods (maybe a researcher trying to concentrate in the library for 8+ hours).

There isn't anything especially unique about the Belkin F5L097btGRN Universal Tablet Stylus - Retail Packaging - Green that would distinguish it from a stylus by Targus or any number of other similar models. In fact, I have a Griffin stylus out next to it , and the only differences I can determine are:1. The Griffin is perhaps a centimeter longer.2. The metal cap at the top of the Griffin is larger (this is where that centimeter comes from) and less decorative.3. The clip is much fatter on the Griffin and connects to the metal cap, so it appears more sturdy to me.4. The Griffin has a slightly more textured barrel and is easier to hold.5. The Griffin is black. I like the green Belkin better, I suppose, because it is different. However, the color isn't really a big deal to me.I like how it writes, but at twice the price of competing products, and with slightly less desirable features (shorter with smooth barrel and a clip design that easily breaks in my experience), I am not sure that I could recommend it over others. It deserves four stars for being a fine stylus, but there is nothing great about it, in my opinion.

The Westcott TrimAir Guillotine Wood Trimmer with Microban Protection is an economical way to trim paper, and is well-suited to light tasks. The construction seems quite sturdy, and the blade is effective with a small number of paper items. Twenty pages of paper, for example, is a little too much, but it works just fine with about ten to fifteen.I think the lightweight construction probably works in its favor, but the blade is so tightly attached that you really have to use one hand to hold down the cutting board, because it jumps around a lot. It's not a big deal, but if you are planning to trim a few hundred pieces of paper, it is probably not the most appropriate tool. For large projects, you'll want something like the Professional Guillotine Desktop Stack Paper Cutter, which is a little more than twice the price, but can easily work through 250 to 300 pages in a single pass, and is very heavy, so it does not move around on your desk.The Westcott trimmer excels with small projects, and I'd definitely recommend it for such cases.

This is my second WD My Passport Studio 1TB Mac Portable External Hard Drive Storage FireWire(WDBGJA0010BBK-NESN), but I think it will be my last. The case is sturdy and the device is one of the few Firewire-enabled devices. The problem is that it is behind the times. The USB 2.0 connection is pretty slow, and my other WD drives have 3.0, so I don't know why they would have kept it with old technology like this. Still, I was hoping that if it was rugged, that would be worth the trade-off. However...Mine is no longer readable (for some reason), and I cannot access it now when I plug it in to either of my computers. It's quite weird. I had this happen on another Buffalo drive last year, and it was probably partly my fault, because I didn't format it Journaled. This one came pre-formatted, though! I'll probably figure out a way to reformat it and try it again, but it doesn't inspire confidence, and I'll have to be careful with my data.Personally, I think an ultra-portable Western Digital drive (Western Digital Passport Essential Portable with a nice case would be a better deal -- faster, less money, and less weight.

[EDIT September 17]: As expected, the handle has split apart. It's still functional, but I don't think they put enough thought into the materials used for manufacturing it. I've reduced my rating from three stars to one. I'd recommend staying away from this unless you intend to wrap that handle in plastic or something.----- Original Review -----The Full Circle Grunge Buster Grout and Tile Brush, FC11125 has an interesting shape, and the designers should be commended on giving us something new here. I like how it reaches into corners well, how it fits in my hand, and how it sits up nicely (like an iron). However, a bamboo handle? This doesn't make much sense to me, and though it hasn't become grungy yet, I don't expect it will fare well in my shower. More importantly, though, is the fact that it cleans no better than any of the other brushes I have used. In fact, the pliable brushes on the narrow top part have already bent and are apparently not really doing much good at all.The grunge is still in my grout. I've got a nice looking tile brush, but I think they need to do a little more work with it. Next time, get rid of the bamboo handle (good looking, but probably not the best thing for humid/wet environments), beef up the bristles at the leading edge, and I think I'll be able to finally get the shower clean!

The Marantz NR1504 Slim Line 5.1 Network Receiver with AirPlay is gorgeous and designed with an eye for small details.SETUP----------If you are familiar with receivers, then you'll have no problem integrating this into your home theatre system. On the other hand, if you need instructions, it might be a little more difficult. The guides are in large PDFs contained on a CD that is accessed from a silly, clunky menu. Go into the CD files and drag out the PDFs ending in "ENG" (if you want English) and load them onto your iPad if you want to have the manuals accessible.HARDWARE----------Slim, sturdy, and clearly labeled. This is a model of straightforward and user-friendly design. I kind of feel like large knobs are a throwback to the past, but I realize that these are de rigueur for receiver enthusiasts.USE----------It does everything you would expect, and does it really well. That is, unless you expect "Airplay" to mean that you can use the device to play videos transmitted from your iPad, iPhone, or computer. As far as I can tell, the only thing that Airplay does on this device is audio. That's fine, of course, but I was really hoping for the video capability so that I would have an alternative to my Apple TV. To be fair, the manufacturer only claims audio capability.SUMMARY----------The Marantz NR1504 demonstrates that a great receiver can be relatively small, inexpensive, and easy to use.

I had pretty high expectations for the  Kodak i2900 Scanner, and though I wasn't impressed with it at first (this review has been edited to reflect my thoughts after scanning several tens of thousands of pages), once I figured out the settings, I developed a more favorable impression of it.HARDWARE---------------------Kodak has built what looks to be a pretty solid piece of equipment. I expect that it will hold up pretty well through a lot of scanning, and the fact that it can handle as many as 250 sheets at a time is pretty impressive. In my experience, it works exactly as advertised, and it is very easy to load paper.One problem I have found is that the wheels sometimes begin squeaking and it can be quite annoying. The problem seems to occur because even when paper is not running through the device and it is pausing before feeding the next paper, everything continues spinning along. The worst offenders seem to be two white plastic rollers in the top of the back section of the device where the paper comes out at the top, and one at the bottom of the front loading area. I have tried cleaning the wheels in the front loading area, with some success in reducing the squeaking. The rollers in the back stopped their incessant squeaking when I shifted them around with my fingers, but they still occasionally scream out at me in protest.Surprisingly, the scanner is missing some functionality you can find in other scanners. For example, it doesn't have the capability to detect double feeds like the Fujitsu ScanSnap iX500 Scanner for PC and Mac (PA03656-B005). It doesn't handle paper misfeeds well unless they are quite nasty, in contrast to the ix500, which is pretty sensitive. These aren't major omissions, but on an otherwise high quality scanner, these kinds of details would be nice to have.SOFTWARE---------------------It was time consuming to install the software, and quite difficult for me to get started. Once I did get it set up, it worked well enough, but it might take me weeks to figure out what all these options do. The most important thing that I realized is that you can go into the File > Page Setup part of the interface to adjust the resolution if you need higher resolution, grayscale, etc. I did not find the interface intuitive at all, and I think the software is not doing Kodak any favors here. It would have been nice if Kodak had included support for Mac users too. If you don't have a Windows computer, then this isn't the device for you.Fujitsu ScanSnap ix500 v Kodak i2900---------------------These two scanners are not even supposed to be in the same league (in price or specs), but in day-to-day use, the ScanSnap comes out ahead in some ways. Despite being a fraction of the size and cost, the ScanSnap is much faster than the Kodak if you go above 300 dpi. I usually scan at 600 dpi black and white, and at these settings, I go roughly twice as fast with the ScanSnap. There is one caveat, though. The ScanSnap has more hiccups (misfeeds, multiple page feeds, paper jams, and problems grabbing onto pages). After 30,000+ pages with the Kodak, I think I may have only had 5 or 6 feed problems. Perhaps one of the reasons it doesn't detect double feeds is because the design of the device makes the problem much more uncommon.There is one point where the Kodak blows the ScanSnap out of the water: capacity. The ScanSnap gets quite testy when you load in more than a few dozen pages at once, so you have to position yourself close to the device and keep feeding it. The Kodak churns through its pages slower, but at a steady pace without the need to constantly feed it. This can be a huge advantage when you get up to several thousand pages, and there have been several times when I give a scanning batch to the Kodak instead of the ScanSnap because I don't want to hassle with the feeding.SUMMARY---------------------I think if you are a regular consumer who doesn't scan more than a couple hundred pages a day, then the Fujitsu ScanSnap is more than sufficient for your needs. If you are running a small business, and you, or your employees don't want to have to station yourself next to the scanner all day, then the Kodak is very appealing. The only stumbling block with Kodak is the software, but be patient with it, and you ought to be able to get it to do what you need.

I found the Runtastic Speed and Cadence Bike Sensor with Bluetooth Smart Technology easy to install and set up. Everything is straightforward, though the guide that comes with it isn't entirely clear in places (I'd say this isn't one of the better manuals out there). Fortunately, there isn't much to mess up with only a handful of items to attach. Do not, by the way, purchase the Runtastic Bike Case for iPhone 4, 4S, 5 (Black). It is a piece of junk, and really shouldn't cost anything at all. This review is about the sensor, though, so let's get on with it.Why is it worrisome? Like another reviewer who kindly posted a video (SMXSteve), this device doesn't look like a good idea to me. I've had things get caught in my spokes and taken a spill before, so I am quite leery of putting something like this on my bike. I worry that this won't end well, and watching the video only made me more concerned that this (unfortunately) might not be for me. It's too bad, really, because it is otherwise a great device. Please note that other products I have seen have similar construction, and I haven't actually experienced this horror, so maybe my fears are unfounded, and we'll all be safe with this. I'll keep an eye on it over the summer and see if it moves. I wonder why this wasn't designed to be bottom mounted?What's good about the app? Unlike others, I had no problem syncing with my iPhone 4S or Samsung Galaxy SIII. Maybe I just got lucky. The app works great, has all kinds of settings, and does a great job of giving me more information than I've ever had before on my ride. My only wish is that this well-designed app could have been paired with an equally well designed sensor.

It is pretty rare that I give a one-star review, but the Runtastic Bike Case for iPhone 4, 4S, 5 (White) has managed to earn it. There really isn't much to say about this poorly designed device except to ask how a company that makes a nice product like the Runtastic Speed and Cadence Bike Sensor with Bluetooth Smart Technology could churn out this junk. I'll just rattle off the problems here, but read the other reviews for details about each point:- You have to remove your own cover to put it in this cheap one, and you know that this transfer process (on a bike ride!?) is bound to be the time you drop your phone onto concrete without a case.- Mounting this on my handlebars was difficult and ultimately a waste of time.- A waste of time because the screen is unresponsive under the cheap plastic. I couldn't get anything to register correctly standing still, and it was even more impossible while riding.Personally, I consider this product to be a safety hazard, I recommend no one put it on their bikes (you can bet the people at Runtastic don't actually use this), and I strongly urge you not to try and operate it while riding. Fortunately, the app to track your ride works fine if you leave the phone in your bag, so just do that, and forget about having the display in front of you.

I moved from a 2012 11" Macbook Air to the Apple MacBook Air MD711LL/A 11.6-Inch Laptop (NEWEST VERSION) and I don't notice any difference at all in performance. However, I think it is the best one I've ever used because of the battery life. I easily get roughly double what I used to with the 2012 Macbook Air. I have the base model with the i5 processor, 128 GB of storage, and 4 GB of memory. [REVIEW EDITED JULY 10]Battery Life---------If you change the brightness to about 75% (this is the level at which Apple did their testing) you ought to easily get 8-10 hours of use out of the computer. From online comments, it looks like other people are getting better results from their batteries after the first charge cycle, so if you are having problems, discharge it once (I went down to 7%), charge it, and see if that doesn't help.Should you Upgrade?----------You ought to see a huge performance boost upgrading from a 2011 or earlier Macbook Air, but is it worth it to upgrade from the 2012 Macbook Air to this one? Probably not for most people, unless battery life is a critical factor for you (it is for me). Some of you might notice a small performance bump, but most (including me) won't.
