Physically, with the exception of a tiny hole on the side for the mic, it is also indistinguishable from last year's model.11" or 13" ?----------I wrote a review of last year's model here (http://www.amazon.com/review/RLCO4ZC1NVQMD/ref=cm_cr_rdp_perm), where I extolled the virtues of the computer. Everything I said there applies to this year's model as well, and my only complaint (the battery life) has been addressed. I also still think the 13" base model is a better buy for the money, but because I value portability, I stuck with the 11".If you are a student or teacher, you can get an academic discount ordering through Apple instead of Amazon. At the time of this writing, it is $50 less than Amazon, but you pay tax, so it ends up costing about $15 more. Both Apple and Amazon offer free shipping.

The OXO Good Grips Measuring Cups, Stainless Steel, Updated Design look great, they're sturdy, and they're dishwasher safe. What's not to like? Well, if you look closely, you can see in the image that the large is not flat, but angles upward. I am sure there is some kind of brilliant design idea behind this, but in practice what you have is a measuring cup that is inexact. It works OK for powders (assuming that the angled area is part of the 1 Cup), but for liquids it is not so great, and obviously one of these has to be incorrect. Either the angled section is or is not included in the 1 Cup.In addition, I cannot figure out how they got the cups to stack so well in the photo. In our drawer, they don't fit together terribly well, and the handles stick up to catch whenever we try to open it. Frankly speaking, I have some cheap plastic ones from many years ago that are made better than this. Sure, I'd like metal ones with the great handles, but it isn't worth giving up the ability to actually use them.The low rating on this review might seem a bit harsh, but after all, it is a measuring cup that cannot possibly measure correctly. That seems to fail the basic measure (nice pun, right?) of the product.

I've already got a couple of great stands for my iPad, but the Fellowes I-Spire Series Tablet Lift (9311301) is a little different from the rest because it isn't especially portable. What you lose in portability, though, you gain in comfort. I've been surprised at how nice it is to have the tablet leaning back at a slight angle a few inches above the desk.I wish that it had some way to adjust the angle and height, but if you are looking for a stand to leave at home / in the office that gets the iPad off your desk and closer to eye level, this is probably going to fit your needs well.

The Withings WS-50 Smart Body Analyzer, Black is a great product for people who are into quantifying their lives and lifelogging, but may be too much if you just want to know how much you weigh!HARDWARE- It is nicely made overall, but it is a little larger than I would like, and the feet are terribly slippery. The cheap 3M adhesive isn't firmly affixed to the feet, so I wouldn't be surprised if they fall off in the future when picking up the scale. It isn't a big deal, because I don't plan to move the scale much, but I don't know why they cut corners there. At this price point, I think it is fair to expect it to do better than my previous scale at 1/3 the price. It is actually very dangerous in our tiled bathroom, like standing on a skateboard, and I plan to put some kind of rubberized surface under it. I wouldn't call this a deal breaker, but I wouldn't get it for a parent or grandparent who has a tile floor unless I could set it up for them with some kind of grippy material under it.SETUP- A little time consuming. It showed kilograms only when I got it, and the scale has no adjustments to make on its own. To get the most out of this scale, you have to install the app, which I did (iPhone), and everything went smoothly from there.APP- It's OK, but doesn't handle two users very well. For some reason, it gets me right every time, but my wife's data has to get assigned to her manually. It is a little annoying, and I cannot see any way to adjust the settings to recognize that the data as hers.ACCURACY- As far as I can tell, it is pretty accurate, though I seem to weigh more than I should! I have no idea if the CO2 readings are accurate, and I really don't know what I am supposed to get from these numbers. Otherwise, it feeds me a good deal of useful information.SUMMARY- As someone who likes to track things like my weight, this scale is perfectly suited for me. It certainly does make it easier to have everything sent immediately to my phone, and I like that it does it automatically. If you are just looking for your weight, and don't plan on syncing with another device, then it is probably overkill.

At the time I am writing this, Office 365 Home Premium 1yr Subscription Key Card only gives Mac users Office 2011, and this is not written anywhere on their Amazon product page. Not only that, but if you get this you will be on a subscription model, and you'll have to pay to keep using it. If you are only using Macs, there is almost no benefit that I can see to getting this product. However, people using multiple operating systems will gain the ability to download versions for whatever operating system you are using (up to 5 computers). You will also have 27GB of SkyDrive usage.SUPPORTI already had a 1 month trial version. The instructions on the activation card I received, and on the website were a little confusing, because they seemed to assume that I did not have an account already. I thought I would take this opportunity to call support and make sure I was doing it correctly. Thirty minutes, and three transfers to different people later, we got to the bottom of the problem. I just needed to follow the instructions I was given on the card!I did learn that the support staff is friendly and helpful; I suppose they don't often get people calling with trial subscriptions, ignoring instructions they have in front of them, and trying to upgrade with one of these activation codes. The last time I tried to contact Microsoft support, I think they tried to charge me nearly $200 to talk with them about an "incident" through their "professional support," so it is good to know that you can easily contact Microsoft for free as well.OFFICEWhat can I say? This is not a very good deal for Mac users, especially if you already have a 2011 version of Office on your computer. I knew I would only be getting Office 2011, because I have been keeping up with the tech news, but because I could receive it through the Vine program as a reviewer, and I run Parallels on my Mac, I thought this might be a convenient way to install two versions for the price of one. Eventually, Mac folks will probably see an upgrade, but it looks like they will continue to lag behind the Windows people.SUMMARYAs a Mac user, would I have gone out and bought it? No. It is the same software I already had, but costs about $100 more to use it, and puts me on a subscription model that will suck $10 out of my bank account every month for the rest of my life. I don't relish the thought of paying thousands of dollars over my lifetime to use a word processor, and I think Microsoft is on the wrong path with this model.My guess is that when my subscription runs out next year, I will uninstall this, install my old copy of 2011, and only use Word when someone sends me a document in that format. Otherwise, I'll stick to Word's inexpensive competitors like Pages, Google Docs, Open Office, etc. Don't get me wrong -- Word is undoubtedly the best program out there, but I don't think it is worth it for the subscription model.

I've enjoyed Lonely Planet books for years, and Lonely Planet Paris (City Guide) is another great guidebook in the series. It is full of historical background as well as practical tips. I have never been to the city, but I am planning a trip now, and I have been going through this book to prepare. The Arc de Triomphe, for example,  starts out with a brief history of the monument, explains some of the plaques, describes some of the sculptures, and concludes with the viewing platform.WIKIPEDIA VS LONELY PLANETIt's all clear and well-written, but in this age of Wikipedia, how necessary is it? If you visit the Wikipedia page for the Arc de Triomphe, you'll find much more historical detail, many photographs of the plaques and so forth that are only briefly described in the guidebook, and better directions about how to gain access to the arch.I've gathered a lot of Wikipedia entries for the trip and put them into my Evernote account, so I'll have them easily accessible. I also plan to have wireless access, so I doubt I will be consulting this guidebook as much as I would have ten or twenty years ago. Wikipedia is sometimes inaccurate when it comes to history (so is Lonely Planet), but it is usually on target when it comes to more practical matters like gaining access to a site like the Arc de Triomphe, and it has photographs galore.If you have wireless access, should you bother bringing it along on your trip? I still think so, because it offers a handy way to find quick synopses of sites, and it still contains great tips on food (though Yelp!, like Wikipedia, is also a potentially more useful alternative). Gathering the Wikipedia entries takes a lot of time, and it is definitely easier to thumb through this guide, so it still has a role to play in planning for a trip.

The TP-LINK TL-MR3020 3G/4G Wireless N150 Portable Router, Pocket  Design, AP, WISP, Router, 2.4Ghz 150Mpbs is easy to setup and works exactly as you would expect.HARDWAREThe device is very portable and compact. This is definitely a device with travelers in mind. However, I found the performance to be quite good at home, and if you only have a couple of devices on the network at once, you could conceivably use this as your home router. Just remember that if you are getting more than 150 Mbps on your Internet provider plan, then you won't be able to take full advantage of it.SETUPIt comes with a CD (this company is really fond of CD installations), but it is unnecessary. Besides, I don't even have a CD player on my computer! It is very easy to get started. For simple wireless access, plug in the cable to the device, switch to "Standard AP Mode" on the back, find the TP-Link network, and type in the "KEY" number on the back of your device. You ought to be connected.SUMMARYA great device at a very reasonable price. If you are a frequent traveler, and you often find yourself in hotel rooms with weak or even non-existent wifi connections, you'll definitely want to consider this.

The TP-LINK TL-WDR3500 Wireless N600 Dual Band Router, 2.4GHz 300Mbps+5Ghz 300Mbps, USB port,  IP QoS, Wireless On/Off Switch is an affordable and well-designed option for a wireless router.HARDWAREIt is low profile, lightweight, and seems to be well-designed with two antennas that can be attached to the back. It has an on/off switch for the wireless, which you don't always see on routers. I imagine if you are plugged directly into the router that it would be handy to have the wireless off instead of broadcasting to everyone around you.SETUPI failed miserably at this. I have a Macbook Air, so the CD that came with the device could not be used. I was also instructed to plug in my LAN cable, but I don't have an Ethernet port on this computer, so I simply couldn't set it up. If I had been using an iPad or any other device I think I would have also had trouble.One of the other reviewers mentioned typing an address into the address bar in my browser along with the pin number from the bottom of the device. Perhaps this would have worked, but the instructions I received from the manufacturer did not work. I think this is a major oversite, and I don't understand why they shipped it this way. Basically, if you don't have a CD drive or Ethernet connector (many of us don't anymore) you seem to be out of luck. How could they not have considered this?Fortunately, I could borrow a Windows computer with an Ethernet port. I didn't bother with the CD and it worked fine with good coverage throughout my condominium.SUMMARYThis is a very affordable router, and s long as you have an Ethernet port on your device, you should be able to set this device up and enjoy it. If you don't have an Ethernet port, you may want to look elsewhere.

The Haas-Jordan by Westcott The Urbanite Folding Umbrella (44-Inch) is a lightweight and sturdy umbrella that does what an umbrella ought to do; namely, keep you dry.A single click of the button on the handle pops it open. I like that the frame is fiberglass, though there is still some metal in there that might get bent and rusted over time with use, and I will keep a watch over those parts.It claims to be good for stormy weather, but I have to admit that this doesn't seem that sturdy to me. It's difficult to say, because it has a nice vent at the top that will let wind pass through, so it may well be OK after all. I keep waiting for a storm to try it out, but we've only had relatively light showers lately. I'll update this review if I meet a storm that it can't handle. So far, this is one of my favorite travel umbrellas.

I would recommend the iHome  Bluetooth Keyboard (IMAC-K111S) as a nice backup keyboard or alternative to more expensive options. I like to use external keyboards paired with my iPad, and I found this to be a great device for that. The keys travel well, the spacing is nice, and everything works as expected. My only complaint is that it is plastic and not nearly as nice of an angle as the Apple keyboard. Of course, you'll pay 2 or 3 times as much for that, so I would say this keyboard delivers the experience you would expect from a low cost solution.

This is my first time using Dragon Dictate, Version 3.0 (Mac), but I've used the software on Windows for many years now. To my eyes this works pretty much exactly the same as earlier Windows versions that I have used. The training is an easy process, and once it is done, the software almost immediately starts improving. I recommend you take the time to correct it in the early days for each and every word it gets wrong, because the time you spend doing this will pay off later when you can run through your work just as fast, if not faster than you would typing.I've seen the poor reviews that the software has gotten, and I am a little concerned about that. It looks like it is working well for some people, and not working at all for others. In my experience, it has been accurate and reliable, but that could change. I will be sure to update this review in the future if I run across any problems. For now, though, I'd say this is a great product and definitely deserves five stars.

The HOMEDICS UHE-OC1 COOL MIST ULTRASONIC HUMIDFIER (UHE-OC1) - is one of my favorite humidifiers. I've had quite a few over the years, but there is almost always something missing.Some of them have annoying blue lights that cannot be turned off. Some have a small tank that runs out too quickly. Others are noisy and keep me awake all night.I won't say that this one is quiet, by any means, because it does make a little noise in order to produce the mist and to turn the oscillating head. However, it isn't as bad as I've had with others, and the trade-off (the oscillation and generous amount of mist) is well worth it.One of my favorite features is the ability to turn off the annoying blue light. Thank you! So many manufacturers of so many devices think that just because you can light a product up means that you ought to.

The Seagate Backup Plus 1 TB USB 3.0 Portable External Hard Drive STBU1000100  (Black) is an excellent product that works much as you would expect, but with one clever addition.The case is solidly constructed, lightweight, and quite slim. In addition to this, it has the ability to work with a Thunderbolt adapter. I don't know if the Thunderbolt adapter is something that people will be interested in using, but it is really nice to have the option!The drive also happens to be pretty inexpensive. I typically purchase either Seagate or Western Digital Drives for my backups, depending on which one has the lowest price at the time I buy. Prices have been falling pretty steadily over the last few years. Although this is a review of the black one, if you click on the white one you'll see that it is $10 less. It is probably the cheapest I have ever seen a drive.

The Seagate Backup Plus Desktop Thunderbolt Adapter (STAE129) is a little pricey (it costs about the same as a few terabytes of storage) and a bit of a pain to setup, but with patience, it might be worth it for you.HARDWARE-------------Like its smaller cousin for the portable drives, it's easy to install. You pop off the USB adapter on the drive and then put this Thunderbolt one on it. The hardware is nice looking, and it adds a bit of stability to a drive that otherwise has a tendency to topple over (Seagate staff have said that it is fine to use the drive on its side).SOFTWARE-------------It's an adapter, so you might think you don't need software. You'd be wrong. Hooking up the Thunderbolt drive, my computer couldn't even tell that it was connected to the device, even though it was fine a few seconds before with the USB connection.In the box is a thumb drive with about 1GB of data on it. This is supposed to be a driver you need for drives larger than 2TB. I plugged it into my Mac and it also was not recognized. Maybe they sent a thumb drive with the adapter that is formatted for Windows, and they forgot about their Mac users. Or, maybe I was just unlucky with a dud. Fortunately, there is a website where you can go to download the drivers [...].It is a rather confusing site with lots of bold red and warnings. It seems to be telling me that I only need the driver if I intend to use both the USB and Thunderbolt adapters. If I am only using the Thunderbolt adapter, I can reformat my drive and be fine without the driver. What is this about reformatting!? First of all, I have data on the drive. Second of all, my computer cannot even see the drive with the Thunderbolt adapter, so I don't even know how I would get this to work.Fortunately, the driver is easy to install on the drive, and once I did that, everything worked fine. The data transfer is speedy, as expected, though limited somewhat by the speed of the non-SSD external drive itself. I really wish they had thought this through more, though, and didn't force me to jump through hoops to access the drive. The portable adapter works much more easily (just clip it on).DO YOU NEED THIS?-------------Probably not if you are just looking for speed, because I don't even think it will be faster than the USB 3.0 adapter. The platters on the external drive don't spin fast enough to take advantage of the Thunderbolt. In addition, it doesn't come with a cable. This means you will spend much more for the adapter than you will for an entirely new USB 3.0 drive.If you are looking to take advantage of Thunderbolt's ability to "daisy chain" (using one port on your computer, you can connect to more than one drive, because the drives connect to one another), though, then this is a great addition to your gadget toolbox. I'm afraid this product may not have a huge audience, but I can at least say that it appears well-made and well-integrated into the Seagate product line.

The Fujitsu ScanSnap iX500 Scanner for PC and Mac (PA03656-B005) is a major investment, but I think it will pay off for you over time if you have a lot of paper to scan. In my case, I am looking to digitize everything from store receipts to my rather large library of dead tree books.GOING PAPERLESS: TWO KEY FEATURES---I've already gone paperless and managed to put all of the loose paper I have accumulated over the years into my computer using the ScanSnap S300. This has been a trusted companion, and is still going strong, so why upgrade? Speed and multi-page detection.1. The ix500 chews through paper at phenomenal speeds, and it even manages to do it much more quietly than my S300. It is beautiful to watch, and even a 500-page book can be finished at B/W 600 dpi in about 15 minutes.2. The multi-page detection will stop whenever it detects that more than one sheet has been fed through the scanner at once. This occasionally happens, and on the S300 I have always had to keep an eye on things to make sure that I didn't miss any pages. The ix500 is very accurate, and so far it hasn't let a single misfeed go through.OTHER FEATURES---I've heard people speak about how wonderful the wireless sync, and the integration with iOS is, but for me, this isn't a big deal. I go through hundreds of pages a day (sometimes even thousands), and there is no way that I would be able to do this from another room (how do you load the scanner?). I also don't want to have all of this appear on my iPad. I am sure there are plenty of use cases for this technology, and I am glad that it is there, but it isn't something I have found useful yet.SUMMARY---If you have a lot of paper to scan, I think this is the device to get, because it is the best one on the market. The price may seem steep at first, but if you consider the time, effort, and money spent filing, moving around bookcases and file cabinets, or storing boxes of books / paper, then it begins to look a lot more reasonable.

Have a Seagate Backup Plus drive that only works with USB 3.0, and you'd prefer to have Thunderbolt, but don't want to spend money on a new drive? If so, then the Seagate Backup Plus Portable Thunderbolt Adapter (STAE128) is perfect for you.HARDWARE---Not much. It doesn't even come with a cable, and if you are like me, then you probably don't have a whole lot of Thunderbolt cables sitting around yet. However, it is exactly as advertised, and is clearly well-built.USE CASE = DAISY CHAINING---If you have a Seagate Backup Plus drive, you just pop off the adapter end, and slip the drive into the Thunderbolt Adapter. Now you are ready to go. Why would you want this, though, because your drive cannot possibly spin fast enough to actually make use of the additional capability that the Thunderbolt offers?The answer: daisy chaining. I hook a Seagate 3 TB Thunderbolt backup that I use to store all of my files (a couple of TB total) into my Macbook Air (only one Thunderbolt slot), and then hook the Seagate Backup Plus into that (the 3 TB drive) for my Time Machine. This frees up all of the other ports on my device, and makes the process of hooking and unhooking drives a lot nicer.SUMMARY---I gave it five stars, because it does what it does well. It is well-designed, and I like the concept, but you probably don't need this unless you have an extremely narrow use case in mind.

The Seagate Backup Plus 1 TB USB 3.0 Portable External Hard Drive for Mac (STBW1000900) is a great deal on a lot of memory. It's difficult to believe how much external drives have dropped in price over the last few years, and this one provides you with USB 3.0 as well.SOFTWARE---It comes with software that you can install, and I think Seagate is ahead of the curve with some of this. You start out with product registration, but Seagate fills in all the fields for you with "fake name" and "fake@email.com." It saves you the time of making up stuff on your own! The Seagate Dashboard software itself, though, is disappointing, because it is so simple, and such a step backwards from the software in years past that I cannot ever see myself using it.I don't really think the uninteresting software matters, though. Fortunately, as a Mac user, you have easy access to Time Machine right in your Menu bar. I cannot recommend Time Machine enough, and this hard drive is perfect for it.HARDWARE---In addition to coming with a stylish, but mainly plastic body, you also have the option to use a Thunderbolt adapter. I don't know how many people will actually do this, especially when the drive is not fast enough to take advantage of the additional speed, but it is a more convenient option for connecting a backup to your Mac.SUMMARY---This would be a great drive at twice the price, and I strongly recommend considering it if you are looking for something trustworthy to store your files.

The Seagate Backup Plus 3 TB Thunderbolt Desktop External Hard Drive for Mac (STCB3000400) might not be kind to your pocketbook, but it is definitely worth considering if you are looking for a solid, fast, and beautifully designed external hard drive.DESIGNFirst, the design really stands out. It is similar to its svelte, glossy, and much less expensive cousin (Seagate Backup Plus 3 TB USB 3.0 Desktop External Hard Drive (STCA3000101)), and clearly they share some of the same design elements. This one, though, is covered in a nice rubberized coating, and sits in a kind of stand, which contains the Thunderbolt slots. Both of them look great, but I feel like this one has a bit more sophistication to it.PERFORMANCEIt is blazing fast (as you would expect with any Thunderbolt device), and works flawlessly. What I love about it is that I can daisy chain devices so that using one slot on my Macbook Air for this drive also allows me to plug in my Time Machine backup. I can't think of a thing I would improve with this setup, and it is so much more elegant than using up all of my USB slots for these drives.SOFTWAREDisappointing. I have to admit I rarely install software, because I am really looking for either a Time Machine backup or I want to save files onto the drive, and I don't want to go through the hassle of software. In this case, the software seems tailored for social media. The thing is, I don't imagine many people out there have 3TB of photos on Facebook! I couldn't really see how I would use it to save regular files. It did not seem set up for doing this, which is kind of odd.SUMMARYThis drive is a premium device (in my opinion) for people who have a lot of data, and really care about their backups. I haven't reduced my five-star rating for the software, because I don't put a whole lot of weight on the bundled software in the first place. What I am looking for is speed, design, and reliability. This drive has all of these qualities, and I highly recommend it.

I wanted to give the 3M Smart Lens Protective Eyewear a try, because I commute by bike a lot, and I am looking for something to protect my eyes from bugs, road debris that gets kicked up by cars, rain, etc.These are perfect, and because they do not get too dark in the light, they can be used pretty much any time of the day. Previously, I would wear sunglasses, but on early morning rides before the sun is all the way up, or in the evening, I couldn't wear them, so this eyewear is the perfect solution. Highly recommended, and sturdily constructed as well.

The Peeled Snacks Organic Apple Clusters, Cinnamon Crunch, 60 Gram makes a great light snack. And, it's also nice to eat something healthy as well. They have a light puffy feel to them, so are a little different than your standard dried fruit fare. My only complaint, and it is a minor one, is that they are a little gooey in the mouth. You'll definitely want to brush your teeth soon afterwards.

I was a little surprised at how tough the Dickies 3000721 Black Heavy Duty Rear Bench Seat Protector was, because it is a little rougher than I had envisioned. It's OK, especially, if you have pets or you plan to haul around something in your back seat, but I wouldn't recommend it on a daily basis if you plan to put people back there. It is definitely not comfortable, and you cannot get at the seat belts, so it has pretty limited use. In my case, I think I'll stick to using it when we take the dog to the dog park on muddy days.

The Seagate Backup Plus 3 TB USB 3.0 Desktop External Hard Drive (STCA3000101) is a beautiful drive that stands up on your desk with an unobtrusive light and low volume of noise emitting from it. Overall, I am pleased with the device and its performance. I am also surprised at how inexpensive such a great product has become, because only a year or two ago 3 TB cost so much I did not even think to look at it. As you can see in the comments section for this review, the Seagate staff are knowledgable and helpful as well.EDITED:(1) My only complaint is that it is not especially stable, so you will want to put it in a place where it cannot get knocked over.- A Seagate representative kindly wrote a comment to this review explaining that it can be placed on its side as well. That is good to know, though it is definitely not apparent that this is possible (or recommended) from the design along, which has no "feet" anywhere on the "sides," and all of the illustrations show it vertical.EDITED:(2) Please note that this drive appears to be listed on Amazon less expensive than the "Mac" version, and it comes formatted for Windows NTFS (read only for Macs), but it apparently has a Mac version of the Seagate software on the drive (I did not install it), and it is easily re-formatted (I recommend Ex-Fat) for your Mac. Personally, I have nothing against the software provided by Seagate (or any other company), but I am looking for a drive to hold my data, and do not need (or want) to go through someone's interface. My rating reflects my experience with the drive, not the software.- The Seagate representative recommended that we do not use ExFat with this drive, as it has certain limitations (I assume these refer to OS restrictions, possible problems with inadvertent disconnections, etc.). Instead, they recommended Mac OS Extended, or use of the bundled Seagate software.

The Philips SHS8105A/28 Ear-Hook Headset for Android (Black) are a nice fit for my relatively small ears. The sound quality is about what I expected for them, and I am relatively pleased with how they feel during long periods of use. I messed around with the Android app, and it was OK, but I guess I am not terribly thrilled about needing something like that just for my headphones. Your mileage may vary.

The Command Large Picture-Hanging Strips, White, 4-Strip performed exactly as I hoped that they would. I didn't clean the surface (painted wall) with isopropyl rubbing alcohol, as recommended in the instructions, but I had no problems. My picture frame is less than 4 pounds, and it worked fine, but apparently these strips can hold something up to 16 pounds.

The KRUD KUTTER KK32 Original Concentrated Cleaner/Degreaser, 32-Ounce comes with a suitably distinctive chemical smell, some suds, and a garish bottle, but for cleaning up "krud," I think your mileage may vary.My hope was that it would clean the bathroom in our rental unit. I might have expected too much, though, because the soap scum and mildew-stained caulking in the bathtub are still there. I will say that the chrome looked really clean afterwards, and it at least seemed to do a lot better than the regular stuff we buy in the store. Some of those brands truly do nothing more than put on a sudsy show. At least this appears to be making a good faith effort at removing krud. Perhaps, as another reviewer noted, I didn't have the right kind of krud.The krud in my kitchen had the right stuff, and so I think the kitchen is probably a better location to try out krud kutter. It is much more effective there against grease.Overall, even though it didn't perform miracles in the bathroom, I'd still recommend the product as an all-in-one, effective cleaner. It didn't do as much as I wanted, but it did a lot better than any of the competitors.

The VSonic GR07 headphones are quite impressive, and I recommend them for anyone looking to move up from regular earbuds to something lightweight, well-built, and customizable. I'll be comparing these to the the far less expensive Apple In-ear Headphones for iPod (White) and the far more expensive Bose® QuietComfortÂ® 15 Acoustic Noise CancellingÂ® Headphones. These are early impressions, and I plan to update this more in the future if anything changes.SOUND QUALITYThe sound quality is good, but it took several days for it to get there, because there is apparently a "burn-in" period. There was a noticeable improvement when going from the Bose to the VSonic, but not such a big difference when going from Apple to it. The Apple sound feels a little dead to me in comparison, but not terribly bad.BUILD QUALITYI wish there was not quite so much plastic, and that the individual pieces were sturdier looking. One thing that stood out to me was the ability to change the direction of the speakers -- it is a tiny thing, but something missing on similar over-the-ears headphones. The Bose (considering its high price) has a shockingly large amount of plastic, and I was concerned about its durability, but three or four years later (with the same price, strangely), they are doing just fine, so my concerns about the plastic may be unfounded. The Apple headphones feel very well-built, and I have had them for several years without any issues, and even though they have just as much plastic, if not more than the VSonic ones, the Apple headphones appear more solid to me.ACCESSORIESThe VSonic wins hands down. It has a wide array of silicone tips and two cases (clamshell and pouch). The Bose headphones came with their big case, but that was about it. The Apple ones came with three silicone tips, but these things are always falling off, none of them quite fit right in my ears. One thing that I really appreciate about the Apple headphones, though, is the voume adjustment on the headphone cables and the microphone. Neither Bose nor VSonic offer this feature.FITWithout the ear guides, I think they will fit in anyone's ears. With the ear guides, though, this is hit or miss. They work fine for me, but I asked someone with different ears to give them a try, and they didn't fit well at all with the plastic ear guides. These headphones are a lot better than with the Apple ones, which love to pop out all of the time, occasionally throw a silicon tip across the floor, or leave the silicon tip behind in my ear when the speaker decides to go somewhere else. The VSonic headphones are very nice in this regard, and there is no hint of the rubber ear pieces coming loose. The Bose headphones definitely fit the best of the three, because they completely encase the ear. Of course, they are also much more bulky than earbuds, and not nearly as portable.NOISE ISOLATIONNo apparent difference between these and the Apple headphones. I was a little disappointed in this respect, because I would like to use them for blocking out surrounding noises as well as listening to music. The Bose headphones are still the best ones I have ever used for noise canceling (active, as opposed to passive noise isolation), but the sound quality is not too great with Bose. You gain quiet in order to hear the music better, but you lose sound quality, so the music doesn't sound as good! I value its noise canceling over the music any day, but if you are an audiophile, then something like the VSonic that doesn't get in the way of the music would be better.SUMMARYI strongly recommend these headphones if you are looking for something lightweight and portable. You'll spend a little on these than you would with Apple, but a little less than you would with Bose, and you'll have the ability to customize them to fit just right in your ears.

I was pleasantly surprised that the RCA HP818 Noise-Isolating Earphones (Black and white) have a different texture to the earbuds that makes them a little more rigid than the typical silicon ones. Personally, I like this feel, because they tend not to slip out as much, especially while working out. For the price, the sound quality was decent: nothing dramatically impressive or disappointing. As far as noise-isolating goes, I guess it is pretty much exactly what you would get with any object stuffed into your ears, and for better or worse, blocks sound about as effectively as more expensive brands that don't advertise as noise-isolating.

As far as I can tell, the AmazonBasics AA NiMH Precharged Rechargeable Batteries-8-Pack work exactly as you would expect. They come fully charged, and they power devices for the same amount of time as batteries from better-known brands do. They also recharge just as they are supposed to, so I think Amazon has created a solid product here. I'll keep an eye on their performance over time and update my review if I notice any drop-off in performance.

Our dog loved the Nature's Variety Instinct Raw Boost Bites Freeze-Dried Treats, Chicken, 4-Ounce Package, and I would highly recommend it to anyone who is working on training their dog. The ingredients are healthy, and apparently it is quite tasty.I gave it four stars, because the treats are a little larger than I would like. Of course, you can just break them in pieces to make great rewards. They crumble a bit, but those crumbs still work! Our dog still hasn't got all of the commands down, but at least she looked forward to the training.

The SanDisk Extreme 32 GB USB 3.0 Flash Drive SDCZ80-032G-X46 is a solid flash drive that works well with the Macintosh. I am using it on my 2012 Macbook Air (USB 3.0) and have not experienced any problems. I have reformatted it a couple of times, but could not reproduce any of the problems seen in other reviews. The sliding connector is not uncommon on flash drives these days, and it works smoothly. I would have given it five stars, but I think the plastic casing really ought to have been a more sturdy metal one that you can find even with less expensive competitors. It isn't a big deal, but it is certainly something to consider for something that will be in pockets and backpacks.

I wonder if the designers of the RCA USB A to Micro B Cable (AH732R) tested this on actual devices, because it doesn't work properly on anything for me. - I tried it with my Seagate hard drive. The design of the plug made it so that the metal end was too short to seat properly. The drive connected intermittently, but I couldn't manage to keep it working for long. - I tried it with my Google Nexus 7. It charges, but that is the best I could do. The regular cord for the Nexus 7 works fine, so it isn't my device, or my technical incompetence that is to blame here.I want to like this cord, because it seems quite sturdy, but otherwise there is nothing to recommend here. Maybe the one I received is a dud.

The Seagate Expansion 500 GB USB 3.0 Portable External Hard Drive works well, just as you'd expect for any Seagate product. I've used their portable hard drives for years without any problems, and while there is no doubt that this USB 3.0 drive is the fastest one I've ever used, it won't win any beauty contests. It's a little shorter in length and lighter than previous models, but the enclosure is a bit more boxy. I've used it on both Windows and Mac machines without any problem (with the proper formatting, fo course). The warranty may be shorter than I'd like, but I've never had an issue with Seagate, and it is very affordably priced.

[EDIT:] The BUFFALO MiniStation 500 GB Thunderbolt/USB 3.0 Portable Hard Drive has failed. I have adjusted the review rating to reflect my poor experience with the defective product, and the lack of an acceptable avenue for resolving problems.I have bought and used dozens of drives over the years, and I know failures occur with every manufacturer (I have never come across a total failure myself), so maybe I just got a dud. I've checked with technicians, and they have confirmed that the data cannot be accessed because a failure somewhere in the device (perhaps the connectors), and not because of my computers or anything on my end. I have enjoyed other Buffalo products in the past, so I do not think my one anecdote here should be taken as representative of the quality of their products.My problem is with Buffalo's policies. I contacted Buffalo and the representative told me I can: (a) send in the device (with my data stuck on it) for a refund, (b) use an affiliated data recovery service for a fee, or (c) void the warranty by opening it myself. None of these seem particularly palatable to me, and the representative was unwilling or unable to be flexible (strikingly different than my experience with other companies like Amazon). I don't know if these policies are standard for the industry, but at least with Buffalo, you should know what will happen if you encounter issues.By the way, as with any backup device, it is worth investing in other backup solutions for your backups. Redundancy is extremely important in a digitized world, and fortunately, my "just in case" drives (by other manufacturers) have my data stored safe and sound. Again, I want to stress that failures happen, and this may have just been bad luck. I accept that. However, I am uncomfortable with the company's policies to resolve problems.----------------------[Original Five-Star Review]The BUFFALO MiniStation 500 GB Thunderbolt/USB 3.0 Portable Hard Drive impressed me right out of the box with its attention to detail, and it delivered with high speed performance as well.--- DESIGN ---- Silver and white with thin black rubber strips on the bottom to keep it firmly in place -- a perfect match for a Mac.- A cleverly placed white light on the bottom that glows softly when it is plugged in.- It feels quite sturdy.--- USAGE ---- The Thunderbolt connection makes a huge difference. This is my first Thunderbolt device, and I was blown away by the speed.- The USB connector appears to be 3.0, and this is what it says in the product description for what I ordered, but the box and literature makes no mention of it being USB 3.0. In fact, it has a strange chart on the back comparing USB 2.0, FireWire 800, and Thunderbolt speeds.--- RECOMMENDATION ---- I highly recommend the drive for its design and speed, but in terms of capacity, you could probably find a portable one with twice as much storage for half as much money. Of course, the cheaper alternatives won't be as nice-looking, and won't have Thunderbolt.

The Belkin Micro (1.1 Amp) USB wall Charger with 4ft Sync / Charge Cable impressed me with its sturdiness. There isn't much to say about it, because it is basically the same kind of charger you can get from Apple for your iPod Touch or iPhone. It works as expected. The difference, though, is in the cable.As everyone knows, the Apple cables are prone to falling apart at either end, and at some point you have probably thought about going out and getting another cable. I know I have bought a couple already!Well, the next time you need to do that, instead of getting the standard Apple one, which you know will break, look into this one. It is quite thick and seems like it will last a long time.  I have only had it for about a month, so I cannot say for certain what will happen, but I have a very good feeling about it! I will update this review in the future to tell you how it goes.[EDIT:} I've edited this review to reflect my experience with it over time. The cable remains in excellent condition, and I quite like that aspect of it, but the connector that is supposed to slip into the iPhone and gently latch itself to the device, only works on the iPhone this way, and not on the iPad. Even a light bump will disconnect the iPad from the cable, which means that if you are going on a trip, you have to bring two cables instead of one. It's no big deal if you only have an iPhone, because that is what the cable is designed for, but if you have multiple devices and plan to use the cable with them, then you are probably not going to be as satisfied.

[EDIT:]  The drive has stopped working for me on my Mac. It is no longer recognized. Could it be my upgrade to Mountain Lion that did it? Every other drive works fine, though. I am happy to say that I can still read it on my Windows machine (I formatted it this way). I've lowered my rating, because I do not think this behavior (losing the ability to access a drive) is expected. I'll keep working with it to see if I can improve the performance, but I have a feeling I may have to reformat the disk and start again.----------The Seagate Expansion 2 TB USB 3.0 Desktop External Hard Drive isn't the best-looking device I've ever had, but I like how smoothly it runs.QUIETI've had other ones in the past (even ones by Seagate) that make a bunch of noise while running, but this one seems to be pretty quiet. The fan  kicked in after a few hours of transferring files. It isn't too bad at all, and that is the only noise coming from it. It is a little warm to the touch, but not hot at all, and I expect it will do fine.FASTThe USB 3.0 tranfer is what you would expect: fast.SPACEIt had 1.81 GB on it. I suppose it is standard for these things to come with a little bit less space than advertised, so no big deal, but something to know.SOFTWARENone. I thought there was some inside (I actually like the Seagate backup manager software I have used in the past), but the only thing I found was a way to register the device. Delete that file and you are ready to go.MAC OR PC?I ran it first on my PC, because that is the model I ordered, but I ended up reformatting it for a Mac. If you do this, I recommend using a PC to reformat the drive as "ExFat". Doing so supposedly makes it possible to use the drive on both Mac and Windows. Apparently, reformatting as "ExFat" with the Mac will not give you this capability.ACCESSORIESA power cord and the USB connection. As this is a desktop version, you have to have it plugged in to use it, and you cannot run it off of the USB connection alone.SUMMARYAll in all, it is a great product, and just what I have come to expect from Seagate. I think the designers could have done a little more with the outside (why do my other Seagate drives from the past look so much better?), but it is a backup drive after all, so as long as it does what it is supposed to do, I can't complain!

I purchased the Apple MacBook Air MD224LL/A 11.6-Inch Laptop (NEWEST VERSION) to replace my 2011 Macbook Pro 13". I am a lecturer / graduate student, and this is now my main computer.BUILD QUALITYIt is surprisingly sturdy. Although I plan to purchase a clear case for it (probably from iPearl), I think you could probably get away with using nothing at all. This ruggedness is an amazing feat, considering its light weight. Owners of previous Macbook Airs will enjoy more of the same.DISPLAYThe Macbook Air has a beautiful display that is quite bright, crisp, and clear. The automatic dimmer function adjusts the brightness level according to the ambient light, and I have found that this works really well. Personally, I think the colors on the Macbook Pro 13" display "popped" a little bit more, and I liked the bezel-less solid piece of glass on it better. However, there is no denying that the resolution on this machine is far superior. I have seen the resolutions on some of the other ultrabooks (Windows), and I think this looks better (the ppi is actually about the same). [EDIT:] The soon-to-be-released Zenbook and others are supposed to have better displays this year, though, so this may change in the future.KEYBOARDIt is full-sized and typing on it feels good. The backlit keys are great. The keys don't travel enough for my taste, and it feels a little less solid than the Macbook Pro, but this is a minor complaint. I write for a living, and I am looking forward to writing on this!TRACKPADThe glass trackpad probably does not get much mention in most reviews, but it is one of the best features of a Macbook, and it sets Apple computers apart from competitors. I retired my mouse a long time ago because of it. If you take the time to master the gestures (see your preferences), and you give full-screen views on applications a try, you can enjoy an incredible experience on this machine. The slightest touch whisks you from screen to screen.BATTERYFar too short. Really, 5 hours is not very much, and it looks like I am only getting about that much with regular use on half brightness [EDITED: after testing a couple of times -- just short of five hours]. I wish they could have bumped this up an hour or two more, and I will miss the long life on my Macbook Pro. I guess battery life is one of the trade-offs for this form factor.SPEEDIt is lightning fast. To be honest, I cannot tell a difference yet between it and last year's model. They tell me it is faster, though, so I guess I will have to believe them. Perhaps a few months of usage will give me more perspective. At any rate, it is noticeably faster than the Macbook Pro.ACCESSORIES / STUFF / PORTSThe cord is a good length, and the power brick is quite small. It is somewhere between the size of my iPad power brick and the Macbook Pro power brick. From what I can tell, it looks considerably smaller than the 13" Macbook Air one. I am thinking that I might not mind carrying it around in my man bag with the Macbook Air. The ports on the machine are very conveniently placed, with one USB port on each side. This is so much better than the Macbook Pro, which had all of the ports on the left, where they would inevitably cause problems. Fat thumb-drives sometimes took up so much space I couldn't get another USB cable into the slot next to it. There is no Ethernet port. No Firewire port either. Be forewarned. It doesn't matter to me, but it might to you.COMPARISONS- 64GBI purchased the 128GB model. With judicious use of cloud services like Google Drive and Dropbox, and perhaps the purchase of a 32GB thumb drive to carry around files in case you are not connected, I think 64GB is also doable. One of the great things about this year's 64GB model is that you get the same 4GB of RAM. I consider that model to be the best value, and I would have gotten it if I didn't have a large number of files in one application that, because of the application's design, I cannot put on the cloud.- 13" Macbook AirThe base model 13" Macbook air is a better buy if you want the extra battery life and screen size. I value portability over those things (I can carry this in a small man bag, but if I got the 13" I would have to move up to a mail bag or backback).- 13" Macbook ProThe Macbook Pro 13" was an OK computer last year, and before the Macbook Air's Sandy Bridge refresh, was definitely the best entry-level product. However, they did not update the resolution this year, it is rather pokey compared to the Macbook Air, and it is much heavier. Unless you just simply refuse to use the cloud and have an obscene amount of files to carry around every day, I see no point in getting it.- UltrabooksAs for Windows ultrabooks, I might actually consider them if there was a significant price difference, but most that I have seen are just about the same price as the Macbook Air. They also have inferior build quality (in my opinion) and no support (all of the good stuff you have heard about Apple's phenomenal support is true). I am excited about Windows 8 (sorry Apple fanboys!) and I like where ultrabooks are headed. [EDIT:] It looks like the soon-to-be-released Zenbook will likely be better in terms of specs and price, so if you are wavering between Apple and Windows, you may want to wait a bit longer.- Upgrade from 2011 modelI don't think I would do it if I had the 128GB / 4GB RAM version. The form factor is pretty much the same, and so is the speed. There are some minor improvements like USB 3.0, but otherwise, it probably isn't worth it. If you have the 64GB /2GB RAM version from last year, you could probably benefit from the extra RAM.SUMMARYBecause of the high resolution display, and the ability to view applications in full-screen mode, I think this computer is portability perfected. It could definitely serve as your main machine, and I think many people will find that it is a better experience than the Pro models from just a year before. If you are a student, this is probably one of the best computers available on the market, and I highly recommend it.

The iHome 2-In-1 Pen Stylus is a thin, well-designed stylus that feels like an adult's pen instead of a child's crayon. I like the thin body of the pen, the smaller size of the nub, and I think it is a great idea to have a ballpoint pen built into it as well. There are still moments when I need a pen (usually lending it to friends and colleagues who are stuck in the middle ages with dead tree paper and no writing implements). What I don't like is the metal (the ring between the nub and the pen body) so close to the screen -- just like the Targus and Griffin styluses (styli).By the way, this stylus works great with the iPad 3.

The Speck Products See Thru Satin Case replaced a clear plastic case I originally bought with my Macbook Pro last year. That one cost about the same amount of money, but had a cheap feel to it and the rubber feet on the bottom eventually came loose, leaving a sticky gummy residue behind as they moved about on the bottom of the case. Although I have only had this for a couple of weeks, and cannot know how it will look this time next year, I have a good feeling about it. The feet are firmly seated, the case material feels more durable, and it looks good as well. I cannot think of anything wrong with this, and highly recommend it.

The Lexar JumpDrive Triton 32 GB USB 3.0 Flash Drive LJDNV32GCRBNA packs a lot of storage into a small package. The outer shell seems sturdy, and with the retractable connector, it is easily one of the smallest jump drives I've ever used.I only have one minor complaint. It is a little bit fat, so that it gets int the way of other devices plugged into my Macbook Pro. As anyone who owns an MBP knows, the USB ports are squeezed close together on the left side. Perhaps I ought to blame Apple for this. Fortunately, it still works, even if it doesn't fit in well.

The Targus Slim Case for the new iPad (3rd Generation) is an excellent case for the new iPad, and in some ways superior to the smart cover + hard case (Belkin) solution I used for the iPad 2. This is a very well-built item, and it looks to me like they have thought of almost everything, but there are some problems.PROS- The magnets wake it up and put it to sleep. It appears that there may have been a problem with this before (see other reviews), but at least with the item I received, it worked flawlessly if you are carrying it around in your hands. If you put it into a bag, that is another matter (see below).- All of the openings (for volume and so forth) line up perfectly.- The surface provides a nice grip and the stitching is high quality.- The back case is lined with a felt-like material that protects the back of the iPad. I am not sure how necessary this is, because my Belkin hard case never caused any damage, but it looks nice! The plastic seems like it is higher quality than the Belkin one, and more likely to last without cracking.- The front cover is a little bit thicker and sturdier than the smart cover, so it actually might provide a little bit of real protection. It also seems less prone to causing those annoying dust lines, so you only get one instead of three.CONS- My one complaint is that the stylus holder (also doubles as a catch for the cover so that you can lay the iPad down on a table at an angle) is invonveniently located so that the case does not lay flat. It is surprisingly problematic when using the case (for example) with the Incase Origami Workstation. And, if you put a stylus into it (as you are supposed to), then it becomes unusable with the workstation. I really wish they would have found a way to make the back flat, because as much as I love pretty much everything about this case (these are difficult to design well), and I also happen to like the Targus stylus, this is a vexing problem.- If you carry it around in a bag, even if it is the only item in there, the cover will move and your iPad will wake up. No matter how gently I moved, I could not keep the iPad asleep. So, I have reduced the number of stars from four to three and added this criticism here. It is really too bad, because this is a really nice case otherwise.SUMMARYI highly recommend this case for someone who does not need to lay it down flat on any surface or carry it around in a bag, because this is a really high quality case that offers stylish, lightweight protection. However, if you plan to use it with the Incase Origami Workstation, or flat on a table top, you might want to be aware of its limitations. It is certainly not unusable (at least, without the stylus in the holder), but it may not be ideal.

The Mueller Max Knee Strap, Black, One Size doesn't look like much, but I was pleasantly surprised to find that it works really well. I have an old sports injury that occasionally causes problems, and I have a couple of other knee supporters, but I haven't been happy with them. The neoprene sleeve ones are OK, but make my knee really hot, and they don't provide much support. I have another one with a hard piece on the side and two straps, but it is bulky and cuts off circulation if I sit for long periods of time.I had low expectations for the Mueller strap, but as soon as I put it on I felt better, and I didn't even notice that I had it on all day. This is an amazingly simple looking product that performs better than any other knee support I've used before.

This is a budget friendly diamond bracelet.  It seems fairly well made but I am worried that it could break fairly easily. The tiny links look so delicate. I think though for a bracelet under $100.00 that these diamonds are really beautiful.  I think if I was gifted this by my husband I would be very pleased.  The diamonds seem legitimately good quality (as specified) and it really is a gorgeous bracelet. I just wish it seemed more sturdy.

I am reviewing the Lenox Grinch's Sounding the Horn ornament.  Lenox is the name in quality heirloom, china and knick knacks of all sorts.  When I was growing up it was such a big deal for someone to have something "Lenox".  I am reminded why they have this reputation when I look at this Grinch ornament.  The cartoon grinch is beautifully rendered alongside his faithful dog Max.  Every little detail from the faces to the 'antlers' on Max's head are just perfection.  I am so impressed with this ornament.  This would make a perfect gift for someone who loves "The Grinch Who Stole Christmas" or get it for your own tree.

I really enjoyed this author's The Testing trilogy.  When I heard the synopsis for Need, I was definitely interested in it.  A social website that pitted people against each other to have their wants fulfilled?  Sounds good.  The book was good.  It just wasn't great.  I think for me that was because of the book's 'reveal'...or rather the explanation of why the site was being run and how the site seemed to know everything about the kids from this one high school.  It was just a very flimsy explanation.  I did like all the different view points, although I agree wholeheartedly with other reviewers who say that some of the many characters aren't very fleshed out.  Well, that is necessary because there are so many of them.  But they work for this kind of story.  The plot is there, the characters are there, and the eerie writing style is there.  This story is pretty dark.  I just wished it hadn't unraveled at the end.

This filter is among a few I have in my household. Being given this is larger than my others, which are counter top /dresser top models, i keep this in my living room which is approximately 150 square feet. The various fan speeds and settings built into this unit along with the remote are very useful. I have the allergy air filter installed in this unit currently and seems to filter very effectively.I have 2 dogs and 3 cats in my home so it is getting its use. The negative I have about this filter is the replacement filters. The price of them are $100 and as of this review are out of stock. For that price i hope that it lasts awhile. I do like that they offer several types of filters depending on what you're wanting out of the air. This air filter is capable of just sitting on floor or being hung on a wall, which i may end up doing to save on floor space. this also has a spot to add fragrance oils into which I have not taken advantage of yet.

The quality of this speaker is beyond incredible. I love it so much, and it has very nice support for bass. It also can reach a significantly loud volume, while maintaining a very nice support with no feedback.The speaker can be used through Bluetooth, however, it also comes with a red aux wire which allows use without Bluetooth connection. My only issue with this product has to do with this wire. When plugged into the speaker, it makes a quiet buzzing sound. It isn't anything too noticeable, and does not take away much from the experience. When using Bluetooth, the buzzing noise is not present.I highly recommend this speaker to anyone looking for a nice quality speaker with nice bass support. I love it very much and will be using it for quite a while!

Dumplin was one of my most highly anticipated reads for the year.  I couldn't wait to see how Julie Murphy pulled off a realistic story about teenage, fat girl joining a beauty pageant.  Willowdean is a heavy girl who lives with her mom, a former Beauty Queen who runs the local pageant.  She struggles with her relationship with her mom and being a possible disappointment to her.  Willowdean works at a fast food restaurant where she has a summer relationship with a hot boy named Bo who pretty much keeps Willowdean a secret.  When he shows up at her school the next fall, she is miserable.  She decides it will show her confidence and bring her closer to her recently deceased obese aunt Lucy if she does the pageant.  That starts a whole other plot line where she and her best friend break up.  Things get pretty confusing and bleak for Willowdean as she is forced to discover who she really is and what she really wants.I like Willowdean just fine.  I think she had a pretty authentic voice for a 'fat girl'.  Yes, she is kind of judgemental of others.  She is a teenager.  Despite her confidence, she still has many insecurities.  I loved the three other misfits who join up with Willowdean and thought the growing friendship between them the best part of the entire book.  There were a couple of things I didn't care for.  First I just can't buy Bo, the hot guy from the restaurant.  I can't figure out what either of them see in each other.  And I don't know that I can buy the super hot jock guy falling for Willowdean.  I mean, it is a fat girl's dream and I know that many good looking men end up with heavier woman later in life  (I have one I call Husband) but in high school?  Does that happen?  Also, the boy that she dated to distract her from Bo seemed more genuine and kind than Bo did.  I feel like that would have been more realistic (and he was still a jock) and more fulfilling had that been the case.  I am also one of the readers who felt like the pageant didnt' get enough focus in the book.  It really did feel like it was tacked on at the end.

My husband loves this watch.  It is very large but looks great on him.  Our watch DOES seem like a very different one than the one pictured however.  Looks like a bunch of reviewers received a watch other than what was pictures.  Ours has a metal bank and a large crystal face.  We are happy with the watch by Invicta which was received in error but I'm sure many were disappointed that they got something other than they expected. I will add that the watch we received was not a Diver watch.  Still Invicta should be recommended for quality style watches.  Time will tell on how well they hold up.

3 1/2 stars...I loved the plot of this book and I loved the author's writing.  Erin Bowman is a talented writer for sure.  The book is about a teenage girl who lives out on the west and comes home to find her father murdered and hanging from a tree.  She immediately embarks on a quest to find the killers, a pack of bandits called the Rose Riders.  There is more than she bargained for when she learns her father has long since kept secrets from her.The book had a twist at the end which I never saw coming so it deserves a bonus for that.  I read so much YA fiction that I can usually call a twist a mile away.  My only real problem with the book was the love interest.  He was damaged goods for sure and I am not really sure that he ever  was good enough for Kate.  I wanted to like him but he was a character with deep tragedies scarring him and deep prejudices that he needed to overcome.  I didn't really feel like he overcame those.Still this historical or 'western' genre is certainly one I'd like to see more of in YA.  This is unique and fast paced book.

We have three cats who let us live with them.  We don't normally feed our cats wet cat food and when we do we use it as a treat.  We normally feed them Friskies cat food, which all three cats enjoy regardless of the flavor.  The Nutro is supposed to be healthier and appears to be based on the ingredients. Two of our cats thoroughly enjoy  the Nutro, however, our older cat, for some reason, does not.  He literally runs away from it.  He prefers his dry food or the Friskies wet food.  One side effect that we noticed is that it gives our cats a horribly smelling poo. (Not that it ever smells good, but this is really BAD).  This is a nice 24 pack of Salmon & Tuna, Salmon & Duck, and Chicken.  We truly do think this a valuable product and worth a try with your kitties.

This was the perfect toy/blanket for the baby in our family.  She loves laying on it and trying to grab at the different animals.  The colors are charming, the animals are delightful.  The sounds it makes pique baby's curiosity.  I love the crinkly sound of the blanket and that it remains soft and cuddly for baby fingers.  It is also small and lightweight so it is easy to carry around on the fly, especially on car trips.  Our particular baby isn't old enough for the teethers quite yet, so I think this blanket/toy will have some good longevity for us.

I am not familiar at all with the original tale of the Arabian Nights that this story is based off of so I can't give any compare an contrast there.  However I did like "The Wrath and The Dawn" enough to read the sequel.  Its the story of the 'evil' caliph who takes a new bride each day and then kills them at dawn.  Shazi has volunteered to be his bride because her friend was recently one of Khalid's victims. She wants explanations and revenge.The plot was pretty easy to figure out early on.  Khalid isn't really evil and the two have mad attraction between them.  Khalid, being our narrator is the 'special' wife of Khalid's hundreds who he actually falls for.  So basically readers keep reading to find out why Khalid is killing these woman and if the two in fact get together.  Now there was a ton of external drama happening throughout the book to add conflict.  There is Khalid's childhood boyfriend and his best friend trying to save her life.  Her own father is a shady character who is most certain up to no good.  But the sections with these characters slowed the book down and they were by far the least interesting aspects of the book.I wish there was more actual danger and conflict from inside Khalid's home/manor/whatever it is called here.  I liked these supporting characters much better.  They include Khalid's best frenemy and Shazi's servant girl.  And the scenes actually featuring both Shazi and Khalid were too few and far between.  I loved their chemistry!The author has done a great job with this novel and as I said, I look forward to a sequel. Some of the plot threads could have been tightened up but there was well done tension and intrigue to keep me flying through the pages.

This book should be mandatory reading for every middle school or high school student.  "Life Unaware" is not a perfect book, but it is close to being so.  Let me back up for a moment.  "Life Unaware" is about bullying...both the bullied and the bullies.  Regan Flay is a mean girl.  She is one of the most popular girls in school.  Her mom is a politician who holds Regan to the highest standards.  Regan will do anything to stay on top of the school food chain.The first few chapters really let us know how cruel Regan is and that she doesn't much think about the consequences of her hurtful words and actions. Readers will likely hate Regan at this point.  However, I bet more than a few teenage readers will see something of themselves in her as well.  Then Regan's world is flipped upside down.  Her private text messages and emails have been leaked.  They are all over the school.  Everyone knows exactly what Regan has said about them.  Her friends turn on her as well.  Everyone looks down on her.  Now Regan is the one being bullied.The is a very hard-core and realistic novel.  It doesn't sugar-coat the hurt that bullying causes.  It deals with suicide, anxiety and depression. Yet, there is such a sense of hope and redemption.  We have a different Regan, a REAL Regan by the end of the story.  And I am so happy to say that the change in her attitude feels like a natural consequence to her actions.  It doesn't feel convenient for the sake of the novel.  There are some bad words in the book and some references to sex.  All of those things are done to capture the realistic feel of the high school environment.Now for one little complaint which still can't make me detract stars:  When Regan is shunned at school and bullied relentlessly she almost immediately has Nolan at her side.  Nolan is another 'freak' at school, but he defends her and is there for her.  Many kids being bullied do not have anyone on their side.  They don't have a "Nolan" to support them or pull their attention away during confrontations.  While Nolan is ultimately necessary for this novel to succeed in telling this particular story, all I could think about is a bullied teen reading this novel and feeling like they have no one for them.  Regan is never truly alone in this book.Still "Life Unaware" is the best story I have read that deals with bullying.  Not to sound trite, but it would be a great movie and I think that would be a great way to get this important story to the non-readers out there.  I will look for more to come from Cole Gibsen.  I am very impressed.

I wasn't overly impressed at the beginning of "You and Me and Him".  I thought it was trying to hard to be another "Eleanor and Park" mixed with some of the gay-centered themes taken from a lot of popular contemporary YA novels that are so in right now. I thought the 'dibs' thing might be shallow and I really worried that Maggie's weight problems would magically be fixed by the end of the book.Then somewhere in the middle of the book I found myself completely absorbed into the story and really connected with the teenage characters.  I'm an adult and my high school days are behind me, however, this book manages to authentical capture exactly what it feels to be a teenager facing challenges in high school.  The basic idea of the story is that overweight Maggie and her BFF Nash fall for the same new guy the minute they see him on the bus.  Nash calls 'dibs' which means he gets to pursue and/or crush over the new guy and it's Maggie's job to support that in any way she can as his friend.  However the new guy Tom seems to have other plans.  However, Tom is such a flirt that everyone thinks Tom could be interested in them.The story truly ends up being about two things: Friendship and forgiveness.  Maggie needs to both forgive and be forgiven. I will say that I really enjoyed Maggie as a character.  She makes some honest mistakes but never means to hurt anyone especially Nash.  There is a scene between Maggie and her PE Teacher that made me so angry.  And I know that there are indeed people just like this teacher in real life.  I also appreciated that Tom isn't all of what he seems to be and neither are some of the other characters.  Teenagers will likely see themselves in the main characters and while the book gets a little bit heave at times, it remains an entertaining book.  Oh and when I got to the part about geoducks I had to look them up online.  Wow, I may never be the same.  I never knew such a thing existed.

A reader can't possibly love every book they read.  And a book can't possibly be loved by every person who reads it.  I did not love "Charlie, Presumed Dead".  I loved the general plot:  Charlie dies under questionable or at least odd circumstances.  At his funeral his girlfriend meets his other girlfriend.  Together they decide to find out if Charlie really is dead and if not they hope to confront him.Anne Heltzel is a good author.  The story was well-written but not always engaging.  There were many times that the novel stalled which really should not happen since the girls jump from one crazy escapade into another.  I did like both girls and my favorite part of the novel was seeing their friendship develop.  I thought the author did a fantastic job of making sure both girls had distinct voices since they take turns narrating the chapters.  I started the novel not liking Charlie and I ended it the same.  However I did not feel like I learned anything real about Charlie.  He told a lot of lies and kept two girlfriends but we don't ever understand what made him tick.  I could never determine who I could trust in the book and while that should have been a good plot device, ultimately it just became sad and disappointing.  I also did not find it believable that the girls were teenagers, one just finishing high school.  They were running all around poverty stricken countries and their parent's did nothing more than demand they come home.  Weird.  When I was reading the book I felt like they behaved like women in their mid twenties.  It may have helped make this book more believable.But that ending was just not right!  It was the worst kind of cliffhanger where absolutely nothing is resolved and you know that you will need to read another book in a year to find out what happens.  Unfortunately, I am not entertained or invested enough to read a sequel.  Many people loved this book and I can see why.  It just was not a good fit for me.

So I love fairytale retellings and I love everything else I've read by Sarah J Maas so it seemed logical that I would love "A Court of Thorns and Roses".  However, I was bummed when I realized this book was marketed as NA-New Adult which in my personal interpretation means "Lots more sex, less story".  I like some romance in my stories, but I am not big on romance without a big and exciting plot.  So I put off reading this book which prior to realizing its genre, I wanted at the top of my TBR pile.  That is very unfortunate because I loved this book.  I was engrossed from the very beginning when I didn't have any idea of what was going on.The basic story is this:  Feyre and her father and two sisters live in a falling apart cottage after the sister's mother passes away and her father loses their fortune.  The entire town is financially devastated and the family is in real danger of starving to death.  In necessity, Feyre learns to hunt.  But life it very hard.  One day on a hunt in the nearby woods, Feyre kills an unusual wolf.  But the wolf is no ordinary wolf and this act causes serious repercussions. A Fae beast comes to take Feyre away to his castle in exchange for the life of the wolf.Thus begins some of the Beauty and The Beast themes.  Tamlin is the gruff Lord of the Fae whose kingdom is under a spell from an evil enchantress.  Feyre wants to get away from the castle at first but soon grows to love Tamlin.  Instead of a library, he gives her art supplies.  There are many, many other things that reminded me of the Beauty and Beast story in general and even at times of things from the Disney cartoon.  The New Adult aspect does come into play in the book as there is a lot of sexual tensions and eventually sex, although it is not overly explicit in nature.I felt like the possibility of rape or torture always hung as a potential threat over Feyre's head.  Some of the fae seemed ok, but some from other lands were legitimately scary and dangerous.I really did enjoy this book, but parts of it are slow moving.  Yet I would have enjoyed more time in the Castle with Tamlin and Feyre as they were some of the most entertaining parts.  Through the course of the book, Feyre grows.  She realizes the strength she has had all along inside of her.  She confronts her feelings of hurt and betrayal at the hands of her family members.  She sees that there is a world out there worth living to see.  The last quarter of the book is fast paced and thrilling.  Feyre makes shocking choices and will have to live with the fallout from them for the rest of her life.  If this was to be a stand alone novel, readers would be satisfied by the ending.  However, there is more than enough threads left dangling for this to be a series.  I will be glad to read any future books set in this world.

This is a really beautiful and high quality watch.  However I was very surprised by how wide the band was.  It overpowered my thin friend's wrist when she tried it on and emphasized by thicker wrist when I had it on.  It is also as heavy as my husband's watches.  I work at a computer all day and I couldn't possibly wear the heavy watch for day to day use.  The design is beautiful, and the black accent on the gold band is very nice.  Its a no frills analog watch.  A good design feature on this is that the clasp is hidden.  The watch has some definite good and bad features.  I guess that would depend on what a woman wants in her watch.

4.5 Stars.  I'm deducting 1/2 star because I found the book a little confusing at the start when the chapters flipped back between before and after.  This refers to parts of the two sisterâs story that happened before or after a horrible accident leaves Dara disfigured and lame and her older sister Nick dealing with the consequences of causing the accident.  Now Dara wonât talk to Nick and the story is told in the sisterâs alternating perspectives.The before part is standard YA fare.  The sisterâs seem to both be involved with the same boy, Parker.  This causes a wedge between the girls who are already in family crisis after their parentâs divorce and their father falling for a new woman.  Then we get to the After.  The âafterâ story is quite strong, as we try to unravel the mystery of the disappearance of a young local girl as well as start working our way backwards to find out the cause of the accident. The two sisters don't talk to each other much as Dara who was always the popular sister holds Nick responsible for her injuries. But Nick wants to make things right between them again.The story felt like a jumble of disconnected thread but I should have trusted the author all along. The ending comes together in a way that wraps up even the most insignificant thread. And there is a shocking twist that I never saw coming.  It made me go back and reread certain scenes from my new and more informed point of view.  The story is and emotionally charged story where the focus is more on family the many contemporary young adult novels are. Of course there are boys and other commonplace young adult themes but this one digs in deeper than most. One quick warning: teenagers in "vanishing girls" casually drink, do drugs, have sex, and use profanity. Overall this isn't done gratuitously but adds to the realistic feel of the novel.

I really waffled back and forth on what to rate this novel.  The storyline, characters and world make it an easy five star book so I shouldn't have had any question what I would rate it.
