However I found out that this book is currently a stand alone book.  The author is not against creating a sequel and it is up in the air now with the publisher.  This amazing, engrossing, beautiful novel ends on what I would consider a cliffhanger.  Most of the threads in the book were not resolved although the story ends on a hopeful note.  Yet, the idea that this is the end of the story leaves a huge emptiness that will cause me to be very dissatisfied and I don't know if I can recommend a book with no true ending.For the sake of this review, I am going to respond as though there will be at least one other installment to wrap up the storylines presented in "An Ember In The Ashes".Last year fantasy, both adult and YA, made up the majority of my favorite novels.  I couldn't get enough.  However in the past few months all the stories started sounding similar.  I decided maybe I would stop reading newly released fantasy books while I just finished out series I had already started.  I also debated moving on and trying some other genres.  Then I had the opportunity to read "An Ember In The Ashes".  The early reviews all gushed over it.  Movie rights were already sold.  I decided to try it and I procrastinated a little bit getting to it.  However I was hooked almost immediately.  The writing is gorgeous and the world is alive.  It also had a unique world and characters which is all I hoped for.  The story is told from two perspectives.  The first is Laia whose family has been killed and her world destroyed by the martials, the ruling class who have oppressed and used the Scholars.  The martials, including their most elite class of soldier the Masks, are scary as anything out there.  They are trained soldiers whose only loyalty is to their commandant.  They are trained to fight and kill.  Eventually the masks they wear form to their faces and can't be removed. And they have arrested Laia's brother, her only living family member.  Elias is the second narrator.  He is also a Mask.Their worlds intersect when Laia comes to work in the training school where she is a servant to the commandant, who happens to be Elias's very unloving mother.I won't go too much more into the plot because I don't want to give anything away.  It is also a truly complex story and every thought I think to write about in my review leads to ten other thoughts.  This book is violent.  More so than most YA books.  There is a serious threat of life and limb at any moment.  There are a few moments of fun and joy and lightheartedness sprinkled through the book but it is really dark.  Yet that makes the goodness in Laia, Elias, and a few other supporting characters really stand out.  It makes you root for them.  And I for one really want to see a change in the rulers of this world.  Again, this was just a phenomenal, engrossing and unique story and I really have to hope for a sequel.

This keyboard is amazing.  It has so many features I doubt we will ever use them all.  I love the way the keyboard feels.  It is almost an old fashioned feel to the keys, like my old Commodore 64 or older typewriter.  My wife doesn't care as much for the taller keys because she is used to the more flat keyboard.  It has a mechanical feel to it.  It is super quiet which I appreciate.  We aren't huge gamers so we won't use all the board has to offer.  However, for the PC games I play, there was a definite improvement in performance and timing.  We are well satisfied with this keyboard.

I really wanted to like this toy...but the cats don't like it.  Cat 1 wouldn't even approach it after having it lay out for a couple days.  Cat 2 is our more adventurous cat and he approached and batted at it a few times.  Then I swear he yawned and walked away, never to return.  Cat 3 is my sweet boy who also likes to play yet this thing scared the fooey out of him.  He jumped straight up in the air and ran away.  He usually sleeps with us all night, in bed every night and he never came back the rest of the night.  Even now, he walks around this one very carefully.  I can't say what they don't like about it... Just that the mice action wasn't enough to entice them to play.  If I had to guess, I'd say the chirping of the mice was just too much.

We looked all over for a sink for several months to accommodate a new kitchen faucet.  It was horribly difficult to find a one hole sink with a double basin.  I was fully expecting a lower end sink due to the inexpensive price offered here on Amazon.  However I was very pleasantly surprised to have  a high quality sink show up at my door!  We have had this sink installed for a couple months now and it is holding up well with no scratches yet.  I fully anticipate this sink holding up with time.  We love it!

I currently own a Rockwell Sonicrafter X2 and have loved it ever since I bought it. One downfall of any of these types of tools are the blades.  The teeth on the blades wear down quickly or even break off easily.  So far, I have had no problems with the Imperial Blade but it hasn't been run through the full gauntlet of possibilities I encounter in my line of work.  I anticipate that this blade will wear down as would any blade but I have a feeling it is going to wear down less quickly than the other standards.  It easily fit on my tool with no issues and it comes with several adapters for a universal fit with other similar tools.  So far so good!

I loved this book.  You will love this book too if you can just ignore from the start any and all scientific background given to explain how science can determine your deathdate (And I didn't see anywhere in this book that the success rate isn't 100% although it mentions a few people out there with undetermined dates).  Then after you suspend your disbelief on the science of it, you need to suspend your disbelief on the governments involvement in which they mandate that every citizen must be tested.  Good with doing all that?Yes?  Ok, read this book.Denton has known since he was five years old that he would die when he was seventeen years old.  Anyone who is sch eduled to die when they are under eighteen is known as an 'early'.  When he is in elementary school he meets Paolo, who becomes his lifelong best friend when they bond over the fact that they are both earlies.  In fact, Paolo will die a month after Denton.  As the book opens Denton is waking up on the day of his Funeral.  In this world, its a huge celebration of life where the deceased isn't actually deceased yet.  In fact, Denton gives his own Eulogy.  But even as the clock on Denton's life is winding down, he still has a heck of a lot of living to do.  For starters, he awoke this morning in Paolo's sister Veronica's bed.  Did they DO it?  Also, did his girlfriend Taryn break up with him last night?  Can he get his dad to tell him more about his deceased mother before he dies?  Why has his mother's life always been such a secret?  Who is this policeman that keeps stalking Denton?  What is this growing purple bruise on his leg?  Is this going to be his cause of death?  Or is he going to die at the hands of the school bully?I can't even believe how many times I laughed out loud while reading this book. But Denton's voice as a teenage facing his death just felt so natural and realistic. Yes, there are some unbelievable threads in the story but when you put those beside charming and relateable characters, suspension of belief becomes much easier.All of that said, I felt like this book ended with many unresolved plot points and I haven't seen where there is a sequel planned but there really needs to be one.  I will definitely pre-order a book with more Denton and company.

I really enjoyed "The Witch Hunter".  It was similar to a lot of current YA fantasy novels, yet different enough to make it stand out.  Elizabeth is a witch hunter along with her best friend Caleb.  The world forbids magic and magic users (witches) are burned at the stake or beheaded.  Even being caught with herbs used by witches can be cause for immediate incarceration and ultimately death.  Elizabeth truly believes, although her job is an ugly one, that it is the right path that she is on.  She is just upholding the law after all.  But then Elizabeth herself is caught with witches herbs and is jailed.  Even though she is one of the greatest Witch Hunters the world has ever seen, her pleas are met on deaf ears.  She is rescued by Nicholas, the greatest sorcerer the world has ever seen and the world's most wanted man.  Surely they are evil and want her for some nefarious purpose, right?From this point of the novel on, Elizabeth must face the truth about her mentors and her witch hunting.  Who truly is evil?  Is magic all bad?  Is everything Elizabeth ever known to be true just an elaborate lie?I loved this world and I loved the side characters in this book tremendously.  There is a little, sweet romantic side plot between Elizabeth and one of Nicholas's men, a healer.  Its not intense, and the book is not a romance novel.  But it is a nice addition and I like that John doesn't fit the normal mold of most YA leading men.  He is shy and a healer.  He is kind of geeky and that makes him adorable and somewhat unique.  I also really, really like Fifer.  She could star in her own book, seriously.  There are so many layers to her that are intriguing.  George is another fun side character.  This group is so unusual and gripping.  The specifics to the magical abilities are also fun and entertaining.I wouldn't say there is anything groundbreaking or shocking about "The Witch Hunter" but it a well written, fast paced and entertaining book.  This author is one to watch for sure.  I have been in a pretty big dry spell especially regarding fantasy novels, but this one still had the ability to stand out and entertain me.  I will eagerly be on the lookout for a sequel.

I have wanted a Dyson for ten years; ever since I bought my home.  We are also a pet friendly home that has two dogs (one a super hairy golden retriever) and three cats.  I won't even deny it:  We have to buy a new vacuum every single year. Why?  All that darn pet hair!  It will kill a regular vacuum unbelievably fast.  This Dyson has made my year!  I have been able to get rid of my current funky half working vacuum.  I have been able to get rid of the car vacuum because this Dyson does a beautiful job with our car upholstery as well.  I was told Dyson's have suction like no other and I want to assure you that is true.  You have to see this to believe it. It is also not only bagless, but filterless!  Which means it is truly a clean vacuum.  There is nothing worse than vacuuming your carpets, and then realizing how gross and disgusting your actual  vacuum has become in the process.  Or even worse, having to dump out the full bag.  You get all those dust flybacks no matter how careful you try to be.  Ever since I was a young girl, first taking on chores, I hated having to wind up the cord. This wonder eliminates that too.  You click a button and the cord folds up by itself.  The true star of this particular machine is that Tangle Free Turbine tool for pet hair/dander.  Holy cow, this price is worth this little tool alone.  Nothing has controlled the pet hair in my house like this tool.  I am 100% satisfied with this vacuum.  Dyson loyal from here out.

As a fan of fairy tales and their retellings, I was very excited to read the newest re-telling of Sleeping Beauty, âA Wicked Thingâ.  Within the first chapter, Aurora awakes to her âtrue loveâsâ kiss.  But realistically she is very confused and freaked out by this strange young man kissing her awake.  When she finds out she has slept for a hundred years, she is heartbroken.  Her family has long since passed away but Aurora remembers the night she fell under the curse like it was just yesterday.  And she herself remains un-aged.  The prince and his family, the new King and Queen just expect her to wake right up and adjust to her new life.  She is going to marry her prince right away and they canât wait to announce it to the Kingdom.  But Aurora is grieving and not one person takes time to look at her and acknowledge that.  It is quite evident right away that everyone wants to use Aurora for their own gain.  After all she is the famous sleeping princess of legends and she will raise magic in the kingdom again.  But Aurora doesnât hold magic, right?  And she canât magically make the kingdom love the new King or make their lives any better.The opening is fantastic.  The middle drags a bit and I became weary of the story.  Aurora seems like a doormat for quite some time, just going along with whatever anyone says to do and questioning very little.  I can excuse quite a lot of this because she truly is shocked and in mourning without one person who really cares about her.  I did really like that there were three potential love interests for Aurora but she ended the book without a single one being an actual romantic interest (at least as of the end of this story).  The middle really did meander along.  But then the end became quite exciting again and was actually what the book should have been like all along.  Aurora is a good person and yet everything feels stacked against her.  She finally gets up the nerve to take matters into her own hands and force a change and it is great.  I am on board for the sequel for sure however I feel like this book could have been stronger than it was.

The Winner's Curse was my favorite book released in 2014.  This is early so far in 2015 but "Winner's Crime" has a fair shot of holding that title this year.  The world Kestrel finds herself in starting this novel is very dangerous.  She has jumped from the frying pan into the fire with her alliance made at the end of book one...the alliance she made to help Arin.  Reading this book is like watching a chess match with bated breath.  There are so many moves being made by players in the story and it is hard to know who to trust.  This one is stressful.  I took my time reading it because I loved it, but also I just knew bad things were happening and I couldn't stop them.  That says a lot actually, for a book to impact its reader so strongly.  But I Iove Kestrel and Arin.  Unfortunately there is not a ton of time showing the two of them together.  While necessary for the plot, it was disappointing because those few scenes are amazing.  There is so much tension, passion, and love between them.  Talk about forbidden love and insurmountably high obstacles. Romeo and Juliet had nothing on this couple.  This book is packed with so much drama and intrigue that I don't want to give anything away.  Just read it...read the first one first, of course. But read it and enjoy one of the best fantasy series around.

This is a cute, fun, Playhouse Castle.  It is made out of cardboard so it comes with all the expected drawbacks of that.  Don't expect something that will last for a super long time, because this is just like letting your kids play with a giant box your hot water heater or your refrigerator came in. (if it was pure white and they could decorate it).  When unpackaging in, we almost threw it out right then and there because there were no directions and the creases from packing were different than the corners of the castle and I got a paper cut.  We then referred to the picture on Amazon and was able to put it up by using that as a guideline.  The doors are perforated not only down the middle but all the way around and they have already fallen off.Now all of that said, the three and four years old have fallen madly in love with this castle  They have played in it for hours now.  They love the window cutouts and the castle shape. Once they seemed to tire of just the white cardboard castle, we introduced the paint and decorating aspects and that was a blast.  It took well over an hour for two kids to decorate the castle.This really is a fun toy/activity.  Just be aware that you are spending money for what is literally is a cardboard cutout.  In my opinion it has a lot of entertainment value and memory making time spent with this toy.

I was in a reading slump.  I needed something different and what is more different that a cult?  The book is told from the point of view of 17 year old Jacob ...or Brother Jacob.  He was very young when his parents left their successful lives in the 'real' world and relocated to the Nodd religious compound.  The Grace cult believes in keeping away from the outside world to keep out the sin and temptation that runs rampant there.  They believe their way is the only way to Heaven and that their little compound is another Eden.  Father Grace (naturally) has multiple wives and when he takes a very young member as his newest wife, things begin to crumble for Jacob and all of Nodd.Jacob had planned to take Father Grace's newest wife as his own. Then he meets a young cowgirl who lives on the ranch next door.  Secretly they begin to visit and talk with each other.  Around this time some new members arrive from the outside.  The young boy with them also begins to change how Jacob sees the only world he has ever known.  I don't want to give much away, but the book is obviously about Jacob's life in Nodd and how he learns to open his eyes and see the downside (and downfall) of the lifestyle he has always known.I really did enjoy this book.  It was a quick, fascinating read.  The only negative is that I knew all along how things would end and there wasn't a lot of surprises along the way.

I love this little wonder!  I am at the point of doing anything I need to do to remove clutter from my precious, small desktop.  This cup hooks right onto my fabric cubic wall. As soon as I hooked it on the wall, I tossed out my old pencil cup.  Good riddance!  This is a very sturdy cup for the inexpensive price.  It holds tons of pens and highlighters.  Highly recommended.

I've always liked this lotion because it spreads quickly and smoothly over the skin, and because it absorbs quickly without leaving a greasy feel.It also imparts a pretty, moist-looking glow on the skin. Also great is the scent, which is very light, fresh, and clean. The scent does not linger, and does not smell like perfume in any way, so it can be used by both men and women.The ingredients of 15% Shea Butter, glycerin, sunflower seed oil, sweet almond fruit extract are especially soothing to the skin.  NOTE: the cream does contain alcohol, and other less-pronouncable ingredients.All in all, I think this is a light-yet-rich lotion that both you and your "significant-other" will enjoy using.

For some reason, I couldn't find an egg timer like this in any local store. All they had was the wind-up kitchen variety.I wanted one of these to use for timing yoga poses. Just flip it over (no stopping to wind up) and I have either a minute and a half, or three minutes.It does the job, it's cute and old-fashioned looking, and sturdy.

First, the things about this bracelet that merit four-stars:--Easy to remove links. I used a paper clip, no special tool.--High shine that mimics silver.--Durability. No scratches or "dings" despite almost-daily wear.--Decent price for a charm-bracelet of this type.But I had to rate it four-stars rather than five, because:--The importance of the Medical ID is what made me purchase the bracelet in the first place.--The Medical ID is so tiny as to be almost unreadable.--The pink breast cancer and medical symbols are also very tiny.--Therefore, the bracelet might be mistaken (by medical personnel) as JUST an ordinary bracelet.Still, it is a good personal reminder to protect your left arm when you go to doctor's appointments, etc. I'd say combine it with a more prominent medical ID bracelet for extra security.

This large, bright, plaid tablecloth is the perfect color for your holiday table. But you don't have to wait until the holidays to use it! (The plaid, btw, is red and green, but also contains ivory.)Example: Pizza party for eight people. We set the table with Crate & Barrel white plates, wine glasses, and 8 oz. frosted tumblers, and the look was "touch-of-Italy". (Of course, we needed to add the party size pizza :>)After laundering, the tablecloth did require touch up with a low iron, but the wrinkles came out easily (I washed it alone, on a delicate cycle, cold water).At holiday time, the addition of different glassware and plates will transform the look to "touch-of-Christmas".Also, the price is reasonable, considering that with a little imagination, you'll be able to use it on many occasions.

This thick, rich cream is made with a combination of ingredients, including the Immortelle flower from Corsica. L'Occitane tells us that the flower has "exceptional longevity" and "never fades, even after it has been picked."Their use of the flower (and other ingredients including daisy flower extract, sunflower extract, honey, etc.) produces a cream which is velvety in feel, delightfully fresh in scent, and works wonders on mature, dry skin.(I will add here that the cream also contains some harder-to-pronounce ingredients such as sodium benzoate, zinc gluconate, etc.)The cream absorbs quickly, and does not leave a greasy feel, but it does leave a dewy moisturized look to the skin. In addition to the dewy look it imparts, it beautifully smooths out fine lines and adds firmness.Pricey? Oh, yes. But a little goes a long way. The pretty glass jar comes with a little spoon, and the tip-of-your-pinky amount it holds will cover your whole face.This is definitely a luxury item, but one that performs well, and is worth saving-your-pennines to purchase.

I adore this cleanser. Yes, it's expensive, but with one use, I saw (under a magnifying mirror), a brighter look to my skin.In addition, my skin felt perfectly clean, and all traces of the BB cream, blush, and concealer I wore that day were gone. Also, the scent is mild and clean.The only "complaint" I have about the product is that it does not completely remove mascara (and mine is not waterproof). So here's what I do: swipe with a bit of eye-makeup remover, and then use the Cleansing Foam as directed.If you can afford this product, I think you'll fall in love with it.

Actually, Keaton's "Let's Just Say It Wasn't Pretty" is a combination of beauty musings, and selected parts of her life story. The life-snippets that she writes about relate to beauty topics, but mostly in a way that reveal her personal insecurities regarding her looks. (By this I mean, she doesn't tell you which anti-aging creams to use, etc.)Keaton writes that insecurity about her looks began early, and continue to the present day. She tells us that she was always uncomfortable with (most) aspects of her looks (and even her personality/speech patterns), and admits that hasn't changed much.She also shares the fact that she is uncomfortable about her insecurity, and realizes that it borders on obsession. For example, in the chapter called "BAD HAIR DAYS", she writes: "Diane, you're not allowed to wear the hat today, and here's why: at this point in your highly privileged life, your hair doesn't matter to anyone but you."However in earlier (and later) chapters of the book, Keaton has some insightful (and even poetic) takes on what makes real beauty in truly authentic women and men. The chapter "PRISONERS ON MY WALL" is a good example of this, as is the chapter called "THE EYES HAVE IT."Though she rambles a bit throughout the book, I found myself enjoying her stream-of-consciousness style, and even agreeing with some of the tidbits about personal growth, and aging.Four stars instead of five, because some readers might prefer a book that is more straight-on beauty book OR autobiography. As for me, I enjoyed the combination of the two genres.

I've tried lots of 5 blade razors. Some gave a smooth shave, some didn't. The ones that didn't had moisture strips that prevented the razor from giving a close shave.While the Schick Hydro Silk Sensitive Care has moisturizing serum (delivered on little dots on each side of the razor), the blades themselves are "curve sensing" and somehow deliver the close shave everyone everyone wants.After shaving, legs are noticeably smooth and yes, silky.The handle of the razor is comfortable to use, and has a rubbery texture, which is better than any hard-plastic types I've tried, because it is less likely to slip in your hand. It's the right size as well, and easy to grip.Great little razor that comes with one handle and 2 cartridges. Recommended.

Have a new little fur-baby in your home? Well, we don't,  but  as "veteran" cat owners, I can tell you, this potty starter kit is a great, state of the art way to help your cat of any age (and yourself) to a cleaner, better-smelling, NEATER "potty" experience. We wanted to try it, especially, because we travel, and wanted to have an "extra", and longer-lasting box in the house as a stand by for when we are away for a couple of days. (We just set it up next to the regular litter box.)Though not inexpensive, the kit is complete, and even comes with instructions for BEYOND THE BOX--as in: how to help train your new kitten/cat to use the box and avoid accidents (clear, helpful instructions for humans include how to avoid over-reacting to any accidents that may occur--and how to switch to this type of litter--just great!)But back to the kit, which includes: a small-ish sized (kitten size for sure) plastic litter box, with a removable strainer-tray, plus a pooper-scooper (These are all all in heavy-duty washable plastic).Also included are 2 deodorizing litter pads, which fold up, for easy disposal, plus a bag of small pellets, which substitute for the usual clay-type litter. (These are also deodorizing.) Both of these items are sold separately from the kit and box as refills, but come with your first kit.Everything in the kit is a little different from what you may be used to seeing/using for a litter box. For example, the litter pellets resemble something you might think belong in a gerbil cage! BUT, here's the good news: they cover P&P (pee & poop) completely, and with virtually NO odor.We found the easiest way to help old Tom adjust was to follow the kit directions, which said to spread some of our old, regular litter on top of the new pellets. Puddy didn't even seem to notice the pellets below, and within half a day, was using the box as usual.Supposedly, you can leave the box alone for a WEEK without changing the litter pellets, but we didn't go there, since our cat is older. Two days, and we changed the contents. I'm pretty sure a longer time would work for a kitten, but if you are switching to this type of litter for a mature cat, I'd still change the pads/pellets more often.All in all, this is a neat, compact, little "system" that will keep your cat's potty area fresh, and better-smelling-than-usual.Four stars instead of five, simply because of the higher cost, and also because you will have to order the refill pads and pellets instead of just picking them up at retail.

This Jouer Mineral Powder Blush comes in different colors, but the one I am reviewing here is "Blossom."  This particular color is a soft, peachy-pink "goes-with-everything" shade. (Think of it as a sort of coral, leaning just a touch more toward peach.)It also does contain the tiniest amount of sparkle, but it is not in any way "glittery". (Glitter isn't something I want on my 60+ skin.) It applies smoothly and evenly. (Note: it doesn't come with a brush, so use a nice, big fluffy blush-brush of your own for best results.) The color also stays true throughout the day, and doesn't morph into something different than what you first applied.The narrow compact opens easily, and has a mirror which, despite its small-ish size, allows a good view of the entire face. (The compact can also be attached to other Jouer products, via a "snap-together" system.)Despite all the things I liked about this blush, I'm rating four stars instead of five, because a couple of the ingredients might not be what every consumer wants. Those ingredients are: Talc (1st ingredient--some women just don't like talc in any face product), and Mica (2nd ingredient--some women might not want ANY sparkle at all, not even a tiny amount).But if talc and mica are okay with you, I think you'll be pleased with this blush.

As a person with "mature" skin that is somewhat on the dry side, I found the jouer anti-aging moisture primer lacking in the moisture department.First I applied an spf 15 for sensitive skin (Olay), and then I applied the primer as directed, except I used a bit more than the recommended "pearl-size" amount since that wasn't enough to completely cover my face. I followed this with a few small dots of foundation which I blended in.I expected that the primer would really make the foundation spread and slip more easily, but it did just a fair job of that, despite the fact that it contains Argan Oil and Shea Butter.I also did not notice (even as the day wore on) any noticeable diminishment of fine lines/wrinkles, nor did I see any evident "lifting".As for improvement in skin texture, there was a slight smoothing of the skin surface, but slight is the key word.Now, having said all this, there ARE some good things about this primer, including what it LACKS, namely: it is free of silicone, parabens, and fragrance.And good things also in what it CONTAINS, namely: Argan oil, shea butter, vitamin E and peptides.Still, overall, I think this is best for women who don't need much moisture on their skin, and for those who don't have many (or any) fine lines and wrinkles.

This coffee has a hearty taste and aroma, which I loved.But...OOPS! I thought you could use it in any Keurig-type coffee maker. NOPE. So I ended up pouring coffee out of the little pods into a ground-coffee ceramic holder, and measuring it out as I would any other ground coffee (approx. 1/2 a scoop per cup). As I said, taste and aroma were delicious.Now, since I don't have the Tossimo machine, I won't purchase more, but I'll certainly enjoy making the rest of my current supply. :>)

Besides the pleasant scent, and the noticeable shine, this product does a good job of subtly toning down yellow/brassy/orange tones.I recently switched from a more golden blonde color to champagne blonde. Even with the cooler tones of champagne, after a few shampoos, I noticed the gradual creeping in of the dreaded brassy areas. I used this a little differently than called for on the directions (more on that in a minute), and the results were: cooler and somewhat darker tones that disguised the brass.Here's how I used it: after shampoo and conditioner were rinsed out (per directions), I applied (approx.) a half-palm-sized amount, and worked in in well from roots to ends (my hair is short). Finished up my shower, and rinsed well.Four stars instead of five simply because some ladies may not like using an extra step like this after shampooing, and they also may not care for the fact that you are supposed to use it 3-5 TIMES AT ONCE. That's a long time in the shower!  Results (as written above) were good enough for me, but I was fine with a subtle improvement. Also, because this is applied and rinsed AFTER conditioner, you may not retain the moisture you like in your hair.

Okay. Here's the facts about me:I'm over sixty, and I still like to experiment with hair color, because I DON'T like white/grey.So, for the past year, I'v been using L'Oreal  91/2B Lightest Natural Blonde (Natural tones). Right after coloring, the result has been good. BUT...2 weeks (or so) after color, I had brassy, yellow/orange/reddish tones. AND...the grey on the sides and along the lower hairline was showing though, big time!  So I resorted to using color more often than the directions advise (which is every 4-6 weeks). This resulted in very dried-out, bleached-out looking strands. With the white/grey still visible.After trying the John Freida Colour Refreshing Gloss here's what  I saw:--Shiny, softer hair--Golden tone renewed--Brassiness reduced (less yellow/orange look)--Worked better than the "purple shampoo" I was using to combat brassiness.--Helped to "blend in" the white/grey at my temples.Overall, good results!Honestly, I think this is a great product for younger women, who use light(er) golden blonde shades, who may want to "rev up" their golden tones. (That part worked for me!)Does what it says, which is: "Adds golden tones".  Also adds shine, and softness.How to use it:: Shampoo, condition, then put a palm-size amount in you hair, finish your shower, and rinse the product out, (The directions say a "quarter-size" amount, but, trust me, fill your palm. and work it in to your strands completely).You'll notice enhanced golden tone, shine, and softness of your hair.As a P.S.--As I said, I"m over sixty, and question my choice of golden tones, so I think I'll soon be trying this product in the "cool blondes" range. Updated review to follow when that happens... most likely in a few days...I'm due!:>)BTW: Came back to edit this review, and explain the 4 strs, instead of 5. That's because, the product says "Salon Fresh Color". Well, yes, sort of. As in, your overall result will be shiny, soft, and "brightened." But the product does NOT (nor is it meant to) completely cover roots or grays. So, 'Salon Fresh" should not be taken literally. Also, though easy to use, it does add an extra step to the shampoo and condition process. Plus, the color does transfer to the skin of your hands, so be sure to wash them thoroughly with soap right after you use the glosser.

In the introduction to this book, author David Acord asks: "Why would anyone want to model his or her life after someone who never existed?"Good question, and here are some possible answers:1) They are fans or admirers of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle.2) They have read and loved every Sherlock short story and novel Doyle wrote.3) They are new to Sherlock literature, but are avid fans of the TV show versions of the Great Detective.OR...4) They realize that Sherlock, though fictional, was, as David Acord puts it: "Genius. Renaissance Man. Iconoclast.Master of Detection."  And they want some of that for themselves.For example, readers may want to know how focusing on the little things, the details, can help them succeed.Or how having fun with their work can help them rise to the top of their field.With this little book, readers can examine and learn from a fictional man who did exactly those things I just mentioned, and more, much more. Also, readers will learn a good deal about Sir Arthur Conan Doyle himself, and they will re-visit some of their favorite Sherlock tales. TV fans will perhaps gain insight into why they've fallen so hard for Sherlock.Here's the best part of this book: all of the "success secrets" it contains are practical, applicable methods that anyone can use to increase their chances of success in their career, or in their life.

For a long time, I've been curious about gummy vitamins. Not because I have trouble swallowing pills, but because they seemed like a FUN way to get the extra nutrients that I usually get in a pill form multivitamin. So I gave these a try.For starters, I'll say that the amount of vitamins and minerals they contain are not as high, nor as complete, as my Centrum Silver.  That's the reason for the 4 stars.However, they taste GREAT, and they are FUN to take. Like chewing 2 pieces of not-too-sweet candy.In order to make up for the less than perfect vitamin/mineral content, I alternate them with my pills. (One day a pill, next day 2 gummies.) And I actually look forward to the "treat" days when I get to use the gummies.For anyone who has trouble swallowing pills, or who is just lax about taking regular multi-vitamins, you might find, as I did, that these make "taking your medicine" a treat instead of a chore.

There are a bunch of "hams" in our circle of family/friends (all of them adults!) and we enjoy games that encourage our "acting abilities" :>).The rules of DMML are pretty simple, you tell the other players what you are going to act out. Then, you just "act out" the stuff on your card. You get votes. You get awards. Easy!BUT you can also abandon the rules (we did), if you wish, and encourage your fellow players to GUESS what you are acting out. Since we were playing this in an all-adult group, this was a more "challenging" way to play, and kept the adults engaged and guessing.  (For kids, I'd probably stick with the game rules.)In any case, DMML made for a fun evening with friends (yes, serve some drinks to add to the fun ;>) which we'll be repeating until we've used up the 100 "Improv cards" that come with the game.I had to take off one star simply because if you don't have "hams" in your family/friends circle, you might want to choose a a game for more reserved types.

I've tried other texturising sprays (Garnier Wonder Waves, for example), hoping to get some "beachy waves" into my SLIGHTLY wavy, layered hair. What I got was "crunch."With this Toni & Guy version, I didn't get "crunch", which was good, but I did get a little bit of "stiffness". (Think hairspray without the stickiness.) I was able to release the stiffness by continued finger styling after the product dried. Still, there wasn't much movement to my hair.As for creating waves, no, I can't say this did it. But it DID give loads of "texture" (defined my layers) and tons of "volume" (my hair was puffed up and BIGGER).The scent was mild ("parfum" is a listed ingredient), and faded quickly.The above points were the good qualities of the product.The not so good qualities: It's drying to the hair (at least to mine), despite the fact that "castor oil" is a listed ingredient, it left my hair with NO shine ("sodium chloride" and "alcohol" are ingredients, and I'm sure they don't do much for moisture and shine).It left me feeling like I needed to shampoo, simply because my hair was so dull-looking, and as I've already mentioned, slightly stiff.Those aside, I can still give it three stars, because I think if you have natural waves, or curls you want to control, this may be the right product for you.

I liked several things about this oil, including:The scent, which is slightly musky/nutty sweet, but not overpowering. In short, it's a lovely aroma. (Contains coconut oil and sweet almond oil, plus "fragrance", which explains the scent combo, I think.)It can be used on damp or dry skin. I prefer it on damp skin. Used this way, you can massage the oil in, then pat dry, and your skin will feel hydrated for most of the day.(On dry skin the oil "sits" too long, not absorbing quickly enough.)A little goes a long way. (I pour a small --quarter size) amount in my hand, and spread it over damp skin. This covers entire torso. Use less for your arms if you try this.)BUT...There were a couple of things I didn't care for, including:The spray applicator releases in more of a STREAM than a fine spray. So you get a "blob" of oil if you use it with the spray. (As I mentioned, I'm a "pour and massage" type, but I tried the spray.)Mineral oil is the first ingredient. And it DOES feel sort of like baby oil. In other words, it feels "heavy" and slightly oily. (Unlike, say, Neutrogena body oil, Light Sesame Formula, unscented, which I've also used, and which feels light on the skin.)Those two things were enough to remove two stars, especially because I think some users will object to the scent,  the mineral oil, the heavy feel, and the fact that it is not truly a "dry" oil.

As a woman who doesn't always want to use a safety razor, I've tried a few electric shavers made for men. So far, this one is my favorite, because:--I used it dry, outside of the shower, and it gave an even, close shave.--The double rotating-head rolled easily over knees and ankle curves, giving a precise shave (as in, it didn't miss any spots, or leave behind any "strays")--No nicks, no cuts.Yes, as women, we can buy a "ladies" shaver, but I've found they usually have very small cutting heads, so it takes longer to shave, and they simply don't give a close enough shave.So if you want the convenience of an electric, it's worth giving this men's model a try.

This is a great little brow trimmer, that operates on a single AA battery. What I especially liked: The head of the brow trimmer is just slightly angled, which makes it easer to control shaping on the brows.For ladies, here's how I recommend using it: comb your brow hair upward; cover the hair you do NOT want to trim with your finger. Then, trim just the TIP of the brow hair (above your finger). I recommend this method because there's very little chance that you'll trim off too much hair if you do it this way.Also, this model is superior to an older Remington trimmer I have (silver color), which has a flat, not angled head.I had to take off one star simply because I can't speak to the effectiveness of the nose/ear trimming use of the product, since I use it only for brow trimming.

First, let me say that I like the way this thermostat looks. It's modern-looking, and I LOVE those BIG easy-to-read numbers.Next, I like the simple controls on the side of the unit. The 2 side-switches are: Heat/Off/Cool,and auto-fan/fan-on. Like I said, simple.The front controls are also simple to use. Just an up arrow and a down arrow for temperature. Again, simple.What wasn't so simple: installation.  I needed help from a friend who is pretty savvy about installing ANYTHING, and even he had difficulty with the wiring on this unit.Why? Because the original wiring from the furnace to our old thermostat is not labelled. Therefore the labelling/identifying of connections which come on the unit itself, don't help much. And again, that is because it's difficult to match it up with the original wiring.We took our time, read all the instructions (which are many) and got it done, but it was tricky.In a nutshell, there are things to like about this unit, thus the three stars. However, if you are looking for something very simple to install, this might not be for you.

I like to use super-fine sugar in my coffee, and so I'm usually breaking up lumps that form in the sugar bowl.That's changed now that I've put the sugar into this Good Grips Dispenser. This little item keeps the sugar in an (almost) air-tight environment, therefore doing away with clump issues.It's easy to clean, which is an added plus. (Common sense note: just be sure it is COMPLETELY DRY when you wash it out before use, otherwise...lump city :>)Overall, it's a nice little "retro" looking sugar dispenser that does a great job with sugar storage. (Final note: it is SMALL, so if you use lots of sugar, you'll be refilling often.)

When I say "mild whitening", I mean that literally. Because:--The gel whitener contained in these pens has a mild taste.--I avoided the gum area, and the gel was mild enough to NOT cause tooth sensitivity.--The whitening effect on my teeth was also mild.By that last, I mean it was not as noticeable as some strip whiteners I've used in the past. (I suspect this is because some of the gel just gets washed away (by saliva) as it sits on your teeth.However, on the plus side, the pens were also easier to use than strips. And there was a (slightly) brighter look to my teeth.Overall, these pens offer a convenient way to gently whiten your teeth. I'd recommend them as a "touch up" whitening system for those who have used other types of whiteners, or for those who don't have severe discoloration on their teeth.

I really like these cleansing cloths, because unlike some drugstore brands I've tried, they removed ALL my makeup.Here's what I was wearing:BB creamconcealercream blushmascara (NOT waterproof)lipstickHere's how I used the cloths:Took one cloth, wiped it over my entire face, finishing with the eye area. Turned the cloth over, wiped again. Then, I rinsed with warm water, took ANOTHER cloth, and repeated the above.I'm writing about the way I used them, because the directions do NOT say you must rinse after using. I just prefer that.As to how they cleaned: after using the FIRST towel (one side) there was NO makeup left on my face. I used the second side of the towlette to be sure, but it came away clean.So why did I use a second wipe? For the softening effect, which I knew I'd rinsed off.Ingredients include: glycerine, castor oil, lemon fruit extract, ginko biloba leaf extract and ALSO a number of other, chemical ingredients, including sodium lauryl sufate and methylparaben.For those who object to parabens in their products, those chemicals I listed might be a problem. Also, if you object to products made in China, be aware that these are produced there.As for me, I liked the job these did cleaning and softening the skin, and the fact that they have a mild, pleasant fragrance made them even nicer to use.

If you're the person in the house who has the honor of toilet cleaning, you'll probably be interested in anything that makes the job:1) easier2) better-smelling3) less "hands-on"4) more sanitaryThis Mr. Clean Magic Eraser Toilet Scrubber does all of the above.1) The scrubber is easy to assemble, easy to store in the bathroom, and easy to use.2) The "Meadows and Rain" scent of the cleaner/febreze beats bleach any day.3) The "click-load-replace" loading of the scrubber keeps your hands off the gunky stuff.4) More sanitary because of #3.However, two issues made me rate this just 3 stars: First, many reviewers have stated that the release mechanism of this unit does not always work. I didn't have that particular issue, but I trust Amazon reviewers ( I am one!), and I can see how some units might malfunction in that way.Second, an issue I did have--the replacement pads are expensive, and this might make the unit cost-prohibitive for some/most people to use.

First, packaging details: Age Perfect Day Cream is packaged in a neat little white pot, that comes with a plastic "protective" cover over the cream. This cover has a small handle on top which makes it easy to remove and replace.The cream itself is ultra-thick, and ultra moisturizing. It spreads smoothly onto the skin, and leaves a dewy look. It does, however, take some time to "sink-in" (probably because it is so thick. And the sunscreen (SPF 15) usually plays a role in how fast a moisturizer is taken in by the skin (many sunscreens just sit on top of the skin as a barrier).The scent is not unpleasant (as in not a strong, chemical smell, as some sunscreens have), and fades fairly quickly.Because the cream is so rich, I found it uncomfortable to wear under liquid or cream makeup. However, with a light dusting of powder foundation, it was comfortable enough.I also used the cream on my neck, and liked the smooth look it provided there.  I don't have any issues with sagging or age-spots, so I can't speak to the cream's effectiveness in those areas.My rating of four stars instead of five, is because of the richness and heaviness under makeup that I noted above. If you like a "light" feel on your face, this might not be for you. But if you use powder foundation, or no makeup, or have dry, mature skin, you may find this your go-to day/sunscreen.Notes: The SPF is only 15, so this would not be for prolonged (day at the beach) sun protection, unless you re-apply. Also: be careful around the eye area! the instructions clearly state "keep out of eyes."

I've reviewed a number of Philips Sonicare brushes in the past, and liked them all, so I thought I'd try out this battery operated Power Up model.There are a few good things about the brush, including:--high quality brush head, which comes in either regular or soft (I used the regular).--fairly powerful brushing action.--good choice for travel (since it's battery operated you don't have to pack a charger).Unfortunately, there were several things which are not as good, including:--it's heavy. (That's self-explanatory, I think :>)--it's bulky. As in, the handle isn't slim like all the other Sonicare models. (Which makes a difference in comfort and control when you're brushing).--while the brushing action is effective enough, it just isn't as comfortable as other Sonicare models, and not much better than certain "spin" brushes on the market.All in all, this is just an adequate brush, probably best used for travel.

I've tried many brands of nasal spray over the years, and always found Afrin to work the best.  Some of the generic, or "no-name" brands, either didn't clear my congestion at all, or they cleared it only briefly. So I always returned to Afrin.This Good Sense Sinus brand, gave the same 12-hour relief as Afrin.  (It has the same active ingredient, in the same amount as Afrin --Oxymetazoline Hydrochloride 0.05%.)The squeeze-to-spray-it bottle gives a good, powerful spray, which you can feel working. Some generic brands I've tried had a weak, drippy spray.Like Afrin Sinus, this brand has a sort of "mentholated" smell to it, which also feels cooling and soothing as it hits the nasal passages.  (If you remember "Vicks", you'll be familiar with the smell/cooling sensation I'm talking about.)All in all, I'd say this works as well as Afrin, and is a sufficient replacement which you might want to try.

Jennifer L. Scott is decades younger than I, but as I read her charming book, I found myself nodding in agreement, and sometimes saying "YES!" out loud.As an exchange student, American-born Scott lived in Paris with a French family. While there, she observed important cultural differences that seemed to endow her French hosts (and all of the French) with a more pleasureable and more elegant lifestyle than Americans.She began to incorporate these "secrets" into her own life, and later, brought them back with her to the states. (She lives in California now, and has a popular blog and facebook page where she also writes about the "secrets".)Her book contains 20 chapters which cover topics such as: Part I--Diet and Exercise. Part II--Style and Beauty.Part III--How to Live Well. Each of the chapters ends with a recap that gives short little reminders to readers for how they can make each secret part of their daily life.For me, the essence of the book is this advice:--Simplify your life (de-clutter, etc.).--Slow Down (be mindful and take time to fully enjoy small daily "rituals" that you create.)--Savor (listen to music, read, buy flowers.)This is about enjoying life, and it is good advice for women of all ages.Best of all, Scott's advice doesn't seem like another "to-do-list" that will drive you crazier. Instead, you can take your time and create a better life that YOU define. (And it doesn't have to cost a lot of money, either!)It's a calming read, and a good reminder that no matter your age, you can design a life of pleasure and beauty.

The Toledo War by Don Faber is your one-step fully detailed book about the First Michigan-Ohio Rivalry.  A conflict over a piece of land bordering the two regions at Lake Erie.  It is a tiny piece of local history yet involved many important historical figures including President Jackson, John Quincy Adams, and even Robert E. Lee.  It is a fun book to read and I don't wish to give anyway any spoilers or interesting facts butI will say that it is a amazing story of might overwhelming right.

Well, the good.  The story did expand a tad on the background and culture of the Solar Clippers.  We also learned more about the other characters, how they handle problems and trouble makers on ship.Now the bad.  Ish is Jesus and Superman and perfect in every way.  Women want him, men want to be him, he is super smart and makes Joxer the Mighty look realistic.Yeah, I loved the first book.  It felt real and gritty and I enjoyed the Free Spirit of the culture of the spacers.Then the second book started having...bumps in the road.  The famous shopping spree and the feeling that people were more interested in sex than finding a partner started to spoil it for me - but it was still good and it did bring up the point of how romance on a ship MIGHT have issues.  Therefore looking for fun with people you will not be seeing in a long time, or ever again, may have advantages.  Reminded me a tad of 1970s science fiction that questioned mainstream culture by placing the reader in scenes that challenged what he or she thought was normal. Or made them uncomfortable.  But a lot of those authors sometimes just showed the sex without understanding the logic behind it or strength behind those freedom-loving characters.This book made me start to feel uncomfortable with where it was going.  The female spacers come across as 2-D characters who, when not on duty, are starved for sex.  The male characters are not as sex starved but they're just as underdeveloped in most cases.  Let me make this clear - there are not any real sex scenes - what the problem is was that many of the female characters were acting like cats in heat when not in uniform.The characters of Sarah is the only one who does not end up rubbing up against somebody.  Robert Heinlein can write such scenes and such stories - but he understood why it worked.  The impression I have here is somebody trying to copy the style without understanding the foundation of how it works.  Like when people copy Lovecraft.The setting is no longer interesting or gritty, many of the characters were ALSO no longer interesting and the character of Ish is a joke.  At least Joxer The Mighty started out as a joke and became something more. This is what bad fan fiction is like.  I should know, I wrote some fan fiction - good and bad.I fear this is where I am getting off this train wreck.  I don't plan to read the next three book in the series.

First off, let me point out, before using any guide you should always read the book.  Guides like this one will not help you write a detailed report or even pass a test on the subjects.  They are meant to work along side the novel or movie or whatnot, to help you understand certain themes, help you view characters in a different light, and so on.I buy such guides to help me better understand some books I have.  Or at least see if anybody has anything NEW to add to my knowledge.  Out of all my guides I think this was the least interesting.  Many of the review questions fail, to me, to bring up anything new to the table (as it were).  There is also one chapter about how to write a literary analysis. Now while this would be interesting if I was writing an essay on The Hobbit this isn't what I want in a study guide.  Also, if I wanted to learn how to write an essay I assume it takes more then a chapter to teach me.

In almost every history class I have every taken that dealt with 20th century European history or World War Two the teachers always talked about how the Spanish Civil War was the proving ground for World War Two and the German Blitzkrieg.  First, the German idea of a breakthrough was developed during World War One, so even before reading this book I knew the latter statement was wrong.  What I did not realize was just how few Tank vs. Tank battles there were in the war till I finished reading this book - and I have a few books on the Spanish Civil War in my library.  But it takes a book like this one - which focuses solely on the tanks - to help you understand just how little there was for anybody to learn.  True, the Soviets learned enough to develop the T-34, but outside of that it seems that the Europeans (at best) learned to replace machine guns with heavier weapons.  The importance of proper training and maintenance was also something the Soviet's picked up on by the end of the war.  So, if anything, it was the Russians who learned about how to build a proper tank and the Germans, and other nations, either dismissed the war or used it to support their own ideas.

Many of the chapters in this book are the essays presented at a conference on George Orwell's book held at the University of Michigan in March 1983.  The authors are across the board, from Professors of History to Professors of Psychology.  So we get a very interesting mixture of essays.  One chapter talks about Orwell's view on women, and the family, while another chapter deals with the Self and how memory works.  Much of the works are, to be honest, same old same old.  There are a few gems, like the chapter that examines the consequences of George Orwell and his books existing and it's not pretty, while other chapters examine the well worn topics of the English language, privacy, and sadism.

I kind of grew use to Matt Smith.  Like all Doctors I started out a little worried about him - could he handle the great weight of the part, could he be serious and yet funny when needed?  But I came to embrace him in the part and thought he worked well across from Jenna Coleman who plays Clara.  The actress is pretty, funny, strong, and a great foil for Matt Smith's Doctor.So this story, which brings their time together to a end, had to be great.  It had to be wonderful and joyful and painful.  It was the passing on of the name of the Doctor from Smith to the new Doctor, played by Peter Capadli, AND it was also a Christmas Special.For me it failed.  Why?  Well, it had a interesting setting - outside of the town being called Christmas which seemed a tad silly to me - and some interesting characters.  True - all the alien races in the universe where there yet we saw only a few.  I mean, don't tell, show.  You have the money to show so show.  SHOW!  I don't want hundreds of alien ships.  I want aliens.Oh yes, narration.  We get told much of the story.  This could have been a audio book or a radio book.But in the end it had, and this is my own honest opinion, no story.  I am not even sure I need to explain this.  The idea is that the Time Lords are trying to break back into our universe.  But they need to find the right one so are asking the Doctor to reply with his correct name.  Why?  Why not just invade any universe they can break into.  And when they are notified of the fact that they have the right universe - Clara gives that away - they help him.  Why?  They hate him.  They were trying to trick him into answering with a truth field.  Why didn't they just invade and why didn't we get a great scene of the renewed Time War?  Daleks vs. Time Lords!  Buy I guess that's kind of overdone also, now isn't it?It isn't a flawed story.  The fact is that it isn't a story at all.  More of a half-formed idea, a rough draft written on a napkin during a dinner at a friend's place, with some wine spilled on it.  With recycled ideas tossed in out of laziness.  Silence Has Fallen.  Crack in the walls.They wanted to make a EPIC STORY to say good bye to one Doctor and hello to another.  I think they may have done better to focus on a STORY and interesting CHARACTERS.  A NEW STORY.  Not a lame monster of old pieces and aging parts glued together with duct tape and chewing gum.The worst part is the lack of a hook to make me WATCH the new Doctor.  That's a sin.Rent or get it from a friend or watch it on the net.  Don't waste money.  Like I did.  Bleh.
Tastes great, not that small, but costs way too much.  Can easily buy it cheaper off line or even buy Hostess Lemon Pies for less ONLINE.

Six pies, each 113.4 grans (or 4 oz), they taste great.  Seems the box is even microwaveable or you can warm up the pie (according to the box anyway).  But for the cost getting only six pies seems to be a tad cheap.  You can get better deals from a vending machine, a walk-in store or even online.  Amazon has some Hostess pies that cost less per unit - if you shop around..

First, this is a review of the movie, not the DVD.  Second, I have been told that there were some changes to the story in making the film.  The Barretts of Wimpole Street is a movie based on a stage play based on a novel based on real events - the romance and marriage of Robert Browning and Elizabeth Barrett.  The story is simple but the actors and actresses really bring it to life.  Charles Laughton playing the father, Edward Barrett, was so good that just his appearance on the screen made ME feel uncomfortable and ashamed!  And I'm not one of his kids!  The fact that his acting skills still can pour out of the film, a film released in 1934, just goes to show how powerful he is.Norma Shearer who played Elizabeth seemed to hit the character on the head.  I was not that impressed by Fredric March's version of Robert Browning - he seemed a tad over the top.  On the other hand, his bright, cheerful character does counteract the dark, depressing atmosphere of the rest of the piece.And it is depressing.  All the more so when you realize is was based on true events.  The father has crushed his children - he controls all parts of their lives, in the name of his love and that of God's.  This is a time when the father was truly the master of the house - if you lived under his roof you lived by his rules.  In real life her father would disinherit any of his children who married and he did disown her after the secret marriage.  Sadly her brothers also rejected her as they felt Robert Browning was a gold digger - but that piece of fact does not come up in the film.It is a dark story with a mixed ending - one of happiness but also some sadness.  This film is not for kids - some of the scenes are disturbing.  Running time is around 110 and while not rated I would suggest it only for 18 and older.  Funny enough the stage play has also been made into a musical and a TV series by the BBC.A little spoiler.  In the film the father is so upset by Elizabeth leaving he orders her pet dog killed.  But she took the dog with her so his order can not be carried out.  One of the changes was that in real life the father did KILL the dog.  I may be misinformed.  The story is already so dark I assume they changed that little detail.

First, this is a review of the movie, not the DVD.  Second, I have never red the book, so I can't compare it against the original story.The film is about a girl who is handed over to her grandfather after her parents are dead.  He is a grumpy old man but Heidi soon bonds with him, softening his heart towards her and others.  But then she is taken away and sold to a rich family to keep their sick girl company.  I would call it an overused trope but this is a movie from the 30s and it likely started the trope to begin with.The grandfather goes searching for Heidi, finds her, and kidnaps her to take her back home.  One horse chase later that makes you think of a bad action episode from "Chips" (a gun is USED) and all the loose ends are tied up.  Fun for the whole family.I've been told that the film and the book are different in many ways but I don't think the lovers of the novel will complain too much about the movie.

I have never red this as a child and, having enjoyed the first (older) movie after so many decades I decided to read the book.  I am glade I did but....it wasn't as interesting or as humorous as I thought it would be.  Maybe you have to be a kid to enjoy it?  Charlie Bucket and his family come across as a tad too silly or too extreme - they are a poor starving family, the basic plot of a lot of books - and Willy Wonka comes across as just plain weird.  And not in a good weird, that guy you invite to parties because he makes everybody laugh weird, oh no.  He is that bad weird, the guy next door who you don't let the kids make eye contact with, that kind of weird.He has a factory that has underground chambers where tiny people, called Oompa-Loompas, who slave away in his work shops, being paid only cacao beans.  The logic kind of reminds me of Alice in Wonderland but for the fact it isn't very logically and Alice in Wonderland was interesting.  In the end, while I am happy I got to read it, it felt more like a chore.  In other words, as the rating says, it was okay.

A reprint (and I think rewrite) of the 2008 edition, this is a detailed account of the making of, and final movie, Blade Runner and its history after release.  Many of the stories are well known and, to be honest, at just over a hundred pages there seems to be very little here that you could not find in a ten minute internet search.  Blade Runner is one of those films that developed a cult following well after its release and many facts have become well known.  A lot of the book seems to deal with the city and its place in the future, the ethics of androids, and the landscape of science fiction in the 20th century.  Which, while interesting, is not THAT interesting to a person who is already well versed in such things.  This is for a person who is totally new to the film or sci-fi films in general.  Otherwise I would give it a pass.

The book covers eight wars, starting with World War One, which heads into World War Two, Korea and Vietnam, the clashes between India and Pakistan, the wars in the Holy Land, Saddam Hussein's Two Wars in the Gulf, and finally ending in Bosnia.  The author was not happy with the old answers and theories on why nations went to war and decided to focus on the leaders for the answers.  It is very eye opening, very revealing, and somewhat scary some of the conclusions the author arrived at in the end of each chapter and in the end of the book.  While the book is already in the 11th edition, making my copy outdated, I found myself comparing what was happening in Eastern Europe with many of the events in Bosnia and other conflicts mentioned inside the book.  Nationalism, the leader's misperception of his adversary's power, overconfidence in the outcome, and so on.

One of the reasons I love Steven Saylor's books is not just the fact that they are based on real events from Roman history but the amount of detail he dives into dealing with Roman thought, society, culture, and ideas without drowning the reader in too much information.  We don't get a data dump.  We also get wonderful characters, some fictional, some real based on what we know of their historical real lives.  Cicero, Marc Antony, Clodius, and Milo are all real people from Roman history and here they are given human, as well as humane, traits and flaws.  Once I pick up one of his mystery novels set in Ancient Rome I have a hard time putting it down.

There us A LOT of Amish Romance novels out there but those I have found are not written by the Amish till I found Linda Byler's books.  Why is that important?  Because a lot of them don't get the Amish way of life or their way of thinking right.  Oh, they do a good job in general, but there is always something off.  they get the way the Amish think about God, the Church, and the individual's place within society off.I liked this novel.  It was a solid plot, based on the real life of the author, with colorful characters, real emotions, and include, like all good Amish books, RECIPES.

Very detailed book that deals with the history of the Amish and the Mennonites, the main focus on how they deal with and adapt to changes in the world around them as well as changes within their own society.  From wars to questioning their own traditions, we get the ups and down of their history.  Somewhat dry, it is a very good overview and I would suggest it as a good beginning point for anybody who wants to really understand the Amish - or at least start the journey to understanding.Heavy use of primary source material and a large bibliography, it is the perfect starting point, and I think would make a good college text book.  I hope that it is updated and revised for future generations interested in the Amish.I enjoyed it but for people who don't love history as much as I do it will seem, as I said, a tad dry.

The book holds many stories, all enjoyable and interesting in their own ways.  The Legacy of Erich Zann is a mixture of the world of Lovecraft and Poe, with the character of Dupin from The Murders in the Rye Morgue set into the world of The Music of Erich Zann.  It is a wonderful, if sometimes confusing, ride and is worth the price of the book all by itself.But we get more than just that story. We also get The Truth About Pickman which is a story that suggests that curiosity can be a bad thing.We get The Holocaust of Ecstasy where we get to see the end of the world.  Cthulhu style.Than we get to enjoy the last story called The Seeds from the Mountains of Madness and we learn that the Elder Race is still trying their best to take over the world.  One greenhouse at a time.  Kind of reminded me of a Tom Baker Doctor Who story.The overall feel of the book is dark but not always hopeless like many of Lovecraft's tales.  We are not defeated.  Not yet.

The Duchess of Duke Street is a book, let us say a novelization, of a good chunk of the first part of the television, The Duchess of Duke Street.  Now, that's kind of funny, from what I understand the series is based on the real life of a real person, Rose Lewis.  In fact I found a book, The Duchess of Jermyn Street: The Life and Good Times of Rosa Lewis of the Cavendish Hotel, a bio on Rosa Lewis.  There is not much to say about this book - it follows the events in the TV story up to a certain point and it well written.  The authors are known from writing Victorian historical pieces, so they know their locations, history, and how to create a proper atmosphere.

First, we found out just what happened in the end of the Time War.  We kind of knew it already, from the last episodes of David Tennant's time as the Doctor.  But in The Day of the Doctor we learn about just how guilty he felt about it.  To the point where he refused to even allow himself to even hold the title of Doctor.  It makes more sense when you watch the special.I am not a big fan of Rose but, funny enough, Billie Piper played Bad Wolf, so that's okay.  We get to see the Daleks and even see the Zygons back in action.  And we get to visit the Time Lords again.Now, we get to see two new Time Lords.  John Hurt, a favorite actor of mine, who has brought many wonderful and horrible parts to life.  He played Smith in my favorite version of Nineteen Eighty-Four, so I don't mean he was horrible at it, it is just a dark piece.He plays a wonderful Doctor, old and tired and bitter and making a decision that will change the very universe itself.We also get a glimpse of the future, and last, Doctor.  Well, his eyes and eyebrows.There is a lot of humor and the interaction between Hurt, Smith, and Tennant is wonderful.  It is always nice to see scenes where the Doctors get together.The Zygon sub-plot isn't that bad either and they do a good job of keeping the whole story moving without any bumps in the road and without over using special effects. And there is a surprise guest at the ending, which was very nice if not explained.  So, in fact we get five Doctors.  Enjoy!

But I felt the ending was slightly weak.  Maybe because it wasn't a true ending but a cliffhanger for the special?  Anyway, I truly hated to see the Ponds leave the series.  And I have to be honest, I was never a fan of Amy Pond, she always seem to rub me the wrong way. But The Angels Take Manhattan was a very powerfully emotional and amazingly interesting episode.Clara was a interesting mystery which lost some of her charm by the last episode The Name of the Doctor.  They kind of solved the mystery there in a way which I felt was a tad underwhelming.Still, I enjoyed seeing the Daleks back in Asylum, the Cybermen back in Nightmare in Silver, even if both of this enemies acted a tad off.  I would think the Daleks would see the Doctor as a greater threat than some music being played on a planet by an unknown human.  But that's just me.The Snowmen was interesting in how it brought back a old enemy for those of us who watched the original series and Cold War was wonderful for one who grew up in the Cold War and also liked the Ice Warriors.A Town Called Mercy I enjoyed very much.  It had a few plot twists, was set in an old Western town (which in fact is one in Spain where many of the great Westerns have been filmed), and starred Ben Browder as Isaac.  He happens to be one of my favorite stars from Farscape (and later Star Gate), so I was very happy to see him.overall I would say a Doctor Who fan would enjoy this season and should watch it to the end for to be prepared for the 50th anniversary special.

Which sometimes is good.  In this case...no.  Still a complex story but mostly about trade, coins, the Church, with some action in the form of a kidnapping.  I like the artwork but the economy heavy plot makes for a good business class 101 but makes for a somewhat bad second book in a series.  Even with the action near the end of the volume it still feels very slow and even a tad confusing to me.  I have decided, if I am going to enjoy this story, it will be via the text novels.  So I will likely read them - in fact already have the first book in that series, which the manga and anime are based on.  In the end, if I wanted a lesson on currency and early trade I could just go to one of my history books on the Middle Ages in Europe.  At least THAT I would enjoy and be able to get into.  Trying to make a realistic system of trade interesting, in a fantasy setting, may help fill out your world during the creation process.  But is a detail that should stay in the background.  You don't build your whole series around it.  Maybe one story, yes, but not the whole series.I plan to drop the manga and just, as I said, continue with the text novel and see if I enjoy that.In the end, the second volume is okay but is not as good as the first, suggesting that the series will, from my point of view, just become more and more uninteresting.

I love world building and this setting is a strange yet familiar place that draws me in with every page.  The view point, at first, is from a traveling trader, a young merchant called Kraft Lawrence.  One night when he is about to go to bed he encounters the harvest goddess, a wolf, in the form of a young girl - Holo.  The history of this world, and the background of both characters, slowly unfold as we absorb the manga, enjoying each detail as it is given to us.  Sometimes it DOES feel like a data dump.  We get a lot of information about the Church, the economy, even coinage.  Yet the story was interesting enough for me to buy the first text volume.  This is one of those reviews in which I don't wish to say much - I don't want to spoil it for you.  But on the other hand I don't wish to give the wrong impression.  It's good but I don't think it's great.  In some ways I feel the text novel is a tad better at delivering the story.  Holo is a wisewolf but also kind of a flirt with Kraft, which seems to happen a lot in manga and anime.  I think I would have found it more interesting if they were not at all interested in each other.  I mean, she has ears and a tail!  Looks cute but in real life he should find that a tad off putting.  In the text novel he wonders if she is some kind of demon.  He believes that in the manga at first.  I would think it would be more realistic to keep that thought in the back of his mind - poking him like a thorn.  It seems fun and mature but sometimes just a tad too fantasy for me.  Even the map in the front of the book seems a tad too simple.  Is this our Earth?  A different Earth?  A alien planet?  Middle-Earth?  Quarter-Earth?I would suggest reading it but maybe getting it used or out of the library - if any library would have it.

This volume is more drama than action.  We learn more about Giuseppe and Jean, and their dead sister.But the book mainly focuses on Petrushka the first of a new generation of cyborgs.  Not as strong as the first girls, the second generation, will live longer, but cheaper to make, easier to maintain, and their conditioning will be changed to make them more flexible.  The Agency feels is an improvement and a Russian girl is the first of the new cyborgs.  Yu Aida changes his style a tad in this volume.  The story is on the girl, showing us before her change, allowing us to see her background story and allowing us to have some emotional reaction to the events that change her life, forever.  Also, she looks older than the other girls, which makes sense as the Agency wishes to start using the technology on adults.  Her handler, Alessandro is somewhat of a jerk, a reaction you may find in other reviews, but is interesting in his own right - being of a different background as the other handlers.  While many of the handlers are ex military or police he use to be in operations against the Padania.  He feels the other handlers have too many...morals?It does make for some new interesting characters while the old ones, just as amazing, are also kept in the story.  There is also some debate about souls and fate, but they don't pound that in with page after page of lectures or anything like that.  They keep a lot of the exchange between characters real, which is always refreshing, and allow the reader to decide on their own about such things as souls, fate, and salvation.  Is it cruel to save this girls only to make them into killers?  To help a girl to walk again so she can run into battle?  To extend a life just to take others?  And why does that remind me a tad of Red Garden?  Enjoy!

A sting operation captures Franca but she is released by Franco and Pinocchio.  The girls of the Agency are sent after Christiano and run into the Padania terrorists who are trying to save the Milano leader.  The final chapter is blood soaked and full of action as the girls, programmed and designed for anti-terrorist work, go against the terrorists, who have been fighting and killing for what they believe in for their whole life, in a all out fight.  Nature vs. nurture in a way.

There was Kull.  Kull was created before the wandering Conan and well before the doomed Bran Mak Morn.  Think of him as a foundation and setting for Mr. Howard's future stories and characters.  Not really good enough to build a whole world on but too good not to use.  One of his stories was recycled as a Conan story and he even time traveled to help Bran Mak Morn against the Romans.  His stories will feel somewhat familiar to those of us who are fans of Conan but once again, that is because Kull came first and was made by the same writer.  Yet he is really a character to enjoy.  By This Axe I Rule! is somewhat famous now, and the setting of the Kull novels is, when you think about it, the history and past of the Hyborian Age.  He is a man who truly started out as nothing but a naked man, a wild ape, who was educated and made into a brooding, thinking, barbarian.  The world of Kull is, in some ways, more beautiful but also more dangerous than those of latter ages.  Kull and his axe are more than just the early shadow of Conan.  Kull is a man who finds out what price he must pay for the prize he wishes.  A crown is sometimes heavier than one thinks.With wonderful drawings, unpublished fragments and drafts, this is a great book for any collection.

Which is not a bad thing.  When you go out for Chinese you don't want pizza.  When you open a manga of Strawberry Marshmallow you don't want gun fights, explosions, plots, and whiny teenagers in comedy romance stories.  Okay, maybe a gunfight would be cool.We get a job search by Nobue with unwanted help from Miu, English homework with unwanted help from Miu, and hide-and-seek with a twist from Miu.  We also learn the very weird story on why Nobue started to smoke.

No plots, no themes, no secret messages.  Just funny shorts.  The poor door to door salesman, the dog dream, and the interviews with the characters between the chapters are great!  Than there is the haunted school story.  I would suggest this book for rainy days, travel on a bus or train, and of course those slow weekends.
