Urd is attacked, her Angel removed from her and the Goddesses must find their enemy before it strikes again. The problem is it seems to be able to bypass all defenses and strike without warning! Lind, the a Angel from the Combat Section, the Valkyries, feels helpless to do anything as one by one the Goddesses fall before the thief. How is it getting to them and who is it? Peorth's angel is also taken and it seems they are running out of time.Will finding out just make things worse?!?! Or will Belldandy end up turning the tables on the invader?

The battle between Lind and the super-cute Hild comes to a close and everything seems to go back to normal.  Kind of...Belldandy seems to be having trouble now that she has two angels.  Well, a angel and a demon turned angel.  Will she be okay?  Will they have to lock her up?  Pull the two angels out?  Operate?  No, there is a simple answer to her condition.  Somebody else needs to take the familiar.  But who?

The beginning of a second series is not the best place to start.  The idea is a simple one - Wuntvor must help his Master and the other Wizards to cure themselves of a interesting malady.  Magic makes them sick.  So the apprentice must journey to the Eastern Kingdoms.  To get the help from Mother Duck.The humor was just not my type of humor and fell flat.  A lot.  Also I picked up this book, and An Excess of Enchantments, without realizing they were part of the second trilogy in the series.  Now, I picked up a lot of what was happening, so I don't really think it hurts it THAT much, but I seem to be very picky about humor in my fiction, be it fantasy, science fiction, or humor.  For me, this was more miss than hit and while I finished it and have started on the other book, I can't say I will continue with the third book.  Just not interested.  Also, I can't say it feels original.  I have never heard of Craig Shaw Gardner and, to be honest, I will unlikely pick up any more books by this author.I'm not saying I don't like humor.  I would always suggest for example Xanth: The Quest for Magic (A Spell for Chameleon; The Source of Magic; Castle Roogna) or M.Y.T.H. Inc. Link/Myth-Nomers and Impervections 2-in-1 (Myth 2-in-1) to anybody interested in humor in their fantasy.  I love both of those series even if, near the end, they started to get a little weak.

I use my yoga mat, exercise ball, resistance bands, amongst other things, for my daily stretching and exercising. Until now, I had been using antibacterial wipes and sprays to clean my equipment and yoga mat. It actually became discolored and started wearing out due to the harsh cleaners I was using. I had to buy a new yoga mat. I even made my own cleaner to use on it. I was so excited to get this Nama Sudz premium yoga mat cleaner. Now that I'm pregnant, I'm extra diligent about using all natural and organic cleaning products. Shipping was fast, I received a 4 fl oz spray bottle of 100% natural yoga mat wash. I love this stuff, it works great. Just a couple sprays and my yoga mat is like new. It doesn't just clean, it conditions the material, making it look new and shiny, it even smells clean. I use it on my waist belt too because it has similar material. It works awesome on all my exercise equipment. I highly recommend this product, it's essential if you own and use a yoga mat. Yoga mats hold bacteria, especially if you exercise barefoot and of course sweating. I'm glad I got this yoga mat cleaner from K3 sports and I will definitely by it again. I received this product in exchange for my honest review and my opinions are my own.

I'm an advocate for using products containing all natural and organic ingredients, after all, the best remedies can all be found in nature. I've used quite a few different cellulite creams and I've even made my own. Different brands have their pros and cons but the same objective. I was excited to try this cellulite and stretch mark cream by Pureasant. I love their products, I've tried a their raspberry seed oil and other skin care products and loved the results. Shipping was fast and I received a nice sized jar of cellulite reducing cream. This stuff is pretty versatile. You can easily apply a thin layer or a generous amount, either way, the consistency is nice. Not too thick, not too thin. Has a wonderful feeling after applying it to my skin. I feel it working immediately. It's packed full of amazing ingredients such as caffeine, retinol, citric acid, organic aloe, green tea, and other vitamins, just to name a few. This formula is wonderful, it works deep into the skin minimizing the appearance of cellulite. It makes my skin more firm, heals stretch marks, lightens old scars, and smooths the lumps. I use it all over. My tummy, thighs, butt, arms, even my chest. I've noticed significant improvement. After 3 weeks of using this cream I've noticed a big difference. It has a tingling feeling that takes some getting used to, that's because the ingredients are working deep into the layers of skin. I highly recommend this cream, it really works. I've used it on its own and I've used it with body wraps. I received this product in exchange for my honest review and my opinions are my own.

I've been making my own skin care and cleaning products for a few months now and I love using all natural and organic ingredients as opposed to store bought. I was excited to try this Aspen Naturals cocoa butter. Shipping was fast and I received a 1 lb solid bar of raw, unrefined, pure, food grade cocoa butter in a resealable bag. It's super easy to measure and use. I warm a knife using hot water, it makes it easier to shave pieces off, and I don't have to use very much for my homemade lotion bars and soaps. Immaculate Blue is about nothing and yet about everything, particularly if you are gay and your "wonder years" were in the late 80's and early 90's. If you read Russell's The Salt Point from 1990, this book follows the same group of friends now twenty years later as their paths cross again in Poughkeepsie for a wedding. No worries if you haven't read The Salt Point though; you won't be lost.The story unfolds in three long chapters in which Russell weaves back and forth between the different characters' point of view. In the first chapter, Chris returns to Poughkeepsie to reunite with friends Anatole and Lydia for Anatole's wedding. Much of the story explores what has happened to each of the three friends over the last twenty years. Chris moved away while Anatole and Lydia stayed in Poughkeepsie. Chapter two is the wedding. Chapter three follows Chris after the wedding as he reconnects with another friend before leaving Poughkeepsie.If you aren't familiar with some of Russell's other work, like The Coming Storm or War Against the Animals, you might find yourself bored at first. Russell likes to explore the human condition and gives the reader a well-rounded look into each of his main characters, so the story tends to move at a slow pace with not a lot of drama happening on the page. You really feel like you know these people by the time you finish the book. Or you at least connect with the way they are feeling and where they are in life. Immaculate Blue is no different. while I haven't lived such an intense life as Chris, I still connected with how lost he felt.Having had a close group of friends during my glory days that I sadly abandoned when I moved away, I related very well to Chris's re-connection with his friends. We like to say that today we could pick up right where we left off, but there are always questions unanswered and things that we don't know about each other that have happened since then. The last chapter definitely explores those "what if's" that we fantasize about coming true.Having read The Salt Point many years ago when I was younger and at a different place in life, it was nice to catch up with these characters much like old friends and see how much we've all changed.

Saw this one on Shark Tank and immediately wanted to give it a try. Mixed it with some vodka and seltzer and it was okay, but I love it with rum and lemon lime soda. The new Flynn is a tiny dose but I wet myself a little when I saw her mention it on her Facebook page.  I immediately downloaded it and finished it in one day! She eventually moves up front to read auras and soon finds her first client is in need of a house cleansing. I'm new to yoga and decided to give this book a try only because it was free on Kindle at the time and included some links to free how-to videos. I laughed right from the first sentence of the book which contains errors, but the book only gets worse from there. Luckily, there are pictures and you can decipher enough information from the text to figure out what to do.  Otherwise, the book is riddled with bad writing, bad spelling, and bad grammar.  It's still a useful book for beginners like me, but hard to overlook the poor editing.

There's always an intriguing story and interesting characters to look forward to when reading something new from Gabriella West. Her latest, Elsie Street, is no different. In it we meet Dave, a young Bostonian who is now enjoying California with his girlfriend Janine.But when Dave loses his bar tending job, his entire world changes. Dave meets a young man named Aaron and his sexual identity is reawakened, stemming from a brief affair he had with his college roommate long ago. What follows is the tensions that sexuality often causes when we are young and figuring out our place in this world, often riddled with guilt while figuring out what our true heart desires.West embraces location. You'll find yourself loving San Francisco just as much as her characters and wanting to visit there if you haven't already. This being an M/M romance, she also writes romantic scenes quite beautifully and leaves just enough of the detail's up to the reader's imagination.Most of the conflict plays out within her characters, especially as Dave questions his happiness with Janine and longs to be with Aaron. Ultimately, she pushes her story forward by giving her characters what they want, and what the reader wants them to have, often avoiding those real-life consequences that we face.And that's the beauty of a great story. We can separate ourselves from woes of the real world and just get lost in the world the author has given us.

Spiralizers are becoming very popular now that people are seeking new ways to make healthy and fun meals at home. It's perfect for turning vegetables like zucchini, yellow squash, cucumbers, and carrots into long spirals that resemble pasta. They cook quicker than pasta too! Great way to get kids to get vegetables too. Would make a great gift for someone who is trying to get fit or incorporate more vegetables into their diet. I highly recommend!

During business trips I take each year, I have previously carried a backpack that holds a laptop. I picked up this spiral slicer after reading Amelia Freer's book, "Eat. Nourish. Glow."  In it, she suggests replacing your pasta with vegetable noodles that you make using a spiral slicer. The slicer is definitely easy to use.  It works better on softer vegetables like yellow squash, zucchini, and cucumbers. I couldn't get carrots to go through it long enough to make a decent noodle. And quickly discovered carrots stain the plastic and make it a bit hard to clean. Speaking of cleaning, bits of veggies get stuck in the teeth which are a pain to pick out but this slicer is dishwasher safe on the top rack. This slicer comes with a simple instruction guide that includes some easy recipes as well. I'll definitely continue to use mine and would suggest it to friends who enjoy pasta or veggies and want to try something new.

I should point out that I don't normally read self-help or dieting books. About the only non-fiction stuff I read is memoirs. As far as nutrition goes, I do love the occasional cook book from time to time but never use or read them cover to cover.Amelia Freer's book is not a cook book or dieting book, but I would call it a bit of a self-help book. And I read it cover to cover in just under a week! That being said, it's not one of those books that is going to beat you up for what you do or do not do. Amelia is a nutritionist and gives you advice based on her own personal experiences with food.It definitely helped open my eyes to my own relationship with food.  I've been a crash dieter, starving myself and counting calories. I've been a binge eater, gorging on sugary foods that I knew weren't good for me.  I've been an addictive snacker, unable to put the chips or candies down until they were gone.Amelia doesn't beat you up for being any of these types of eaters. She does point out the medical issues you could face, but also offers advice on how to change those unhealthy food habits.  First, she tells you to convince yourself you are not on a diet. You can eat anything you want (in moderation). But you should change what you eat, how much, and how often.Now, due to her own health issues, Amelia does not eat any processed foods, sugar, gluten, or dairy. She is a very organic eater and relies on fresh ingredients. Throughout the book, she reminds you that you do not have to give up gluten or dairy if your system is okay with it, and my system is actually okay with dairy and I enjoy it in moderation.She also discusses another battle of mine which is time. Like many, I work all day and come home and don't want to cook. I want something fast and easy. And it usually leaves me feeling sick or bloated and even more tired. And unfortunately, a quick meal like this is usually full of sugar and unhealthy cancer-causing preservatives also responsible for obesity and other problems. But Amelia encourages you to identify your problems, like time, and address them slowly.  You don't have to change your entire life all at once. That can be overwhelming. But small changes over time can make a big difference. Amelia has convinced me to try!

I consider myself a student and fan of Emily Dickinson.  I first discovered her when I was in college and only recently wrote a book about her myself. So, once I came across Amherst by William Nicholson I immediately wanted to read it. Nicholson focuses primarily on the affair that Emily's brother had with Mabel Todd, a friend of the family.  He parallels this love affair with a present story about a woman named Alice who goes to Amherst with intentions to write a screenplay about the Dickinson affair while having an affair of her own with a local teacher named Nick.Since I was very familiar with Austin and Mabel's story, I was anxious to see how Nicholson would treat it or add his own flare. There is one scene in the book where Mabel comes to the Dickinson home to play the piano while the reclusive Emily listens from the hall (Mabel and Emily never met face to face.).  I had included this scene in my book as well so it was fun to read Nicholson's interpretation.The present story of Alice and Nick helps to move the story forward as Alice reads over Mabel's diary and Emily's poems and we see her conflicted on how to portray Mabel in her screenplay. Emily is also handled well in the story and there are some brief chapters from her told in first person.  I love the way Nicholson eventually pays homage to Mabel in the end, despite the affair, for she is the one who edited Emily's poems and was ultimately responsible for getting her work published. Nicholson points to Polly Longsworth's book "Austin and Mabel" for his inspiration. Though I have not read it, I will soon because I was intrigued by how Mabel's own husband seemed to approve of their affair and may have participated.There's a bizarre twist revealed in the end with Nick that I did not see coming and I must admit it was a pleasant one. I really feared we were going to be left with the predictable ending between Alice and Nick, but it takes a turn that I did not see coming. Nicholson researched his real-life characters very well and his respect for them shows.  He even references several of Emily's poems throughout. The story of the American family who gave us Emily Dickinson is a bizarre one indeed, and I thoroughly enjoyed Nicholson's interpretation of it.

I hope that the marketing "genius" at Axe makes a lot of money, and I'm sure they do.  I still have to laugh at whoever comes up with these names, and what's worse is the lab rat who came up with the scent!Slap a peace sign on the label of anything these days and we're sure to appeal to the "old" generation or the rebellious one.  And believe me, this smells old.  It's an okay scent, but not at all pleasant.  Doesn't leave you smelling fresh smelling at all once you step out. It might as well be non-scented. It's like some sort of man candle you'd find at Yankee.  Or motor oil if it smelled good. I definitely wouldn't buy it again based on scent alone.What's worse is the back label pomotes that by using this product you might "get some."  The label says something like, "The cleaner you are, the dirtier you get," complete with graphics of a nude man in silhouette showering and then talking to a ahem...lady...and is it just me or is the man still nude? Seriously, Axe folks?  What a joke!  What does that have to do with peace?  If anything, you should have spelled it "piece."  It even says UNLIMITED FEMALE ATTENTION underneath the graphics on the back. Again, what does that have to do with peace?  I know it's all a gimmick to promote the product to strapping young men full of hormones (unless they are gay), but if they all smelled like this, they are in trouble.Save your money.  There's better smelling stuff on the market.  Even Axe has made better products than this.

I picked up Love Letters after receiving a marketing email about it from Goodreads.  In the email, Stephen Chbosky, author of Perks of Being a Wallflower, sings its praises.  I lover Perks and after reading about Love Letters, I decided to give it a try. I learned in the Acknowledgements that Chbosky and the author are acquaintances and it is very easy to see how Ava Dellaira was inspired by Perks to write Love Letters.  They are actually a bit too similar if you want to go there.Love Letters to the Dead is a collection of letters that a young girl named Laurel writes to famous dead people: Kurt Cobain, Judy Garland, E.E. Cummings, Amy Winehouse, Amelia Earhart, River Phoenix, and more.  She particularly favors Kurt. Through the letters, we experience Laurel's teenage life - making friends, going to parties, skipping class, dating boys, etc. But Laurel is also dealing with something much greater. Layer by layer, we learn what happened to Laurel as she spills it in the letters and overall ends up facing her demons.Now, notice I did rate it four stars and I read it cover-to-cover and thoroughly enjoyed it. But again, the praise from Chbosky stuck out in my head as it probably has for many other readers.  In Perks, we also have a lead character who is writing letters to someone and slowing spilling his story about something bad that happened to him, he's in high school, making friends, connecting with girls, and throughout the book there is a huge connection to popular genre music, just like there is in Letters.Despite these obvious similarities, I still enjoyed Love Letters.  I wouldn't say it's better than Perks, by all means. Once you experience something so great the first time, a copy cat just won't do, right?  Read it for yourself and decide.  I'd still recommend it to anyone who liked Perks or anyone else who I think might enjoy it.

I've known about Peter Straub since my Stephen King days in high school, though I never read "Talisman" which he cowrote with King. When a recent bookstore was going out of business, I snatched up most of Straub's work in paperback and finally decided to give him a try. I started with Lost Boy Lost Girl.I thought this was a decent read and it reminded me a lot of King's writing, where we are given a horrific story line but the author chooses to avoid the graphic scenarios and instead dwells inside the minds of all his characters, which is often a much more dangerous place to be. Here, we have a serial killer, a suicide, a missing child, and a ghost girl, but Straub doesn't spoon feed you the details of any of these conflicts. Instead, he flushes them out as his here and now characters must explore the situations and find the facts as to what is really going on.That being said, sometimes this doesn't work. Sometimes you much prefer the details over the fodder. But Straub somehow makes it work. I didn't find myself bored or skimming through conversations between characters.  I was invested in the story just as he hoped I would be.Timothy Underhill, the lead character in the book, is Straub's alter ego and apparently makes appearances in some of Straub's other writings. He's a likable character here which made me turn to Google to research him, and also made me eager to immediately pick up another one of Straub's books.  This is a great "different" type of horror book which I certainly appreciate.  I can't believe I haven't read Straub until now, but I will certainly again.

Being a huge Emily Dickinson enthusiast, I was so pleased to receive The Gorgeous Nothings for Christmas without even having to ask for it. I was familiar with Dickinson's envelope poems after researching her extensively for a historical fiction book I wrote about her in 2012 which was published last year. Imagine my surprise when I discovered this coffee table book of her envelope poems was about to be published!  I was so tempted to order it for myself, but in the end I didn't have to!Since receiving it for Christmas, I've picked it up several times and just thumbed through it, picking a poem at random to read and think about. I finally made myself sit down and read the book in its entirety. Emily was bizarre enough as we know, but seeing her own handwriting on scraps of paper just adds to the admiration I have for her.I love how she even wrote on both sides of some pieces - one side is featured in the book on one page, and when you turn the page you find the opposite side lined up perfectly.  And the images are so real.  I found myself rubbing my fingers across them, wishing I could pick them up. No joke!  They look that real!  Don't worry about not being able to decipher her handwriting - there is an illustrated/typed graphic on the opposite page in the same shape as the envelope so that you can read it with ease.What's more important is that these pieces are preserved and everyone can enjoy them in this collection.  After reading it, I wanted to sit down and hand write a letter to someone.  Forget email. Forget Facebook. Computers have given us such ease and speed when it comes to communication, and while I'm guilty of taking advantage of that just as much as anyone else, I wish it wasn't so. I miss handwritten letters. I miss journal writing. I still get an occasional Christmas or birthday card from relatives, but with nothing more than a quick I love you and signature. Perhaps I'll find something to write my own thoughts on, like Emily, and not care what anyone thinks or who sees. And maybe one day, you'll be reading and reviewing it here.Yeah, I know, wishful thinking, right?  It's nothing. Or is it?  Who cares? For now, enjoy Emily's words in their originality.  This is a volume of hers I know I will cherish and pick up again and again.

When Miri receives a strange cat amulet from her dying grandmother, her past and present converge and her life is forever changed. Young Miri discovers she is a shape shifter who can turn into a cat. Abandoned by her snooty Aunt and Uncle at a boarding school, Miri is soon led to join a secret underground society in Forest Park in St. Louis. There, she makes new friends like herself who are also shape shifters and learns to tape into her inner feline.But where there are shape shifters and mysterious pasts, there is always conflict. Allistair, a sinister werewolf, is forming a pack to track down Miri while making plans to steal her amulet and take down the secret society. A plethora of questions are soon raised as the intensity builds: Where is Miri's mother? Why does Allistair want Miri's amulet? Are their young wolves in the society who are actually on Allistair's side? And who is Miri's father?Kupfer introduces a whole world of both good and bad characters, each with their own story lines that revolve around Miri. She does a fantastic job of characterization, building each personality and explaining their powers. There's even a gentle love story. But more importantly for me was the historical aspect of the story.I had the pleasure of hearing, in person, Mrs. Kupfer read the first chapter of her book before it was published. I was immediately drawn into the story due to its Nazi Germany setting in the introduction. And hearing the author read it, it's easy to see the passion she put into the book. I heard her voice in my head as I read the book which made it even more lively.Being an animal lover, and living in St. Louis made the book even more enjoyable.  It's always fun to read a story that takes place in locales that you are familiar with.  Here we have Forest Park, the Jewel Box, the St. Louis Zoo, and Turtle Park, all places I know well and have visited so I always knew where the action was taking place.I could have used a bit more resolution in the end, but it is my understanding there is a sequel to come. I have no doubt Kupfer will pick up where she left off, my questions will be answered, and there will be more adventures waiting for Miri and her friends. I highly recommend this book to the young fantasy readers, Harry Potter enthusiasts, animal lovers, or other St. Louisians. It's a book to be enjoyed by all ages.

It's always fun to get a new toothbrush, even when you are an adult. It's one of those things we don't part with as much as we probably should because we like the one we have and they are so pricey sometimes. Sure, they wear out but we keep using the same old one.  And then we finally break down and buy a new one and find we are glad we did!  It's like trying out a new cologne or shower gel. It's the little things that make us happy.And the Colgate Max White Full Head Toothbrush made me happy when I first tried it!  My previous toothbrush had a clunkier handle and was a bit wider around the top. I like the Colgate Max mainly because it is much thinner just below the head of the bristles.  It makes a huge difference when moving it back and forth in your mouth, and getting between your teeth and mouth.In the end, yeah, it's just another toothbrush. Not something for which we find ourselves tied to a certain style or brand, but I'd buy this one again and suggest it to others.  It's comfortable and works well and does the trick!

I loved Austin's first book, Steal Like an Artist, and did exactly what he told me, including buying extra copies of his book and giving it to all my friends. As a writer and an artist, his advice is simple, inspiring, and fun to follow.  I still use that book as a reference when I need a pick-me-up.His new book, Show Your Work!, feeds the need for those of us who wanted more!  It's the same format - quick chapters with full page black and white photos, quotes from famous folks that you will be pinning to your studio walls,lots of his newspaper blackout phrases, and the same simple noteworthy advice that Kleon is so good at!Building off of his first book, Kleon encourages the artist, writer, or anyone creative to dig a bit deeper to reach their audience. He teaches you how to introduce yourself at a party, how not to be human spam, to tell good stories, to share something small everyday, to build a mailing list. But then there are good life lessons like stepping away from what you are doing, or starting over, teach what you know, think process not product, and so much more.If you are looking for a step-by-step how-to guide to getting rich and famous at novel writing or art selling, this isn't it.  But if you want a fun cheerleader-type book chocked full of good advice that's to the point and easy to follow, Kleon is your man.  This book would make a great gift for the artist in your life, if you aren't one yourself.But as an artist or writer, you have to follow through!  Follow him on Twitter, do the little things he suggests, scratch each others' backs, and show your work!  It really works - removing the stress from your creativity and helping you to step back and see the bigger picture! I always feel energized and ready to dive in after reading his books.And I will definitely be buying extra copies to share with my artist friends, and am already anxiously waiting for the next one!  Kleon calls himself a writer who draws; he's also a genius!

C.V. Hunt dares to go there, and by "there" I mean places where no other writer dares to go but everyone is thinking just that!  In Baby Hater, she takes a hard punch at how society looks upon motherhood...quite literally!  Put a fat drooling baby in a stroller and go to the park, and suddenly everyone is your best friend.  But what about women who can't have babies?  Think about their anger.  They are probably so angry they'd...well...punch a baby!With her addictive dark humor, C.V. treats this idea with a matter-of-face slice of life point of view, and it works!  I laughed hysterically and wanted more!  It's a quick read and had me cheering for the Baby Hater and looking for her on Facebook!  I love this author because she doesn't take herself too seriously, but this girl can write!  Keep it coming, C.V.!

I have read almost all of CV Hunt's books. I enjoy them so immensely because they are short novellas packed with interesting characters and anecdotes. I have yet to be disappointed by her. I know I'm in for a shock and I want to be shocked.In OPS, we are faced with a somewhat odd epidemic. Not zombies. Clowns! At random, people wake up and they've changed into clowns. Their livelihood is completely ruined. Spouses pack up and leave. Children disown their parents. They lose their jobs.But unlike typical apocalyptic stories where we are trying to figure out what happened or we are trying to survive, Hunt's characters accept their fate and OPS becomes a slice-of-life story about a bunch of clowns. Yep, it's pretty disturbing.So what is a surplus of clowns supposed to do to make a living? They become public custodians. Yep, they get to clean up other people's...ahem...just as the title suggests. Let's face it. "It's" funny!And Hunt does not hold back. She paints a (brown) picture of a bunch of clowns cleaning up a public toilet. Dirty humor abounds! But the author doesn't stop there with just toilet humor... Clown bars. Drag queens. Toy vomit. Cyclists lit up like Christmas trees. Even Fred Savage. Yep, that Fred Savage.I got completely wrapped up in the "silly" story line and kept reading because I wanted to see where this was going. As I said, Hunt doesn't disappoint. Yeah, OPS is somewhat dark and dirty, but you have to respect a book about a clown epidemic that isn't only disturbing, but says a lot about the way we treat people in general based on who they are or what they do.At some point in our life, we all have to clean up other people's...

I've always liked Nivea products but usually avoided them because of the price.  Unless they are on sale or you have a coupon, their price is unattractive when there's other cheaper stuff on the market.  But you definitely get what you pay for.First, let's talk about the scent.  Nivea is different.  It's not too strong or overbearing.  It's not too sweet.  And it doesn't smell like anything else on the market.  I love that about Nivea products.  It makes it feel new or unique every time.Living in the Midwest and being a dude, I'm quick to use my usual body gel for my face and I pay for it in the winter.  My face usually feels dry, especially if I skip a shave, and can even get flaky sometimes on my forehead. Yeah, I put lotion on it, but I don't really like smothering myself in smelly lotion so that's another story.  I decided I wanted to try a true face wash instead, so I looked to Nivea.  And I found what I wanted!As I already mentioned, I love the smell and how subtle and pleasing it is.  It does not linger after you wash it off.  It does make your skin feel smooth and clean.  Though it's winter, I don't feel as if my skin is oily or shiny later in the day.  And no more dry feeling or flaky forehead either!No complaints!  I don't care about the price anymore.  I like Nivea.  I'd pay full price for it.  I'd suggest it to others too.  It works!

Nothing beats Old Fashioned Sassafras Drops. This is a great "yesterday" candy that reminds me of my childhood, and will probably remind many others. Even the bag it comes in looks nostalgic. For those who don't know, sassafras drops taste a bit like root beer barrel candy but have a softer flavor with a bit of black licorice taste mixed in.If you had it has a child but didn't know what it was called at the time, you will definitely remember it once you taste it again!  I purchased a bag through Amazon to use as a stocking stuffer for someone who loves Sassafras candy and tea. It is hard to locate these days in stores so finding it like this online was quite the treat!

This 9 piece outdoor toy tool set is great for a day at the beach, or in the sand pile at the park, or just for helping in the backyard with gardening or planting flowers. The tools are plastic and perfect for small hands. There's even a cute pair of sunglasses included. There are six tools: various shovels, scoops, a rake, and spade. Also includes a small watering can - perfect to help Mom water the flowers! All comes in a small bucket for storage, great for making sand castles too.  A very cute and inexpensive gift for the young toddler who enjoys the outdoors or the beach!

This celestial necklace would be a great gift for your star gazer, young astrologist or astronaut want-to-be, tart reader, or new age fan....as long as they like bling!  It's very bright and shiny and could even be hung in the window as a sun catcher.  The charm is about the size of a half dollar coin. The chain, with claspe, is a bit long and hangs about 18" to 20" down from the back of the neck. The chain is also a bit thin, but for the price, it's fine. Arrives in a small black bag for safe keeping.

Who doesn't like wild horses?  This necklace and charm is a perfect gift for the young cowgirl, rodeo queen, fairest of the fair, horse lover or animal lover. The pendant is quite nice.  The necklace is a bit long and thin, but for the price, it's perfect.  Arrives in a small black bag perfect for storing away safe.

This would make a great sweet sixteen gift, stocking stuffer, or birthday present for the horse or animal lover, cowgirl, or young rodeo queen. The chain is a bit thin and likely to eventually break, but for the price, the pendant is nice and will certainly be adored. The necklace comes in a small black bag, perfect to be wrapped for gift giving or to store away and keep safe.

Besides watching The Walking Dead, I tend to avoid all of the  "end of the world" hype on TV and in literature these days. Most of this was brought about by the failed predictions of the world ending in 2012, right?  And here we are, but the craze goes on. For me, what even makes The Walking Dead enjoyable is that it's not about the zombies; it's about the people.  The zombies are just a gory distraction that keeps things interesting, but the strong characterization and story lines are much more important.  We don't even know what caused the zombie outbreak, which also keeps things interesting.  And I have to say the same goes for Josh Malerman's first novel, Bird Box.Wow!  I was intrigued right from the start.  The questions I wanted answered quickly piled up and the pages kept turning!  We meet Malorie and her two children, only known as Boy and Girl, who are preparing to leave their house and go to a better place in a world that has suffered some kind of apocalyptic end. Malerman feeds us bits and pieces of the story, but leaves us as blind as his characters when it comes to knowing what has really happened.  And I mean "blind" quite literally. This outbreak is caused by "seeing something" outside, possibly a creature of some kind, that causes you to go insane and do harm to yourself and others just by looking at it.Imagine having to put on a blindfold and leave your house to go to the grocery store, or to work, or just to the neighbor's house.  Could you do it?  And you can't peek or you might see something that could kill you. Imagine never getting to look outside again.  Imagine children born in this world and not getting to play outside, or see a tree, or see an animal even. Malerman challenges his characters and builds an exciting story line simply by removing sight. And it works!  Remember every scene in an old horror movie where the girl is feeling around in the dark and we know the killer is right there beside her?  Or that scene at the end of Silence of the Lambs where Agent Starling is in the dark and Bill is watching her through his night vision goggles?  This is it, only just like the characters, the reader doesn't know what is out there either!The story is divided into two parts that are four years apart.  We have Malorie and her four year old children, who she has trained to be good listeners, having to traverse a river in a boat (while blindfolded!) to get to a safe haven. Back up four years when Malorie is pregnant and the outbreak has just started, and we follow her trying to get to a house where others have gathered for safety. Much of the book takes place in this house where Malorie interacts with a group of survivors and various everyday story lines and conflicts play out as they try to gather food and resources and make contact with others. The two story lines converge with a maddening climax at the time Malorie is giving birth!The writing is solid and believable.  While some questions are still left unanswered in the end, I was okay with that and felt the book and a satisfactory conclusion at least, and there's definitely room for a sequel. The title of the book becomes a metaphor for the situation the world is in, and Malerman gives the reader a lot to think about and digest. Like I said, I've avoided apocalyptic books for a long time, but this one intrigued me and I'm so glad I read it. I'll definitely be looking for more from this new author, and keeping my "eyes" crossed for a sequel!

I bought this dope necklace to help with my swagger (Can we say dope on the internets?). I be like wearing it around the house when I'm getting baked with my home slice crackers.  No, seriously, I bake and slice my own crackers. Better than Saltines!  Text me fo the recipe! My mama thought the green flakes on 'em was pot, but it's just oregano (Can we say pot on the internets too?). The greeter at Wal-Mart stopped me cause he be like, "Is that pistol real?"  I said, "Dawg, it's real bling, aight?!"  He be like checking out my new gold tooth too. I fooled him.  It's just a yellow Chiclet. Anyhoo, buy this necklace fo yo-self, or yo mama, or yo gurl or her mama too, or that other gurl in the trailer next door you be hitting on. Does she know you sleepin' with her mama? Peace!

Having read all of the Tales series, I was very excited to dive into what is to be the last book in the series, which as the title suggests,  catches us up on the beloved Anna Madrigal. We find Anna in her 90s, aging gracefully and still with all her wit and charm. Her storyline shines here through flashbacks to when she was "Andy" and living at the Blue Moon, a whorehouse run by his mother. We see Andy's interest in a local town boy named Lasko, and a horrible misunderstanding that Anna regrets later in life and wishes to apologize for.It's a wonderful plot line that at least keeps the book a bit interesting because the rest of the storylines are sadly not interesting at all. There's Jake, Anna's caretaker, and his boyfriend Amos. Jake is also a transexual. They want to pay homage to Anna with a giant bike at the Burning Man festival. There's Brian and Wren, who take Anna home to make amends. There's Shawna, who wants to get pregnant through insemination at the festival. And of course, there's Michael and his Beau who are off to Burning Man too. Mary Ann even pops up and makes a brief and boring appearance at the festival.One would hope that all of our favorite characters would celebrate their lives together at the festival for what could have been a wonderful reunion. Sadly, most of them don't even cross paths. While the attention is put back on Anna in the end as it should be, I still had hoped she would have at least had a last scene with Michael. Instead, it's as if Maupin forgot about them and never got around to writing that scene, or didn't know how to.There's just no drive to the story lines that keep them interesting or even suspenseful other than Anna's, which means you could skip about every two chapters and still come away satisfied knowing what happens to her. Maupin also uses crutches like Facebook, Twitter, and Craigslist sprinkled throughout to put the reader and his characters into a certain present day time. Though humorous, they stuck out like obvious cliches that everyone uses time and time again.  I've seen Maupin's pics on FB of him attending Burning Man, so it's easy to see where he drew his inspiration for that setting, but even it wasn't as interesting as it could have been.Eh, it's an okay book. I am not mad at having read it and would suggest any other Tales fan to go ahead and read it too.  It's just not the ending to the series I think most of us wanted.

Susan Boyle is back again this year with another Christmas album that at first will probably sound like her previous Christmas album, The Gift, to you. When I first listened to it, nothing stood out to me other than the duets with Elvis Presley and Johnny Mathis which are both splendid! Surprisingly, there's only one song that shows up on both albums.And that's my biggest (and only) complaint, not just with this album, but with any "classic" Christmas album like it. I want to be blown away with an original Christmas song that I know I'll be hearing each and every year on the radio at this time of year. (Remember Mariah Carey's Christmas album?) While I appreciate the classics, I'd love for someone to write an original song just for Susan.Like so many others, I have followed Susan's path to fame since day one and I love a good story like hers where we are quick to judge someone by looks and they completely prove us wrong!  To me, she completely deserves all the fame and fortune.  I will continue to buy her albums, original or not, as long as she continues to record. And yeah, I'm happy to add this one to my classic collection and will pull it out again next year and enjoy it just the same.  It is a good heartfelt album.

Kim Fu's short novella, For Today I Am Boy, explores one Chinese boy's struggle with gender and his place in society.  Peter is the only son of a Chinese family living in Canada, though he wishes he was a girl. Fu has a talent for painting interesting pictures  and scenes with very few words and I was immediately drawn into Peter's story and wanted to know more.We see Peter in the shadow of his domineering father, or as a young boy amongst his other male school mates. When he becomes a young man, we are with him at his first job as he faces a very sincere but tough boss in a restaurant kitchen, and later as he moves away from home to be on his own, keeping very little contact with anyone other than his sisters as he forms intimate relationships with the opposite sex while exploring his own identity.Fu gives colorful detail into her canvas of secondary characters, making them almost more interesting than Peter. There is a strange neighbor who shares a secret with Peter's dad.  There is Ollie, Peter's classmate who takes Peter to the gym- we get to see a very heartfelt scene between them when Ollie questions Peter's sexuality at school! Or Peter's boss, Chef, who proudly had sex with a transgendered man once!  And Margie, Peter's older sadist lover who treats Peter like a toy. And then there are Peter's sisters, who all accept and protect Peter for who he is early on while they live at home.The book is only ten chapters long at 289 pages and sadly, it is a bit disjointed.  Each chapter reads like a wonderful piece of memoir, but there are holes in between and parts of Peter's story that go unexplored until the very end. I found myself more interested in learning about the other people in Peter's lives, or what his sisters were doing, because Peter's story wasn't revealing what I really wanted to know. My heart went out to his mother in one late chapter where she is facing prejudice at the border for trying to come into the U.S. to visit her daughter, though she'd lived in Canada for 40 years. Scenes like this gave the book so much depth!Notice I'm still giving the book a 4 star rating though. It captivated me, and though it wasn't a very satisfying read when it came to Peter, it was enough to keep me reading.  This might be a respectful book to give to someone young who might be facing a sexual identity crisis of their own. I certainly appreciated it for a look into a Chinese family's life, ruled by a traditional father, but with children eager to explore what's out there for them in today's world. It made me think about prejudice in this world, racial or sexual, and any book that makes me think is worth my time.

I have been a Capote fan since high school, have read almost all of his work (including In Cold Blood), and have seen both recent films based on his time spent in Kansas (Capote in 2005 and Infamous in 2006).  While researching a project of my own, I decided it was time to read Ralph F. Voss's book also devoted to Capote and his time spent in Kansas.While it is a well researched book (30% of the text is Voss's notes and bibliography), there is nothing new here for readers like me who are already well versed in the topic of Capote's real-time research of the Clutter murders, the capture and trial of the killers, their execution, all culminating with the publication of In Cold Blood.I would highly recommend this book to a new person who has just become interested in the topic, perhaps someone who has just finished reading In Cold Blood, but has not seen any of the movies or read anything else; someone who is intrigued and now wants to dive a bit deeper into it. If that's you, then this book is a gold mine.For the others out there like me who are a bit more familiar with all of it, you might find yourself bored. Voss's style of writing reads more like an essay or public speech: "In the next chapter, I will argue this" or "As I stated in chapter 6â³ and"I will now discuss this."  You are constantly reminded of the author's presence and opinion, which gave the book a rough edge for me.Another problem is that after Voss pinpoints his lead sources of inspiration (movies and books), he spends quite a bit of time just regurgitating their plot lines and discussing their elements like a book reviewer or movie critic would. Obviously, he discusses In Cold Blood in detail, along with its 1960s movie, the 1990s television remake, the film Capote of 2005, Infamous of 2006, Gerald Clarke's Capote biography, George Plimpton's book on Capote; and for some odd reason Kim Powers' fictional book Capote in Kansas of 2008, and even the comic book version of 2006 - spelling out every detail of how they are different and giving his opinion of how they relate to the real life facts, even though the latter two are complete fiction!  Again, this made for quite a tedious read, filling up pages with information that interested readers might want to find out on their own, if they haven't already.Am I glad I read this book?  Yes.  There are several pictures sprinkled throughout the text, some taken by Voss in Kansas which I had not seen before. And, being a diehard Capote fan, I always appreciate hearing someone else's thoughts on Capote and his "infamous" work. Is there anything new here for fans like me? Not really, but you might want to take a stab at it anyway.

This is a short story written as "tweets" from a young girl returning from vacation with her parents and younger brother. They stop at a "dead" zombie circus and things get bizarre from there. These kinds of stories have been done before, so it's not too original, but Joe Hill gives it a new twist that was decent. A quick read that Hill, Horror, or Twitter fans will enjoy.

I'm not much of a biography reader but having grown up watching Sesame Street and The Muppets back when we only had 3 or 4 channels on a bunny-earred TV (and PBS was fortunately one of them), I have always had a soft spot in my heart for Henson's work. So I knew I wanted to read this bio!Due out this year on what would be his 77th birthday, this book is definitely for the serious bio reader. There are not a ton of pictures (an insert and a picture at the beginning of each chapter), but you do get a well-rounded, well-researched look at who this man was.  The author had complete cooperation from Henson's family and friends, and had access to many of his personal effects and papers.The book starts with how Henson's parents met and settled in Mississippi, tracing Henson's creativity back to a relative in the Civil War, and shows how Henson was raised a kind and patient man with Christian Scientist roots. There was always laughter in their house. His parents were hard workers too so it's easy to see where Henson got his determination. You also learn where he got his creativity from - he was a very imaginative child and was encouraged by his grandmother.This book is pretty much a linear timeline of Henson's life, which chapters devoted to Sesame Street, Sam and Friends, The Muppet Show, each Muppet movie, The Dark Crystal, etc. It definitely takes patience to read it. But there are some real gems sprinkled throughout the text. In the first chapter, we learn The Wizard of Oz was his favorite movie (it came out when he was just three), but he was more afraid of the MGM lion roaring at the start of the movie. We also get behind-the-scene glimpses of the Muppets and Sesame Street that are noteworthy, like reading how all the sets were elevated six feet off the ground so the puppeteers could stand up while operating the Muppets. Or how the director would yell "Blue Sky!" when a child came on the set to alert adults to watch their language (though Henson hardly ever said a cuss word). We learn how Kermit was born and got his name. Or that the Muppets partly got their name from a TV listing that was badly copy-edited. I loved the personal glimpse into his early professional relationship with Jane when they were doing "Sam and Friends."I especially liked the chapter about how young Jim loved TV and just wanted to work in television back in the early 1950s.  He was more interested in being artistic and working on set design or publicity.  He excelled in college in theater doing set design and doing publicity artwork. He learned puppetry by checking two books out at the library in order to audition for a TV show looking to hire a puppeteer, and of course the rest is history though Jim kept trying to get out of puppets and into show design.And of course, there's a personal glimpse into Henson's life. We learn about the creation of our beloved Muppet characters. We find out Henson loved women, and loved to collect art and fast cars. You'll learn about his early work with the Muppets on SNL and how he strived to get his characters their own show, and obviously succeeded.  And then of course there's quite a bit about the eventual sale of the franchise to Disney and also Henson's untimely death which happened on the day the sale was to be final. The man really was a creative genius who worked very hard for his small company, and in the end, that's all he wanted to do was be creative, be an artist.Henson is very much the man I expected he was. My one problem with reading bios is whether or not I trust the author, and I must say I completely have faith in Brian Jay Jones' work here.  It is well written, entertaining, and thorough. I also love a book that has me researching things on my own - I went to YouTube numerous times to watch old Muppet segments that are mentioned in the book and even bought the first Muppet movie on BluRay. For those expecting more pictures or more concise background information related to the Muppet characters themselves, there are other better books on the market. For those who want to get to know the man behind them, this bio is for you!

I love blackberry anything and love blackberry sage tea even more. I've been drinking Republic for at least thirteen years now, first introduced to it when we sold it and served it in a bookstore where I worked. Republic of Tea is the best brand by far, and worth the price. Yes, it is a bit higher than some basic teas on the market but you get what you pay for. I enjoy it hot or cold.One single bag will do for a single cup to sip. If you are going to make a larger batch of cold tea, I suggest boiling about 5 bags together in a few cups of water, or add them to a gallon to sit out for sun tea. I enjoy it with sugar or honey.I love keeping the tin afterwords to store buttons or coins in. My favorites are Ginger Peach, Mango Ceylon, and of course, the Blackberry Sage. I can honestly say I don't care for anything else that is mango flavored other than Republic. And their Blackberry is one of the best!If you are new to tea or a loyal tea sipper, I highly recommend Republic of Tea if you haven't tried it already. I have never been dissatisfied by any of their products.

I never knew Stephenie Meyer wrote anything besides Twilight until I saw a coworker reading The Host one day. She told me it was Meyer's attempt at writing something for a more mature audience. I knew I wasn't going to read it, but I did want to see the movie when it hit DVD.The concept is that aliens have taken over most of earth. They are a peaceful race and humans serve as hosts for the alien souls. The conflict arises from a group of humans who live in hiding who are confronted by one of their own who was recently captured, all while the alien seekers are trying to find them. Could an alien switch sides?  Is it possible for the human soul to still be alive inside their body? If so, can the human soul interact with the alien now living in its body?Saoirse Ronan does a great job in the lead as Melanie (the human) and Wanda (the alien). Her voice is in a slightly different register to help you determine which is speaking, though only the alien as function of her mouth when she takes over, and Melanie is an interval voice. She is surrounded by a young cast of mostly unknowns - but that's pretty much how the cast of Twilight started out too. I did recognize Boyd Holbrook only because I'd watched him on The Big C and recently in Behind the Candelabra.For those who prefer their alien fiction a little more fast paced, blow-them-up, giant space craft, war-type films, you'll hate The Host. There is nothing more than a bit of blood shed. The aliens themselves are even tiny, white, sea urchin-looking things. If you are looking for a different and interesting teenage romance, Meyer has served you that dish again just as she did with her previous books.  And there are some new and interesting concepts here when it comes to the whole romance thing: Melanie's lover, Jared, is there in the group. And another member of the group falls in love with Wanda. How does Melanie get Jared, her young brother, and the group to realize that she's still alive in there? Can they save her? What will happen to the alien?There are also a lot of underlying themes about the soul and reincarnation to explore here, which really makes this a serious and phenomenal film. Look past the young inexperienced cast and the fumbling romance stuff, and you will be rewarded with a film that is worth the watch. There's a great line in the film where the humans have been experimenting violently with extracting the aliens from the humans.  Wanda tells them it will come out peacefully if they just basically ask it to. It's very true of the way humans look upon those who are different or those who could be a threat. We act out in anger.Like everyone else, I loved making fun of Twilight even though I watched all four films.  The Host has given me a new respect for Meyer if she continues to write stuff like this.

What a wonderful treat this short book was! I have to admit I almost abandoned it early on.  It's the slow detailed account of two estranged sisters who haven't seen each other in over fifty years. Over a period of four days, the story of their earlier lives together unfolds against a backdrop of lepidopterology (the study of moths) which was the family namesake.We meet Virginia, the lepidopterist of the family and the narrator, who took over in her father's footsteps while sister Vivian moved away and married. Virginia remained in the family's aging mansion, and now Vivian has chose to return after all these years. Through Virginia's eyes, we slowly learn of their mother's alcoholism and other dark matters in the family that led to Vivian staying away all this time.While Virginia prattles on in long bouts about moths and bugs, she suddenly throws in shocking hints as to what happened between her and her loved ones, all while obsessing over why her sister has come back.  And that's what kept me reading!  I wanted answers.Like others here, I was a bit let down by the ending - right up to that last chapter was fine. And that's the only reason I'm giving this four stars instead of five. For those who love dark secretive family drama, complete with decrepit old houses crawling with bugs, this book is for you.  I couldn't put it down.

I dabbled in tarot years ago and had the plain Rider-Waite set that at the time came with two guide books in a nice box set. I lost interest in the cards, and apparently lost the cards too, until recently when a tarot reading (using the Rider-Waite) revealed I was a bit intuitive and that I should consider reading the tarot. I thought that was odd because it was the second time in my life that a reading had revealed that. I already had several books on the shelf and picked up another the day of that reading.  So, now it was time to buy a new set of cards.I chose this deck mainly just to have something a bit different from the regular set without straying completely from it. The "Radiant" part of their title really just refers to enhanced color. All of the cards are still based on the original version as far as the pictures go. So, I would definitely suggest this deck to anyone who is looking to buy the basic deck, or someone who might want something a bit "prettier" to look at. As you have probably heard before, it needs to be the deck that speaks to you.However, the tiny guidebook including won't be enough if you are serious about learning the tarot like I am.  Pick up two or three basic instruction books - there are several on the market.  Thumb through them and try to stick with the ones that show the Rider-Waite pictured inside. Most of your basic starter books do.

I admit I found this app on my cell phone minutes before I turned my phone off to go into an actual tarot reading. It was the first reading I'd had done in at least thirteen years or so. During the reading, the psychic told me I was intuitive and that I should explore that.  That's the second time a tarot reader had told me that. I dabbled with the tarot back in high school and enjoyed doing spreads for friends, but I always had to consult the book as I was learning, and I eventually abandoned the cards as I became interested in other things. But I've always believed in the power of tarot and remained interested in it, wishing I had kept it up.I'd forgotten about the app until I got home and turned my phone back on and it had finished downloading. So, I began to explore it. It uses the traditional Rider-Waite tarot cards as a reference. You can pick the cards and study the meaning of each one using the tarot encyclopedia, or you can actually do spreads and pick cards at random. The cards actually turn over as you tap them. Tap them again and they fill the screen so you can examine them up close. Tap them again and the meaning of each card pops up. It also teaches you what the placement in the spread means. You can also draw one single random card at a time to study or learn about.  And there's a galaxy profile where you can view the card of the day, upgrade to save spreads, change card themes and more.The set up of this app is magnificent.  It's easy to use and you can even begin using it right away with no instruction. For someone like me who wants to learn the tarot more thoroughly, it's the perfect way to study the cards on the go. I downloaded the app on my phone and on my Kindle Fire and I've used it almost every day since. It even inspired me to buy a new deck of cards. For those who want to stay plugged in and might not have time to read an actual book about tarot, this is the perfect app to get started.Definitely one of the best apps I've downloaded as far as simplicity, set-up, color, art, graphics, information, and use go!  I highly recommend it.

Like most of the recent reviews, I recently read this book because of the HBO movie based on it which was released this year. For what it's worth, I knew the story from the headlines having grown up reading about Liberace in the National Enquirer of all things.I became even more fascinated by him after watching Liberace: Behind The Music when it came on TV many years ago when I was very young.  I've since gone back and watched some of it again and discovered how horrible that version of the story was. Scott Thorson was barely mentioned in it, but again, that was more of Liberace's side of the story and we now know he lived a double life.I can honestly say I wasn't all that thrilled with the HBO version either, though it follows Scott's book practically verbatim. Even some of the dialogue was right from the book!  But, I still wanted to read the book itself and I'm glad I did. Scott's writing comes off as a bit glittery and gossipy at times, but that was definitely the world of Liberace!  Otherwise, he's very candid and I feel he's being honest.I felt so sorry for him. Being a foster kid, he had a rough life before he met Lee, so suddenly having a companion and father figure in his life who gave him everything seemed like he'd had the world literally handed to him. Unfortunately, it was Lee's perversion and materialism, tempered with Scott's own drug addiction, that tore the relationship apart. Scott accepts just as much blame here and it's so sad to read how alone he felt when Lee cheated on him and then kicked him out.The story also serves as a historical reminder of how different our world was back then when it came to AIDS and homosexuality. Lee publicly lived a lie his whole life and would stop at nothing to make sure his sexuality was kept a secret. His materialistic greed and "showmanship" was to be expected - look at the costumes and oddball things Elvis and Michael Jackson wore and bought.  I was also surprised to see Lee's true thoughts about his mother - I'd previously believed he was very close to his Mom, but that too was a sad facade. He felt very free after she passed.What's even sadder is the new afterword written by Scott where he briefly tells you what has happened to him since then. He's battled drugs, cancer, crime, and desperately needed money; he admits to writing the book for a paycheck. And he also still feels the pain of Liberace's rejection to this day. Overall, this is a very private and honest look at one of the world's most bizarre and popular entertainers - well worth the read if you have interest in Lee and Scott's story or not.

I have a bird-themed office with cork boards on the wall, so these pins were a perfect accent to pinning pictures and keepsakes up on the wall. My only complaint, which is very very minor, is that the pins are so small (under an inch). But the size listed in the description is accurate so I knew that before I bought them. It's just the nice picture of them here really shows the detail up close and larger than the actual pins. But, I'm still very happy with them and would even buy another set for myself or for a friend. They are a lovely substitute to plain old push pins.

Harry Bosch and Mickey Haller team up again, but Harry is clearly in the lead. They don't see eye to eye on the case either. A mismatch of brothers.Crossing: retired detective Bosch crosses over from the cop camp to become a defense investigator in a murder case, working for lawyer Haller. Defense, in Harry's view, is the dark side. Gross. His old world of righteous defenders of the law will ostracize him. Innocence of the accused is irrelevant.That's not the only line Harry crosses. His methods don't always stay this side of legal. That accounts for a share of the suspense and causes its own legal complications, though in the end it is the goal that counts, not the way there, right?He also tends to cross the boundaries of his teen daughter's sensitivities. Daughters are foreign territory. Harry can't figure out her thinking. One sympathizes.Crossing is also an issue in the case(s): where and when did the alleged killer's path ever cross the victim's? Is there a motive? Was there even opportunity?Why does the surveillance car cross the highway lane to cut the biker's ride and push him out?Has the murdered cross-dressing prostitute double-crossed his client? Are we supposed to believe that was the cause of his death? Did he know too much?That the cosmetic surgeon crossed his line and had sex with a much worked on patient is not particularly surprising, apart from esthetic aspects.All in all, Harry and Mickey are an appealing team. Connelly has produced a strong procedural detective story, again.I am not particularly keen on the narrative method that injects the odd chapter where action is seen from the opposition's view. That has become rather common in many crime novels, but I don't like it much.

This Booker winner is another big disappointment. Centerpiece of the story is the 1976 assassination attempt against Bob Marley in Jamaica, in the middle of a civil war in the middle of Cold War. We hear from slum bosses, gangsters, reporters, CIA operatives, groupies.... It is a cacophony of voices that doesn't really come together to form an interesting plot.  Or anything else that could keep my interest. There is more life and suspense in an average Wikipedia entry. My stamina carried me half way through the nearly 700 pages. There are better things to do.Much overrated.

A new contribution to the biographical exploration of Vladimir Nabokov.The groundbreaking Nabokov bio was the two volume work by Newzealander Brian Boyd. Volume 2 was called, somewhat misleadingly, The American Years, though Nabokov spent his final nearly two decades in Switzerland.This new book is an update on the American Years. That's legitimate. New details will usually come to light while time goes by, and that may justify new biographies. This book begins in Europe, tracing the attempts of the family to escape from Hitler to America. We get there by chapter 3.A core theme of VN's American years was his lepidoptera addiction. We get a lot of that, combined with road trip research. It gives me ideas for my own road trips.Main subject though is the writing of Lolita and the related travelsThe author seems to like wandering off on tangents. Example: the Nabokovs join another couple for a vacation... And now we are given a biographical summary of the other man, for no obvious reason. The man has no particular importance for the life of the Nabokovs and never shows up again.The important question, whether the preoccupation with young girls, that can be found in more than one of VN's fictional piece, not just in Lolita, is based on real life inclinations or experiences, is relegated to the end notes. The answer is 'no, but'. Not quite satisfactory.Another core subject: the rise and fall of the Wilson friendship. Nabokov's interaction with literary czar Edmund Wilson was a highly entertaining soap opera. It gives a lively touch to the narration.Another important subject: family issues - the affair in France in the 30s that nearly broke the marriage with Vera; the role of magnificent Vera in VN's career;  the growing up of son Dimitri; the relationship with parents and siblings. Was Dimitri a CIA agent? No conclusive evidence.I am always happy to read about Nabokov, and therefore this wasn't boring for me, but did I learn new things? Not so much, I think. Some additional details, sure. Like: VN had a 'true crime' case as a model for Lolita. Around 1950 a man had abducted an 11 years old girl and travelled the country with her, including sending her to school during the trip, until he was caught. VN took some aspects of that sad story and grafted them on his Enchanter tale from the 1930s.Also: interesting comparisons of Lolita with The Catcher in the Rye, as well as with Eugen Onegin, as well as with Moby Dick. Less convincing ones to Hamsun and Faulkner.Less enticing: a little too much on contents and interpretation of Lolita, Pnin, and Pale Fire, the three main pieces of fiction written by VN in America. I didn't need that.

Pramoedya Ananta Toer was an outstanding phenomenon in Indonesian literature. No other writer came close to his epic force, social awareness, plotting skill, and psychological realism. That the Nobel committee by-passed him, often for second rate writers, is a shame.This novel is the first volume in the Buru quartet, which was conceived on Indonesia's prison island in the 1970s. It is set in Surabaya in the early years of Queen Wilhelmina' s reign on the Dutch throne, the late 19th century.The world is on the threshold of modern times. Science, technology, industry are entering even Indonesia, then called Dutch East India, a colonial backwater. The native Javanese society stews in its own world, oblivious of modern times. This colonial society is a layer cake, similar to a caste system.The narrator Minke is a young man, the only native student at a Dutch high school. He observes the world of the Dutch and of the 'intermediate' stratum of the 'Indos', the Eurasian mixed population. He comes from a family with 'royalty roots'.He falls in love with Annelies, an Indo girl, daughter of a Dutch agro-industrialist and his native concubine. The girl's mother is an outstanding personality; she is the manager of the business. Mother and daughter are endlessly puzzling to Minke, who marvels at their lack of conventionality. The father of the family is dysfunctional, sidelined in the business by Ann's mother. There is a mystery here.Despite his feelings for the girl, Minke has doubts about his relationship with that family, due to the mother's dubious social standing. Her life story is a major part of the plot. She is a victim of conventions and circumstances. As a concubine, her legal status is nil. She sees herself as a slave, having been sold by her parents as a teenager.Minke's name is another mystery. He doesn't disclose his real name, and he doesn't know what 'Minke' means. The name was given him by a Dutch teacher. The vicinity to 'monkey' is mentioned, with a hint at colonial racism.Minke's time with Ann's family is interrupted by demands from his own parents. His father has been promoted to a senior administration position and summons his son away from his shady friends. Minke is caught in a conflict between tradition and his modernist ideals.The temporary separation has dramatic impact on the young girl, which increases the pressure on poor Minke. The final plot twists in this first of four volumes involve a case of murder and a clash of colonial law with native law and with common sense.Pramoedya first told the story while in prison, with no writing material. Later, in house arrest, he wrote it down. The English translation was done by an attachÃ© at the Australian Embassy. The man lost his job over it. At second reading, after 30 years, I am even more impressed than I was then, possibly because this stands out so high above other Indonesian writing.

During WW2, China and the US were allies. When the war was over, friendship ended. That's a short summary of a complex and complicated piece of history. This book is a good, solid attempt at cutting through the maze towards a fair assessment of the problems and the mistakes made.Hindsight still debates a few crucial questions. How bad a leader was Chiang Kai-shek  really? Could he have won the civil war if the Americans had supported him properly? Did American disaffection with CKS make the US 'lose China'? Or was it a communist conspiracy that operated from inside the USA? Could America have handled Mao & Co better and avoided the conflicts that resulted in the Korea and Vietnam Wars?Bernstein's book is an interesting treatise on the subject. Some of his convictions:CKS wasn't all bad. His strategy to beat the communists before committing to a full fight against the Japanese invasion was right in view of resources and outlook. He could have made it, had he not been forced into a pseudo cooperation with Mao against the Japanese. That allowed the communists to survive and wrestle national power from the KMT after the war.It is unjust to claim, as Vinegar Joe Stilwell did, that CKS did not let his army fight against Japan. In fact, serious battles were fought in earnest, with many losses. After all, China was never fully occupied, but held out in large parts, tying down Japanese armies.Stilwell lacked insight into the Chinese power struggle and he lacked diplomatic skills.Without doubt, this negative attitude towards CKS at the end of the war led to reduced support and thus to the communist victory. Explaining this by a communist conspiracy inside the American camp is however not justified. There was much honest misjudgment. Stilwell was not the only wrong appointment.American attitudes towards 'Chiang vs Mao' were based on wishful thinking and produced a self-fulfilling prophecy. The Chinese communists were not the reasonable bunch that a half informed comparison to the ineffective, corrupt and vicious Nationalist rule had suggested. Expecting the Communists to win the civil war facilitated just that.Anyway, the claim that the USA 'lost China' is based on illusions over the American influence in the world.Anyway, the key pre-condition for the communist victory in China had been the Japanese invasion.  The KMT would otherwise very likely have crushed the communists.Anyway, the fate of Sino-American friendship was ultimately decided elsewhere. The war in Europe came to an end. The Soviets invaded Manchuria and made the communist victory practically unavoidable, unless the USA was prepared to provide massive military and manpower support to the KMT. Truman's priority was different: get American soldiers out of this war. Demobilization. Not another big war.The American alliance with Uncle Joe, in which FDR had believed fervently and naively, came unstuck and turned into its opposite. Cold War started. Riens ne va plus between China and the USA, for a while.George Marshall's last ditch effort to avoid civil war by negotiating a compromise was based on wrong understandings of the relations between the antagonists and therefore hopelessly stillborn, though false hopes had flared up briefly.(One serious error needs correction: on page 349 it is said that the May Fourth Movement preceded World War 1. Absolutely not.)

'Any man who would change the World in a significant way must have showmanship, a genial willingness to shed other people's blood, and a plausible new religion....'A spaceship called Whale takes Jonah (a temporary name of its billionaire owner) to Mars. Later, under other names, he will travel onwards to Mercury, and finally to Titan, where three impressive beauties, the sirens of the title, are waiting and have been promised to our hero, who is a womanizer.This is prophesied by another rich man, who furthermore predicts that our hero will become a father on Mars, with the role of mother allocated to Mrs. Prophet, who is quite reluctant about the whole thing. The prophet turns out to be he who would change the world in a significant way, the founder of the Church of God the Utterly Indifferent. His prophecies never fail.Sounds like science fiction to you? One could classify it like that, but there is really not much 'science' here, though some of the phantastic devices in the story look remarkably real.Anyway, mostly satire, or silliness. Vonnegut's view of business, politics, religion, and all that. As per 1969. I think I was a little childish myself, then.Coming back to the space trip. What on earth is its purpose? Quoting Monty Python: what does it mean? Exactly. Right answer. The meaning of life. You will like the book if you don't need answers. Does that make it nonsense? Probably, but let us leave that question open.The story belongs vaguely in the category of fiction like the magnificent Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy, and has elements of the Matrix film plot. Consider it an imperfect precursor to greater things.I am glad that I finally learned the meaning of Stonehenge. Turns out it is an intergalactic message telling a stranded cosmic astronaut: Replacement part being rushed with all possible speed.Will the spare part arrive in time? No spoilers here!

Magical realism, rather surprisingly, isn't dead yet. Here we have a specimen from Indonesia, and it is quite alive. Kurniawan's  Macondo is called Halimunda and is located on the South Coast of Java.Author Eka Kurniawan has been touted by some international observers as the first worthy successor of Pramoedya Ananta Toer. Well, I don't know, really. Granted, there is not that much serious competition. Indonesia is not a reading country.After giving birth to her fourth daughter, at the ripe age of 50, the heroine Dewi Ayu, a prostitute with an attitude, decides to die. She lies down and it takes her 12 days to get it done. 21 years later, she changes her mind and rises from the grave. Sort of a zombie, not the only one here.The baby had been unusually ugly, which must have been caused by her mother 's curses at her pregnancy. Javanese voodoo.Beauty is a wound? Women, especially beautiful ones like Dewi Ayu and her first 3 daughters, get raped with shocking frequency in this novel. It is a message, but hard to put up with.Dewi Ayu's and her daughters' life stories are placed in historical context: Dutch colonialism (Dewi is an Indo, a mix of Dutch and Malay), World War 2 and the Japanese (Dewi spends years in a Japanese pow camp, becomes a comfort woman), independence struggles of the new nation Indonesia, political troubles in the framework of the global Cold War, the Suharto dictatorship, the Timor war....But don't expect an historical treatise. Flights of fantasy and hyperbole run wild, putting Kurniawan in the world of Rushdie and GarcÃ­a Marquez. Dewi is a fearless, practical and shameless woman. We find reason to admire her courage, but most of her person remains outside the realm of realism and plausibility. Much of the fantasy elements of the story is on loan from traditional Indonesian sagas and fairy tales.
