I played for a few hours and didn't experience any type of pain in my hands from prolonged use.I used this controller to play Rayman and some Nintendo classic games and it was hard for me to figure out which button did which at first.  Once I got the hang of it though it was easy to use and click the buttons you intended to.  All were easily reachable and while I have small-average size hands for an adult I had plenty of room which makes me think that the average child should be ok to use this controller as well.  I had the buttons set up for the toggles and arrow button to control direction, A and B performed the same function (jump) and the two x buttons were the same function (hit).  The left and right top buttons also performed the same function (run).I was a bit surprised to see a wire on this controller.  I thought they all were wireless anymore.  But this was almost wireless in that it plugged into the Wii remote to use.  So you didn't need to be close to the console, which was a relief as the cord is not that long.  You do however HAVE to have the wii remote to use it.  At least on my Wii U, there is nowhere to plug directly into the console.Bright red and blue, the ability to not have to use the remote or game pad, this definitely made using the Wii U a lot easier for me.  As someone who's stuck in the past, this controller made my playing experience a little more enjoyable.  And now I may have a hope of beating my boyfriend when Smash Brothers is released.Review by M. Reynard 2014

I like the Brainwavz brand.  I've tried some other earbuds from them in the past and ended up using them every day at work.  This set is ok, but I can't say I like them nearly as well.The Brainwavz Delta are the economy style from the company.  They have a cheap price point and are the every day "throwaway" type of earbuds that people sometimes buy.  The kind that if you lose, you're not going to be up nights crying about the loss.  These earbuds come in a plastic box with the buds themselves, 4 sets of ear tips, and an instruction manual.  Pretty basic set.  The plug is a 3.5mm L-Plug and it has a y-cable for the cord.  They also come with a warranty.For sound clarity these are good.  I don't ever really hear the difference between expensive end earbuds and regular, unless there's a lot of static so I can't say these sound less than a set of more expensive ones would.  But there's no static and everything seems to come through pretty clear.  I have no complaints on the audio.  The cord is a typical cord and gets tangled occasionally as it isn't really tangle proof.My complaints actually come in the form of these earbuds.  While the tips fit comfortably in my ears, there is a purple cap on the end of them that my hair LOVES to get caught in.  I've ripped out strands more than a few times.  So these are not earbuds that someone with long hair (i.e. past their ears) would probably want to wear.  It gets wrapped in there and then when you try to take them off you get an unpleasant surprise.  People with short hair will probably enjoy these earbuds as they won't have that problem.Not my favorite, anything that pulls my hair out presents an issue to me.  But in terms of audio quality these are first-rate and I like Brainwavz as a company.  I would just recommend their Brainwavz S1 headphones.  More expensive but the same great audio quality and they don't rip your hair out.**This product was received as a free advanced reviewer's sample**Review by M. Reynard 2014

I go through kitchen towels pretty quick.  Having cast iron will do that to a person.  Although I try not to use white colored towels to do any cleaning on those pans.  But I'm sure everyone, regardless of cast iron collection or not, finds themselves going through towels pretty quick if they spend any decent amount of time in the kitchen.So you would think that a pack of four towels would be a decent deal, especially for a price in the mid-teens.  But in my opinion, these towels aren't quite worth it for the price.  Four towels came in this set and right away I thought they had a nice bright color.  The red stood out well and the pattern of boxes is pretty standard for a kitchen.  They are also quite large, which is a boon.Absorbancy was good.  I used the towels to wipe up a variety of spills, dry hands, etc. and have no complaints on that part.  They also tackled grease pretty well.  Any non clear liquid shows up pretty well on these though, due to the white color of the towel, but that's to be expected.  Which brings me to washing the towel.  The stains came out of the towel reasonably well after washing.  The problem with washing these, especially since it says they are machine washable, is that the hem became completely thready after one washing.  It looks like my cat went to town on the towel and pulled out every loose thread she could (which she actually didn't, that's just what it looks like).  I would hazard a guess that some very quick sewing went into these hems.  And it's happened on all of the towels that I've washed, not just one so it wasn't a fluke.These were no better than a set of towels you could get at a big box store.  And considerably more expensive than those same towels would be at that store.  So I can't say that I recommend these.  They absorb ok, but have some other issues that make their value less than their price point.Review by M. Reynard 2014

Maybe if I had read the author's first book I would have been more charmed by this one.  Certainly the author was genuine and had done some off the beaten path type of things with her life.  But I just couldn't find a connection or really appreciate the story she had to tell.Having lived in Afghanistan and then leave abruptly when her son is threatened with kidnapping, Rodriguez finds herself back in the states struggling to make sense of what happened.  She stays for awhile with a friend turned a little more until he decides he's had enough of the relationship.  And then it's off to Mazatlan Mexico where she buys a little house and settles down to try to pull the pieces of her life together.  Here she makes new friends but still feels as if something is missing, and with personal problems, family problems, and other problems, peace sometimes seems unobtainable.Rodriguez can be pretty blunt about herself at times.  Especially when it comes to her choices in men.  She is very frank about all her mistakes there.  And her two sons, while seemingly important to her, actually feature very little in her life.  Yes, one comes and lives with her, but that's when she starts describing him in detail and showing a sense of caring.  She has a lot of drama.  And it gets tiring.  You want to just shake her and say why do you keep doing this to your life?  The other characters she describes nicely though and she usually has something nice to say about almost all of them.This book is drama.  It's disguised by the fact that it's about moving to Mexico and becoming part of the community there.  But really it's about Rodriguez's personal struggles and how she tries to overcome them.  Mexican culture is a second, although through her interactions with her son's married family help bring the culture to the reader.  She also mentions her first book a lot and that gets a little tiring.  After about the fifth mention, it's like, "ok, you have a book about the beauty school you started in Afghanistan.  That's fantastic, and wonderful for those women, but you've told me this before."  It's obvious she's very proud of it, but redundant after awhile.This is an ok memoir.  A little too much drama for me and not enough description of everything else.  I'm sure those who read the first book though will find it much more absorbing.**This book was won in a Goodreads Giveaway**Margarita WednesdaysCopyright 2014276 pagesReview by M. Reynard 2014

I never used to wear aprons when cooking.  But then I discovered I'm somewhat of a klutz and messy in the kitchen, so they're great for protecting my clothes from oil stains, etc.  And this one had such pretty colors that I couldn't resist.  But I can't say I'd ever recommend it to anyone.  Way too many features about this apron that made it not quite as good as it could have been.Let's talk about the fabric on this for one.  It's a beautiful chocolate brown with a light blue sashing, straps and light blue polka dots on it.  No complaint about the colors, I think they go very nicely with each other.  However, the texture of the apron is a little disturbing.  It feels like the stuff you put on picnic tables.  Kind of that waterproofed oil cloth feeling.  Only the fabric is very thin.  I understand that this is to prevent stains, but it feels like you're wearing a paper apron.  It's not a pleasant texture.  And it also means that this apron is supposed to be hand washed only (yeah right, into the washer it went with no issues!).  No apron should be hand-washed.  They get far too dirty for that to be convenient.  In all, I find it kind of hard to believe that it is 100% cotton, because it sure doesn't feel like it.The fit is supposed to be one size fits all.  But I'm not sure what that optimal size would be.  I'm 5'7" and 130lbs and while I easily could get the strings around to tie a bow in front, it still bulged out in the front and made me look like I was smuggling something inside the apron.  And it bunched on my hips a little strangely as well.  Not a big deal if you're just cooking and staying clean, but since this is advertised as "flirty" it definitely didn't make me feel flirty while I was wearing it.  There is a pocket on the apron, but I don't use pockets and it seemed kind of deep for any kind of functional use.I think for the price point this apron is about twice as expensive as it should be.  While it's pretty, I'm not convinced it is functional and I'll probably use my other apron (that has softer fabric and fits nicer) more than I would ever use this one.  This is great if all you're doing is putting it on to host a party, but it has no meaningful utility in the kitchen.Review by M. Reynard 2014

I'm fairly convinced that this book wasn't edited.  Or at least if it was, it was a rush job.  While it was interesting subject matter, the way it was written and the numerous mistakes and spelling errors made it hard reading.Mistresses of Mayhem is a resource book that describes some of the most famous women criminals in history and the present.  In fact, some of the women featured in this book are still alive while others have been dead for hundreds of years.  There are murderers, prostitutes, and even pirates.  Background on each of the women is given, and the events of their crimes are provided.There are some bad ladies in here.  And a good one that had charges against her dropped.  And some who there are doubts about their guilt and undecided charges against them.  Because their backgrounds are provided, there is some speculation into why they did the crimes that they did.  Although their history doesn't always account for the terrible things that they did.  I hadn't heard of the majority of the women in here, and some of their stories definitely came as a shock.  It's enough to make you want to wish it was fiction.This would have been a great reference book, except it didn't really read as a standard non-fiction reference book.  There was tons of personal opinion in it  I'm always a little skeptical if in a book that's supposed to be non-fiction, the term "white trash" is used several times along with other non-professional names and descriptors.  It also had numerous spelling errors, places where you can tell a "find and replace" feature was used incorrectly, and probably the worst of all, some facts actually weren't recorded correctly (IE: two sisters names are reversed leaving the wrong one dead in the book).  An editing read-through would have caught a lot of these errors, so I'm not sure what happened.  The formatting is a page or two for each woman and it is sorted in alphabetical order.It certainly doesn't seem as if this book was actually ready to be published.  A little cleanup and it would be a good tome on women readers.  In its current condition, I just can't recommend it.Mistresses of MayhemCopyright 2002248 pagesReview by M. Reynard

Never watched the movies, this is my first experience reading any of Brown's books.  I don't understand all the hype or the controversy.  It was mildly entertaining, and the "clue" format was interesting, but it was nothing outstanding or deplorable in my eyes.Robert Langdon is minding his own business when he is contacted by an official at CERN to come look at some evidence and a dead man.  Nevermind that Langdon is a professor, not law enforcement, his expertise is needed.  It looks to be the work of the Illuminati, a cult made of scientists who has a very big vendetta against the Catholic church.  Can Langdon solve the Illuminati riddle in time?  The very future of the Vatican depends on it.The characters were mostly unbelievable in this.  They had too many powers, too easily overcame obstacles, and apparently had super-human strength and healing properties.  There is no way, after some of the things that Langdon went through, that he'd want to be walking let alone want to have sex (and that's all I'll say on that).  Vittoria was a shallow character that seemed to be there in an attempt to have a "strong" female character.  But she neither added much, nor was very strong on her own.  She relied on Langdon's character quite a bit.  And the character and personality changes in some of the others were hard to follow and made it seem as if they weren't even the same character at all.If you ignored the poorly written characters, the plot was actually fast paced and kept your attention.  There was always some kind of action or gruesome scene to read and the clues and mysteries kept the reader engaged.  I also liked that the entire book took place in the space of a day, but didn't seem too rushed.  It was an impressive way of writing the story.  I can't comment on historical accuracies, etc.  I know nothing about the Illuminati or Catholic church history, etc.  I'm going to assume some is accurate and some is not, as seems to be the case with most fiction works.Certainly entertaining but by no means a work of art.  I'll read the next in the series just because it is a good way to spend a rainy weekend.Angels & DemonsCopyright 2000569 pagesReview by M. Reynard 2014

Bhutan, a country that many have heard about but few have really given in-depth study to.  Which is amazing considering their practices as a country.  Measuring how well they're doing by happiness rather than money.  But it's a country worth getting to know and so this memoir/lessons book is one that opens the door a little wider on Bhutan.A Field Guide to Happiness is part memoir, part lessons in how to live life happier.  That's not to say that you have to move to Bhutan to achieve the things outlined in this book, it just shows how the author learned these lessons in life while living in the country and following their way of life.  Each chapter has a small lesson and ties into an experience or story from the author's personal life.I never really felt as if I actually knew the author or her husband.  Which is strange because she did describe both of them, but it wasn't in-depth and I just didn't feel any kind of connection.  And the people of Bhutan were just described in general ways, there was never much of a chance to get to know any of them in-depth as individuals, just as a collective.  She wasn't mean or unkind in her descriptions, just brief, and you can tell she really does love her adopted country.The whole book can be described as brief.  I get that it was supposed to be in snippets as a lesson format to impart some of the wisdom she learned in Bhutan, but it just felt like large journal entries that were mixed with a self-help book.  The writing was clear, good even, but again, that sense of connection just wasn't there for me.  I don't know if it was the format or the briefness of the chapters, but I just couldn't bury myself into it.  On the positive side though, I like that for her lessons she tried to include snippets of her life in Bhutan.  Especially the descriptions of how the people of Bhutan share and the way they treat property there.  Everyone is striving to be a better person (in general) and that's a commendable way to live.I enjoyed the book mostly but wish it would have been something I could have immersed myself in.  I think anyone who enjoys self-help, discovery memoirs will probably enjoy it though.  I would definitely consider reading the author's other book on Bhutan.A Field Guide to HappinessCopyright 2014232 pagesReview by M. Reynard 2014

I read "A Mountain of Crumbs" and really enjoyed it.  So I was interested in seeing where the rest of Gorokhova's life went after she came to the United States on the arm of her new (stranger) husband.  Having studied English for most of the time she was in Russia, it is still quite the transition to a new culture.In her previous memoir, Elena meets a young American man who says he will marry her and have an "open" relationship in order to bring her to the United States.  She isn't sure what she's signing up for, but quickly realizes that he is not the man she had thought he might be and that she is lonely and unsure of how to act in this new country.  Eventually they fall apart and she is able to meet another man who will become her husband and the father of her child.  As she transitions into a way of life here, her mother still worries about her though and eventually she has worries of her own as a mother that she must overcome in order to be more at peace with her life.Elena was very much a worrier in this book.  She worried about everything.  And I can't say that I blame her.  She had a lot going on and felt very out of place and didn't have the support she apparently needed when she first moved.  Her first husband seemed distant and cold, but we are just getting her side of the story.  I do wonder if she ever reimbursed him the money he spent in bringing her to the United States, but I suppose at this point it doesn't matter.  Her mother was not as strongly written in this book either.  She was a sideline, a strife that was dealt with sometimes, and an endearing mother in others that the author recalled fondly. The same goes for her sister who is briefly mentioned.  Her husband gets a lot of detail though (the 2nd one) and I felt that he really was a good person.I wasn't as engrossed in this one as I was the first.  It was somehow both lengthy and too short all at once.  The parts I wanted more detail on (transition to life in America, customs, etc.) there just didn't seem to be enough of, and those I didn't really care about (family members Dr. appointments) there was quite a bit of.  I thought her interactions with her family were interesting, but didn't need to know every kind of Dr. her mother had appointments at.  I was also surprised at how little time was spent on her daughter as I expected that to be a larger part of the book.  Really, the best detail though was her description of encountering a hamburger for the first time.  It made an impact and showed just how different life in the Soviet Union is from here.I can't say that it was an exceptionally strong 2nd memoir, but it certainly was expressive writing.  It does what a memoir should; bring you the life of the writer.Russian TattooCopyright 2014315 pagesReview by M. Reynard 2014

Despite being a part of the "Mists of Avalon" series, this book was not actually written by Marion Zimmer Bradley.  However, it was written by a woman who did co-author several books with her, and the similarity of their voices make it seem as if they are one and the same.Ravens of Avalon tells the story of Boudica.  Boudica was actually a real life queen who waged war against the Romans.  This fictional telling of her story has her start life as a young royal who is sent to train with the druids and priestesses of Briton.  Instead of choosing a destiny as a Priestess, she decides to return home and serve her family and people best by marrying.  During this time the Romans have forced a truce with the different tribes of Briton and become increasingly antagonistic, which spurns a war that Boudica must lead.Boudica is an interesting woman in history.  Because you don't hear of very many warrior queens (although there are a notable few).  I liked how I got quite a bit of her backstory in this book and what her life could have possibly been like before she was Queen.  But I don't think I got to see enough of her warrior side, and I was slightly disappointed in that.  Lhiannon was also somewhat of a disappointment.  I didn't really like her character in The Forest House (same series) but thought maybe her younger self would be more interesting.  I still saw her lead around by the will of others and of a certain Priest and although she thought she was free, she never really truly seemed to be free.This book had a slow pace.  But not quite as slow as some of the other books in the series.  Both Bradley and Paxson enjoy detail and spend a lot of time building up history and people in the books.  This one in particular covered a lot of people in their younger days and the quarrels, loves, and aspirations that they held.  I did think that the war scenes were well done, although a tad brutal.  Since this was the story of Boudica you'd expect their to be some battles, but more time was given to history and character building than to gory descriptions and bloody scenes.  There was also some magic as well, which, depending on your stance of myth and legend, is what really made this a work of fiction.I don't think it was the best of the series, but it's not a bad prequel.  Just one you'd probably not want to read until after having read all of the others.Ravens of AvalonCopyright 2007394 pagesReview by M. Reynard 2014

Playing with alternative flours can be fun.  Especially when you're baking for someone who is gluten free.  Because let's face it, rice flour is disgusting (at least in my opinion) so it's nice to know there are some other alternatives out there.Viva Labs offers an Organic Coconut flour that is also labeled as Gluten Free, unbleached, Non-GMO, and Vegan.  Which is a pretty impressive lineup.  It comes in a resealable plastic bag that is thick enough to keep odors and other things out.  It does recommend that after opening, it should be stored in the refrigerator.  However, a dark cool place is ok as well.Baking with this flour can be tricky.  You shouldn't substitute it cup for cup with regular flour in a recipe as I discovered.  Because it just doesn't rise.  Instead, had I been reading the label, it says you can use 1/4 to 1/3 cup mixed with other flours to substitute for baking.  You also have to include additional liquid.  That being said, I made a cake and did substitute cup for cup with no added liquid, and while dense, still tasted pretty good.  It definitely has a strong coconut flavor which would probably make it not so good for such things as cheesebread, etc.  But good for things like breading shrimp or making dessert.  So not entirely versatile, but still pretty close.  The texture isn't bad either.  It's very smooth and not a messy powder.  Which means it won't make a mess of your kitchen.I would probably use this flour again for dessert baking, but I don't see myself using it for much else.  Still, it's not a bad product and for those who have to eat gluten-free, a great alternative to regular flour.**I was provided with a free reviewer's sample**Review by M. Reynard 2014

When you have knives leftover from college days, anything is bound to be better than them.  That being said, I was only half-pleased with this Bread Knife from Oxo.  While it had a good grip, it did manage to squish my bread a bit.This knife is about the average length for a bread knife (8 in.) and so it can be used like any other bread knife.  The packaging also says it can be used for melons, however, I have not had the inclination to try that out since I can never seem to eat a whole melon by myself and don't want to waste food.  It also can be used for harder, crustier breads, which is the utilization that I tried.  It cut through the bread mostly ok (just a crusty round loaf from the grocery store) but still had a bit of squishing and flattening out, which kind of defeated the purpose.  It was almost the same result I would have had with a steak knife.  I also tried it on some homemade pepperoni bread, and again there was squishing, but it's a softer bread so that was probably to be expected.I think perhaps that the blade just wasn't sharp enough out of the box, although I sharpened in between and it didn't seem to have much effect.  When slicing too, since you had to press quite firmly (part of the problem with squishing the bread) it also didn't give straight cuts and so my slices weren't as uniform as they like.  In the grand scheme of things, they all tasted good, so not a huge issue, but if someone is worried about presentation they may not enjoy using this knife as much.  At least when you're trying to hold the knife, the no slip handle is soft and easy to hold on to and doesn't hurt your fingers.I've liked my other OXO knives so it seems like just this one isn't the greatest of designs.  But it still does a serviceable job for a cheap knife and is good for your average cook.Review by M. Reynard 2014

Sometimes you read about a character you absolutely can't stand or relate to.  But more on that later.  This book was suggested to me, and as I always like a good conversation about books, I told him I would read it.  Hermann Hesse is a pretty well known author, although I've heard said that this book is one of his more misunderstood ones.Harry Haller is a recluse, a wolf, as he likes to call himself.  He spends his time contemplating poetry, music, books, in the privacy of his own rooms and has never learned to dance nor unleash the more animalistic side of him, despite knowing that it lies dormant within him.  When he meets a woman named Hermine, his world starts to change though.  She introduces him to dancing, pleasures and cheap thrills, and eventually to the magic theatre, where he is taken on a ride so out of the normal that he cannot tell what is real and what is not.It was interesting, when talking with the friend who suggested this book, to discover just how different he and I viewed Harry Haller.  I viewed him as narcissistic and with a superiority complex.  He viewed him as misunderstood and socially awkward.  I guess it really is true that our own life experiences shape how we view things.  My reasoning for finding Haller narcissistic were a result of his constant moaning about how the upper classes of society didn't understand or appreciate his views on art, literature, etc.  And that dancing, etc. that he secretly was interested in was considering lower class by him and more animalistic, a different side to him.  It was as if he felt himself so superior to either group of people, that he couldn't fit in despite trying.  I just found it a real turn-off.  I also didn't like the way he discarded a certain character once finished with his development of his own character.  It's like learning much from a good book and then setting fire to it when you're done reading.  Destruction with no real purpose.That being said, if Hesse's intent was to make me dislike Haller then he did a very good job.  The book is descriptive and evokes emotion, if not necessarily the positive kind.  But the first third of a book was a whiney drag to get through.  I got tired of Haller describing himself and his suffering of being alone and it wasn't until Hermine entered the picture that things actually got interesting.  I still didn't like the social interactions he had, but at least there were new characters that offered different perspectives.  The Magic Theatre was also intriguing and the images evoked from the writing were disturbing yet colorful and varied.  It was like having a very vivid nightmare.  I realize that I may not fully understand the emotions or worldview that Hesse was expressing through Haller, but I just couldn't connect with any part of him which made this a difficult read.  It was like looking at a piece of abstract art; it may appeal to some and I can appreciate that the artist had a lot of thoughts and emotions going into the work, but I certainly don't want to hang it in my house.I think you can be of two minds of this book, you either like it or you don't.  For me, I can't say that I enjoyed it, other than enjoying the debate about the writing and character motivations that came out of it.SteppenwolfCopyright 1927256 pagesReview by M. Reynard 2014

I love knives.  I love cooking.  I hate using my knives at home because let's face it, they're leftover from my college days and not the best quality.  I've used some of the OXO products before, so I was curious to try out their knives.First off, this is a comfortable knife to wield.  It has that no slip grip on the handle which I thought was a gimic at first, but I was slicing sausage and other meats with it and from touching that my hand got slippery with gunk (mmm, appetizing description, I know).  Despite that however, I was still able to hold onto the handle of the knife without any issues or slippage.  It also, despite being large, was relatively light weight and easy to hold.The knife was sharp.  It went right through some mostly frozen meat that I was slicing and also chopped up an onion super quick. And it only minimally had the food stick to it as I was slicing which is a plus.  Nothing drives me nuts more than slicing an onion and you have to stop and slide the pieces off the blade each time.  It still happened with this knife, just not as much and I figure that's pretty good.Cleaning is relatively easy.  You have to be careful of course since the knife is sharp and hot soapy water and a sponge will get everything clean.  Do not put this knife in your dishwasher.  Not only does it dull the blade but I can see it quickly destroying the handle material too because of the high heat.I didn't find any flaws with this knife.  It sliced evenly and quickly and had a sharp blade.  It was easy to hold and easy to clean.  Can't get much better than that.Review by M. Reynard 2014

Travels with Casey; one immediately compares the title to the Travels with Charlie written by Steinbeck.  And that's kind of the point.  The author thought about that classic book and then decided to do his own spin on it.  Take his dog on a trip around the country in an RV, but instead of learning about the people, he wanted to learn about the dogs of the country.Denizet-Lewis never really felt connected to his dog.  Sure he took care of Casey well, made sure he had everything he needed, but he always felt as if maybe Casey didn't want to be his dog.  There just wasn't a connection with him despite several years together.  So on a writing assignment he decides to pack it up and see if being stuck in an RV together will do anything for that connection.  Along the way he'll stop at various points in the US known for Dog Shows, unique dog parks, dog people, and other such things relating to dogs.Despite this being a book about dogs, Denizet-Lewis encounters several different people as well.  From the guy who will stop at nothing to find a lost dog, to the guy who lives with wolf-dogs, people can be just as different as dog breeds.  Some of them he describes as a bit crazy, but he takes care to show the goodness that they all have and the common bond of dog ownership.  These are all people, that for various reasons, are obsessed with their dogs or helping dogs.  And it's nice to read about that sometimes when there's so much on the news that points to the other directions.  For himself, Denizet-Lewis tells you all about his flaws, but he comes across as a genuinely likable guy.I liked the pace of this book.  While there were sections I would have liked to read more on (Best Friends Animal Sanctuary) I think overall the different snippets were enough to keep the book moving along and interesting.  I enjoyed all the different things related to dogs that he found on his travels and didn't know about some of the others (dog shaped hotel, etc.).  The only part I didn't really like was that so much of his personal life and drama invaded the book.  I think it's probably more of a memoir/dog travel book and while there was nothing particularly out there, I guess I just expected it to be more about the dogs and less about his personal anguish.  It was a mix between.  Again, that doesn't mean this book was poorly written, it just wasn't what I expected based on the title.For those that like memoirs and books about dogs this is probably going to be a good read.  It has enough whimsy mixed with enough serious topics to keep it interesting.**This book was won in a Goodreads Giveaway**Travels with CaseyCopyright 2014309 pagesReview by M. Reynard 2014

I usually go for the powder detergents, just because the liquid ones getting all goopy at the nozzle icks me out.  So pods seemed like a good way to go.  Just toss them in, no measuring, and you're set.  Which is great if laundry is not a chore that you enjoy.I frequently have large loads of clothes so I use two of these pods (as recommended) quite a bit.  But it isn't necessary for smaller loads.  Since I had the Free & Gentle type, there are no associated smells.  In fact, my laundry came out smelling like nothing.  Which is perfect because that is what was advertised.  It also came out clean, although I didn't notice my whites being anymore white than normal or my colors being exceptionally bright.  But again, they were still clean, and that's all I go for when I do laundry.I also like that these are in a recyclable plastic container.  While I like my powdered detergent because it is in a cardboard container and eco-friendly, at least this is something I can dispose of responsibly.So in conclusion, with this particular scent (or non-scent rather and no dyes) I have not noticed any staining, my laundry smells like nothing, meaning it's probably clean because otherwise it would smell like my workout clothes, and it's easy to toss in the dryer.  Not too shabby!Review by M. Reynard 2014

Not going to lie, I'd never even heard of Miele until recently.  And then I found out they were quite popular and considerably high-end.  And considering I was ready to throw my old vacuum off the balcony in frustration, it was the perfect opportunity to try a canister vacuum for the first time.We'll start with setup.  This vacuum comes largely put together.  You'll need to setup the filter (which involves removing a sticker and pressing a button (although the pressing a button was a tad confusing from the instructions because it wasn't a normal button but a dye release).  You'll need to put the click button on the telescoping wand (which mine was tricky but I finally got it in the end, was afraid I'd break it first though) and you'll need to attach the hose to the vacuum.  You'll also need to place the batteries in the wand for the light feature, which requires a small phillips screwdriver.  So overall, not really that hard to setup, just hard to understand the instructions sometimes (which came in a variety of languages and was more of a summary and the pictures weren't always in English).  There are also numerous attachments that come with this unit, but all are easy to pop on and off of the wand.The canister itself is really made quite well.  It has two different compartments that open up.  The bottom lets you access the bag and the filter for changing them out as needed.  Yes, this is a bagged vacuum and requires brand specific bags and filters.  The second compartment has room for three of the attachments (brush, small nozzle and upholstery tool) and they are already located there upon purchase.  There are numerous buttons that can be activated by pressing or using your foot on the canister itself.  The on button, which starts the vacuum going, a cord return button which will wind the cord back up for you, and plus and minus buttons that control the power of the vacuum for different levels.  The cord is long enough that I can plug the vacuum in in my living room and vacuum my whole apartment without seeking out a new plug.  There are wheels on the canister that allow for easy maneuverability around the house.  Some other attachments come with the vacuum and they are in one of the cardboard boxes contained in the main shipping box.  They are too large to go in the canister itself and are a dusting brush, a larger plastic nozzle and a cap if you want to remove the hose and have the canister separate.The main head (shown in the picture) for vacuuming floors also has some settings and can be used by flipping the toggle for hardwood or carpet.  And boy does this thing have power.  At the highest setting I was convinced I could probably climb walls with this thing because of the powerful suction (although no worries, I didn't try).  But then, switching the power mode, it went light enough that I could vacuum my one carpet that even me walking gently across sometimes pulls up loops.  So that was a positive.  On the lightest setting it can even do curtains.  My only complaint about this head is that with the cat and me having long hair, it pretty much developed mats that I had to pull out and manually throw away.  It makes me wonder if I'll manage to clog it one day if I don't see these mats and remove them (I found another upon detaching the head and putting on another attachment).  But it sucked up everything on the floor that needed to be sucked up.  I tried to upholstery brush and it did a good job as well, making my couch look better than it has in awhile.  There was a plastic attachment that looked like a long pointed tube that was great for getting at the edges of walls and corners as well.This unit is exceptionally quiet too.  I'm  used to wanting to put on headphones while vacuuming just to drown out the noise and I didn't have to do that with this.  In fact, I could probably play music on a radio and still hear it.  I was quite astounded by the quietness actually.  The light feature is nice in theory, but it isn't one that you can shut on and off.  It has a timer and will go off by itself, which necessitates the need to press the button every half minute to keep the light on, which I found slightly annoying.  Sure it will save on batteries, but I wish the timer was a little longer so I didn't have to keep pressing the button.For the filters, I can't say that I really noticed a difference either way.  I'm not one of those people that goes into sneezing fits from dust when I vacuum so to me vacuuming is vacuuming.  I'm assuming since everything else works on this unit, that that part is working as well.For the most part, I really enjoy using this vacuum.  Not sure if I'll ever get used to a canister as compared to an upright, but it definitely is more versatile and can clean a multitude of things which is beneficial.  And with the suction power and quiet running, it's definitely made me a fan of the Miele brand.Review by M. Reynard 2014

I'm not the best drawer.  But I like trying.  And I figure if I have decent supplies then the outcome can't come out too terrible, right?  So oil pastels seem to fit the bill.  I mean, they're like crayons for grown ups.This set comes with 24 different colors ranging from bright red to black to blues, greens, and yellows and all sorts of colors in between.  Personally I think it seemed to favor the warmer tones more if we're considering the browns and earth colors to be "warm", but it still had a pretty good range.  It came in a nice box with a spot for each crayon, and providing you return them where you got them, there is a color chart on the inside of the box with the colors names.  Each pastel has a wide tip, about the size of a larger crayon, so they are a little bulky in that regard and you have to get creative to achieve thin lines.I'm a big fan of the blending, using either a tissue or my hand and these pastels worked great in that regard.  The layering, not so much.  Unless you're using a darker color over a lighter you're not going to be able to completely layer with these.  I can see maybe using a metal tool to take some of the pigment off a lighter color and thickly placing it on the surface to achieve shading that way, but you're going to have to blend if you go from dark to light.  They also work well for just a light coating, achieving a crayon looking texture.  Pressing harder you get a smooth shiny surface, but it also uses the pastel up fairly quickly.  I did a larger drawing on some of my professional art paper, and for every pastel I used, I used up about a sixth of the pastel on that one drawing.  So I don't see these lasting very long.  On just plain paper alone they stay true to the color you see in the box.  I didn't have any turn out paler or darker than I expected.Not a bad little kit.  I can see a wide variety of people using these for different projects.  While I wouldn't let a toddler have a go at them, I think anyone else would be appropriate.Review by M. Reynard 2014

Ok, I have to admit, I just got this shampoo because I thought about all the old commercials where those women were having a fantastic time in the shower because of this stuff.  Sadly, reality is not like that at all, but it's still a pretty decent shampoo if all you're looking to do is get your hair clean.Herbal Essence is known for having good scents.  This particular flavor, Mint and Grapefruit, does smell good.  It smells, sweet fruity, and doesn't have a hint of mint scent that I could distinguish.  Which for me is a good thing, as I don't really like mint.  The smell goes on in the shower but it doesn't stick to your hair (and it's gotten me some weird looks as I sniff my hair throughout the day trying to decipher if I can still smell it or not).  What's nice about this, is just because it smells like a fruit, there aren't artificial dyes trying to make it look fruity.  This is a clear shampoo.The ingredients in this bottle of shampoo aren't too bad either.  It's called "Naked" (they really are trying to go back to their commercial glory days!) and that means it has no parabens, silicone, or colorant in the mix.  There's still some sulfates and other things, but largely, for a conventional shampoo that's not bought in a specialty store, this doesn't have that bad of ingredients.  Still, if you're in the all organic, all natural, all healthy crowd, this may not be a shampoo you want to use.  There are a few ingredients in here that I couldn't begin to pronounce, let alone spell.After using, my hair is its usual clean.  And it will stay that way for a day or so, depending on how active I am or how sweaty I get.  Which is pretty standard for any shampoo.  For the volume part of this, I can't say I've noticed any difference.  My hair has always been the thin type, and as it gets longer it seems to stay that thin.  Although as much as I lose in a day I suppose I could say this shampoo is working just because I haven't found any bald spots, which is impressive considering I could make wigs out of what I take out of my brush every week (you really wanted that detail didn't you?).Overall I like this shampoo and will probably continue to use it.  I rotate through the shampoos I use just to keep my hair guessing, but I like to have a few different ones that I consistently come back to.  This one could fit the bill.Review by M. Reynard 2014

I'd love to travel, I'm somewhat scared of commitment.  These are the things that make me readily identify with the author of this book.  Even though in reality I'm nothing like her.  While she's out traveling the world, I've never been out of the country (unless you count the Canadian side of Niagara Falls).  While she bounces from relationship to relationship and seemingly doesn't care about sticking with one person at a time, I'm a serial monogamist.  So why on earth am I so drawn to her life?Eaves decides during college that she needs to travel.  Her boyfriend at the time goes all over the world and it inspires her to do more with her life.  She bounces along from Egypt, to Yemen, eventually finishing up college and going on to other relationships, to New Zealand, Australia, and other places.  She has a few more boyfriends, goes back to school again, and travels to a few more countries.  She never stops moving.  And this book tells of all that moving, although it mostly focuses on her relationships.The relationships in this book are somewhat shallow.  Eaves herself admits love to several different men, sometimes at the same time, and it makes it hard to know whether what she was feeling was deep or authentic.  Not that I'm to judge, I'm sure you can love multiple people on that level, but with the ease that she separates herself from some of these relationships, it calls it into question.  For herself, we recognize that she doesn't want to be held down.  That she likes the freedom of travel and that she seems to enjoy having superficial relationships that she can easily be freed from.  She's very solitary in a way.I enjoyed most of this book's descriptions of travel.  Towards the end it was more about her relationships, and I would have liked to have more detail on the countries she was staying in.  It seems that she sacrificed the part about travel for the part about social and her somewhat controlling boyfriend in the latter part of the book.  Granted, she was in France, which she didn't think was terribly exciting, but I'm sure there were some positive things about it and some beautiful sights.  Overall though, I thought the book moved fast and that it kept me fully engrossed in what was happening.I enjoyed this book, although I recognize not everyone may agree with the way that Eaves travels or her relationships.  I found it an interesting, non-conformist way of living life.WanderlustCopyright 2011301 pagesReview by M. Reynard 2014

I'm getting back into acoustic guitar, and have purchased a few of the books by Mark Hanson, namely "The Art of Contemporary Travis Picking" and "The Art of Solo Fingerpicking".  Those books have a lot of excellent content, but this is the book to start with. Simple enough to sound decent pretty quick and hold your interest, at least for a neophyte like me.  If you just get the book and CD, you'll hear Mark say things like 'notice that I'm using a capo', because there is a companion DVD with the same title that is available separately - it's not too expensive and worth considering.Update 11/21/15I've only been working with this book a short while, and have finished learning the "Canyon Canon" which sounds really good but which I found pretty easy to play with daily practice.  If you are learning acoustic guitar, you will want to start off with simple pieces so that you build your confidence. The beauty of this book is that as you progress, you will probably drop most of the easy tunes you start with, but these pieces by Mark Hanson will more than likely stay in your repertoire.

I'm a total guitar slide novice and have recently bought a few to experiment with. My favorite is the Dunlop "Mudslide" -  I really like the weight and the sound that slide produces. This glass slide is very inexpensive, so I figured "what the heck".  I like the compact size, but I'm not crazy about the sound. Wish it was porcelain, like the Mudslide. Cheap enough to try, though - you may love it.  :)

I bought one of the "acoustic" versions of this stand,  and liked it enough to order another.  Some people say it's not compact or light enough, some say it isn't stable enough - I don't agree.  First, folded or unfolded, this stand is compact and not overly heavy - despite the brand name,  I think it's more of a permanent home stand than a travel/stage stand.  Second, once the arms are opened up fully, this stand is plenty stable - Most any floor stand is not going to be impervious to kids and critters on the loose.  The one possible issue I see with this stand is the pointy front supports might not work well on a deep shag carpet or other uneven surface. That said, this is a cool stand that will cradle and display your acoustic guitar beautifully.

I have to admit up front that I only find slide guitar palatable in small doses.When I first attempted to play a long way back, I bought a cheap metal slide and didn't like the sound at all.Now that I have been more earnest in my second attempt, I decided to check out the Mudslide.I produces a very cool bluesy sound on my Gretsch  Jim Dandy, though I am still just noodling with it. :)Same as most other's experience, this "medium" slide has a rather small inner diameter - I have small/medium hands, and while this slide fits my pinky with wiggle room to spare, it's a tight fit on my ring finger.Construction is very nice, the interior finish is comfortable.  Treat it with care and it should last  forever.Dunlop even includes a little leaflet with slide facts and a couple alternate tuning suggestions.

Wow, there is a lot of quality content in here - the book starts off with some well written instruction on music theory, then dives into the title topic.  Along with the lessons, there's tons of side notes and interesting tidbits on origins, styles and artists. This book is a labor of love and would be a great addition to any blues guitarist's library.

Great book with lots of helpful information and examples.  One reviewer lamented that this is not a "beginners" book, but honestly, I don't see how this style of playing could have been broken down any simpler.Why anyone would buy the Kindle version of this book is beyond me - the accompanying CD that comes with the printed book is a treasure - kinda sounds like it was recorded in someone's home studio, and the narration is pretty laid back (I don't mean these as negatives).  It's all pleasant enough, but when he gets to the "blue" notes section, a chill just shot up my spine. TOO COOL!!!If you are at all interested in this style of guitar playing, you really can't go wrong adding this book & CD to your library.
Well made case - I like the "bubble" inner padding, though it's probably overkill. Handy front pocket for a short USB cable. Anyway, should accommodate most portable CD drives.

Excellent all-in-one device - I bought this primarily for the metronome, and I am very pleased with it:- Good tempo range, with both audible and visual reference- Accent beat can be adjusted, or turned off- Beat sounds are pleasant (typical digital metronome sound)- Volume can be adjusted (might not be loud enough for some extreme situations)- Mini headphone jackUpdate 11/12/15I'm using the tuner feature with my acoustic guitars now, and it's fantastic - there's lights to guide you if the string is sharp or flat, and when you nail the tuning, the display turns green.For all it does under $20, I bought another one to keep at the ready in my guitar case.The tuner feature set is equally robust, but even if it were just a metronome, it would be worth the asking price!

What sold me on giving this parlor sized guitar a shot was the positive and detailed reviews posted here plus some pretty awesome YouTube videos (it's amazing what some people can do).Even with all the positive press, when I first pulled this out of the box, I thought "toy"!Then I tuned it,  played it and lost track of time - I love it!Yes, it doesn't project, and don't expect much bass, but it rings really sweet and the body size makes it "extremely" comfortable to play. The neck isn't exactly thin, but it isn't a baseball bat, either, and it has a silky matte finish that feels great.  When I get a  chance, I'm going to put a set of heavier strings on and see what happens.Bottom line, if $160 is dear to you, then you may want to see this little guitar in person first and try it.  Otherwise, go for it - it will put a smile on your face.

I have recently gotten back into guitar playing, focusing on acoustic.  I never did like the feel of the Fender picks, they felt too slick and "brittle" to me. My pick of choice back in the day was Dunlop nylon - they felt ok, but didn't give me the control of a "shell" pick.I bought a Dunlop medium/heavy assortment pack and zeroed in on these .88 green Tortex picks - they have a really nice feeling surface texture, and the .88 gauge makes individual notes ring beautifully.I am going to try the lighter yellow gauge - if you are experimenting with picks, you should definitely check out Tortex.Update 10/4/15Tried out the yellow .73 gauge, and was surprised at the difference in sound vs. the green .88's.  The .73s  produces a more "trebley" sound, with a more pronounced click when striking the strings, which is not unpleasant!  Will be keeping a supply of both gauges handy.  :)

Haven't finished it yet, but it's safe to assume that "Robopocalypse" was written with a movie deal in mind.The first few chapters reminded me very much of  the movie "Close Encounters of the Third Kind," where we are presented with a series of vignettes that are all tied together to the main event.Some of these snippets are more convincingly described than others, but all the characters read like they were conceived by  Ayan Rand.  :)I will finish it, but it's not as compelling as I had hoped, and I'm glad I bought it used on the cheap.

I played this on a PC and had to pick it up for my PS3. You are on an island where a Soviet experiment with a (then) newly discovered element went crazy wrong around 50 years ago, and you use a time shifting device (along with your guns) to save the world.For a shooter, it's got a pretty decent story, with some humorous moments (I love the 50's styled  Russian film clips at the beginning of the game) and a couple jump scares. Very nice graphics and good use of the DualShock's rumble feature.Typical variety of upgradable weapons for a shooter,  but the time control aspect adds another level of interest to the game in that it's used in a variety of clever ways to support the story , and yet  it's not bogged down with too many controls to learn.

This isn't just a mindless 'shooter in the air'.  Even with the simplest control scheme, it takes a bit of patience to learn to take off, get to your destination/targets, maneuver and survive, then land your plane - but the way it is presented here is far better than any other flight & fight game I have tried (I am using a standard controller). So considering what they are attempting to recreate here, I think the game designers did a fantastic job of making this as assessable to players of all skill levels as they could.Once I got through the excellent tutorials, and finally landed my plane in one piece, I got the feeling of actually accomplishing something. For those with the interest and time to invest, "Birds of Steel" should be a very rewarding game!

Love these!Please note that these are NOT "gel" grips - I think they got the "spongy-ness" and raised dots just right.  As others have said here, they won't slip off easily like other grips do.They fit perfectly on my PS3  Xbox 360 wired PC controllers, and the colors help you identify who's controller belongs to  who, or which one you just charged...

I have owned my PS4 system for one year now, and if someone were to ask me what gaming system to buy, I'd recommend the PS3, and this particular bundle would be a great choice.My PS4 is by no means collecting dust, but as of September 2015, and after purchasing several PS4 titles, I still spend the majority of my gaming time on my PS3s.  IF I played online a lot or IF the PS4 played PS3 games, I might feel different, but for a stand alone gaming system, the PS3 is a way better value.This console in this bundle has a 250Gb drive, which would take most people quite a bit of time to fill up.  Note that this PS3 console has a top loading drawer instead of a disc slot -  There are pros and cons to both designs, but personally I think that less can go wrong with a mechanical drawer vs. a motorized disc slot.This bundle includes "The Last Of Us," which will probably be the PS3's crown jewel of game titles. Great graphics, great adventure, great fun.Finally, as of this writing, the PS3's title library dwarfs the PS4 - there are dozens of great games that you can pick up new or used for about 1/4 the price of a new PS4 title.

Found this title while browsing Amazon's bargain Blu rays.Just when you think the "incidental film footage" genre had been exhausted after movies like "Blair Witch Project" and "Cloverfield," along comes "Chronicle".  It floored me.  This is an extremely clever fantasy film about a group of teenagers coming to grips with superhuman abilities acquired after an accidental encounter with a mysterious object buried in the earth. Worth repeated viewings, though note that it's pretty moody in tone.Superbly acted, and most of the visual effects are seamless and believable.

"Scrubs" is a great medical situation comedy series,  if you like their brand of humor, which is warm offbeat, but never too vulgar IMHO.The series was wonderfully cast  - fun to watch how they play off each other.It's good that the shows are 1/2 hour - you can get a few chuckles and get your mind off things for a few minutes, then move on.I had been waiting for this series to come out on Blu ray, but with the odd exception of season 8, this may never happen.  From what I have read, it wouldn't make a big difference picture quality-wise anyway. Bottom line - the first season DVDs looked good on my old tube TV, but look like crap on flatscreens. :(

These are better that nothing if you are passing a disc onto someone - not a good choice for long term/constant use.  Price and overall quality are reasonable, but I docked one star because as others have said here, the description would lead you to think that the paper is going to be robust, and actually it's pretty thin.

Love it - great addition to my growing collection of goofy bottle openers!Big, heavy, high quality,  though a bit awkward to actually use. Not practical as a key chain.Just watch out - a friend or family member may try to stick this in their mouth - you're smarter than that, right?  :)

I used to get the Memorex brand ridged plastic CD cases, but hate them because the two pieces separate and break way too easily.This type of "shell" case is great because it's one piece, and made of a softer plastic that flexes.Note that this style of case is made by many manufacturers - I suggest looking for the ones that snap shut via the spindle button. I think this closure is less prone to accidentally opening than the cases that snap close at the edge. The flat hinge on these cases can vary  in length, too - the ones I received were as pictured here and have about a 3" hinge.If you shop around here, make sure to check out the pictures and descriptions before buying,  :)

I used to use a Kensington brand laptop cooler, which worked fine until the connection from little wire coming from the backside of the unit broke. The fact that this device works with a USB connector on both ends (a cable is included) is very nice. It also provides a spare USB port on the back, so unlike a lot of other coolers, you don't lose a port.  It also has a rocker-type on/off switch and 3 fans are lit with blue LEDs which look cool but are totally unnecessary .  :)  The unit is also very light and nicely built.Just received this new cooler today, and have been testing it out on my new 15.6" HP laptop - After several hours, my computer has been much cooler.  I like that this unit has 3 fans, one of which is positioned over a "hot spot" on the left side of my laptop.The fans themselves run very quiet.

Easy hookup, nice size and feel (it is smallish, but I prefer it), has an on/off switch, you can store the receiver in the base of the mouse if want, has a low battery light, tracks flawlessly on the arm of my couch (!), and comes with batteries (AAAs). Love it.

Very high quality case for the price. May be too tight to accommodate a laptop sleeve, but it has a good amount of padding and pockets for additional small, non-bulky items like pens and USB drives.Really, I didn't expect this case to be so nice for just around $20.

Overall, I am quite pleased with this laptop.As far as the look, it's all plastic, but it's high quality plastic, if that makes sense - being a fan of HP computers,  I've seen some better looking HP laptops, but regrettably, lately, I've seen some crappy looking ones too. This one has a clean two- tone look. All of the connector jacks are nice and snug. Keyboard is chicklet-style, and feels nice - you can turn the keyboard backlight on and off with the F5 key.Sound-wise it isn't bad for a laptop/it ain't stellar, either - don't let the sales video and "subwoofer" spec. fool you - there isn't much bass improvement over any other mid-priced laptop. The highs and mids, however, are nicely detailed. IMHO, the onboard sound is decent enough for no-fuss on the go sound. If you want the best sound, use good headphones or an outboard speaker system.Performance-wise, it runs like a charm. This is my first experience with Win 8.1, and it all makes sense - I like the "Tile" concept, but you can easily switch to the familiar desktop  with a single click.  I am also becoming addicted to the touch screen - I know I will soon be habitually poking all of my other standard monitors now. :)It's had no problem running the stuff I've loaded so far. FL Studio 12 runs awesome on this machine. For games, I loaded "Call of Juarez: Gunslinger" - looks and plays wonderful.My only reservation? Even doing simple tasks, this machine runs warm within a half hour or so of use - much warmer than my 17" HP laptop. A cooler fan helps, but it's just more stuff to lug around.Will update my review if needed, but other than the heat concern, I am delighted with this laptop.

Nice case, well made.I got the brown, and from the pictures, I thought it would be a dull canvas-like brown - it's actually a vinyl plastic with a bit of a sheen to it. No biggie.6/15 Update - At the current $13.00 I initially thought it was a bit overpriced, but after using it while, I can really appreciate the quality of the materials and construction.

O.K., Since I intend to use this as a handbag for work (a few reference books,occasionally a small laptop computer,a calculator, other misc. small gear) I am keeping it - it makes my stuff easy to carry, and the bag will fit into my locker. Overall, I am very happy with it!The aesthetics:It's a nice medium brown khaki - similar to what I saw on screen.Seems quite well made - stitching and materials are top drawer. The top handle has the usual X-stitching on the tabs, but they also reinforced this with a grommet - time will tell if this was a good idea or not. The backside panel is U zippered, which provides access to the backpack straps - the backpack straps are nicely padded. They also include a non-padded shoulder strap.There's a mesh half pocket on the bottom probably designed to hold a water bottle - I put a compact umbrella in there.It does have a very mild odor, but no where nearly as bad as what some people here were claiming.Some people were saying the bag itself seems heavy. Nope.It does have the following curious gibberish printed on the leather face panel:*******D/E/A/R(then the Kaukko logo)simple casualCOMFORTABLE & FREE STYLENATURE...DEEP RESPIRATION(DAILY LIFE)WESTERN U.S. CATTLE SUBPACKAGESFREE PERSON AT TIME*******Now, at least one person was so self-conscious about the above printing that they position the bag so that others can't see the panel. That's a bit extreme, but if the printing bugs you, don't get this bag. It's innocuous enough for me to live with. The leather panel has a zipper that travels under a canvas flap. If you know the utility of this, let me know.Will it fit a laptop computer? Not without caveats - a 17" is out of the question.  It has an inner pocket designed to accommodate a smaller device - a tablet would slip in no problem ,but oddly, the top zipper opening is just a bit too small to allow you to get a 15" laptop in the pocket easily, though you can put it in front of the pocket. Too bad, but not a deal breaker for me.All the above may read like I don't like this bag, but really, for my purposes, I do! I just wanted to provide some additional information for those on the fence.Update 6/15 - Have used this case for over a week,  and have upgraded my review to to 5 stars - easy to carry, keeps me more organized, and it looks cool - love it!

There are several "Call of Juarez" titles, but this appears to be everyone's favorite, and for good reason.This is just an awesomely fun shooter and I'm not even a big fan of westerns.The campaign (Story) mode has an interesting & funny story.Some people feel the graphics are a bit too "cartoony," but I really like the look (and sound) of this game. If you play this on a PC, I would recommend using a gamepad controller.Aside from the campaign, this game also has one of the best arcade modes I have ever seen - definitely has replay value.I have the game loaded on my PC (you do need a Steam account set up to download the game, but you don't have to be online to play it), but I was really geeked to find out recently that this title is also available for download on the PS3 (from the Playstation store).

Being a console gamer most of my life, I've started to explore the world of PC gaming - there are a lot of great established titles out there that are being offered at rock bottom prices, plus tons of cool indie games that may never appear on a console.The thing is, it was very frustrating for me to play these games using a keyboard and a mouse. I can appreciate that it's the only way some people play, but I just can't get used to the layout.Boy, did this controller come to the rescue! My consoles are all PlayStations but the layout of this controller is similar enough. The build quality is excellent for this price - I got the wired version so I don't have to mess with batteries, and the cord length is very generous. Genuine plug and play, too (at least on my Win7 laptop).Games like "Call of Juarez: Gunslinger" and "Melody's Escape" are now just a joy to play on my PC.
Wow. Even if you don't like real world golf, any Vita owner should check this game out.Once you get past the mind-boggling array of options and beautiful graphics, the game itself is crazy fun!
Fits my first gen Vita like a glove. Slots in the lid for 3 additional game cartridges and one memory card. Well built and worth the investment.

First, as far as zombie movies go, both of these films are good! I saw them several years ago, and watching them again makes me think that some of the people involved in "The Walking Dead" tv series must have been taking notes.My main aim here is to warn people that the Blu-ray transfer of the original film "28 Days Later" looks pretty bad. YES, the film may have been intended to have a dreamlike soft look, and it was never meant to be tack sharp. The problem is, that the high def transfer is riddled with artifacts that really distract you from the dreamlike quality the director intended. It looks like a transfer from a DVD that was transfered from a VHS tape (the second film in the set looks decent). Granted, this was probably the best transfer they could do, but it does the feel of this film more harm than good.Remember "Jacob's Ladder"? That film was also meant to have a dreamlike quality, and people complain that the Blu-ray transfer looks like crap, but I think it managed to stay pretty faithful to the source film and the director's intent. Not sharp, not meant to be, but far fewer distracting artifacts.In the case of "28 Days Later", this is the first time I would suggest buying or sticking with the original DVD instead of buying the Blu-ray.

I wanted to get my hands on a PS4 exclusive title and was going to wait for the price on this one to drop, but I finally found it locally on sale -really glad I picked it up sooner than later, as inFAMOUS Second Son is quickly becoming my favorite new console game.Never played any of the earlier titles, but the gist is you are an average joe that acquires superhuman powers, and you choose the path your character will travel -good or evil.For an "origin" type of story, I was kind of surprised about the meh way that Delsin aquires his first set of super skills, but those first skills are a blast to use.  As the game progresses, you pick up new skills or expand the strengths of the existing ones.The contoller layout is pretty easy to get the hang of - playing Delsin is a lot of fun. His movements are very fluid and also very fast - I am an older gamer, and I tend to like stealth elements in games, but haven't  come across any in this game yet (this ain't Batman). That's cool, but I can only play this game for short stretches because the action is full tilt and so far the only "breathers" you get are in the cut scenes, or when you're traveling from one objective to the next (haven't played any of the side missions yet, the main story is keeping me busy).The graphics of this game are easily the best of any PS4 game I currently own - the look of this game is quite stunning, especially when you unleash one of your superpowers, and it helps to pull you into the story. Second Son also utilizes the DualShock 4's touch pad and onboard speaker to good effect.Anyway, so far I am very happy with this game.

Yes, there is a "game" aspect here, but it's very simple. I think it is intended to be more of a relaxing experience than a game, so if you are looking for that type of thing it will do the trick (once you get used to the controls).

Back when the buzz was building for "Destiny", I saw one of the trailers and it certainly looked like  it would be a "must have" game once I got a PS4.I purposely avoided following the news for this game, didn't check out the beta when I preordered the "Destiny" PS4 bundle, and maybe that was my bad - I was hoping for an "epic campaign".Aside from the irksome requirement that you always have to be online, what surprises me even more is that after several hours of playing  the story mode, I have yet to experience a "wow" moment with this game. There's nothing about it that strikes me as unique or compelling.  When I think back on recent games I've really enjoyed, there have always been "wow" moments - For example, the first  several minutes of "Uncharted 2: Among Thieves" - that incredible train wreck opening grabbed my attention from the start, and compelled me to keep playing.That was the hope I had for the campaign, but it really hasn't won me over  yet. I know people are sick of the "Borderlands" comparison, but I think at least for the "Story" game mode (the campaign), it's fair - It's a quest based FPS. Enemies have those same horizontal  health bars over their heads, and as you beat them, you see the numbers fly, you pick up the booty they dropped - just like "Borderlands".  Heck, even the Ghosts remind me of Claptrap.To be fair,  if you have the inclination and time to invest, the other game modes may be where all the mojo is at, but as a fan of campaigns, "Destiny" won't be the first game I grab when I fire up my PS4...

This is one of the first games I've picked up for my PS4, and I have been playing it a lot (I just play campaigns so no multi-player is no loss to me). The prologue playthrough is pretty long and "ok", but once you reach 1960, the game really takes off.The graphics are excellent, and controls are responsive (like the duck/lean feature).The game does give a nod to its previous incarnations - you have to manually pick up health, armor and ammo, and you enter at map point A, do the required tasks, and exit at map point B.I am fine with that - you do a LOT of shooting, and there are a wide variety of enemies, but you are doing more than that - you have to stealth your way through some spots, cut your way through fences, find hidden items...And there's also a decent story here, which keeps you coming back to see what happens next.This game has a lot of violence, gore, and non-PC content, so it won't be for everyone, but it's a great FPS.**** Edit 9/18/14Just finished the game (Fergus Timeline), and still think it's a great FPS, just thought it worth mentioning that while the story held my interest, up at around 70% completion it goes off on a tangent that was rather slapdash/meh. I agree with another reviewer here who said it would have been cool to take the story to the USA (as one of the trailers would have had us believe). Oh well, maybe this will happen in the sequel...

If you are not a fan of slower paced stealth games, then you should pass on this. If you enjoyed V2, then you should really like this.Sniper Elite V2 was one of the few PS3 games I played through twice, and III improves the formula in every way (almost).I don't know how this game plays on the PS3, but on the PS4 the graphics are very good, and the character movements are smooth.The world is more open, and there is much more flexibility in how you accomplish a mission.AI of the bad guys seems improved (at least to me).Honestly, the X-ray Kill-Cam was never a major selling point to me, but of course it's back (apparently there is now an option to adjust the frequency).The only thing that takes some getting used to, is that like other shooters, they've swapped the functions of L1/R1 and L2/R2.This game is a prequel to the events of V2. At the conclusion of V2, they mentioned that your character (Karl Fairburne) becomes one of the first big players in the Cold War. That could make for an interesting follow up. In the meantime SE III satisfies my itch for stealth.

If Amazon allowed reviewers to post half stars, I'd give my new PS4 4&Â½ stars.Some of my "peeves" have to do with "Destiny" (see below), but as I  bought the Destiny Bundle, I think it's still fair to include it in my overall score.I own every Playstation from the original on up, so I knew it would be a great console, and it is:Small, sleek footprint - no power "brick" (I am no Xbox One basher, but it is pretty funny to watch those YouTube comparisons).  The build quality seems good, it runs fairly quiet, and Glacier White is a nice change of pace.In my opinion, all of the improvements to the Dualshock 4 controller are welcome, including the slightly bigger and rounder handgrips and improved trigger (shoulder) buttons. The new touch pad is also a big "button" itself, and has some interesting possibilities.The operating system is (for the most part) cleaned up and pretty easy to navigate (much improved over PS3).System utilities are improved - you can charge the controller without the console needing to be fully powered up, you can download updates in the background, etc. You can change the brightness of the lightbar on the controller, and you can adjust the controller speaker's volume.  One weird thing is that to turn off your controller (which I did a lot while playing Blu Ray movies on my PS3), you have to drill down a couple menu steps - on the PS3, this operation is a lot quicker.Most important of all of course, currently available PS4 games look good and play very smoothly and are great fun - really looking forward as the PS4 exclusive titles pick up momentum in the next few months!I did some research before buying, so I knew some things this system would be missing, but in case you don't know:The PS4 will not play PS3 games, and let's face it, there's still a lot of play left in PS3 titles.Unlike its predecessors, the PS4 doesn't have a dedicated RCA audio output - if you are just using your TV's onboard speakers, then sure, HDMI is a one connector solution, but if you want to route the PS4 audio to a separate sound system, that system needs to have an HDMI or optical input.  I've got an Onkyo amp that isn't ancient and has hosted my PS3 for several years - but all it has are RCA ins, so I can't use it with my PS4.  Sure, RCA is old technology, but Sony STILL  puts cassette players in most of their boom boxes, for cripes sake! How much would it have cost them to include RCA outs like they've always done?The hard drive is only 500Gb - that might seem big, it's really not, considering that some games now require a minimum of 50Gb, and it'll probably go up.  Yes, you can buy a DIY drive upgrade, but not everybody wants to dive into their PS4's guts.  I wish Sony would have tiered the product - i.e., made it also available with a 1Tb drive - I think a lot of people would have paid the extra cost if it were an option.I knew about the non backward compatibility, the lack of RCA outs and the smallish hard drive -what I didn't know was that for "Destiny," a "sufficiently robust WI-FI connection may be required".  Yep, even if you just play the campaign, you have to be online because apparently even the campaign has multiplayer elements. I can appreciate that they have a  grand plans for this game, but I hope this isn't the start of a trend for other titles.  I have a decent WI-FI setup, but not the best.  Every PS4 title I had purchased loaded without incident, but I struggled with the online requirements of "Destiny," and that was frustrating.  When I finally got the update downloaded, I was able to play for about 45 minutes without a glitch, and yes, it is no doubt an awesome game.  I just don't like the idea that every time I fire up "Destiny" I'll also have to power up my network and hope that it's "sufficiently robust" that day. :)Worth mentioning:Several people have been having trouble with the coating on the thumbsticks (joysticks...whatever) on their PS4 controllers disintegrating with regular use, and others have had no such issues.  I don't think it's mishandling,  it might be an interaction with the oils & sweat from some people's hands and that particular formulation of material.  I have a not too old Logitech mouse with a rubberized coating that's  doing the same "shedding"  thing.  Anyway, if you have a new PS4 controller,  it might be worthwhile to buy one of the many brands of protective  "caps" out there - this is what I bought: Grip-iT Analog Stick Covers  and they work fine.I don't regret my purchase at all - just wanted to document my opinion of some pluses and minuses...

This is one of the first games I picked up for my new PS4 system, and it's like a glorified version of one of those goofy Android app games that you just cannot put down.I love it because anybody can pretty much learn all of the main controls in a few minutes, but the devil is in mastering those controls.It's also cool that so far, the courses have not been overly long, yet they have multiple check points, and any time you want, you can press the touchpad to start at the beginning. The goal is to make it through a course in one go, but you will also probably burst out laughing every time your rider faceplants.This all equates to a game that you can pop in to kill a few minutes, or play for extended periods (if you don't mind saying "oh, sh!#" a lot).Graphics are very nice, but I think the main advantage of this type of game on a next gen console is the smoothness of play.
