After hearing that many people are experiencing trouble with the coating on the sticks of their Dualshock 4s, I picked these up at a local store.They are pretty easy to put on - the trick is to turn them inside out, position them on the stick, then pull the lip down.They fit snug, don't add too much height or bulk and have a nice grip (with a very subtle raised dot texture).How long they will last remains to be seen, but at this price you can always just buy another set and keep your controller protected...****Update 9/11/15****I still hold these grips in high esteem, but if you want something less "mushy," with a higher raised dot texture, and more color options, check out the "Mudder" brand grips available on Amazon.

I just play the campaign aspect of games;Starhawk is not your typical shooter - some shooting games incorporate sequences where you drive a vehicle or operate a turret for a short period of time, using simple controls.With Starhawk, operating land and air vehicles take up a good chunk of the game.In addition to that, there are spots in the game where you build and utilize structures, like defensive walls and automated gun turrets, adding a another layer of strategy to the battles.With all this going on, the game has a much steeper learning curve than most shooters.Still, once I got the hang of it, I really had a lot of fun with the some parts of the game, like the air battles.If all you want to do is 'gun and run', this game is definitely not for you. If you want to do more than just shoot, and you have the time to get used to the controls, then "Starhawk" is worth checking out.

The beginning of this book - and the part I had access to via the preview function - starts out well enough. We are introduced to Andrea, and immediately to a situation where she determines that fighting solves nothing. It then jumps to a hypothetical situation of Andrea's cat being hit by a car and we are walked through Andrea's struggle between two concepts she knows to be right and realizing that they can't both apply to the situation. Should her cat be 'put to sleep' and spared inevitable pain or kept alive, suffering, in an effort to delay inevitable death. Before Andrea makes her choice, the question is offered, aptly, to the reader. Then next page shows Andrea choosing the difficult but most logical choice -- to end her cat's life, and thus, his suffering. I found this portion of the book to be precisely what I expected in terms of reader interaction and the promotion of free thought the book is supposed to be based upon.The question regarding Andrea's cat posed on page 20 of the 76-page book, is essentially the last real thought-inducing question posed to the reader. Allow me to express my surprise here, as I believed that this book would gently guide its reader to conclusions, rather than stating them outright.There are some pages following this discourse which discuss the concept of morality and there being 'good people who do believe in god(s)' and 'good people who do not believe in god(s).' Appropriate enough.Then it jumps into small segments of 'do and don't' lists, ie. 'Do be fair.' or 'Don't cheat' and most of these have little follow-ups on the 'why' of explaining the reason these are or are not things we should do. I honestly expected more. As in, I expected that rather than laying down a bunch of adult concepts spelled out in simple kid language, that the adult concepts would be geared toward a kid audience on a kid-level while still maintaining their core ideas.Perhaps the following example will demonstrate this fairly succinctly. On page 48, addressing the topic of honesty it gives this example: "Suppose a woman you know comes to your home and says she needs somewhere to hide because her husband has been beating her up." Huh? Really? Because dozens of 5 year olds are running their own covert battered women's shelters?I begin to question, with that last example, what age audience this is supposed to be geared toward. On one hand, the illustrations and tone of the writing seem quite well matched to an early grade-school child. It is written in simply-worded text that my five year old daughter could easily read herself (though I certainly intended to read it over with her first). But when you touch on a prickly topic like battered women, something that hopefully most children will not have to encounter, you open up some rather uncomfortable possibilities. The one that comes to my mind is my daughter going to school and telling her teacher than if daddy ever beats mommy, she won't tell him where mommy is. Parents out there may grasp why this would be an undesirable outcome of broadening their child's mind..... For children who have already encountered real-world domestic abuse, I think it's fair to say they have bigger fish to fry than pondering whether providing shelter to battered women whilst being honest with the husband is the moral high ground. The subject matter is too mature and could have been better chosen given the potential age group.Moving on.Later, on page 57, the Golden Rule is addressed. I'm quite fond of the Golden Rule and its endless applications. As I understand it, in its most common form, states "Do unto others as you would have them do unto you." Barker has a different take on it and says it means, "Some people are kind to others because they want to be treated the same way themselves." That's actually a quite different thing. Amazing how you can change words around ever so slightly and convey an entirely different concept. Barker goes on to demonstrate this glaring difference by saying, "But other people are kind because they think human beings are valuable, not because they want a reward." I find this perplexing. Perhaps I've gone my whole life interpreting the phrase "as you would have them do unto you" incorrectly, but I always believed that you treated others the way you would ideally like to be treated -- though that may not necessarily be the way they actually treat you in return. It's a form of empathy, you know? One that comes from the most valid source of logical data one has for interpersonal relations - their own interpretation of how the actions of others effect them. If an action effects you negatively, then you should not visit that action upon another being (human or otherwise). Which, going back to the initial scenario, could have easily been the logic for euthanizing the pet cat. If your death were inevitable and you were suffering greatly, would you choose euthanasia or would you prolong your life, suffering, dignity beyond reason? I would have euthanized the cat because I would ideally hope that another would use their own insight to do the same for me in a similar situation. I would still euthanize the cat, even if someone chose not to euthanize me were the tables turned, because my moral compass is internal and greatly based on my experience of personal pain and suffering and the experience of watching others needlessly endure it. That is all to say, I find the section on the Golden Rule to be off- perhaps influenced by a negative connotation with its general association with religion?This book is presented and titled as being a guide for young thinkers. But as I got progressively further into the book, it seemed to be laying out a sort of moral dogma, with little justification, and requiring little thought and contemplation from the reader. Dogmatic presentations of moral thinking are precisely what I believed the book was created to counter, and I feel it fell flat. This is even more sad because on each and every page I can see the author's *intention* and then as he carries that good idea along he almost seems to trip himself up on it and it just gets regurgitated on the page in ineffective form. By the end I felt that the ability to think your own way through it was rather squelched by the 'do and don't' tone it takes on.I bought this book as part of a long-term plan to counter Christianity-based indoctrination that has been directed at my daughter. As an atheist of many years, I find it difficult to stand idly by and let her believe that what little she has been fed by religious infleunces represents the thinking of the entire world. I'm terribly disappointed to say I don't this will make its way into our 'Chrisitanity-unschooling' curriculum. Which is a shame, because I've looked extensively and can find nothing else like it.I plan on returning this book. It will be my first book return on Amazon. But I feel our money could be better spent on educating our daughter about -- well anything. Mythology, eastern religions, philosophy, ethics, science and the cosmos.... There are a lot of paths to free thought. But this one, I believe, is too forward, too black-and-white, and not informative enough to be the optimal one.

I bought this truck for my daughter's 5th birthday. She'd seen it in the Bruder catalog that came with her younger sister's Man garbage truck, and talked about it for weeks after Christmas, so we didn't hesitate to make it her 'big' birthday gift.I tried it out a bit when it arrived and was immediately impressed with the spinning drum. I put in a few marbles, and discovered that - as advertised - the drum can be cranked in one direction to mix the contents, and the other direction send the contents down the chute. Like our garbage truck, the inside of the drum is a simple Archimedes screw-type design. The chute comes with two snap-on extensions which can be stored on either side of the truck and can be easily attached/detached as desired.Of course, my daughter's fondest desire was to make 'real cement' (ie. a water/sand mixture) and send this down the chute to, she says, make 'perfect sand castles.' So after unwrapping this truck, playing around with it indoors with marbles, shoving the cab full of her Playmobil people (which are really a quite nice fit, if slightly out-of-scale with the truck), she demanded an outdoor trial.You actually can, technically, fill the drum with sand and water, this is true. And it will, if you don't dilly dally, come down the chute when turned in the correct direction. But, the drum is not sealed and this created a bit of an issue. Sand and water will dribble out on the part where the drum rests on the bed up by the cab, creating friction on the spin of the drum. This can be gotten around somewhat by manually turning the drum, rather than using the crank, but even then the drum is difficult to turn and she found this a bit frustrating and demanded my help on a few occasions. No big deal. This friction, I will add, also strips the blue stripes around the same area of the drum which are a vinyl-type appliquÃ©. Not that this has ruined the truck's appearance or anything. It's a very small area. But.. I'd rather hoped that this truck might fare better as an outdoor plaything.The second issue is that I've not yet found a way (and this could just be me being overly cautious or missing some obvious detail) to fully open the drum. It seems possible, but every time I attempt it, I think forcing it might break something. This becomes an issue when our curious three-year old stuffs Calico Critters, Playmobil people, wrapping paper and other large/oddly shaped objects into it. Of course, turning the drum is futile if the object is too big to go down the chute, so a grown-up has to turn the truck upside-down and try to wriggle the object between the obstacles to get it out. A little annoying and tedious.All the same, the kids do love it. They are mostly content playing with it indoors, and my five year old is pleased with the objects that do work well in the drum: small rocks and marbles. She's also thrilled with having the doors to the cab open, being able to look at the engine compartment and simply zooming the truck to and fro. It's a massive toy, but it is very nicely made of sturdy, safe ABS plastic, and is attractive, realistic and superbly detailed. Most of the parts are durable enough for the 4+ set, save for the rearview mirrors. There also appears to be no water tank on this variation of the truck, so the people referring to that may be referring to another truck by Bruder.For the price we got it for (it was a pretty drastic discount after Christmas) I think it was a fine deal, and will see lots of play - even if not the precise sort of play my daughter hoped for. I've come to the conclusion that Bruder trucks are really better indoor toys, after having bought this - our second one.Country of origin: Germany

We decided to buy a Bambina doll for our soon-to-be-two-year-old daughter, because we wanted to buy her a nice first baby doll that was not made in China, and we wanted a doll made from materials we felt safe having her cuddle and sleep with. Kathe Kruse seems to have gone the extra mile to make a safer baby doll, as well as adhere to higher standards of quality. Also, all Bambina dolls, and their accessories are made in Germany. The vinyl components of these dolls are made of PVC that is mixed and processed with the high-quality (relatively) environmentally-friendly plasticizer Hexamoll® DINCH. They are also nonylphenol-free and phthalate-free.Before we purchased our Bambina doll, I pored over the internet looking for customer reviews, more photos, a better description, anything, and save for one review on Amazon Germany (which I was only able to poorly translate) there were none. Maybe that's because the Kathe Kruse dolls are so gosh darn expensive, and not a lot of people are willing to splurge for this sort of thing, but I would have loved to have some kind of customer perspective on what these dolls are like, in detail.I hope I'm able to provide that to someone else seeking the same information.We purchased Bambina Lara. Near as I can tell she only differs in her clothing and eye color, but these were the specific things I liked best about her anyway. Bambina Lara is a beautiful doll. Her face is all at once elegant and sweet. Her features are actually not as harsh as the oversaturated stock photos most of the sites have of her, although I was surprised, and perhaps a little dismayed to find that the color of her lips had been used to also make two small dots where her nostrils should be and at the corner of her eyes(see my photos). These are hardly noticeable when you're just looking at her normally, but when you really look at her closely, they stand out and are a bit odd.However, I quickly overcame this minor flaw. When you hold her, she has such a nice weight. She just feels good in your arms, from her heavy-ish limbs, to her large bottom that is the perfect shape for sitting up, or resting on your arm. Her eyes are exquisite, and while a lot of dolls have a little bit of creepiness to their eyes, Bambina doesn't. I had a hard time understanding what this "light" was people kept referring to in the eyes of Kathe Kruse dolls, but I totally get it now. I've always been partial to sleepy-eye dolls, but this doll has expanded my preference.Bambina Lara's clothing is absolutely fantastic, and I'm convinced this is the case with all Bambina dolls. The material and design really is exquisite in a way that is unusual in modern times, and reminds me somewhat of my grandmothers old Madame Alexander dolls. Her little shoes actually have a firm sole, and remind me very much of real baby shoes.Speaking of real babies, I've read more than once that Bambina dolls are the size of a real baby, and can wear newborn size clothing. This was an issue of particular curiosity to me, because we have so much newborn clothing from my girls I can't bear to part with, and how cool would it be to reuse these for this doll? Well Bambina sort of does and doesn't fit into newborn clothing. Like all dolls, her neck and shoulders are more slender, proportionately which leaves most necklines looking too wide or a little bulky. Her waist also appears to be shorter, so onesies don't fit her at all really (I admit I haven't tried a preemie size yet), and pants sit rather high on her, if they fit at all. Baby hats and socks and booties fit her perfectly, and I even have a 3 mos dress that fits her rather well (a little long), but ultimately, I would say maybe 1/15 newborn outfits may fit her well enough to keep in the mix, and maybe preemie clothes would be a better choice.Bambina's arms, legs, and head are made of hard vinyl that has a satiny surface. We received our doll with dirty marks on her arms, and I feared this satiny surface wouldn't be able to be thoroughly cleaned, but these marks came right off with soap and water. It's good to know she can easily be cleaned. Bambina's body is made from thick, durable canvas in skin-tone, a shade lighter than her extremities. Her vinyl limbs and face are a medium skin tone.Our Bambina's lips are pink with a strong coral overtone. In some of the pictures, this coral overtone looks a little heavy, but it's actually a pleasant color. Her eyes are a mixture of green and brown, and are obviously the part of her given the most attention detail-wise. It seems that the eyes are actually quite different on each doll, though I've not seen enough close-ups to verify this assumption.Bambina's cheeks are rosy, without being garish. Her hair is a dark brown and rather a flat tone in the middle, which becomes wispy as it nears her face and neck. Hopefully, I've captured this better in pictures than I can describe.Overall, she is a lovely doll, and I'm glad we chose her. I can't wait to present her to my daughter on her birthday, and hope she will be as overjoyed as I am about her new 'friend'.Updated Note: One gripe we have with this doll, having owned her for a few months now, is that despite the fact that she is handled very carefully her head has become incredibly scuffed. There are paint marks on it from where she's been accidentally bumped into the walls while being carried about, and various small scratches from literally every time her head has been bumped or dropped. Perhaps this is because she has such dark hair - though her hands and feet also get bumped they don't show the wear and tear in such an obvious way. Definitely a consideration when paying nearly 200 for a play doll. I imagine an easy way around this would be to go for a doll like Kikou or the bath babies that come with hair. This doll is otherwise fantastic and well-loved. My girls don't care that she is increasingly becoming more flawed - that's just a mom issue.

These adorable little mushrooms are not kaleidescopes in the traditional sense; there are no beads inside, they are merely a faceted lens that gives a different perspective to anything you view through it. When we were a kid, they always referred to them as being 'bug eyes' and I think you were supposed to gather this must be how bumblebees see or something of that sort.The neat thing about these little kaleidoscopes - and something I wasn't aware of when I ordered a handful of them for party favors - is that each bears a differently faceted lens (see uploaded images). The red mushroom has almost a diamond-cut. The center is flat (normal view) and the diagonal facets that taper toward the edge create a kaleidescope view all around. The green mushroom has a blocky-style faceting and this translates, of course to many blocks of the same image when you look through it, turning this one while viewing gives a really lovely effect. The yellow has straight lines of faceted plastic across the the convex top. The effect of this one is really trippy (especially when being rotated while viewing), and is a totally scrambled view of the world, whereas the others just distort but still leave fairly recognizable shapes within the patterns. Either way, this variety was a totally unexpected bonus. While I like the appearance of the red mushroom best aesthetically, the green and yellow nearly tie for best kaleidescope view.As is the case with all Plan Toys, the rubberwood is stained rather than painted, super-smooth, and just feels really nice to the touch. They're really attractive and could easily double as large mushrooms in the play kitchen, or toadstools for little people to sit on. I like them and think that they were a great buy for an eco-friendly, safe toy to share with my girl's friends at their birthday party this year.Country of Origin: Thailand

I'm totally in love with the little duck erasers in this set. They're every bit as cute and detailed as they appear to be in the picture. The frogs are... well, a great deal cuter than most erasers out there, but aren't quite the level of adorable the ducks are. Both, however, accurately match the photo.Like all Iwako erasers, these seperate into three or four different pieces; this is seemingly more a practical detail of manufacturing the multiple colors, than anything else. My kids have a few of the other erasers, and just love them for the cute characters. My three year old was appalled by the idea of using them as erasers when I told her that's what they were.We bought this  particular set as favors for our girls' upcoming party, and I think they'll be a fantastic and unique little addition to the gift bags. Very cool little item, never a disappointment. I love that they are made in Japan, rather than China. I can definitely see acquiring more of these down the road!

My daughters didn't explicitly ask for a plane for Christmas, but when I saw this one by Playmobil, I was so taken by it, I was sure one or both of them would appreciate it.I decided to give it to my four (almost five) year old, after reading the reviews about the parts coming easily detached. Before Christmas, as is my routine these days with Playmobil items, I assembled this piece as fully as I could, still allowing for repackaging. Much better than dedicating Christmas morning to lengthy assembly.The assembly on this piece is fairly straightforward, and is not more (and perhaps a little less) work than any other major Playmobil sets. There are lithos to be carefully applied to the cockpit, a bathroom within the plane to be assembled, complete with a tricky roll of toilet paper. Probably the most tedious aspect were the tiny windows, of which there are many, which must be popped into place. You do, however, get a rhythm going with that about halfway through. Then the jet engines and landing gear (which is stationary, and does not fold up into the plane). All told, I imagine I spent 30-odd minutes on it.The plane itself, when complete is magnificent. It is about 2'1" in length, by 2'2" wingspan. As another reviewer notes, this would not make for easy storage. We just park it in the corner of our living room alongside out massive Bruder garbage truck, and accept that we have a toy-littered house.The girls both love it, but unusually enough, it's been a far bigger hit with my two (almost three) year old daughter. She played with it all Christmas morning, and is often filling the half-dozen passenger seats and cockpit with her 123 people and/or the penguins from her Pengaloo game. The effect of a plane full of penguins is a riot!There is, of course, the issue of durability. Those who are familiar with Playmobil may have already made acquaintance with the four-part pegs that seat into one piece to attach it to another piece (sometimes poorly) in System X buildings. These are what is used to attach the wings, landing gear, and jet engines. In a vehicle with the proportions of the plane, these connectors don't hold up well, and will probably become more prone to detaching over time. This isn't so much a problem for us. Because of the size of the plane, it's more a land vehicle at this point. It's a little too bulky for our little girls to effectively 'fly' and they are not terribly rough with it. Nonetheless, I've replaced the landing gear and jet engines a few times. No big deal. However, introduce a rowdy two-year old boy into the equation (we were babysitting) and the pieces seem to go flying every which way more rapidly than they can be replaced. So a word to the wise: consider your audience before purchasing.Our audience, however, was ideal. It has been effectively integrated into all aspects of imaginative play, and it's just a fantastic, attractive, very realistic toy from the exterior to the interior. I love the way the door opens like that on a real plane. We also purchased the silver Playmobil Cargo crates to go with it, and this has added a dimension of interest, as the kids love to fill these with little goods and load them into the cargo area of the plane.If you're looking for the ideal plane for a preschool+ aged child, look no further.Country of Origin: Germany

When we became vegan a few years before the birth of our children, we struggled a great deal - at first - with trying to recreate those old familiar dishes - minus the eggs and dairy.This cookbook isn't the fanciest, it isn't gourmet, but it does provide a rough guideline for making simple meals - like pancakes! - without the seemingly requisite eggs and dairy. For us, the 'Brainless Banana Pancakes' have become our standard pancake recipe, even though since the kids came along we reverted back to a lacto-ovo diet. This recipe is so easy that I no longer refer to the book for it. I just mix what appears to be the right amount of ingredients, tweak it a little 'til the texture is right, and it turns out perfectly every time. How cool is that? It's also a  great way to get rid of those almost-bad bananas without the work of banana bread.We probably tried a couple dozen of the recipes in this book (as well as others we got from friends, family, the internet, etc.) before getting our bearings and beginning to create our own unique dishes... but I view this book as having been an important part of that process. One of the most helpful aspects of this book is that the ingredients for the recipes are common, inexpensive, and easy to acquire. We found this was not always the case with vegan cookboks, and was the primary reason a few of our cookbooks sat on the shelf untouched. You won't need to visit a specialty food store to find many, if any, of these ingredients.So while this may not be the final word on vegan cuisine, it's a great introductory book for when you find yourself thinking veganism is the way to go... but are unsure of how to go about it exactly. It's a purchase I don't regret and would recommend to any budding vegans looking for direction in changing their diets.

We bought this basket to attach to a retro-looking 14" Diamondback Della Cruz bicycle for our four year old daughter. When the basket arrived, I initially thought it would be too big for her bicycle. But it turned out to be the perfect size. It is bigger - wider and deeper - than most children's plastic bicycle baskets. This has turned out to be quite a good thing. When my girls go bike riding, my daughter is always pleased to be able to carry the larger stuffed animals or her lunch sack or a huge pile out outdoor treasures (rocks!leaves!magnolia cones!).It's held up really well. I'm ashamed to say we've left the bike out in the rain a few too many times, but the basket - despite a slight change in color - is sturdy as ever!I'm not convinced this would be the ultimate basket for an adult's bike, but that all depends on what you're wanting to tote along. You could carry a small purse in here, or maybe a few (2-4) library books, or a small Sigg bottle and a paper lunch sack. But it's definitely not good for a trip to the grocery store or anything.For our purposes, however, it was absolutely ideal. It's also easy to attach which is nice. I'd recommend it to anyone looking for a smaller basket for an old-fashioned single-speed bicycle.Country of Origin: China

My three year old daughter received this little mouse family from a relative for Christmas.And I'll confess, every time we went to our local boutique-y toy store, I pondered these little animals with mixed emotions. There's no denying their cuteness which borders on being saccharine, but walks that fine line carefully enough so as to still appeal to virtually anyone -- including myself in an odd sort of way.I've always balked at the price (I'd assumed our local store had jacked it up 50-odd%, but no - their pricing is spot-on). I continue to marvel at how PVC (a fairly nasty, toxic-from-inception-to-disposal, chemical-leaching, cheap plastic) manufactured in the third world could have attached to it such a fancy price. I mean, I could totally see if they'd pioneered locating an uber-safe replacement plastic for PVC like Boon's Odd Ducks, or if they were recycling something -- *anything* like Green Toys, or making grand philanthropic social gestures in the third world like Plan Toys. But this company seems to be doing none of the above (though the PVC is supposedly phthalate free, though no information seems t exist on whther this translates to 'safe' -- and are they actually monitoring this, I wonder?). They're making toys from cheap materials that cost pennies and selling them at an insane mark-up. It's actually pretty ingenious.As for the toys themselves, they are pretty much exactly what they appear to be. Semi-hard PVC bodies, with white nylon fuzz fused onto them, pink fuzz on the ears and nose (the fuzz does pick up lots of lint, and doesn't weather long-term play well as our local toy-store's display animals can attest). The heads and limbs - arms and legs - do move, but not easily. My daughter seems oblivious to this - she never moves their limbs. The clothing can be removed, and most outfits attach with velcro. The little boy mouse's outfit, oddly, has no velcro, but stays on nonetheless. Most of the outfits are a single piece, except for the daddy mouse who has both a shirt and overalls. All of the mice have bendy white tails in the back and black bead-like eyes. Their expressions are pleasant and endearing.Despite any caveats mom may have about PVC toys, they are a permanent fixture because they are loved - fiercely. They are toted about the house and on car rides, gently fed and tucked into little beds, snuggled, the whole bit. Truth be known, I think I'd have easily been crazy about them as a young child too, long before the days where toxic toys were a source of maternal angst.

My three year old daughter received this set from a relative for Christmas. I was a little taken aback when I saw the price on it (FYI: it can be found for 40% less, I later discovered).Nonetheless it's a really pleasant little set, and its play value extends beyond the pieces that it comes with.This set essentially consists of a sturdy fenced enclosure (note: not all our Playmobil fenced enclosures could be termed 'sturdy') with two attached gazebos to provide the animals shelter. Then there is the group of animals: A goat & kid, a calf, a black sheep and white lamb, a mouse, bird, donkey and pony. There is a tree that seems to have difficulty standing on its own (not the best of the Playmobil trees, but we fortunately have dozens so its functionality is not missed). There are vegetables as food for the animals, bottles for the baby animals plus a bottle warmer and table, decorative foliage, and two straw beds for the animals to sleep on -- though none of the animals' legs move, so it seems a moot point. There are lots of bandage-stickers which outlive their usefulness immediately and will end their lives by becoming attached to the bottoms of socks and so forth. And finally there are people: a female adult and two little girls.Assembly time was only slightly tedious. Maybe 20 minutes - I wasn't rushing either. Re-assembly is intuitive and quite speedy.What ultimately makes this set great fun for my children is the enclosure, with its functioning front gate. It stays put during a bit of rough play, which is nice, and has become home to all manner of creatures, inluding our Playmobil dinosaurs who easily fill the entire area. It seems all animals, from Calico Critters to Iwako eraser animals, must be taken to this enclosure to receive their meals, and so - unlike much of our Playmobil sets, which get disassembled and stored when not in immediate use, this set has stayed intact on the living room floor since Christmas, where it sees daily play. The animals have provided a fair amount of play and plenty of squabbling. The other (smaller) accesories, have been generally dismissed, perhaps because the animals have deluxe meals concocted for them in the adjacent play kitchen and are served fruits and veggies that are about ten times the size of their bodies.All told, I think this set has been a big hit. I probably wouldn't have shelled out top dollar for it had it been my decision to purchase, but I'm glad someone else did, seeing how much play the children have gotten out of it.Country of Origin: Spain

I'm writing this from the standpoint of a non-Ableton user, to talk about how it integrates with opther DAWs. I run StudioOne 3 Professional and need a controller for post-recording work once back in my home studio/office. I mainly record grand piano and vocals in our church and the add other orchestral parts and percussion in post, so I don't really the LaunchKey for piano pieces. I was using an Alesis Q49 before this came along and have since sold the Alesis, no brainer considering the tap pads and other mechanical controls that the LaunchKey offers. In addition to StudioOne 3 I also use a control for orchestral scoring with Notion so I'll comment on that too. Sorry, don't have any info for ProTools users. FYI, I did hook the LaunchKey up to my iPad Air (with the Apple Lightning to USB Camera Adapter (MD821ZM/A)) and fired up GarageBand as a quick test and it all worked immediately, as expected.The SetupI run StudioOne 3 on Win10, and to use the LaunchKey on Windows you'll need the USB 2.0 driver. When you register the controller, just go to the Download section and you'll find it there. There's no Mac version of the USB driver, Mac probably doesn't need it. Anyway, I clicked the link for the driver on the webpage and just told it to Run, and it installed in seconds, and now Windows recognizes the device.I fired up Studio One and opened External Devices and chose Add a New Keyboard. There isn't a Novation preset but no worries, we're about to make one. [ADD NEXT SECTION]What I LikeWhat I'm Not Crazy aboutBottom Line

Two of these in my garage-door opener really lights our two-car garage qite well. The color temp is kind of warm and quite pleasing, no greenish-blue dungeon look like with standard flourescent tubes and daylight CFLs. I'll be getting more of these when 100w lights are needed.

For this price I'm thinking it's the best value for the dollar in a budget laptop, because I haven't seen a screen this nice on a sub-400-dollar laptop before. You get a full size keyboard with 10-key pad (MacBook Pro doesn't even have that), it's super light weight yet includes a DVD burner. Someone else mentioned that the screen was NOT great and text was blurry, and that may be a defective unit unfortunately. The screen on mine was quite sharp ("sharp" is relative I realize... we have a 15" MacBook Pro w/Retina in the house and no standard LCD can match THAT, but for a cheap LCD, the Asus' screen is quite impressive).There are a few cons to a laptop at this price, main one being the keyboard really. Instead of a solid keyboard in a metal tray like with more expensive laptops, the cost saver here was a cheap keyboard built into the THIN top deck. You can definitely push down on the keyboard and have the whole thing sink in a little. Not a deal breaker at this price. But the other sort-of downer is the hard drive and the upgrade options. I set this up as our laptop for Rosetta Stone language learning and coming off an i7 desktop I don't want a sluggish unit. i3 processors are not too bad but they need help, mainly with an SSD as the hard drive. This laptop comes with the dreaded 5400rpm mechanical drive which is unacceptably slow in 2015. We didn't need a ton of drive space so I grabbed a Samsung 250GB SSD for 79 bucks on sale and installed it, and it truly sped up but THAT is the big downer... the installation. There isn't a hard drive slot (or door on the back) that you pop open to exchange the hard drive, the drive is inside the laptop and you have to pop the deck off the laptop, a clip at a time, basically disassembling it. I did find a YT vid where a guy walks through it, just search the model number. I work on PCs all the time so no biggie but it's a little involved. NONETHELESS, with the SSD this thing is a little speed demon now, not for gaming obviously, but for every day stuff it's QUITE relevant. Again, the screen is a surprise, really quite nice for this class laptop. Oh, it has 4GB ram soldered on the motherboard, and there is a VERY easy-to-access extra RAM slot on the back requiring only one screw, and I popped that off and put in another 4GB 1.35v stick I happened to have, so now this thing is running the i3 w/8GB ram on a Samsung 850 SSD (non-pro model) and it's pretty quick for what it is. The laptop is very inexpensive and the case is kinda cheap as expected, so don't drop this thing, but it's a good travel size laptop and with the SSD the battery is averaging 4-5 hours (with the brightness down a little). Not bad for most flights.Oh, yeah, disclaimer: I'm not sure how Asus will feel about you popping the top deck off when it comes to honoring the warranty, so it probably voids the warranty. But the cruddy mechanical hard drive makes the laptop pretty much useless by 2015 standards, so I figured I might as well give an SSD a shot, and it worked very well. But my lawyer (if I really had one, lol) would make me say the following: THE AUTHOR OF THIS POST ASSUMES NO RESPONSIBILTY IF ANY DAMAGE IS INCURRED FROM ANY OWNER-EXECUTED UPGRADE OR DISASSEMBLY. PROCEED AT YOUR OWN RISK AND RESPONSIBILITY. Ok, legal broohah over with!

These do work well for food prep. My wife cooks a lot but actually has food sensitivities and has to wear gloves. These work well with her small hands, she found them easy to pull on, and food handling was pretty easy, much better than those baggy clear loose gloves that you buy in membership warehouse stores. The only thing to note, if this is importany, the gloves are somewhat porous so if you submerge your hands they will feel damp when you pull the gloves off. For most food applications that's not an issue but definitely don't use these if you work with acidic things like copper cleaner, etc. Overall, decent glove.

This review is really for the DIY'er, want to share the installation experience and hopefully save someone a headache or two.PROS:Well, it's installed, it works, it's definitely quieter than our old Genie, the adjustment process is simple and the parts are properly manufactured because everything fit together well.CONS:Just the manual. It's fine, you just need to read through it, TWICE, and get a handle on all of the part names which get referred to throughout the installation procedure as if they are cousins coming over for dinner, lol ("clip the idler pulley cover tab to the master link cover slot and slip through the trolley casing spring-loaded link slot on the outside of the casing")... that sort of thing. I definitely had a "wait... what?" moment a few times, LOL! But the drawings are ample enough, so if you take your time and refer back to the parts list in the beginning of the manual, you figure it out. In hindsight I would have printed the parts list from the PDF manual you can get online (you get a printed copy, not to worry) and taped it to the workbench, because I had to look back at it many times.So I just installed this on Saturday (10/31) and was able to do 99% of the job by myself, only had my son hold the motor end once while I connected the rail on the header over the garage. I took my slow, sweet merry old time and it took about 5 hours, including removal of our old unit. Basically I did a task on a page of the manual, then sit at my workbench and read the next page, then execute, etc. I'm sure the whole job can be done in 3 hours or less, I was in no rush really. Plan on installing everything before you test, meaning, the laser sensors that go near the bottom of the door need to be in place or the unit will not run.During assembly, there's a maneuver you do with a spring loaded bolt where you try to hold a slotted ring with a flathead screwdriver while turning the nut at the other end, and after a couple 1/4 turns the thing is supposed to go SNAP and lock itself in, and your belt tension is then properly adjusted. It's kind of weird even after reading the instructions a few times but I finally got it. The screwdriver in the slot thing didn't work, it kept buckling, so I grabbed the ring with needlenose pliers and turned the nut with a wrench and in one turn it popped into place. If that sounds confusing, it is, but when you go to do it, it'll make more sense. Read that manual before you start, can't stress that enough.Door operation works well, although I'm used to a gear drive and this is a belt unit. Here in Phoenix our garages get up over 120 degrees and plastic stuff doesn't do well so hopefully that belt stays pliable. It's definitely quieter in its movement, but motor really whines as it's moving the door, almost sounds like it isn't going to make it, but the door movement is quite steady so I believe it's just what the motor sounds like.When I first went to test it by hitting the wall button, the unit opened fully where the trolley hit the stop pin by the motor, and then the door wouldn't work again. It kept trying to open further but of course it couldn't move, and after 2 seconds it gave up obviously. I couldn't get the door to go the other way and close. The wall unit has an LCD and shows error codes which refer to the manual. My code told me to make sure there were no obstructions, and if there weren't then the motor needs to be replaced. HUH?? So I read the Adjustment section again and realized that the unit initially wants you to set the Up position, followed by the Down position. Since I hadn't told it where Up was, it kept trying to open, lol. So I went through the adjustment procedure, told it that Up was right where it was, and now lets do Down, and the thing reversed properly and worked. Then I re-adjusted it so I could set the real Up position, about an inch in front of the stop pin for our door. Sorry for the long explanation but if you hit that wall where it's acting like it's seized, do the Adjustment procedure and it should be fine.The two remote units were already programmed which was nice, and the visor clip is bigger than the remotes our old Genie unit which is nice because visors these days are way thicker. The wall unit has a thermometer and clock in its LCD so we finally get to see HOW hot the garage gets in the summer, lol. You can also program it to tell it hpw the light fixture should work (come on when the door opens, or come on from motion sensor, or both). The wall unit has a separate light switch which I'm really happy about, because this unit has a bulb socket on each side of the motor and and lights up the garage quite nicely. I used these 26w CFLs which are max it takes (or 100w incadescent): GE 15836 - 26 Watt CFL Light Bulb - Compact Fluorescent - 100 W Equal - 2700K Warm White - Min. Start Temp. 5 Deg. F - 82 CRI - 65 Lumens per Watt - 12 Month Warranty . Now the garage is nice and bright and these CFLs are nice and warm with a 2700K color temp. Daylight CFLs are so blue and dreary, but these work really well.OK, wireless home network hook-up and iPhone app: don;t slap me but I'll be setting that up on Thursday, didn't have time these past couple days and the review was due. Sorry! I do work with wireless networks in my IT job so I'll be sure to explain how that process works and how easy or hard it was to get it to connect and work. Update coming!

This is the bigger brother of the XP-830 that I've been using and REALLY liking because of the excellent dual-sided paper handling via a motorized tray, and because of the print quality. This 960 is the exact same: Clean printing, fast output that still looks sharp (draft mode used to be a JOKE with Epson), and a mechanically driven moving paper deck for DOUBLE SIDED PRINTING THAT IS FLAWLESS. I'm not kidding. I wrote in the 830 review that I didn't expect that and I had actually wondered why this printer was up there in price when you can easily get AIO's for 89 bucks. The motorized paper handling deck works very well, and looks totally cool while it's "performing", lol.Also, Epson has done such a great job with device printing on this Expression series. I now keep this printer connected to my PC at work, don't want it on the main wireless network nor do I want to share it. But I want to be able to print from my iPhone and iPad. Asking too much? NOPE, not with this unit. It creates its own wireless network and therefore you can print directly to it (I assume that means Android also, just have no way to test that). The LCD on the printer is a flip up color screen with menus to set everything up including the AirPrint network, or even print direct from your memory cards. Speaking of setting up, the driver and app software was an easy download from Epson's site, and it actually WORKED, quickly at that. Setup with the 4 Epsons I owned between 2000 and 2007 was ALWAYS a nightmare, the software would never detect the printer. That's all fixed now, the setup on this 960 was easy peazy, and right after it was done (using the online Windows 10 drivers, not the CD), the Epson utility software went right back out and checked for a Firmware update which there WAS one. I downloaded that and the update went perfect. I had done that with the 830 as well, so it appears Epson has that all shored up, and you won't brick your printer with a firmware update.The copy machine part also performed pretty near perfect. This printer also does CD/DVD printing and Epson provides a nifty slot to store the tray so you don't have to find a spot in your desk drawer to store it.OK, Photo printing: Epson uses 6 cartridges to include Photo Magenta and Photo Cyan which are lighter version to help get good gradations in color. Pretty standard in a true photo printer so I'm glad to see it in this all-in-one. The overall photo print quality is superb as expected and a big part of that has to do with the quality paper handling the printer has, that makes a HUGE difference. When you start printing your own photos bigger at 11x17, they really start to take on a different dimension. Landscapes look super sharp when using a glossier paper and this 960 excels in that area. There's no separate Photo Black cartidge in this 960 like with the 830 which is a little disappointing, but instead Epson opted for the light magenta and cyan cartridges instead. Great for landscape images, but for portrait work on matte papers, things like hair on a brunette may not have as much detail with just the one black cartridge. Nonetheless, the print quality is up to 2015 standards, if that helps explain it. I own two other Canon 13x19 printers as a comparison, and this supposed "office all in one" can keep up quite well.One last thought in regards to ANY photo printer: while the concept of borderless printing is a nice feature, nearly every pro photographer that I know that does their own prints never uses that feature, and neither do I. The nozzles have to stop spraying ink at the edge of the paper but in order to ensure borderless, the ink does spray slightly past the edge, and over time it makes quite a mess inside the unit. Ths 960 does do borderless so that's why I mention it. One way to get around that is to print with a slim ¼" border then trim the print. This is just a suggestion based on many years of printing but it will cause less headaches down the road if you avoid that. Overall, this is best printer for office work and occasional photo printing I've own because all of the features work well (print, scan, copy). But if it was your ONLY photo printer then you will be more that satisfied, don't let the AIO category bother you, photos (with good photo paper) look great.Often when someone wants a home office AIO I steer them to Canons because I had given up years ago on Epson. But things have changed and the local wireless AirPrint network and the motorized dual-sided printing (and small footprint) makes this a new favorite. I use it everyday at work and it's been flawless.

Great watch. Built like a tank. I own several Invictas and one of my favorite attributes is the bands are long enough to fit my 8Â¼" wrist. In fact, I had to remove one link from this band, it was too loose! Definitely a big guy's watch (which I am at 300+). It's pretty heavy, but it looks great. It looks better in person than the photo. The crown is real easy to turn and adjust. BTW, get a watch band link remover tool (like this one: Leegoal Watch Link Remover with Pins (12pins)) if you plan on getting the pins out to remove links which I'm almost certain you will have to. The pins are TIGHT, in fact there was an audible crack when I popped one of the two out. It's perfectly fine but no way you'll get these Invicta pins out any other way. Look inside the band and you'll see which direction to push the pin out with the tool, Invicta puts arrows there, great feature.The only things I was not so enamored with may not be a problem for others: the three dials are super small, no way my 50+ eyes will see them, but that's OK, the time is most important. The other thing to note is that the band rattles if you shake your arm. It's kinda cool in some ways but it does make noise. Lastly, if you've ever had to deal with the Invicta website for registering and/or creating account, you'll discover why they make money building watches and not websites. Pretty buggy, lol.Overall, for the price, it's a heavy bulky Sherman Tank that looks awesome, I'm quite pleased.

Stanley did a good job on this container, it really lives up to its claim for keeping things cold or hot as expected (my wife sends a huge pot of spaghetti to work with me in this thing, not sure this is a good or bad thig, lol!). What I really like it the construction, the locks work well, the handle feels strong, and Stanley uses real 18/8 stainless as well as BPA-free plastic. It's a workhorse without a doubt.

Absolute 5-star filter. For 30 years I argued with all brands of filters (threads going bad, hard to keep clean, list goes on), and about 7 years ago Idecided to invest in a B+W and have never looked back. I only use CPLs and neutral density filters now (got past the gimmicky filters so prevalent in the 80s) and B+W are the only brand I will touch. There are a couple specific features of this XS-Pro CPL but first I want to mention that the precision of the threads and the fact that they use brass and not aluminum has always set B+W apart. Also the way they seal the film in between the glass is key to the optical quality they offer.I recently changed my wide angle lens from a 16-35/2.8 (with 82mm threads) to Canon's new 16-35mm/4.0 with IS which uses a 77mm filters, same as my 70-20mm, so I was ready for a CPL that would work on both. When B+W announced the XS-Pro line with the ultra thin ring, it was a no-brainer. It justy happened to become available on Vine, hence this review. But the two important  fetaures are the obvious lack of vignetting even at 16mm (on a full frame 5D3), and that the CPL effect is completely consistent and even , yet it's only a 1-stop loss of light! This will actually change how I use a CPL because it's mostly been to remove reflections from leaves and water for landscape work, and reflections in glass for architecture. This filter excels in that just like the F-mount Kaessemenn version. The 3-stp loss of light in those situations is not normally an issue because I'm on a tripod. I never liked using a CPL for darkening the sky because all CPLs made it look so postcard-blue, totaly fake looking. BUT, this HTC version only darkens the sky by one stop and therefore leaves the sky with some brightness but allows the camera's metering to open up to expose ground shadows. This is pretty crucial for shooting outdoor images handheld. I was walking sround on my street with the 16-35mm taking shots of the neighborhood that actually showed detail in the gorund and houses while still maintaining a not-too-blown-out sky. It was like I had a graduated ND filter that knew to just attenuate the highlights! This is crazy, opens up the possibility to reduce (not eliminate, that'll never happen) post processing for certain types of images. I usually shoot in manual and select the exposure which I still will quite often, but to have the freedom to control the luminance range on the fly BECAUSE this CPL is only cutting one stop of light is a special feature that I was not expecting. I absolutely need to purchase the 72mm version for my 50mm lens. This might sound a bit odd but I think B+W has a game changer here for run-and-gun street shooters, al la Henri Cartier-Bresson style of shooting. I'd give this filter 6 stars if I could, and I'm usually not that big of a filter fan.I've posted a photo showing how well this HTC removes reflections, even with only a 1-stop reduction in light. Quite impressive. The real advantage of course is when shooting landscapes with a ton of foliage, the reflections of light off of shiny leaves gets removed and the result is some seriously rich-looking foliage in your shot. That's one thing that Photoshop can't really do, but for this filter it's a breeze.

I actually expected to NOT be that enthralled with this printer, I owned several Epson letter-sized inkjets from 2000-2008 and got fed up with the cheesy paper handling, the BUGGY driver installation that didn;t recognize your printer half the time, and worst of all, the clogging heads. I spent more time than necessary back then cleaning and soaking nozzles to try and get the things to print. I made my switch to Canon and never looked back until this came along.So I've been using it daily, hammering away, and its been nothing short of amazing, especially in the paper handling area. Clean printing, fast outout that still looks sharp (draft mode used to be a JOKE with Epson), and a mechanically driven moving paper deck for DOUBLE SIDED PRINTING THAT IS FLAWLESS. I'm not kidding. I didn't expect that and I had actually wondered why this printer was up there in price when you can easily get AIO's for 89 bucks. The motorized paper handling deck works very well, and looks totally cool while it's "performing", lol.The copy machine part also performed pretty near perfect. I copied several documents for my guitar students and almost couldn't tell the two apart. I don't use the fax segment, but both copy and fax are really a scan and then execute an output so there's no reason faxing should noty look good.Photo printing: Canon added a very good feature that you see usually on the higher-end pro photo printers: besides the standard Cyan, Magenta, Yellow and Black cartridges, they included a Photo Black to handle certain types of photo paper media. Nice. I have that in my pro non-Epson 13x19 photo printers but to see it here makes this quite a viable unit to hammer out 4x6's to 8x10's.OK, last but very cool feature: device printing. I keep this printer connected to my PC at work, don't want it on the main wireless network nor do I want to share it. But I want to be able to print from my iPhone and iPad. Asking too much? NOPE, not with this unit. It creates its own wireless network and therefore you can print directly to it (I assume that means Android also, just have no way to test that). The LCD on the printer is a flip up color screen with menus to set everything up including the AirPrint network, or even print direct from your memory cards. Speaking of setting up, the driver and app software was an easy download from Epson's site, and it actually WORKED, quickly at that.Oh, one more feature! This unit also does CD/DVD printing. I'm starting to think this printer is capable of writing my uncle in the Navy...Often when someone wants a home office AIO I steer them to Canons because I had given up years ago on Epson. But things have changed and the local wireless AirPrint network and the motorized dual-sided printing (and small footprint) makes this a new favorite. I use it everyday at work and it's been flawless.

What I liked:Good RAM, good price. I put these in my AlienWare 17 R2 and put them to the test: first an hour long run using MemTest86+, and they pass with no errors. Second was rendering a 1.3GB .mov HD 1080p video file out of a Canon DSLR, and transcoding it to an .MP4 with H.264 compression very common rendering set up), using Adobe Media Encoder. The video conversion ran as expected on my system, a little faster than real time (I did leverage the NVidia mobile graphics card. So, it all worked as expected.The BIOS mounted the memory without any problems and listed it as 1600MHz as expected.What I didn't like:The packaging is the worst kind, the heat sealed clamshell NON-recyclable plastic, where you have to grasp the package tightly and sliced along he edge witha box knife, undoubtedly cutting your hand on the plastic's newly cut edge. Really PNY? Mushkin and Corsair are using pull-apart recyclable plastic, opening your package shouldn't be dangerous, lol.

Well, as promised (and after following directions), grass is starting to emerge. I noticed that with the hydro-coated seeds, the birds in our yard aren't really interested in devouring them, a nice bonus. Anyway, I'll revisit this review and probably up it to 5 stars once the lawn is fully grown... it's a bit difficult to evaluate this seed with the 30-day time limit, lol. But so far, so good. It did take about 10 days before any grass showed up, jsyk.

This iOne is probably the BEST point of entry devices for any musician or budding audio engineer. Here's why: the unit itself has some terrific features for the price (which I'll explain in a sec) but the double bonus is the Studio One 3 Artist version which is the DAW software (Digital Audio Workstation) that comes bundled, because the ease of use of Studio One is superb. But first about the hardware, because it has a couple nice features, but there are also some scenarios where you would do much better with the iTwo version which I'll explain.OK, the iOne: it's like the ultimate songwriter's dream come true, especially if you play acoustic guitar and sing (or any type of instrument really). The setup is super easy, you can use your laptop, desktop OR iPad, it sounds good and does have monitoring so you can hear playback while recording additional parts. The Class A preamp in the XLR input jack does sound better than expected for a hundred-dollar unit. Not quite the headroom of the XMAX preamps in the PreSonus SudioLive board we use at church, but still quite good. I used to use the Focusrite iTrack Solo but the iPad connection required a very short and stiff specialized cable to connect the iPad.. If i have to worry that I need a special cable that could get lost, that's a deal-breaker. That's one feature of this iOne that I like: all you need is an extra iPad cable.OK, the Setup I use to record parts and song ideas, and I'm focusing this on the iPad setup because that's a flagship feature of this model series: I use a Groove Tubes GT50 mic for my acoustic guitar plugged into the iOne as expected. You then plug a standard Apple cable into the iOne and the Lightning end goes into the iPad, again, easy peazy. That's the extra Apple cable you will need. Then all you need is your iPad charger & cable which you'll actually use to power the iOne. If you are using a PC/Mac/laptop, the iOne powers off of that, FYI. OK, just download the PreSonus Capture app from the App Store and your recording setup is complete. If desired, you can also plug and standard guitar cable from your guitar into the second jack with is a 1/4" TRS, and record two separate tracks. For additional tracks you can listen with headphones, and there's a 50/50 mix switch to monitor as you record. That's not ideal, the iTwo gives you a knob to dial the mix, but on this iOne it's a switch. Anyway, that's the simple setup.The Studio One 3 software that comes bundled (you download it) is for your Mac or PC. Once you install that and also download teh bundled instruments, etc, then the really cool part happens. With your computer and iPad on the same network, you open the Capture iPad app that has your recordings, and wireless send them to Studio One on your computer. DONE. Now you can do all of the editing you need, add effects, EQ, whatever. Even add more instruments if you have a MIDI USB Keyboard. The one thing I would say is that the available upgrade to Studio One 3 Professional is something you'll want to eventually do, it has a mastering section and supports 3rd party plugins like what you can get at Waves.Here are a couple reasons to consider the iTwo, just FYI: First is dual XLR inputs. If you want to record a piano or other live situation in stereo, the two mic jacks are huge. Second is that variable monitoring knob, WAY better than the 50-50 mix button on the iOne. Last is MIDI support if that's important, the iTwo has the ancient MIDI barrel jacks in the back. But overall the iOne is a songwriter's dream, and bundled with Capture and of course Studio One, what PreSonus is offering here is best features for the buck. I admit I'm a dedicated PreSonus customer, and Studio One 3 Pro is absolutely my favorite DAW. This iOne will be my songwriting quick-and-easy setup rig, and when the Studio 192 gets released, that'll become my main interface for serious recording.

To my surprise this turned out to be quite a nicely built clamp meter. Most AC-only clamp meters in this price range pretty much have the same features (this model doesn't do DC but it perfect for home construction). What I really liked was the narrower case and the strong rubber coating on both the case the selector knob... here's why and I should mention that this is my favorite feature: EASY one-handed operation (right hand). Most situations where I need to clamp a circuit almost always seem to be in a tight spot between studs over my head tucked in a corner, so having to reach with one hand has to be made easy, and this model 210 does that. It's so easy to change measurement modes and open the tight clamp it offers (a good thing). I also feel like if I drop this thing it'll bounce and laugh at me, not crack. It came with a decent cancas case as well, plus moisture-proff leads with the barrel plugs. For this price, great deal. My only gripe and this was the same with my previous clamp meter: needing a screwdriver to open the battery compartment, and it has to be a #1 Philips. A sturdy clip door would be so much better, but overall, good meter.

This is quite frustrating, the iPhone app simply will not connect to the Link unit, which is the transceiver that is the"link" between the siren & door mounts, and the iPhone App (and remote control unit). I have tried every option that the manual and the website gives you for resetting the Link, it simply will not work. When the iPhone app DOES connect the screen immediately throws back "Device Already In Use". Huh?The most frustrating part is that MyFox has kept this TOO simple. The manual is a single sentence and an Ikea-like drawing on what step to take next, with NO troubleshooting info. The Link unit has several different types of flashing paterns for its one lighted logo, and you don't even know what they mean unless you go search it on their webpage. Absolutely nothing in the manual provided.I do know that the Link unit is connected to my network, that's a simple peek at the DHCP table on my router's firmware page. So I was hoping there would be the same firmware utility page for the link, but there is NONE, so simple troubleshooting is not possible and I have no ideas why the iPhne won;t connect, therefore making the system unable to be setup and managed. I know it's not my iPhone 6 Plus, I use that regularly to wirelessly link to our 32-channel digital mixing desk at our church and run the gain on our auziliary monitor mixes remotely, plus I'm the iOS support at the semiconductor company I work for (just stating that so it's known that I have somewhat of a clue). I have a decent NetGear router powering our network, not a cheap $59 model. The playing field is set, this system should work. At this point, even if I did get this working, how can I trust it? Ether the thing won't trigger when I need it, or that 110db alarm will fire off at 3am, I just know it. This is so frustrating, I thought we had a decent first line of defense with this system, but it simply will not connect. Also, you get ONE door/window sensor and the additional are $50 a piece, so with the additional 11 doors and windows in our home, that's $550 just for sensors.If this system jumped into action like MyFox claims, I'd give it 4 stars right off the bat. I'd even up it to 5 if they got more realistic about the sensor price (I know, a lot of research went itno making them, so the price better descrease as sales increase). But as it stands, it's useless. I wish it wasn;t.

Three stars means It's Okay and for me PERSONALLY, that's where I'm at with this tuner, but not for the polytuningtechnology part. That feature is good, works as expected, I've never been disappointed with TC stuff ever since the 80's when I started using their gear (in fact, I own the M-One XL of theirs). But I'm not so crazy about this tuner because of its construction, not because of function. The tuner has VERY sharp metal edges on the body and the clip, I seriously think you could cut yourself slightly. I know if I drop this and it hits my guitar it's going to damage the finish. The other problem is the clamp itself: forget the squeaky noise it makes when you squeeze the clip open, it's the STRENGTH of the clamp that's a bit too much. And the rubber feet that actually touch the headstock are pretty hard, not pliable at all, so I'm definitely convinved that repeated use will dent the headstock ot at least the finish. I sprang for a Taylor 618e new 2015 series with the super-thin 3.5 mil finish, and this TC tuner is NOT going on my guitar any more. I don't need the polytune feaure all that much now that I've tested it. My Snark Super Tight works just fine, one string at a time doesn't bother me and that tuner is completely rubber coated. If you have something like a Strat with a thick gloss finish on a maple neck then you probably won't have finish damage. The tuner works well, I just don't trust how it mounts. So if you have no issues in that regard and want a polytune clip-on, then yes, go for it.

I use several Nexxus shampoes and thier conditioner so I'm already biased on the good side. And this Emergencee does do what it says, my hair feels great and doesn't look ratty. The problem I can't get past is the scent. It's that super thick perfumed powder scent that, to be honest, gets pretty sickening after even a short time of smelling it. And the scent stays with you all day. Not for me, I'm a guy, don't need that in a shampoo. So it works, my brtittle hot-all-summer-in-Phoenix hair has nicely come around using this, but this stuff is stronger than Febreeze I think...
Good stick and tape strength but VERY difficult to peel. Basically you need to press a corner on metal like a knife blade and scrape the corner of the paper back. But the stick is quite good.

I'm a longtime SanDisk User and have been waiting for this day, where I can get a multiformat card with at least 32GB, and to get this at 14 bucks is crazy good (My first CF card was 512MB, 92 bucks, lol). This SanDisk version supports UHS-I so shooting video or rapid fire shots is easy peazy. Then to be able to pop the card into an Ultra Micro slot and a huge advantage especially for Droid slate owners.Overall it's a 4-star card simply for the slower Write speeds, which are about ¼ of the Read speeds. Yes, it's under 20 bucks but only cards that ead and write at the same speed are 5 star cards IMO. I'm seeing about 15-17MB/sec writing to this card from an SSD (using a 700MB test file) on a PC. However, reading from this card to an SSD, that same 700MB file copied to the SSD instantly. Therefore copying off of this card to another device is fast and a big plus.Great build quality, the adapter feels very solid so you canb use this as an SDHC card without worry the Micro card will fly out. 10 year SanDisk warranty also can't be beat.

Well made, perfect system for managing lessons and sheets for my guitar students. The built-in file folder pockets make it worth while, usually ring binders have a cheesy pocket. The vertical flip feature works but the binding is stiff and it feels like repetive folding will eventually make it fall apart, so i just open the binder flat to get to the files. The outside pocket fits my iPad quite well. I use a slim DeviceWear case, FYI.
Works exactly as described with my Alesis Q49, feels well-made and the action/pressure of the pedal is just right (to me anyway). Not much more to add, for this price, no-brainer.

Works very well because it's wide enough so that ladles and other larger utensils don't roll off. We tried a couple others that were narrower and all had that issue. Since this Le Creuset is wider it also lays flat and stays put. My only gripe is that it's a bit expensive for a spoon holder. But it does what we want, so lack of aggravation is worth the price, lol.

I use this on an Altec-Lansing speaker unit that has the 30-pin plug, design for you to sit your old iPhone or iPod on it. That unit sounds really good with its subwoofer so I hated losing the ability to use it with the new iPhones. Popping on the CoolStream is now a dream come true. Connects right up and does what it's supposed to. You will need one of the older 30-pin cables to charge this unit off of any USB port or even the Apple charger, but if you don't have one of those older cables laying around, you can pretty much find those in the impulse aisles for 5 bucks in every store from Walgreens to Ace Hardware, they're all over the place.One thing I want to mention: I had a problem one day where the music would cut out and come back on every 3 seconds or so. That happened with another BluTooth adapter I tried, I thought it was the adapter. Not so, it's the BAD memory management in the iPhone. They only come with 1GB ram, and often most of that gets used up. I have an app that shows available ram and it's usually down to 6-10MB available (not a typo) with only a few apps open. So I cleared my memory, tried playing music again and it worked fine all afternoon. So if you have that issue, close your apps, but the important one is to close ALL PAGES in Safari before you close Safari. If you just swipe up Safari to close it, all of your open web pages stay in memory and eat it up. I'm pretty ticked, $950 for an iPhone 6 Plus with 128GB storage and STILL only 1GB ram? ASpple has no excuse and it's not like they can't afford to up the ram in these things. ANYWAY, this CoolStream is awesome and make sure you have apps closed down once you start streaming with BT and it'll work great.

I'm still trying to understand this... a very well-made and HEAVY cable tester with all of the audio connections you'd expect in a standard live rig or studio set up, and it's under 20 bucks. I'm still trying to figure out what the catch is. I guess the only drawback is that it IS built like a Sherman Tank and it's not that light, so it'll add weight to your tool bag. But if/when you drop this thing on a tile floor, you'l be replacing tiles, not the tester, lol. Very impressed, for this price, no-brainer.

OK, a cable is a cable mostly, I get that, but to be honest I was expecting a lot CHEAPER quality for a "Basics" cable. Instead I was quite amazed how well made and strong these cables feel. I now have a couple other Amazon cables and I'm thinking these are the industry secret, lol. Great quality at an amazing price. FYI, I also own several Basics camera gear bags and a 17" laptop bag and they are ALL well padded and well made. So Amazon is on to something here which ends up saving us some bucks. Can't beat that. Anyway, this cable works like a charm, has gold plated connectors and thick tough casing around the plug. Definitely worth using.

I put these in an Acer V3-772G 17" laptop and they posted immediately and run great, as expected. Been using Crucial RAM since 2006 and have purchased MANY different sets for PC builds and repairs. The stuff just works and is mostly made right here in the USA. Not much else to tell really!

I'm a hefty guy with fairly wide thumbs so finding a thumbpick that fits comfortably is a task in a half. I tried Nationals, forget it, not even close. I tried John Pearse and with a little heat-n-adjustment (I'll explain that in a sec) they fit really nice, BUT, the pick part is too short for me, doesn't stick out enough, I keep missing the strings. That's just how I play but the Pearse picks are comfortable. But now I have found thumbpick bliss with the Dunlops. Granted, out of the bag they are not quite right... the top part with the logo curves into my finger too much and digs in, I need it flatter. So I Googled a bit and discovered that tossing the pick for 8 seconds in my microwave (1000w unit for the scientifically minded) makes it perfectly moldable! I "uncurve" the top part a bit and then open the thumbpick up a little to make the opening bigger overall, and I am one happy picker. Fits perfectly. I have NOT tried this on the tortoise shell versions, it may work the same but the plastic compound may be different, not sure. But for the white ones, it's a dream come true. The pick part sticks out just enough for my liking, but certainly test that before yyou buy a bag of 50, lol. Final thought: I heard Tommy Emmanuel mention in an interview that he buys a big bag of Dunlops (Medium), goes through and finds the few that fit right and gives away the rest. So the picks are obviously a bit different in shape and opening size (as you would expect, it's plastic) but with the microwave trick you can pretty much make a custom tailored suit for your finger, lol.Somebody hand Tommy a microwave oven. =-)

So far so good... I'm not getting the famous error that says "This accessory not supported" like I get with other 3rd party cables. I plugged in my iPad Air into my Win 8.1 PC, fired up iTunes and the iPad appeared right away, didn;t have to do the repeated plugging-unplugging to get it to show in iTunes that even happens with Apple's cables. However, that may be an iTunes thing but at least this Belkin worked. I did a backup and then loaded up a bunch of .mp4 vids to transfer onto the iPad via iTunes and it all flew right in. Data-wise, two thumbs up. I've tried other "MFi Certified" 3rd party cables that still failed.The build quality of the cable is noticeably tougher and it's also longer than the stock Apple cable. So this is an overall winner, aside from the longevity test which I can't do obviously in my 30-day review window. However, if and when it fails or cracks, I'll absolutely report back with that.

I've got this oven in my office at work and have been putting it through its paces... frozen pizzas, french bread pizzas, you name it. Also got english muffins with a jar of sauce and provolone to make little minis unfrozen. In all scenarios this pizza oven did a great job, but ONLY after I learned its ways and its quirks. The manual gives you general temp settings and times for everything from cinnamon rolls to frozen deep dish pizza, but just like any manual there's a bit of idealistic verbiage on how the thing really works. So TEST IT and you'll pick up pretty quickly how best to use it. As an example, frozen french bread pizzas (Stouffers) don't come out singing Kumbaya ready to be eaten with the stock temp in the manual, they come out a bit cold in the center and the pepperoni a tad burnt. So I modified the cooking a bit, and to be honest, this method seems to work for most frozen pizza: PREHEAT for 3-4 minutes first, that's pretty important (and I'm a guy, we like to toss it in, turn it on and nothing else), but do the preheat. Then bake the frozen items 10 minutes on Bake which is 375 degrees. Once the bell rings, turn the knob one click to Frozen Snacks which is 600 degrees and do 2 more minutes. Ba da bing, awesome frozen pizza. Skip the two minutes if you don't like a toasted top. So with a little experimentation you can get great results.Some folks call it a glorified toaster oven but the elements and size definitely work GREAT for pizza. The three top elements are spaced wide apart unlike a normal toaster oven so the broiling on top is quite even. Also, this thing runs HOT and will cook way faster than any toaster oven I've used. Because it's a pizza oven the inside area is not very tall, so things like foil-wrapped leftover fried chicken that DOES fit in our Black & Decker toaster oven definitely doesn't fit in here. But the deck is wide enough to handle 3 leftover pizza slices at once and heat them evenly due to the wide spaced elements up top. So for what it's SUPPOSED to do, it does well, hence 5 stars. I really couldn't think what to dock it for as a pizza oven. BTW, the deck is really heavy duty and stick-free, so if you're careful you won't many or any crumbs to clean out. I like this unit more than expected, hope it lasts. If it fails, I'll be back.

I purposely waited three weeks to write this review because this is the 5th extender I've tried and I wanted to be absolutely sure this thing would work like it stated. I had reviewed a D-Link DAP-1650 that I had purchased and it seemingly worked well with our Linksys E6900 router. Then Cox offered me a nice bundle upgrade that included them providing a new NetGear N900 router, and when they did that the D-Link extender went erratically nuts and we fought it for over a month, dropping connections intermittenly especially with iOS devices. SO, the Netgear Extender comes along... here we go again. Unbelievably this extender has been totally flawless (I can't believe I just said that about a consumer network extender). First, it was, by far, the easiest setup I've ever done, and I don't use the easy button, I always set wireless networks manually becuase I change a certain range in the IP Address, and the setup webpage was a breeze to configure. I did it on my iPad, not even a laptop. Then the next huge plus I noticed was the LEDs on the unit letting you know if the location you chose has a strong enough signal. I had always wondered that, is the location I picked in our long-ish ranch home the right distance from the router? I have a constant green light, no orange so I know I'm good. I set up the unit as an Extender (you can also choose to run it as an access point) and the two networks, 2.4 and 5.0GHz, have worked perfectly for nearly a month. AND, the second set of LEDs on the unit shows the signal strength of your connected device. Our iPads are all green on the extended end of the house, and FINALLY we have full coverage, almost can't believe it. In fact, the router alone would fade on the other end of the house and my iPhone would switch to LTE before using an extender, and now of course I get full bars and am happy. BUT, the bars stay full walking back all the way to the router end of the house, this device is that strong!
