So we keep our devices on the extended network all the time and the drop-out headaches are gone finally, after two years of arguing with extenders.This unit does have a heftier price that other extenders and I believe that price vs performance means that the price should be considered, but I tell you what, the extra cost is worth the piece of mind to not have to deal with quirky intermittent signals any long. The only scenario I CAN'T review on is if this works as stable with non-NetGear routers. Being a higher-priced unit and clearly well-built, I'd guess it's work on a Linksys or other router. I sure hope so, this thing WORKS.UPDATE, 6/18/2015: Our power got cut off temporarily at our house which shut this extender off in a flash of course, and when the power was restored, it was back online and working in under a minute. I should say that our router/modem is on a battery backup so that never shut off, but still, cutting the power on extenders usually freaks them out for a few minutes, lol. This thing came right back up. And still not one dropout or interruption while on it, and we do stream a lot of video with the buggy Cox Contour app on our iPad. That's our TV in our bedroom and on the last extender we had, rebooting was a daily ritual. Not this NetGear, I'm still amazed.UPDATE, 8/3/2015: Energizer Bunny, this extender just keeps going and...It's usually after the first month when extenders seem to really start struggling, yet this NetGear is still flawless. Since our Cox-provided NetGear modem/router needs to be rebooted every few days because Cox can't get it together, we've basically stress-tested the extender's ability to jump right back on the network, and it has not failed AT ALL. rebooting the modem in the past meant rebooting the other rand extenders as well. No need for that with this NetGear. I still can't believe we found an extender that works, amazin'.

This wrench set is just what I wanted. Sturdy wrenches but not too heavy. Each wrench is clearly labeled with it's size. It comes with a holder as well that keeps them all neatly organized in my tool drawer. Love them!

This was the perfect follow-up to Jon Krakauer's Missoula. While Krakauker's book focused mainly on the rapes at the University of Montana, this book was much broader and did a great job of discussing many different aspects that contribute to our "rape culture" and how this is affecting women -- and men too. I found the book extremely well-written in a style that informed but also engaged the reader. Rape is a scary, hard-to-talk-about issue, especially when victims of this crime are so discredited. But the book offered hope as well. This definitely gives me a lot to talk about with my almost college age daughters.

What an attractive but useless piece of junk that is going straight into the garbage. I tried this out with a nice, fresh, juicy piece of ginger and got nothing but scraped fingers and a little bit of ginger mush that made the rest of the ginger too slippery to hold. This goes not work at all.

This oil is very thick so a little goes a long way. I squeeze a small amount into my hand and then rub into my damp hair and comb it through. It definitely leaves my hair soft without being greasy. The scent is a bit strong but it is pleasant.
The moisturizer itself is nice. Creamy but not greasy and leaves my skin soft. The scent, however, is too strong for me.

Justine is running away from her abusive pimp and ends up in an obscure Scotland town where she becomes the only witness to a hit and run accident which puts a boy in the hospital, and ends up staying with the family of the boy.I was hooked on this book right from the first page and seriously could hardly put it down until I was done. Great writing, quirky, well-drawn characters, weird happenings, and plenty of suspense. Absolutely LOVED it! Can't wait to read other books by this author.

This is supposed to be a tinted moisturizer which supposedly changes to match any skin type. Sounds too good to be true right? Well, trust your instincts and skip this if you want any tinting. The cream is thick and white and does not do any tinting other than a whitish sunscreen look. I was very disappointed in this and it's going straight in the trash.

I'm completely happy with this planner. It's just what I had hoped for. Each month has a monthly view as an overview and then opens to weekly views with plenty of room for writing notes. I also like that this is not spiral bound so it slips in and out of my purse easily. I love everything about this planner and am glad to have found it.

I love to listen to my iPod while doing yard work but I've had the worst time with earbuds. They are always falling out and it's such a pain to get them back in when wearing gardening gloves or with dirty hands. Plus I'm always getting things tangled in the cords. Well these in-ear headphones are the answer to my problems. First of all, they do NOT fall out. Seriously. They are held securely in my ear and I had no problem even when I was hot and sweaty during my last stint of 3 hours of yardwork in the blazing sun. The other thing I love is that there is a little clip on the cord so I could clip it to my shirt strap to keep securely out of the way of getting tangled in foliage or garden tools. I'm so happy to have gotten these headphones. I'll never go back to the other kind!

I was disappointed in this product. It left my hair sticky and dry, rather than shiny and smooth. It may help with the volume, but I'd rather have soft hair. I'll stick with my argan oil which gives much better results.

If you are looking for a plain, functional, high quality datebook, this is the one. It's large with plenty of room to write in your plans. There are no cutesy designs--in fact no designs at all--so it appears professional and businesslike-like. It's large and thick so it's not going to fit in a purse--but to keep at home or in the office it's perfect.

What stands out the most on this datebook is how pretty it is. It's attractive and makes me smile to use it--but the  design also takes up a lot of space which leaves less for recording actual information in the book. I was impressed by the quality -- I think this will hold up well to being taken in and out of my purse all year long. Overall, I'm very happy with this planner.

The headmaster of a New England boarding school receives a video of several students engaged in sexual activity which starts this story off with a bang. The book alternates from the point of view of a whole cast of characters who were either involved in the unfortunate incident or affected by it. Some is given as "testimony" and some is narration. The book also alternates between time periods--before the incident, the incident and after the incident. I thought all the different points of view worked well to get the reader to realize the far-reaching effects something like this has, though I was occasionally confused about where in time we were. I love Shreve's writing and really enjoyed this book. It seemed to lose steam at the end as it meandered to a finish, which is why I rated this 4 stars rather than 5. I will say, this is a book I'm still thinking about and has me wanting to talk to my teenage daughters about the potential consequences of a bad decision.

I have to say that I was expecting more from this cleaner. I used it to clean my patio furniture and it didn't work any better than regular soap and water. I was able to get the dirt off of my furniture, but the stains remained. Also, the sprayer doesn't spray--it either shoots in a line or it just kind or drizzles all over (I guess that's the foaming option). I recommend using this in the shade as it dries almost immediately in the sun.

I must say I really love this cleanser. At first the foam felt so light, I didn't think it would wash well but really you only need a little bit and it cleanses gently but thoroughly. My favorite part, however, is the smell. It's not perfumey at all but has a wonderful natural citrusy (lemon verbena maybe?) scent that is just heavenly.

This tube of hand cream is the perfect size for my purse. It feels a little oily when I first put it on, but after a few minutes, it soaks in and leaves my hands feeling very soft and smooth. It has a perfumey fragrance, but it is not unpleasant and not too strong. Overall, I am happy with this cream.

The soap is okay--it doesn't lather up as much as I'd like but it works well enough as a mild soap. I dont' really like this as a variety pack, because the only scent we like is the Mango Ice Cream. The others are two perfumey.

Tessa was the only survivor of the Black-Eyed Susans-a group of girls tortured by a serial killer and found in a shallow grave adorned by said flowers. Though the supposed killer is convicted and sentenced to death, she still finds the flowers planted at the various places she lives and is unsure if he really is the true killer. As the execution date nears, Tessa has to relive her experiences to determine if he really is guilty or innocent.It took me a while to get into this book. The book alternates between the present which is a countdown to the execution of the convicted supposed killer and the past when Tessa was in therapy to help her deal with the aftermath of her experience with the Black-Eyed Susan killer. The past segments were repetitive, but eventually the book got moving and became quite engrossing with a nice surprising twist.

I am very impressed with the quality of this juicer. It's sturdy and attractive. It works excellently and the feeder tube is large enough that I can put whole apples in so I don't need to cut them up. All the parts are BPA-free and I like that I can choose the pulp level and the speed. I also appreciate the covered pitcher that comes with the juicer. Be sure to put the cover on as you are making the juice as it prevents the juice from spraying all over your counter and the large size of the pitcher is nice for storing any extra juice.That being said, this is advertised as an "easy clean" juicer. I don't find it easier to clean than other juicers I have used. There are many pieces to disassemble and clean--though the parts mostly just need to be emptied of pulp and rinsed. The only thing that needs to be scrubbed is the basket (the scrubber comes with the juicer) and that takes a few minutes. But still, it does take time to assemble, make the juice, disassemble and clean just to get a cup of juice. Not something I'd use every day but great for when I have the time, and the juice really is fantastic.

This novel is a fictionalized memoir of Nathaniel Hawthorne's wife Sophia. Sophia, a talented but sickly artist, who falls intensely in love with Hawthorne from the first moment she meets him as does he with her. The story tells of their love, their trials, and along with glimpses of other classic authors they were friends with including Melville, Thoreau, Emerson, etc. The story was very readable, the characters real and likeable, and the tone of the book really kept to the period. The only thing that disappointed me was that personally I would have liked the book to be a little more about Hawthorne and his works, but it really about their relationship. I also found the sacrifices Sophia made regarding her art very sad.In any case, Robuck is a good writer and this was a very enjoyable read!

I like to use pantiliners for the last day or two of my cycle. I like the thinness or pantiliners but the small size is irking because if I don't always get them in the exact right spot. So I was really, really happy to find these longer ones. They are PERFECT and give me just the light protection I need. I also love that they are unscented.

A Spool of Thread takes the reader through four generations of the Whitshank family and how they came to live in their big, fancy house. The book skips around in time but eventually all of the stories and first meetings come out. While the beginning and end of the book did not do much for me and didn't really seem to fit the rest of the book, Anne Tyler is such a good writer that the meat of the book was engrossing and the characters as always were well drawn and compelling. I enjoyed the book very much.

It was a little hard at first for my artist teen daughter to remember to twist the pencils back and forth not rotate them around, but once she got in the habit, she has been raving about this sharpener. She finds it sharpens well and easily and she loves that she  can do a blunt versus sharp edge.

This game is so much fun! My boyfriend and I love Scrabble and love Cribbage so this game that is a combination of both could not have been more perfect for us--but happily for my boyfriend, he doesn't have to worry about spelling! We have been playing this daily since getting it for Christmas! Highly, highly recommended for cribbage fans. It's like taking the game to the next level. Tip: We use a cribbage board to keep score -- much easier than pencil and paper!

This little light is just perfect for my teenage daughter. Not only does she love the mustaches, but the light works great. She uses it for reading and also hooks it onto her sketchpad when she wants to draw. It stays in place and gives her just enough light for reading or drawing. We are so happy with this!

My daughters are loving this curler now that they've gotten the hang of it. It's a little tricky to figure out and kind of scary how it sucks your hair in. We had a couple of crisis with hair getting stuck in the thing and having to rip it out because it was burning, but with a little practice they got it down. The trick is to be  careful not to put too much hair in the thing at a time and to make sure all the hair goes in the right place--if there are strays they get stuck. The actually curler works very well and creates long lasting curls. It's actually easy it is to use (once you know what you're doing) and my 13-year-old is happy that it is almost impossible to get burned by this iron. Another nice feature is that you can adjust it for which side of your head your are curling so you get matched curls which is difficult with a regular curling iron. This is not something to use when you are in a hurry but works very well if you take the time to learn how to use it and are very careful.

Two troubled teens--once popular Violet who has been severely depressed since the death of her sister and misfit Finch who thinks constantly of suicide--meet on a ledge six stories high. But rather than either of them taking the plunge, they begin a odd relationship as partners on a school project and Finch helps Violet find her way back to leading her own life again.The book alternates between Finch and Violet's perspective in short chapters. The characters are real and relatable and quirky and the book was both funny and touching. Definitely a good choice for fans of The Fault in Our Stars.

These were a big hit for a 14 year old boy's birthday present. He put them on immediately and loved they way they look like a shark eating his leg. They were a big on him but would probably fit a man just fine. Very pleased with these.
My teen daughters love this scrub. They just love the scent, and they also love the way it cleans and exfoliates  without irritating their skin. We are very pleased with this product.

This fan is light and easy to move to wherever in the house you need a little cooling. It's a little bigger than I thought it would be -- not really small enough to take with you on a trip (we like to take one along for white noise when traveling). I like that there are four settings: sleep (very low), white noise (low), refresh (medium), and power cool (high). You can also chose whether to have the fan stay still or rotate from side to side. What I don't like is: 1) you can't adjust the fan angle up or down and 2) it has a funny rattle noise to it so that it doesn't actually work that well if you like a fan to sleep with as white noise. This is okay but I like my other smaller Honeywell Turboforce fan better.

If you are curious to hear the backstory of pretty much every character ever mentioned in the Vampire Chronicle series -- mostly as told by one character to another -- then this is the book for you.  This book reminded me of a TV reunion show where all the characters are brought back to together and we get snippets from all of the various shows throughout the seasons. The story itself--what little there is--is pretty much a B-movie plot with an evil "voice" trying to take over the vampire world, complete with a doctor who can operate on vampires and actually gets one to procreate (give you three guesses who is the one and only vampire this procedure works on). The characters have no spark, no magic. Lestat, who repeatedly refers to himself as the "brat prince," is really just an over-the-hill-prince who comes off like some bland, benevolent father in this book. Where is the charisma and outrageousness that made him the most fascinating character in the first few books of the series? And this new character Rose -- so completely helpless and needing to be rescued every few chapters -- is this really the best Rice could come up with?My recommendation: If you are a Vampire Chronicle fan looking for behind-the-scenes info on the characters, read this book. But if you are looking for a magical, engrossing story like the first few in the series--give it a pass.

I got this serum for my teenage daughters and they have been happy with it. It does help to prevent breakouts and clear up the ones they have. The one thing they don't like is the very strong, unpleasant smell. Also, be sure to use moisturizer after applying the serum (as directed) as it is very drying otherwise.

Barbara Parker, though she looks like a beauty queen (and in fact is!), wants to make people laugh. She wants to be like her idol Lucille Ball. So she chucks her crown and heads to London and soon lands a part in a new sitcom and becomes Britain's darling.This was a very enjoyable book -- easy to get into and fun to read. It lagged a bit in the second half but came nicely full circle in the end. Barbara reminds me a bit of Mary Tyler Moore and the writers a bit like Buddy and Sally on the Dick Van Dyke Show . . . in fact the whole scenerio reminded me of the Dick Van Dyke show. Nice nostalgic kind of read!

When Maggie is laid off from her Silicone Valley job at ArGoNet software, she holes up in a little used book store reading romance novels. In the hopes of getting her job back, she decides to see if she can get the bookstore to become successful and uses an old book that had been used to pass messages between lovers to get a buzz going.I love to read about bookstores and people who love books, so I gave this a try. It's a sweet story about a woman trying to find her way . . . but the romance part seems to keep getting dropped and the book seems to drag.

Is this a new trend? Talented writers writing books where nothing really happens? This is the second book I've read this month by authors that write really well but have come out with boring books.The story starts after the death of Nora's husband but from there on there is really no plot--nothing to keep me turning the pages. Nora (and the story) just kind of drifts on. The reader never gets very close to Nora or any of the characters in the book and the book just meanders on and stops. This isn't a bad book . . . but just not a very compelling one.

After the death of her husband, Sydney takes a summer job tutoring a teenage girl at her family's summer house in New Hampshire. She becomes almost part of the family, hanging out with Julie's two older brothers. But when a relationship develops between her and one brother, it causes a rift between the brothers which affects everyone.I really enjoy reading Shreve's books. Her characters are real and relatable and I care about them. I especially like the way she just tells a straightforward story that you can get into and become immersed in -- no alternating viewpoints, no jumping back and forth in time -- just a book to relax with and enjoy.

Teenagers Ada and Stefan are in love -- but Ada lives in West Berlin and Stefan in East Berlin and in the 1980's those sections are divided by the Berlin Wall. Ada begs Stefan to come to West Berlin but escape is very risky.My teen daughter and I love books about Germany and were excited to hear about this book with such an original premise (most of the German books we find are about the Holocaust). But we both found this book really hard to get into and stick with, because of the way the author chose to tell the story. She does use some beautiful, poetic language but the telling is so disjointed and sketchy that is' hard to know what is going on sometimes--especially if the reader doesn't have a good grounding in what was happening in Germany during that time with the Turkish people. I was also confused as to why Ada is working so hard to have Stefan defect. The book made it seem that life was much better on the East German side. Stefan seemed to have a pretty comfortable life but Ada was living without heat. Why didn't she move to the East if she wanted to be with him.The book alternates between Ada's story and Stefan's story. The chapters are very short, which is another reason it's hard to get drawn into the story. But the worst choice the author made was to write Stefan's sections in the second person point of view, which is so distract and confusing because it actually isn't a second person point of view -- it's first person point of view but the author uses 'you' when she means 'I'. Ug! So the whole time I'm reading Stefan's sections I'm distracted by this point of view choice and not concentrating on the story.I'm so disappointed in this book -- the characters and the premise are really cool, but the book is just too much work to decipher and too many things didn't make sense..

These measuring cups are pricey, but they really are as good quality product. The handles on my previous set of stainless measuring cups kept breaking off so I like that these cups are all one piece. I also like that I can easily read the measurement size on each cup--which has been difficult in other  sets I've had. I'm very happy that I got these.

The product does go on dry as advertised -- other than the blast of very cold air, I wouldn't know it was going on, which in a way makes me unsure that I did get the area covered sufficiently since I can't feel if it's on. This antiperspirant has a VERY strong scent and though it lessens after a few minutes, I do still smell it throughout the day and I don't really like it. I want an antiperspirant that removes scent not adds it.

This book, though a novel, is written in the style of a memoir. It is the story of boy who moves from southern Illinois to Goochland, Virginia and the narrator pretty much pokes fun at the place, the people, his family. The writing is very tongue-in-cheek and quite humorous but at the same time very hard to read for very long. The first chapter felt kind of like reading a prologue where I don't mind writing a little difficult and hard to follow -- but then I was ready to settle in and get into the story--but it's just more of the same. The writing seemed more like essays than a novel. It's hard to read more than a chapter or two in a sitting and there was definitely nothing calling me back to read on. I really don't think this writing style works for a novel and I had to really push myself to get through the book.

I wanted to like CLEOPATRAâS SHADOWS more than I did, because I thought the idea was a great one. The author intended to reimagine the beginning of Cleopatraâs saga by telling the story through her younger sister Arsinoe. Cleopatra barely appears this book, which I was more than okay with, as I tend to like historical fiction that centers on lesser known figures. Arsinoe, and Cleopatraâs older sister, Berenice, are both footnotes in history because of their more famous sibling, but both had important lives of their own.CLEOPATRAâS SHADOWS alternates chapters between Arsinoe and Berenice. Berenice takes the throne when King Ptolemy sails to Rome for aid. Arsinoe is left behind in the palace by her father and mother, a lost child. Berenice struggles to hold the throne, to find enough men to fight for her, and to deal with her vengeance hungry mother. Arsinoe longs for Cleopatra, in the way younger sisters long for older sisters, but must beg Berenice for her life.I think my biggest problem with CLEOPATRAâS SHADOWS is that â¦ it just wasnât very interesting. It wasnât riveting or page-turning. It didnât keep my attention. There were portions that were good, such as Berenice debating between her motherâs lust for vengeance against Ptolemyâs other daughters or mercy for Arsinoe. Berenice was much more interesting for me than Arsinoe, but even so, many of her chapters plodded along. Arsinoeâs chapters were even more boring -- even though her life was in danger, I never felt like she would die, and I got tired of the many tutoring lessons. Other readers might find the inclusion of Roman histories and tragedies interesting, but I eventually had enough of being lectured. I also had a lot of unanswered questions, such as why Ganymedes left Arsinoe in the market. Based on the bonus material at the end of the book, I have a feeling CLEOPATRAâS SHADOWS is the first in a series, so perhaps my questions will be answered in future books.Iâm a character-driven reader, and unfortunately, I couldnât connect with either Berenice or Arsinoe. I didnât like or hate either one of them. My feelings towards both, and the secondary characters, were very blah. The author didnât bring them to life enough for me to care about what they did or what happened to them, and an hour after finishing CLEOPATRAâS SHADOWS, Iâve already forgotten a fair bit of the book.

THE PRISONERS OF BREENDONK tells the history of Breendonk, a little known âreceptionâ camp in Belgium during WWII. I consider myself fairly knowledgeable about WWII, but I had never heard of Breendonk before.The author focuses on personal narratives to tell the history of the camp. He tells the stories of many prisoners, including information about their lives before and after imprisonment, if possible. He starts with the story of Israel Neumann, a prisoner who has a sad tale: he once immigrated to America, but after a visit to Europe, he was declared unfit to re enter America and eventually ended up at Breendonk. I think that using so many personal narratives will help younger readers really connect with the tragedies of WWII.The book also includes lots of photographs, illustrations, and maps. Most of the photographs are from the only ones taken during the war, by Otto Kropf, a propagandist in the Wehrmacht. The illustrations were done by inmate Jacques Ochs. There are charts showing what happened to prisoners transported from Breendonk to other camps, and how many survived. Lastly, the author has a section detailing what happened to some of the Breendonk prisoners and their families. I always appreciate that sort of section, as so often youâre never sure what happened to many of the people mentioned.I do wish that the author had used full dates every single time, instead of just the month and year, because sometimes I wasnât sure of the timeline.I found THE PRISONERS OF BREENDONK quite informative, and I think it would be a good introduction to camps for high school readers who likely havenât read a lot of WWII nonfiction.

I really like the idea behind MECHANICA. While inspired by Cinderella, MECHANICA is more than a fairytale retelling. Nicolette is determined to make her own way in the world by becoming a successful inventor just like her mother. But with both of her parents gone, Nicoletteâs been turned into a servant for her Stepmother and step-sisters. On her sixteenth birthday, she receives a letter from her long-dead mother, informing her how to get into the workshop hidden in the cellar.Having the workshop changes everything. Suddenly Nicoletteâs able to invent her own machines, rather than just fix the ones left from her motherâs day. Nicolette comes up with a plan for independence, working very hard to perfect her projects and find ways of making money. Unlike many fairytale princesses, she doesnât sit around and mope while waiting for a prince to rescue her.I was a little wary at first when she met Fin and Caro, and warier still when she had such strong feelings for Fin. But. BUT. I *love* how the author handled the whole thing in the end. Nicolette thought about her feelings for Fin quite a bit, and a lot of the time, he was like an imaginary friend, someone to talk to during the long, rough days. And when thereâs a chance for them to be together, she thinks about what *she* wants, not what everyone else wants. MECHANICA doesnât go the usual route of romance in YA, and I was so, so, SO happy about that. I also liked that the author mentioned how the Fey have friend families instead of spouses.MECHANICA did have a couple of things I have to nitpick. Is there another book coming? I canât find any information so far, but I sure hope so. There were some unresolved things that were really built up, like the Ashes. I also hoped for more information on what happened during/after the Exposition, since attending it was so important to Nicolette. I didnât find MECHANICA to have a real big climax, just a kind of whimper at the end, regarding both the Exposition and the Steps.Overall, however, I quite enjoyed MECHANICA and Nicolette. I really do hope there is a sequel, so I can watch her continue to grow and find out more about the fascinating world the author created.

I love historical fiction, especially historical fiction that covers less popular time periods than Tudor England or WWII. Thereâs nothing wrong with those periods, but there are thousands of years of stories to tell rather than rehashing the same thing over and over. So, I was obviously excited to start LEGACY OF KINGS. Alexander the Great as a boy? Bring it on!LEGACY OF KINGS is the first in the Blood of Gods and Royals series. Itâs over 400 pages, and for the first book in a series, it felt about a hundred pages too long. Part of the reason why I felt it was too long is thereâs a huge cast of main characters. There are seven! The author had to spend a lot of time introducing everyone and setting up their arcs. Iâm sure all the characters are important in their own way, but a few were boring for me, because they didnât get a lot of page time and I didnât know enough about them. Yes, I know thatâs contradictory, but I wish the author had slimmed down her cast and really focused on characters such as Alexander and Cynane.Due to the large cast, LEGACY OF KINGS has a slow start. It takes the book a while to get going, and switching perspectives didnât immerse me in the time period at first. But I kept going, and after Iâd gone through everyoneâs perspectives at least once, the book got better. I swore I was reading a historical soap opera â but in a good, really entertaining way.I think the author did a great job of showing life in ancient Macedonia. I really liked the little details, such as how thereâs a bucket of sand in most rooms in case of fire. I also like how thereâs some magic in LEGACY OF KINGS, and hints of more to come. Itâs the end of the Age of Gods â¦ or is it? I donât know, and I canât wait to find out.I wavered between three and four stars for LEGACY OF KINGS. Itâs a book I liked because of the time period and the story. But I didnât love it, due to the large cast of characters and the slow pacing. Based on the ending, I think the authorâs going to really amp things up in the next book, EMPIRE OF DUST, so this is a series Iâm eager to continue.Disclaimer: I received a copy of this book from the publisher in exchange for an honest review.

MAGIC SHIFTS is the eighth book in the super awesome Kate Daniels series. I just read the entire series to get caught up to MAGIC SHIFTS, and this is one series where the books get better and better. I canât recommend this series enough if you like a snarky, kick butt heroine, solid and creative worldbuilding, and villains and bad magic from all over the globe.In MAGIC SHIFTS, Kate and Curran are trying to live a normal life. As normal as life can be when Kateâs the daughter of the most powerful man alive and Curranâs the former Beast Lord. Thanks to Kateâs agreement with her father in the previous book, MAGIC BREAKS, theyâve left the Pack. But instead of settling into their new house, theyâre catapulted into a confusing investigation when Eduardo, a werebison, goes missing.THE GOOD:â¥ I was a little worried when I started MAGIC SHIFTS, because one of my favorite things about this series is the Pack. I liked watching Kate manage the shapeshifters, and seeing them bicker and politic their way around the Keep. But many of the characters I liked in previous books are still in the series, and you know what? Kate and Curran shine even outside of the Pack. Their relationship is solid but still growing, and seeing Curran try to behave for the neighbors was hilarious.â¥ At last, there are some real consequences for Kate throwing herself headlong into danger. I enjoy how Kate never hesitates to draw her sword and rush into a fight, but with the amount of abuse she puts her body through, you start to wonder how sheâs still alive, even with magic. I wonât spoil things, but I *loved* what happens to her in MAGIC SHIFTS.Disclaimer: I received a copy of this book from the publisher in exchange for an honest review.â¥ Three words: Roland. Likes. Applebeeâs. Those three words lead to what has to be one of my favorite scenes in the whole series. Again, Iâm not going to spoil the fantasticness, but I like where the authorâs going with Kate and Roland.â¥ As with the bad guys in other books, the author doesnât go with the traditional Western European supernatural creatures. Iâve seen the creature in MAGIC SHIFTS before, but this time it was *scary.* Yet again, I donât want to drop spoilers, but I will say Iâve never read such a cool theory on ghouls.THE BAD:Nothing. Nothing at all.

Daaaaamn. I just finished MAGIC BREAKS, and Iâm at a loss for words. Iâve said this in almost every review Iâve written for the Kate Daniels series, but this is a series where the books just get better and better.Iâve been looking forward to Kateâs confrontation with her father for seven books now. I had absolutely no idea how the author would handle it, since Kateâs always known that Roland has a gazillion times more magic than she does. Iâm not going to spoil what does happen, but I like how it all went down. It makes sense and shows how much Kate has grown over the series. Because you know if she had met Roland in book one, she would have stuck Slayer in his heart, and he would have killed her, and that would have been it. But now that Kate has lots of friends, fiancÃ© Curran, adopted street kid Julie, and the welfare of the Pack to worry about, she canât go in sword point first.In other books, I liked seeing lots of the Pack, but I also missed the Kate from the first few in the series, where she was more on her own. In MAGIC BREAKS, Kateâs separated from Curran and the Pack, and she has to rely on every bit of training from Voron to stay alive. I loved it. I had absolutely no idea where the story was going in this book, and I loved that, too. It was also great to learn even more about Roland and Kateâs powers, which is something I enjoy in every installment. The author has some super creative ideas for magic.Iâve been binge reading this series, but if youâve been following it all along and need a refresher, the author includes a handy list of characters and summary of events by Barabas, Kateâs bouda nanny.One of my favorite things about the Kate Daniels series is how talented the author is at making me feel about every single character. Lots of old faces are back in MAGIC BREAKS as well as some new ones. Even though Iâve never really liked Ghastek before, I felt for him in this book. Same with the alpha wererat couple, Robert and Thomas. Christopher, the insane guy Kate rescued in MAGIC RISES, shows up too, and I felt for him. Seriously. These characters tug on my (mostly nonexistent) heartstrings.And the last page of MAGIC BREAKS? As Kate would say, âWhy me?â Iâd have screamed that if I had to wait a year for the next book, MAGIC SHIFTS.Disclaimer: I received a copy of this book from the publisher in exchange for an honest review.

MAGIC RISES is the sixth book in the Kate Daniels series. This is the first book where we get to see the rest of the world Post-Shift, as Kate and the Pack travel to Europe to guard a pregnant shapeshifter. They know itâs a trap, but they go anyway, because the promised payment is panacea, a medicine that can reverse loupism.I really liked getting to see more of the world than just Atlanta. Itâs good to see how other countries cope (or donât) with magic, and who has come out on top. You wonât believe who the lord of the castle is in MAGIC RISES â but heâs an excellent pick. MAGIC RISES has a lot of Pack dealings, but it also moves Kateâs arc towards her inevitable confrontation with her father. I appreciate that the author isnât making Roland a one book enemy, and I like how weâve learned more about his background and Kateâs powers as the series progresses.I wasnât super thrilled with Curran in this book; it felt like Kate and Curranâs relationship took a step backwards. There are a couple of inconsistencies with how they act, and I wanted to slap Curran for a good portion of MAGIC RISES. I didnât buy his excuse for the whole thing with Lorelei, and with the sheer amount of important stuff happening, I couldâve done without the relationship problems.Otherwise, I really enjoyed MAGIC RISES. As usual, I canât believe how much the author packed into the book: a bodyguard case, the lord of the castle, mysterious new shapeshifters, Kate/Curran, and some big important battles. There were a few scenes that made my eyes sting, because I care so much about the characters in this series.

MAGIC SLAYS is the fifth book in the Kate Daniels series. I say this every review, but the books in this series just keep getting better and better! Iâm a latecomer to this amazing urban fantasy series, but thatâs good in a way, because I canât imagine waiting a year between installments.If you thought Erra was bad in the previous book, MAGIC BLEEDS, the bad guys in MAGIC SLAYS are even worse. Kateâs case this time spotlights a danger to the entire city of Atlanta. Itâs something she canât handle herself, even though sheâs quit the Order and doesnât have them holding her back anymore. I really liked the big fight in MAGIC SLAYS, because lots of different groups come and fight together â it felt epic in scope.My favorite things about this series include Kate, Kate and Curran, the Pack, and the other characters. The author continues to deliver on all of those points.â¥ Kate has grown so much from the first book in the series while staying true to herself that itâs incredible. Sheâs still snarky and bad ass, but now more vulnerable because sheâs formed attachments and friendships with people.â¥ Kate and Curran â their relationship has become one of my favorite in an urban fantasy series. They bicker and have to work to develop their relationship and support each other. Itâs realistic, which is always important to me.â¥ I do so enjoy the Pack. Itâs great to see Kate act as the Alpha, showing the shapeshifters that she can act like them without going furry, and that sheâll protect them just as much as Curran does.â¥ I love Kate and Curran, but I also love all the other characters in this series. The authorâs really good at making you feel for everybody, if theyâre in one scene or multiple books. Andrea is back, which was great, since I like her friendship with Kate. Julieâs also back, yay! Although maybe not yay, because the poor kid goes through some rough stuff. The new bouda Ascanioâs a hoot, and the attack poodle Grendel is back. Seriously, there are some great characters in this series, and Iâm greedy enough to want novellas about all of them.MAGIC SLAYS slays it.

MAGIC BLEEDS is the fourth book in the Kate Daniels series. Iâve been binge reading this series, and each book is better than the last, which is rare in a series. Kate Daniels has a spot on my favorite kickbutt characters list. Sheâs just plain awesome.MAGIC BLEEDS digs deeper into Kateâs background than previous books have. Kateâs case starts out as a typical Order investigation â as typical as something involving magic, death, and deadly diseases can be. Which, of course, is pretty typical in the authorâs version of Atlanta, where magic and tech alternately rule supreme. But the case becomes something more when she finds out the true identity of the Steel Mary whoâs been infecting corpses with diseases like syphilis and cholera.As with the other books in this series, I enjoyed the lore of the bad guy, which was inspired by Babylonian mythology. I never know whatâs going to come next, or how Kate will save the day, which is something I love. Itâs never fun when books are too predictable. I was scared for Kate and Curran and Atlanta, because there were some nail-biting action scenes where it looked like the end was about to come.Kate and Curranâs relationship takes a huge step forward in MAGIC BLEEDS. Iâm usually picky on romances, but I like the way the authorâs developed theirs over the course of the series. I thought what happened between Kate and Curran was realistic, which is really important for me with romances. They act as theyâve been characterized â they donât change personalities as things heat up or cool down.I also liked getting to see more of Pack politics. How well do wolves, rats, cats, hyenas, and other shapeshifters get along? Not very well. The Pack, its structure, and politics are just one more thing I enjoy about this series. I like how the authorâs given each clan a distinct personality and place in the hierarchy, because I love seeing Kate come in and totally ignore everything.MAGIC BLEEDS is full of everything I like about the Kate Daniels series: inventive magic, a scary world, well-developed characters, creative use of mythology and supernatural creatures, and too many other things to name.

MAGIC STRIKES is the third book in the Kate Daniels series. I highly recommend this series if you like creative urban fantasy with a side of kickbutt heroine, sizzling chemistry, and non-stop action.In MAGIC STRIKES, we at last learn more about Kate and her background. Previous books in the series had some clues, but here we get the full story. Why Kate is so careful about never leaving her blood or any traces of it around. Why Kate knows so much about the powerful, mysterious, and secret leader of the People. And why Kate is a loner, which might be the most important information of all, since she bucks all of her life experience and training to help her friends.Kate doesnât have many friends, you see, so when Derek ends up nearly dead, sheâs willing to take part in a deadly tournament to get revenge on his attackers. The bad guys in MAGIC STRIKES are inspired by Hindu mythology, and damn, they were creepy and scary, but also cool. I like how the author never sticks with the traditional Western European baddies, but draws inspiration from all over the globe.I enjoyed every aspect of MAGIC STRIKES, from watching Kateâs protective side come out again to seeing her growing friendships with a variety of Pack members. Julie from MAGIC BURNS even makes a cameo appearance; I was happy to see her again. And I canât forget the romantic relationship developing between Kate and Curran. Iâm not always a fan of romances, but I appreciate that this one hasnât been rushed, and that Kate doesnât lose herself whenever Curran shows up. She admits sheâs attracted to him, but she doesnât let that attraction override her brain.The ending made me snort with laughter. Iâm not going to spoil, but itâs *good.* Thatâs just one more thing I like about Ilona Andrewsâ writing â it makes me laugh all the time, even in the middle of a dangerous action scene or when Kateâs just sitting in her apartment.

INK AND BONE is one of those books I always wanted, but I never knew it until I read it. There are so many good ideas and itâs such a great story that Iâm still thinking about INK AND BONE a month after finishing it. With the amount of books I read, about 20 per month, itâs rare that a book sticks with me.Jess lives in a world where owning personal copies of books is illegal. The Great Library has survived since the days of Alexandria and now exists in every city. The Library controls access to book and knowledge, functioning with as much power as a country. Jessâs family makes a living selling books on the black market, and seeing an opportunity, his father sends him to the Library, with the intent of having a spy on the inside.But joining the Library isnât that easy. There are 32 postulants and 6 available spots. The competition is fierce and dangerous. Jess must navigate a murky world, one where disagreeing with the Libraryâs policies and politics can be deadly. For example, when Jess is in the middle of a war zone, he could call on his family connections to survive, but doing so would expose his book smuggling background. What to do?Imagine the greatest texts of the world surviving through the centuries thanks to the Library. But at the same time, imagine the same Library controlling which of those texts the public can see. Imagine a world where you canât own your own books. Itâs every book loverâs nightmare, right?Rachel Caine explores those ideas and others in INK AND BONE. Itâs a very thinky book, but enjoyably so. Jessâs time as a postulant for the Library is the best sort of dangerous adventure, one thatâs fun to read but left me thinking. I cannot wait to return to the world the authorâs created â bring on the next book!Disclaimer: I received a copy of this book from the publisher in exchange for an honest review.

I was looking forward to reading A ROYAL ROMANCE because I wanted to see how the author would pull off an openly gay monarch. The answer? Pretty easy and plausibly, in my opinion. The book is set in 2053, not too far in the future, but far enough that Great Britain adores Georgiana, and thereâs medical advances to take care of that pesky heir issue.George and Beatrice are thrown together when the new queen picks the charity where Bea works as her main charity leading up to her coronation. Bea isnât happy that sheâll have to spend time with the Queen â sheâs a republican and thinks the monarchy should be abolished. But of course, once the two start interacting on a personal level, and Bea sees that Queen Georgiana is much more caring and responsible than she expected. George, isolated by her position as monarch, finds Beaâs bluntness and honesty refreshing.A ROYAL ROMANCE was a guilty pleasure read for me. It was just *fun* to see the relationship develop between George and Bea, to see Georgeâs life as queen and Beaâs as a commoner. It was also refreshing to see that both of their families were encouraging, even when Bea doubted that things could work between them because of their class differences. I did think the ending was a tad rushed, considering all the buildup and back-and-forth on their relationship. But A ROYAL ROMANCE left me wanting a sequel, and romances donât usually do that to me.Disclaimer: I received a copy of this book from the publisher in exchange for an honest review.

I am picky when it comes to contemporary. Very, very picky. I originally picked up UNDER THE LIGHTS because I knew it had a girl/girl relationship, and those are all too rare in YA/NA.By the way, this is the second book in a series, but you donât need to have read the first, BEHIND THE SCENES, because UNDER THE LIGHTS is Vanessa and Joshâs story, not Ally and Liamâs.I got that relationship and so much more. Honestly, I was surprised at how deftly the author wove in many big important things, including:â¥ Diversity. Vanessa is Korean American. Sheâs part of the main cast for Daylight Falls â not to fulfill a racial quota, but because sheâs a good actress. Her parents want her to quit playing around and go to college, get a real job. But she wants to be an idol to girls just like her. So when she realizes sheâs attracted to Brianna, and that she might be gayâ¦â¥ Sexuality. Vanessaâs not so sure she can survive in Hollywood being a minority *and* being gay. Parts just donât exist when you fit into those slots. As it is, sheâs typecast in movies as the med student or science nerd. Her boyfriend, Zander, has never made her tingle like Bri does, *and* heâs pushing for her to make a purity pledge so they can be even better role models. Meanwhile, Josh, the other main character, makes no apologies that he likes to have sex with a different girl every night. His sexuality is praised â a reality TV show wants to follow him around.â¥ Celebrity culture and expectations. Joshâs mom, an aging soap star, wants a reality TV show to replace her canceled show. The only condition? Her famous bad boy son must be a part of it. Itâs totally okay for him to be a jerk to his fake girlfriend and woo girls in clubs. But for Vanessa? Itâs not okay for her to even be seen in a club â it goes against her good girl image.Thereâs so much good stuff in UNDER THE LIGHTS. I loved the authorâs voices for both characters and her writing style. I was in a reading slump when I started this book, and it helped pull me out. On one level, UNDER THE LIGHTS is fun and includes some very yummy scenes between Vanessa and Bri â including a non fade-to-black sex scene. On another level, UNDER THE LIGHTS has great commentary and observations on so many important cultural and life issues.UNDER THE LIGHTS has so much of what I want to see in YA and NA that Iâll be recommending the hell out of it. And reading everything else Dahlia Adler writes.Disclaimer: I received a copy of this book from the publisher in exchange for an honest review.

THE DUNGEONEERS has a healthy helping of Dungeons and Dragons, a dash of Harry Potter, and a heaping spoonful of humor and fun. I ate this book up like candy â it was much better than the endless stew served at Thwodinâs Legion.Colm Canderly has eight sisters who love to torment him (but they love him, too). But thatâs not the worst of his problems. Heâs from a poor family, and no matter how much cobbling work his father does, thereâs never enough to go around. So one day, he decides to lift the purses of wealthy men â¦ just to help the family, of course â¦ but discovers he has a real talent for thievery. Naturally, his honest father isnât happy, and insists Colm give the money back.Enter Finn. A member of Thwodinâs Legion, a premiere dungeoning guild, Finn recognizes Colmâs talent, and offers him the opportunity of a lifetime. What twelve-year-old boy wouldnât jump at the chance to make lots of gold, fight orcs, and get his name out there? At the guild hall, Colm is teamed up with his party, consisting of Lena the Barbarian (who faints at the sight of her own blood), Quinn the Mage (who stutters when heâs nervous, casting unpredictable spells), and Serene the Druid (whoâs scared of animals with lots of teeth). They must learn to work together, balancing each othersâ strengths and weaknesses, to survive in orc-infested, trap-laden dungeons.THE DUNGEONEERS was a treat to read. A funny, well-written, fantastical middle grade book great for kids and adults. I do think itâs a tad long, as there are some chapters without a lot of action or story forwarding. But the characters are all developed â all unique, with their own personalities that expand beyond their party roles. I enjoyed watching their friendship grow, and watching them train together. I appreciated that the author put time into showing how a rogue might practice his skills.THE DUNGEONEERS is the perfect book for when you canât find someone to play D&D with, or when you want to escape into a dungeon and come out with storybook gold without dodging boring orc traps!Disclaimer: I received a copy of this book from the publisher in exchange for an honest review.

CIRCUS MIRANDUS is a magical book.Yes, itâs about a magical circus, so you could assume some magic there, but thereâs magic in the characters, the story, the relationships -- everything, really. When I started reading this book, I was 14 chapters in before I knew it, and later I didnât want to turn the last page.CIRCUS MIRANDUS is a book you can read on a few levels. One, for kids to experience a fantastical circus and the power of relationships. Two, for adults to remember the power of magic and hopefully to think that believing in magic is a good thing, and to see how it can help anyone through tough times.I think the most impactful thing I can say about this book is that it made me ugly cry at one point and left me filled with hope by the end. Very few books affect me emotionally, but CIRCUS MIRANDUS was one. Why? *Everything* about this book is fantastic and so well done.I ached for Micah. At the start of the book, heâs facing the loss of his grandfather Ephraim, who is really more of a father to him. Aunt Gertrudis tries to keep them apart in their last days together, and gets angry any time they share their special stories of Circus Mirandus. Ephraim visited the circus as a youth, and was given a miracle. Heâs hung onto it for years, but now is the time to use it -- and Micahâs determined heâll get to do so.One little thing I especially loved about CIRCUS MIRANDUS was that we got to see the magic circus from both Ephraim and Micahâs eyes. I thought it really added to the book that the author included chapters from a young Ephraim, who went through something very similar to Micah.I have so much love for CIRCUS MIRANDUS. My experience while reading was amazing, and I canât recommend it enough.

I was super excited for A SCHOOL FOR UNUSUAL GIRLS. At Stranje House, unmarriageable girls are supposedly reformed. But in reality, their unusual qualities and abilities are further developed. Sent to Stranje House after she sets her fatherâs stables on fire while trying to create invisible ink, Georgiana wants to escape â¦ until she meets Sebastian Wyatt and learns that Miss Stranje wants her to create that ink.The summary strongly hints at romance, but I didnât think it would take over the whole book. The ârelationshipâ that springs up between Georgiana and Sebastian caused me to dislike A SCHOOL FOR UNUSUAL GIRLS. Georgianaâs supposed to be smart, but she falls in love with Sebastian after about two seconds of looking at him. Or thatâs what it felt like. I think they spent less than a week together, but they were falling in love by the middle of the book. I canât stand that type of undeveloped relationship, and it influenced how I felt about the book.Aside from the insta-love romance, I didnât get Georgiana. Again, sheâs supposed to be smart, but where does this come from? Why is she the only one who can develop the ultra-important invisible ink spies need in the war effort? Where do her special skills come from? Weâre not told of her successes, just her failures: setting the stables on fire, jumping out a window and hurting her arm, etc. And when Georgiana works on that ink, she nearly kills Sebastian and then makes another mistake because theyâre swooning over each other. And Stranje House itself? It sounds like an interesting place, but Georgiana doesnât partake in very many lessons because sheâs busy with Sebastian.Ultimately, A SCHOOL FOR UNUSUAL GIRLS just wasnât what I expected it to be. Instead of a history-filled, girl-powered jaunt through 1814, itâs an unrealistic romance with a tiny dash of adventure.Disclaimer: I received a copy of this book from the publisher in exchange for an honest review.

MOSEHâS STAFF is the fourth book in A.W. Exleyâs Artifact Hunters series. In the past, Iâve described the series as quirky and unique. A good blend of historical fiction, fantasy, romance, adventure, mythology, and steampunk. These descriptions hold true with MOSEHâS STAFF, which is sadly the last book in the series. Iâm sad to see the end of Cara and Nate, but I do like how the author finished everything.As Queen Victoriaâs artifact hunters, Nate and Cara must figure out what artifact is causing endless winter and misery in London. Itâs April, but the Thames is frozen. London is the only area affected, and Victoriaâs not very happy about it. Cara and Nate have a good idea of who is behind events â the Curator â but how to stop him is a different question. How do you stop a man who bleeds water instead of blood?The hunt becomes even more personal when the Curator reveals his intentions to take Cara as his own, severing the bond of Nefertitiâs Heart that connects her and Nate. I love Cara and Nate together, but it was great to see Nate on his own as well. The author showed more of Nateâs darker side, the no holds barred man he was before Caraâs presence in his life. Nateâs the guy Iâd want on my side if someone took me, because he stops at nothing to rescue Cara.Thereâs a lot of revelations in MOSEHâS STAFF, tying up loose ends from previous books in the series, such as explaining why Cara and Nate fit so perfectly together, or bringing back the dragon from HATSHEPSUTâS COLLAR. Many of Cara and Nateâs friends show up in MOSEHâS STAFF (minus Loki, sadface), rallying around Nate to help find Cara. And Cara, kick butt woman that she is, isnât content to sit back and be rescued. She confronts her own demons in MOSEHâS STAFF while trying to figure out which artifact powers the Curator.All in all, MOSEHâS STAFF is a satisfying conclusion to the Artifact Hunters series, full of what I loved about the previous books: Cara and Nate, twists on mythology, humor in dark moments, and lots of action.Disclaimer: I received a copy of this book from the publisher in exchange for an honest review.

Even though Iâm a huge fantasy fan, Iâve never read any Shannara books. I have read most of Brooksâ Magic Kingdom of Landover series and liked them, but I never knew where to start with Shannara because there are so many. THE DARKLING CHILD, the second in the Defenders of Shannara trilogy, is supposed to be a standalone, and a good entry point for new readers.After reading THE DARKLING CHILD, I have no interest in reading any other books in the Shannara series. I struggled to get through this book, and wondered more than once how Brooks is so popular. Maybe his work has decreased in quality over the years, because THE DARKLING CHILD? Substandard fantasy. I really felt like the author was trying to hit a certain page count and that was it.I donât even know where to start, other than to say I canât remember much of the book, and I finished it a day ago. I was tempted to put THE DARKLING CHILD down after the first few chapters, but I know fantasy can have a slow pace to start, so I gave it a chance. But I wish I didnât, because this book was a slog to get through.I wouldnât recommend this if youâre new to Shannara, because other than explaining the origin of wishsong, thereâs no real worldbuilding. I donât know what the Federation is, what the druids do, etc. There are also references to the first book in this trilogy, THE HIGH DRUIDâS BLADE, but those werenât as bad as the shoddy writing, YA-style romances, predictable story, and lack of women other than as plot devices.After my dismal experience with THE DARKLING CHILD, I wonât be returning to Shannara.

The summary for DAUGHTER OF DEEP SILENCE makes it sound like the kind of book Iâd love. Frances is one of the few survivors of the destruction of the Persephone; more importantly, sheâs the only survivor whoâs willing to face the truth of what happened. The two other survivors, a Senator and his son, claim a rogue wave destroyed the ship, but Frances knows everyone on board was murdered at gunpoint. After rescue, she takes on the identity of Libby OâMartin, a girl she met on the ship. Frances is determined to get revenge for the murders of her parents and the life she lost.Fast forward four years. Frances has seamlessly become Libby, and now sheâs out to destroy the Senator and his son for covering up the truth about the Persephone. The only snag in her plan? The Senatorâs son - Grey - is her first love. They also met on the ship, and somehow fell in love in a few days. When she sees him again, Frances is torn between her revenge and loving Grey.I found DAUGHTER OF DEEP SILENCE skewed too far in the unbelievable romance direction for me to enjoy the book at all. I wanted to put the book aside by page 8, after I read, âIt didnât matter that Iâd known him barely a week, it had been long enough to fall for him with an intensity Iâd never experienced before (p. 8).â Okay, I get that theyâre both fourteen at the time, and swept away by each other, but when Frances encounters him years later? When sheâs putting her revenge plans underway? Sheâs pretty much in love with him all over again, and the Frances part of her thatâs hiding inside the Libby disguise wants to throw all caution to the wind and be loved again. To top that off, Iâm not sure why Frances liked Grey at first -- maybe because he was the first boy that showed her attention? I donât know. You canât just tell me that they fell in love in a few days and itâs a ârelationshipâ that overcomes her desire to get revenge for the murder of her parents and hundreds of other people.DAUGHTER OF DEEP SILENCE requires a *lot* of suspension of disbelief: that Libby and Frances looked enough alike for Frances to assume Libbyâs identity; that Frances and Grey fell in love at first sight; that Frances can carry out such a complicated revenge plot without any real experience; etc., etc. I also found the authorâs writing style to be somewhat stilted, with lots of telling that didnât add to the suspense for me. The pace was super slow, and I skimmed a lot of the book because I just wasnât interested in what was going on. The only reason I kept reading? I wanted to find out why everyone on the Persephone was murdered. But even that wasnât too interesting. I wish Iâd gone with my instincts and put DAUGHTER OF DEEP SILENCE down after the first few chapters.

I was considering making myself a pair of PVC parallettes to exercise at home, so this was a great product for me to review. Although I know the PVC could support my weight, I just feel more comfortable with wood and metal.These are extremely easy to assemble; thereâs even an included wrench. All you have to do is screw the upper portion of the bar to the non-skid foot bars. They donât take up a lot of room in the house, which is good for storing them when youâre not using.I do wish that the company had included a brochure on exercises to try, rather than just putting their website address on the bottom of the assembly instructions. When I put something together, I want to try it out right away, not have to go look up exercise ideas. I also didnât like that the handles are unfinished wood. I could feel a couple of slightly rough spots â not splintery, but just a tad rough. I might do some sanding to make the bars silky smooth.Otherwise, I do like the product, and can see myself getting a lot of use out of the bars.

A COURT OF THORNS AND ROSES is the first book in a new fantasy series by Sarah J. Maas. A New Adult retelling of Beauty and the Beast in a world where faeries are the real power, the book follows prickly Feyre, who is stolen from her home after she kills a faerie disguised as a wolf. Now, instead of struggling to provide for her family, Feyre will spend the rest of her days in Prythian, the faerie lands. But are things what they seem in magical Prythian? Are the faeries as bad as Feyre has always been told?This is my first Sarah J. Maas book. Iâve heard good things about her other series, but A COURT OF THORNS AND ROSES hooked me because of that cover (perfect!) and that itâs New Adult. Basically, if you donât know what New Adult means â itâs the next step after Young Adult. Older protagonists, more romance than just kissing, and more serious situations. I will say that this book doesnât veer too deeply into NA territory. There are a few sexual scenes, but I personally wouldnât call them explicit. Your opinion may vary of course, but compared to other NA, this book is somewhat tame and mostly reads like a YA book.Okay, that aside, I mostly liked A COURT OF THORNS AND ROSES. I liked Feyre. For years, she had the responsibility of keeping her father and sisters alive. Itâs a thankless job, since they mourn the life of privilege they lost and donât care that Feyre has given up her dreams to take care of them. So, in a way, when Feyreâs taken to Prythian, itâs an escape for her. I liked watching Feyre rediscover herself and having the chance to do things she enjoys, such as painting. I also liked how she gradually realized that maybe not everything sheâd been told about faeries was true.I liked the authorâs vision of faerie courts and lands. I tend to like darker fae, and Maas definitely has some of those. The last quarter or so of A COURT OF THORNS AND ROSES was my favorite part for that reason, since itâs where we get to see a lot of fae and their trickery.I thought the book was paced too slowly. Yes, I know A COURT OF THORNS AND ROSES is fantasy, but there were portions of the book where it seemed like nothing happened other than Feyre and Tamlin staring at each other. 75% of the book is slow, leaving the last 25% and the final climax feeling too rushed for all those pages. By the time I finished the book, I couldâve sworn it was 600 pages, not ~430.Some of that slow 75% was used for the development of Feyre and Tamlinâs relationship. While Iâm happy it wasnât insta-lust or part of a love triangle, I didnât really feel the love. However, I did like that once Feyre committed, she committed big time.Overall, A COURT OF THORNS AND ROSES was an okay book for me. I had a couple of issues with it, but this is a series I will continue. The author interested me enough in her version of fae history/courts/politics that I want to know what happens next with Feyre and Tamlin.

âBut really knowing me, few people do (p. 2).âSo says Billy Zeets, unlikely hero. He claims he isnât a hero, and that if he did what he did, so could you, âCause I ainât betterân nobody (p. 5).âBilly is the best part of ASK THE DARK. The book is written in his voice, and while it might take a bit of getting used to, his vernacular is what piqued my interest when I sampled the book. Billyâs a poor boy raised on the wrong side of town, a mostly reformed troublemaker who doesnât do well in school. It would have been unrealistic for him to speak grammatically correct English.The next best part of ASK THE DARK is Billyâs drive to keep his family from losing their house. Thanks to a series of unfortunate events, Billyâs father canât keep up with the remortgage payments and, a broken man, heâs ready to give up. But Billy doesnât think itâs right that they lose the house his dad worked all his life for. But how can a fourteen-year-old, let alone one with a bad reputation, make $48,000 in three months?So, when Billy stumbles over some mysterious boxes in an abandoned house, his first thought is what he can find to sell. Not that the boxes are the first clue in solving the mystery of kidnapped boys. It takes Billy a while to put the pieces together, and even when he realizes he might know something important, he also knows the police wonât believe a word he says because of his past.ASK THE DARK was a bit slow paced for me, especially for a thriller. But I suppose the slower pace makes sense, because Billy has to connect all the clues on his own, and thereâs not always a lightbulb moment. Sometimes it takes thinking about. I also wish there had been more details on what happened to the kidnapped boys, rather than Billy saying youâd have to ask them.But overall, I like the messages in ASK THE DARK. Billyâs devotion to his father and sister, to saving their house, and how he realized sometimes you have to be the adult when your parent(s) arenât acting like adults. I also liked how Billy became an unlikely hero in his quest, and how he faced the darkness, even going above and beyond to save a boy who had bullied him.

A THOUSAND MILES TO FREEDOM is Eunsun Kimâs story of her nine year quest to escape North Korea. I was interested in this memoir because I havenât read any before about North Korea, and I just know the little Iâve heard in the news.While the content of the book is often difficult to stomach -- Eunsunâs family nearly dying of starvation, being sold to a Chinese farmer, being caught by the police and returned to North Korea -- the writing is very simple. I think teenagers and mature younger kids could easily handle this book, if they are curious about North Korea and what one might endure to escape. The simple writing also makes A THOUSAND MILES TO FREEDOM a relatively quick read. I was expecting something with a higher quality of writing, although the style might be due to translation. I believe the book was originally published in French.I also would have liked more insight into life in North Korea. I understand that the author didnât know a lot when she lived in the country, because citizens were only supposed to know the propaganda. But since finally finding a safe place in South Korea, Eunsun says that she has learned a lot about her country and its regime. I wish she would have shared more of what she learned with the reader.A THOUSAND MILES TO FREEDOM is mainly the story of Eunsun and her familyâs journey to escape starvation and death in North Korea. They didnât leave because of politics -- they left because if they didnât, they would die because there was no food to eat. But escaping was no easy task, and the family endured a lot. But again, I wish the author had gone into more detail on certain things. When sheâs sent to a North Korean reeducation camp, experiences there are described in a very short passage, compared to say, the description of her life on a Chinese farm.I did find it interesting that once Eunsun and her mother made it to South Korea, the country helped them out. They were made citizens, took a course on capitalism and acclimating to life in South Korea, and were given money to rent an apartment. Eunsun was even able to attend a prestigious college because of a special program for North Korean students.Overall, A THOUSAND MILES TO FREEDOM is a hopeful memoir, but I wish it had a bit more depth.

In SISTERS OF BLOOD AND SPIRIT, twins Lark and Wren take on a vicious ghost thatâs targeted some of the townâs teenagers. Lark and Wren are uniquely capable of fighting ghosts because Wren is dead and Lark can talk to ghosts.WHAT I LIKED:âLarkâs personality. Sheâs abrasive, snarky, and speaks her mind. Understandably so, since most of the school sees her as a freak for talking to her dead sister and trying to commit suicide.âNan. It was great to see a supportive parent figure in a YA book. Nan is understanding, accepts Lark and Wren, and doesnât try to talk Lark out of fighting ghosts. I also liked that Lark fessed up to her grandmother, because she didnât want to keep secrets.âThe romance between Lark and Ben. Usually Iâm indifferent on romance, but I could get behind this one. It was great to have a boy who came out and said he liked Lark without being arrogant about it. I also liked that they crushed on each other a bit and didnât rush things.âThe concept. The idea behind SISTERS OF BLOOD AND SPIRIT is what made me want to read the book. Twin sisters, able to communicate and interact even though one is dead? Pretty cool.WHAT I DIDNâT LIKE:âA lot left unexplained. I see now that SISTERS OF BLOOD AND SPIRIT is the first in a new series, but I was still left with a lot of questions. What are the Shadow Lands? Why is Wren so powerful? Why does Wren stay with Lark? Why does Bent (the bookâs villain) want to form an army? Who is Emily? And so on.âToo many in the Scooby Gang. Most of the book is taken up with Lark and Wren helping their new friends hunt a ghost, but I couldnât tell some of those friends apart. Thereâs Mace, Sarah, Gage, Ben, Kevin, and Roxi. Some have more page time than others, and maybe theyâll have more development in future books, but in this book, some of them are just chess pieces.âLarkâs suicide attempt. The author mentions this a lot, as well as mentions that the ghosts at the psych ward wanted to recruit Wren. I feel like the reader needed to see this, rather than be told about it again and again.âThe ending is rushed. Lark and the others actually put some preparation and thought into defeating the bad ghost, but itâs over super fast. I expected more there, and hey, what happened to Bentâs razor?Disclaimer: I received a copy of this book from the publisher in exchange for an honest review.

Iâve been using the Hefty Ultimate Flex trash bags for a while. I really like the Clean Burst scent -- itâs not too floral and isnât overpowering. Call me weird, but I like smelling it when I put in a new bag.My one previous gripe with the Hefty bags was that they stuck together like glue, and I was always worried Iâd make a hole when I was stretching the bag open. But Hefty has fixed that, because these bags open way more easily than they used to. It now takes seconds to put in a new one, rather than 5 minutes of fussing with the bag.The âGripperâ drawstring is nice and strong, and Iâve never broken one when tying closed or stretching around my kitchen wastebasket. I donât put trash bags in metal trash cans, so I canât say how well they fit those.

Have you ever wondered what happened after the prince kissed Sleeping Beauty? Did they live Happily Ever After?A WICKED THING is the first in a new YA fantasy series that explores life after The Kiss. When Aurora is awakened by Prince Rodricâs kiss, sheâs thrust 102 years into the future. Her family is dead, the kingdom she knew is full of strife, and sheâs expected to marry Rodric even though she barely knows him.I really like the idea behind A WICKED THING. I think the book is a realistic exploration of what happens after Aurora wakes up. Aurora spends the first bit of the book confused and disoriented, unsure of what to do. Sheâs somewhat passive, which would usually bug me, but it made sense here. I like to think Iâd be all kick butt, but Iâd probably act exactly as Aurora did in this situation. I mean, what would you do if you were woken up by a strange prince, and then his family basically threatened you and made you marry him?But somewhere along the way, A WICKED THING became boring. I feel like the book was missing something, even though thereâs a lot in it. Thereâs cute rebel Tristan, shy and friendly Rodric, the enigmatic Finnegan, the wicked witch Celestine, etc. Thereâs a lot of storylines and a lot of possible love interests, but they donât really go anywhere. The majority of the book is Aurora debating between running and marrying Rodric. I didnât feel too connected to Aurora, likely because of the third-person point-of-view.When I finished A WICKED THING, I was left wanting more. I wanted more to happen by the end of the book, and I wanted an idea of where the series is heading. The beginning of A WICKED THING was better than the last half, but I probably would continue the series because I like the idea of it.

I havenât read a Barry Lyga book before, but Iâd heard good things about them. AFTER THE RED RAIN has an interesting summary -- Iâm a sucker for post-apocalyptic books -- so I gave it a go.But after finishing, Iâm honestly not sure what I read.AFTER THE RED RAIN asks a lot of questions and introduces some cool ideas, but fails to follow through on answering those questions or developing those ideas. I donât know if this book is a standalone, but if it is -- Iâd recommend not reading if youâre the type of reader that likes a complete ending. Thereâs quite a bit left unresolved at the end, which left me disappointed.The setting of AFTER THE RED RAIN was my favorite thing about the book. Thereâs no explanation for *how* the world ended up in its current state, but the current state is well established. People live in Territories, go to work for their ration, and thatâs about it. Thereâs nothing to hope for, because although I saw Ludo Territory as a miserable place, with dangerous air and rain, food recreated from the DNA of extinct animals and plants, and citizens tracked through their brands, Deedra and the others donât know any better. They donât know anything about the past, so they think their world is good, and getting better. That aspect of the book was well done.But the rest of AFTER THE RED RAINâ¦ I got the impression this is a book written to be a movie. There are some chapter long fight scenes that I could see recreated in an action flick. Thereâs Deedra the orphan, surviving on her own and doing okay, but then falling in love with the mysterious Rose. Thereâs a corrupt government magistrate and a mad scientist. Thereâs a shocking revelation about âthe Red Rain.â Thereâs a scene where Deedra and Rose stare off into the scant sunlight and talk about making a difference.I wanted more character development for Deedra and Rose. I wanted to know where the heck Rose came from, and what his purpose was. And so on. I wanted answers! I also think AFTER THE RED RAIN was too long, limping along at a slow pace to the vague ending.

Iâve read quite a few young adult and adult books, fiction and nonfiction, about life in religious cults, so EDEN WEST wasnât anything new for me. Before I started the book, I thought it would be a fresh take on the subject, especially as itâs written from the perspective of a boy, seventeen-year-old Jacob.But EDEN WEST was just an average book. Thereâs a lot of focus on themes and symbols, such as the wolf slaughtering the sheep. Thereâs a lot of the âcult mainstays,â such as polygamy for the powerful men, teenage wives, living off the land, seeing the outside world as evil, the End Days are coming and only the Grace will be saved, etc.In the book, Jacob encounters two outsiders who start him on the process of questioning his faith and himself. Lynna lives on the land next to Nodd, and Tobias is brought to Nodd with his mother and sister to be a convert. Jacob has lived in Nodd since he was five, so his reactions to knowledge of the outside world and questioning his beliefs are understandably childlike at times.
