There are about 26 languages included and instead of including all of the instructions for a particular language together the instructions are split into 5 sections and you have to hunt for your language in each section. Fortunately it is simple enough to operate that after reading through once you won't have to refer to it again.

Olay states that these are suitable for all skin types but with alcohol only second behind water in the ingredient list and the salicylic acid these would be too harsh and drying for anyone who doesn't have oily, acne prone skin.The "Exfoli-dots" textured surface is quite effective at scrubbing and these wipes do an excellent job of removing facial makeup but can't be used for eye makeup because of the alcohol and salicylic acid.They have a light fruity fragrance but the alcohol is the most predominant scent.Ingredients:Water, Alcohol, Sorbitol, Propanediol, Decyl Glucoside, DMDM Hydantion, Salicylic Acid, Glycerin, Laurel Glucoside, Polyglyceryl-10 Caprylate/Caprate, Sodium Hydroxide, Citric Acid, Fragrance, Tetrasodium EDTA, Glyceryl Oleate, Coco-Glucoside, Sodium Benzoate, Sodium Citrate, Iodopropynyl Butylcarbamate.

This case provides great protection and utility in a nice looking package. It is a great choice for anyone who wants the convenience of a traditional keyboard but especially for those who want to carry their iPad for school or work. The closed case is only 5/8" thick; one side is satin finish aluminum that holds the keyboard. The other side is a sturdy plastic frame with a large rubberized plastic panel and hinge. The iPad snaps into that side and is held securely but is easy to remove and replace. The rubberized panel provides a good grip when holding the closed case. This case will add about 15 oz. to the weight of the iPad.There are three magnetic areas behind the keyboard that lock the iPad frame into one of 3 viewing angles. These slots double as on/off switches for the keyboard. Once you pair the keyboard with your iPad it will automatically connect in seconds when you place the cover in one of the slots and disconnect when removed.They have made some small changes from the original Ultimate Keyboard Case. Instead of one center magnet holding the iPad upright on the keyboard there is a magnet on each side so the iPad is held even more securely in the desired position.  They have added two tiny bump out feet to the aluminum bottom of the case so between those and the silicone edging around the hinge the aluminum sits slightly above the table surface protecting the aluminum from scratching.The back of the iPad is completely enclosed and protected while allowing full access to all controls, ports and cameras. The case also has wake/sleep magnets. Unfortunately there is no portrait orientation for this case.The full qwerty keyboard is small but has a good feel and is easy to use. There are shortcut keys for cut, copy, paste and search. Also keyboard volume, play/pause forward and reverse. There is a home screen key and a microphone key that will bring up Siri. One charge will last about 2 months even with daily use. I set up a reoccurring reminder to charge the case so it doesn't run out of power at an inopportune time.I like the convenience of a keyboard and think this case is the best available. I have another Ultimate Keyboard Case for an iPad 4 that has been in daily use for 2 years now and it still works and looks great.

I purchased the tortoise/green glasses. I was concerned that the green might be too bright but it is a slightly subdued lime green that works well with the tortoise and adds a bit a playfulness to a classic design.They are well made with spring hinges and clear distortion free lenses. The width is a little narrower than I expected at 5 1/4" from temple to temple. The lenses are 1 3/4" wide X 1 1/4" high.It comes with a simple faux suede sheath case.

This tool is for someone who regularly needs to prune larger branches of something like a tree with sparse branching. To open the jaws up enough for even a 1" branch the spread is 38" at the end of the handles.  It is also heavy, just shy of 4 pounds.  It wouldn't be a good pick for someone looking for a general duty pruning lopper.The gear makes a huge difference in the amount of effort required to cut through a branch. I easily was able to cut 1 1/2" to 2" branches that I ordinarily would need a saw to cut through. While the cuts are generally very clean, I was disappointed to see slight tearing of bark at the bottom of most of my cuts.The lopper I received; Fiskars L5532 power gear lopper differs from the product listing picture in that it has a nonstick coated blade. The blade can be easily removed for sharpening by removing two hex bolts.Made in China.

I tried the Veggie Penne made with tomatoes and carrots. While waiting the 11 minutes for the pasta to cook I compared the nutritional information the Veggie pasta and Barilla traditional pasta. Comparing 2 oz. servings both pastas have Iron, Thiamin, Riboflavin, Niacin and Folate due to the enriched flours. Both have 2g of fiber, the Veggie has slightly more protein; 8g vs. 7 grams. Because of the vegetable content the Veggie pasta has 30% Vitamin A, 2% Calcium, 2% Vitamin C, 8% Phosphorus and 8% Magnesium.In addition to all of the extra nutrition the Veggie pasta just tastes great. I could taste the tomato in the cooked pasta and the chewy al dente texture is just perfect. I prepared it simply with just olive oil and parmesan with julienned fresh basil and it was delicious.  I love this pasta and just placed an order for 8 boxes.

The upper reservoir holds about 4 cups of water so to max fill you need to wait for the first 4 cups to clear and add the second 4 cups and wait a little longer to add the last two cups. The reason that's important is because of the tyranny of the filter change indictor. The indicator works by sensing when the reservoir lid has been opened longer than 10 seconds. To be accurate you need to fill the pitcher at one time and use it completely before filling again. When you close the lid after filling one of the 3 lights will blink indicating good, change soon or change. I tried to beat it by sneaking in a quick top-off under 10 seconds but it blinked anyway ticking off another complete fill.The instructions state that "the indicator contains a sealed battery. After several years of use, the indicator will stop working, but the pitcher is still functional".  With that I would prefer to not have the indicator light at all and just keep track of filter changes with a calendar and top off the water whenever I darn well please.For years I have been using one of Brita's Slim pitchersBrita Slim Water Filter Pitcher, 5 Cup; the capacity is only 5 cups so I am constantly filling it. I thought it would be great to have a larger capacity pitcher but I find this Grand pitcher cumbersome and when filled with 10 cups of water it weighs 7 1/2 pounds.  The Slim doesn't take up so much counter or refrigerator real estate.Things I like about this pitcher.The front of the handle has a grippy silicone facing that provides a secure grip.The new filter design does significantly reduce the amount of carbon particles that usually would accumulate in the reservoir with the original filter.

I was most interested in the UV Protection claim on these pouches and devised a short term test. I printed out three of the same photo and laminated one with a 3 mil Fellows Image Last, one with 3mil Scotch laminating pouches Scotch Thermal Laminating Pouches 8.9 x 11.4 Inches 3 mil, 200-Pack (TP3854-200) and left one sheet as control without any lamination.  I taped all three sheets in a south facing window for two weeks. Comparing the sheets there was slight but noticeable color fading in both the control and the Scotch although the Scotch did fair better than the control. I could not detect any noticeable fading of the Image Last laminated photo.I did notice some other differences between the Fellows and the Scotch. Despite both pouches were 3mil the Scotch feel slightly thicker than the Fellows and an after laminating the Scotch felt stiffer and less flexible than the Fellows.  The clear laminated edges around the Fellows sheet are much clearer and sealed tight right up to the edge of the laminated photo and the edges of the pouch. The Scotch edges are cloudier and more prone to slight sealing gaps around the edges of the laminated sheet and air bubbles around the edges of the laminated pouch.When I wrote this if purchasing the 200 sheet packages the Scotch pouches will cost about 15 cents a sheet versus the Fellows at 19 cents. If your laminating projects would benefit by the UV protection and nicer looking edges the Fellows are well worth the extra few cents. If these things are not critical and you like the idea of a stiffer end result and saving a few cents each sheet the Scotch will do a serviceable job.

For years I have been using a Casabella squeegee Casabella 44037 Clip on Silicone Squeegee, White to dry off the ceramic tile in my shower and always thought it worked well in addition to being nice looking.The OXO squeegee has a very thin silicone blade similar to a windshield wiper that does a much better job removing water and even getting into the grout lines that the Casabella with its thicker more rigid blade would just skim over. The OXO also is lighter and the thinner handle is much more comfortable to hold.The soft silicone swivel hook is a great design that allows you to hang it from the shower pipe or a towel bar. The interior of the hook is about 1" in diameter and made of flexible silicone so it can expand to slide over the pipe and won't scratch metal surfaces.  It is a big improvement over previous OXO squeegees.

This twine holder has the one feature I have been looking for; I can pull and cut the twine with one hand. So when I am tying up a roast or trussing poultry I don't have to worry about contaminating the twine or even touching the holder.  The non-slip feet keep it steady and the removable cutter is a nice touch for trimming the knots  or when tying up something large like cardboard for recycling.The footprint is 4" x 4 1/2" and is 5 1/2" tall.You can purchase OXO 300ft refills OXO Good Grips 100-Percent Natural Cotton Twine, 300-Feet or use any 1/2 cone up to 500 ft.

The grill has a 6 1/2" x 9 1/4" cooking surface and would be tight fit for 4 servings of something over 3 to 4 ounces each.  Not including the 2 prong plug the power cord is 24" long and there is a cord wrap on the bottom. It has a floating hinge to adjust to the thickness of food and it does indeed heat up in 4 minutes. Instructions are minimal; safety instructions and a suggested cooking time chart for burgers, chicken breast, steak and salmon.The elements will cycle off when the plates are about 400° then cool to about 300Â° before cycling on again. The difference between the center temperature where the element is and the outer two inches around the edges is about 20Â°, not bad.  A sear temperature would be about 450Â°, because this cooks at a lower temperature and drops 100Â° before heating again the best results would be with thicker cuts that have a chance to get nicely browned before overcooking.To check out its versatility I planned a bacon cheeseburger panini. It did a very nice job with thick-cut bacon. The top plate was not able to make full contact but  still was able to keep the bacon flat while cooking and it turned out evenly crisp and brown in 5 minutes. I liked the results much better than pan fried bacon.  I made two 3 oz. beef burgers and they were done in about 5 minutes. Because they were small the burgers did not get a deep brown sear before they were done but they were browned with grill marks.  I unplugged the grill and wiped the plates with paper towels to have a clean surface for grilling the sandwiches before plugging it in again. My sandwiches were thick and I had an issue with them sliding while setting the top down and not setting flat. I ended up carefully lifting the hinge end with the handle of a spatula to level the top before setting it on the sandwiches.There are five 1/4" high stops cast into the bottom plate so food like sausages won't roll off the grill. The plates are easy to remove and are dishwasher safe but to extend the life of the nonstick surface you would want to only hand wash the plates. The back of the plates are aluminum which reacts poorly to automatic dishwasher detergent so that is another good reason the hand wash the plates. The non-stick surface works very well and the clean-up from cooking bacon and burgers was easy.Things I don't like about this grill.The rear feet are hard slippery plastic and will slide around quite readily. The front "feet" are tiny silicone buttons so they provide a slight grip. On the unit I received one of my buttons was missing.The drip tray is shallow at 1/2" and does not lock or snap into place. It rests on the counter and the back edge is tabbed to fit into a recess at the bottom of the grill. It will keep it from moving from side to side but is very easy to pull away from the grill so it could be a hazard if snagged with a hot pad or spatula and pulled out with hot grease in it. Because the grill slides around easily just opening the lid can move the grill away from the drip tray.

This is similar to the GoalZero Nomad system except the NOCO uses lithium ion battery packs instead of AA NiMh rechargeable batteries and the Nomad is a 7W panel vs. the NOCO at 9W.This NOCO package includes a combination flashlight/11Wh battery pack, one solar panel, a 5V Flex USB regulator, a USB to Micro USB cord to charge the flashlight/battery. The size of this battery pack is really only practical for charging items like a cell phone twice, an action camera or GPS three times. For more charges or for a tablet you would want one of their larger battery packs like the XGB6 NOCO XGrid XGB6 22Wh Rugged USB Battery Pack or XGB12 NOCO XGrid XGB12 44Wh Rugged USB Battery Pack. The battery packs can be charged from an outlet or the solar panel.The flashlight is a nice compact size with a rubberized case and is bright with 4 modes; 100%, 50%, 10% and Strobe. It does not have a power remaining indicator like the larger battery packs do. The hinged bottom cover over the ports does not close securely and detracts from an otherwise well designed device. Under ideal conditions with full sun the flashlight battery pack will charge in about 4.5 hours. If it is partly cloudy it can take significantly longer. You can also directly connect your device to the solar panel for charging.The system is flexible; you can string solar panels together to increase the charging power or purchase 12V NOCO GC027 12V 2A Flex Regulator or 6V NOCO XGrid FLEX6V 6V 2A Flex Regulator Regulators for charging auto batteries. The solar panel is sturdy and can be hung across a backpack. It includes mesh pockets on both sides for holding the accessories and could also be used to hold the device you are charging while hiking.

The labels come two to a 4 x 6 sheet with a separate sheet of clear adhesive "laminate".  There is no downloadable template for these labels; the only printing option available is through their Design and Print Online at Avery.com. Through Design and Print there are many options for customizing the label including backgrounds, images, frames and fonts. The final design opens as a pdf for printing and you can save the pdf for future printing if desired.I went through the process and designed a label and did some test prints. The problem I ran into was getting my printer to accept the sheet straight. I tried and failed 4 times and was never able to print out a perfect set of labels. There was one I could trim and apply to the intended container and then the task of getting the very thin laminate sheet on straight without any ripples or bubbles. Fail. Two bubbles and one small ripple at the edge.  It is a nice idea but expensive, troublesome and the thin laminate doesn't look very professional.

Yamaha YAS-93  This review is for the basic model without Bluetooth or wireless subwoofer.This is a good option for someone just looking to improve sound quality over the built-in TV speakers in a small to medium sized room at a reasonable price.The sound is clear and distortion free but will not provide a real projecting surround sound or thumping subwoofer experience. Increasing the subwoofer volume is just increasing the bass.The Clear Voice feature works very well. My husband uses hearing aids and understanding dialog over the soundtrack has always been a frustrating issue for him. Using Clear Voice does make understanding dialog much easier.The IR remote signal repeater feature also works very well. The sound bar sits at the base of our TV and does block the remote signal but the repeater function has worked flawlessly.Set up is very easy with the included optical cable to the TV. It does come with a template for wall installation.

If you own any of the ATK cookbooks you already know that it will have extensively tested recipes, equipment reviews and recommendations, kitchen tips and discoveries and lots of helpful photos.The make-ahead cookbook is no exception and I was happy to see the wide variety of recipes and preparation methods included.There are family friendly meals, meals that would be great for entertaining and many recipes with ethnic flavors including Mexican, Asian, Italian and Indian. There are lots of  great tips and techniques that can also be used to adapt and improve other favorite recipes. For recipes that can be cooked on an outdoor grill they provide instructions for that as well as broiling so if you can't grill outdoors you can still enjoy the recipe.The majority of the recipes use meat, poultry or seafood but 43 meatless meals are included. All recipes include the prep and cooking times but these are not all quick meals; prep and cooking can range from 30 minutes to several hours.  If you are looking for quick meals they did publish a great book for meals that can be prepared in 45 minutes or less; The America's Test Kitchen Quick Family Cookbook: A Faster, Smarter Way to Cook Everything from America's Most Trusted Test KitchenThe book has 8 different strategies for make-ahead meals. Although one of the chapters;Shop Smart-One Grocery Bag Makes Three Dinners, focuses on planning and shopping for three meals. None of the meals are make-ahead but each take 1 hour or less to prep and cook. 8 three-meal menus are provided in that chapter. One of the menus that happens to be vegetarian is Baked Quinoa with Roasted Kale and Chickpeas, Gemeli with Caramelized Onions,Kale and Mushrooms and Grilled Portobello BurgersPrep ahead: Ready to Cook Meals. Contains  27 recipes including Spiced Rubbed Flank Steak with Toasted Corn and Black Bean Salad, Roasted Pork Loin with Potatoes and Mustard Sauce and Indian Spiced Chicken with Yogurt Sauce.Reheat and Eat: Make-ahead Stews and Braises. Contains 18 recipes including Easy Overnight Beef Stew, Cider Braised Pork Chops and Marsala-Braised Chicken and Mushrooms.Bake and Serve: Oven Ready Casseroles. Contains 17 recipes like Curried Chicken and Brown Rice with Red Peppers, Roasted Zucchini and Eggplant Lasagna and Rustic Polenta Casserole with Sausage.From Fridge to Table: Ready to Serve Entrees. 20 recipes for meals to serve cold including Herb-Poached Salmon with Cucumber and Dill Salad, Pesto Pasta Salad with Chicken and Arugula and Sesame Noodles with Chicken.The Sunday Cook has 6 recipes for large Sunday dinner roasts with two additional recipes each to make something completely different with the leftovers.  One of the included menus is Braised Turkey Breast en Cocotte with Pan Gravy, Thai Style Turkey and Jasmine Rice Soup and Turkey and Green Chile Enchiladas.Come Home to Dinner : Easy Slow Cooker Favorites has 22 recipes including Asian Braised Beef Short Ribs, Smokey Chipotle Beef Tacos and Turkey Wild Rice Soup.Stock the Freezer: Big Batch Suppers. 19 recipes including Cheese Pizza, Beef and Bean Burritos, Meat Hand Pies and Crispy Chicken Fingers in addition to classics like Beef Tamale Pie, Lasagna, Chili and Macaroni and Cheese.Overall an excellent cookbook and a great value.

What I like most about this set is the size and shape.  There is not much of anything available for food in the 7qt range that isn't a bowl.The main container is 8 1/2" x 13" x 3 3/4" deep and is great for big batches of food like salads as well as bars, cookies, cake and cupcakes.  The included trays I expect to use less frequently but they are a nice addition that increases the versatility of the set. The container and trays are made of sturdy plastic. The lid can be also be used as a serving tray; turned over it has a 8 1/2" x 13" x 3/4" deep depression.The weak link in this set is the lid. I am used to food storage containers having airtight seals that "snap" closed. This lid has a friction fit that does not feel secure and is not airtight so any food stored more than 24 hours would need to have a layer of plastic wrap under the lid to keep the moisture in.  If the lid were to get bent or warped in any way there is not enough friction in the fit to be able to keep it on.  So for the lid only I recommend hand washing and storing on the container.I keep some large rubber bands around the house to secure food containers when transporting just to make sure the lid stays put. With this container unless it was to be transported very carefully some sort of band would be a must, preferably one on each end.  If this had been designed with an airtight lid and wrap-around band/handle strap it would be five stars.The rest of the pieces are dishwasher, microwave and freezer safe. Technically the lid is dishwasher and microwave safe but I wouldn't put it in the microwave or dishwasher. If using the container in the freezer it would need to be short-term because without an airtight seal the food would get ice crystals and degrade quickly.Because it is plastic it has the usual caveats about microwaving. Foods high in oil, fat or sugar can cause pitting or staining in the case of tomato based foods.Despite the issues with the lid I'm happy with the set because I have a lot of use for a container this size and shape.

The apron has a nicely detailed apple print on a teal background. It's made from tightly woven lightweight cotton twill with a subtle sateen finish.Dimensions after washing and drying are 32" long x 26" high. The pocket is 7" x 11 3/4" and the ties are 30" long. The bib is 9"wide at the top and 10 1/2" wide at the middle of my chest so the coverage is not as complete as the product picture would imply.It definitely could use some ironing when it comes out of the drier.This would make a nice gift along with some apple related tools like an apple slicer-corer Amco Dial-A-Slice Adjustable Apple Corer and Slicer and a red pie plate. Good Cook 9 Inch Ceramic Pie Plate, RedMade in China
I love this sprinkler, it is so easy to change the width and travel of the spray. Second season and its still going strong.

This is a very elegant looking bottle; even the wrist strap is a beautiful fine stainless steel mesh.  Empty it weighs 18 oz, full it is a hefty 2 1/2 pounds. Water does taste better in glass and while I don't think I will be taking this to yoga class I do use it at work and fill it from the cooler in the morning.The silicone sleeve does provide a secure grip but it is not removable so if I were to get something under it I don't know how easy it would be to clean.The picture of the color is not quite accurate; I received the Greyed Jade and on the product page it appears bright turquoise but in reality it is more green than blue. The product description also is not accurate. This bottle is NOT a 24 oz. AUTOSEAL Grace Water Bottle that is engineered for an easy one-hand drinking experience. This bottle is 20 oz and has a brushed finish stainless steel screw-off cap with a silicone gasket.If you are looking for a glass water bottle that you won't be carrying around I think this is a great bottle at a nice price.2.5" wide at the widest point of the body, 10.3" highest point with cap and 2.3" diameter at base"Made in China

These brownies bake up moist, fudgy and chewy with great chocolate flavor. They taste like homemade because they use the same ingredients a home baker would; sugar, unbleached wheat flour, semisweet chocolate chips, organic cocoa powder, corn starch, salt and natural vanilla flavor. There is a generous amount of  mini chocolate chips in the mix that contain only unsweetened chocolate, sugar, cocoa butter and vanilla extract.In comparison the major brands can contain bleached flour, corn syrup, vegetable oil and artificial flavor. If they contain chocolate chips often they are made with lecithin, palm oils and artificial flavor.All you need to make the brownies in addition to the mix is 1/2 cup of melted butter and two eggs. I baked them in an 8" x 8" pan and they were 3/4" thick. I especially love the chewy texture and I think these would also be great baked in an 11" x 7" pan and used to make ice cream sandwiches.I am very impressed with these brownies and would definitely buy this mix. It is almost twice as much as the major brands but well worth it.

I'm comparing this with Intermatic DT620 astronomic timers Intermatic DT620CL 15 Amp Indoor Astronomic Digital Timer that I have been using for years.  I wouldn't want to do without the convenience of a timer that can adjust for the changing dawn and dusk times and DST. No more moving furniture twice or more a year to manually adjust the timing. Once you go astonomic you will never go back.What I like about this model DT121K is that it's more compact; 3 1/4"H x 2 1/2" W x 1 7/8" D  vs the DT620 at 3 1/4" H x 3 1/8" W x 2 1/4" D (not including plug). The DT121K is also much easier to set up and program; I had it done in just a few minutes, less than half the time it takes me to set up and program the DT620. This model can be used with LED and CFL bulbs unlik ethe DT620.The two plugs are not controlled independently but come in handy if one plug is blocked by something else or if using for two table lamps on either side of a couch.This DT121K is being used with table lamp that comes on at dusk and off at a set time. I use one DT620  for a night light in the hall that comes on at dusk and off at dawn. In the winter I use one for a heated mattress pad that comes on the same time every night but off at different times for weekday/weekend.Before you program the timer for the first time or if it hasn't been used for a long time you need to plug it into an outlet for 30 minutes to charge the lithium battery.  You can adjust the current dawn/ dusk times. I found the default setting for my time zone was different than my location in the time zone. Another reason to adjust the dusk time would be if you wanted a light to come on just before dusk. Once you have set the time it will automatically adjust it a few minutes each day.

It wasn't apparent until we installed it that the front cover assembly had been damaged. I have a Friedrich Chill and love it so I did not want to give up on the Kuhl. I called the Friedrich customer service number included with the unit and explained the problem. A few minutes later the part had been ordered for me and I received it in 5 days with installation instructions.The Kuhl is substantially quieter than the GE AEL08LQ 8000 BTU it replaced.  It's actually possible to have a conversation in the same room with it unlike the GE. With most window air conditioners including the Friedrich Chill it is obvious when the compressor is running but the Kuhl is so much quieter with almost no vibration.I wonder if the reviewers who didn't feel any cool air coming out had the control set for fan only because the air coming out is very cold. Despite using it in an area much larger than the 300 sq ft it is rated for; a 550 sq ft living room & dining room it is doing a great job of cooling the area. And it is excellent at removing humidity. So much so when it is cloudy and not hot enough to run both my main floor air conditioners but still humid I can run just this air conditioner and it dries the air in the rest of my first floor. I use a tower fan to circulate the air from the living room where the A/C is installed to the dining room.It does come with two pre-programed schedules one for home use and one for commercial use.You can also customize one on and one off setting per day but if you want anything more complicated than one on and one off per 24 hours you would need to purchase the additional accessory of Wi-Fi Lite Friedrich KWIFI wi-fi kit for all Kuhl & Kuhl+ N-Series models and download the phone app to operate it.This unit is larger than other 7800-8000 BTU air conditioners. It is 20" wide x 23 1/4 inches deep compared to my GE 8000 BTU that is 18 1/2" wide  and 15" deep. It will fit windows from 22 to 45 inches wide.It has a generous 70" cord length not including the plug. The cord is on the left side of the unit but instructions are included for changing to the right side.Installation in a window is incredibly easy but because of the weight of this unit you do need two people. After attaching the curtains to the cabinet you place it in the window and screw the cabinet down to the sill with one screw in the center.  We needed to add a shim to the sill of our 1920 window because it is deeper than in newer homes. Then attach the side curtains to the sash and frame with screws and then you are ready to slide the A/C into the cabinet and plug it in.It comes with one of the optional replaceable carbon filters Friedrich KWCFQ carbon filters - 3 pack for Kuhl and Kuhl+ series - Q chassis models that they claim will capture allergens such as dust, mold spores, pet dander, dust mites and pollen; adsorb odors, ozone and volatile organic compounds.

I thought these would be handy to keep in my gardening basket for harvesting herbs, tomatoes and deadheading flowers. I have been using traditional bypass pruning shears but they are cumbersome for light trimming or getting into tight spaces.Maybe I have gotten spoiled by soft grip garden tools and scissors but the handles on these are so hard. And there is a lot of friction between the blades so opening and closing them takes more effort than typical shears.  I even tried a silicone spray on them but that had no effect. Because of the friction and hard handle using these for any repetitive task is very fatiguing and uncomfortable. I prefer my soft-grip spring assist pruner for gardening chores.They are sharp and the ability to take them apart for cleaning is a nice feature. My shears did not come with a sheath so I can't comment on the quality or usefullness of that.

The frustration free packaging identifies these as Belkin Anti -Glare. I think they might be "seconds". Mine had an extra rectangular hole above the front speaker. I received the 4-pack and there were 2 screen protectors in each pack for a total of 8. The anti-glare coating does help quite a bit when using the phone outdoors. Viewing the screen straight on there is a very slight loss of brightness and clarity; that increases to hazy grey when viewing at a sharp angle.I didn't have a problem applying these but prep is everything when putting on any screen protector.  Some brands like Tech Amor give you a microfiber cleaning cloth and tacky tape to clean your screen before applying.Tech Armor Apple iPhone 4 and 4S Anti-Glare & Anti-Fingerprint (Matte) Screen Protector with Lifetime Replacement Warranty [3-Pack] The Armor Tec also has plastic on both sides of the screen protector so you don't scratch it when burnishing out the air bubbles and are also slightly thicker than the Belkin's. All those niceties so add to the price and you can't beat the value of these Belkin's if you don't mind flaws like an extra hole on the screen.To use these you will need a microfiber cleaning cloth MagikCleen. Superior Premium Microfiber Cleaning Cloths for cleaning Smartphones, Tablets, Laptops, Cameras, iPads, Hand Held Video Games, Eyeglasses, Sunglasses, LED Screens, LCD Screens, Electronics(5 pack-4+1 bonus) , a can of dusting spray Dust-Off FALDPSXL12 Disposable Compressed Gas Duster, 12-oz. Can and a credit card or other smooth edge card.  If you want to preserve the original finish on your phone's screen don't use anything but a little water on the cloth if needed for stubborn spots. Don't use Kleenex or paper towels; they are linty and they scratch.Once you have the screen clean use the dusting spray to blow off any remaining dust. Remove the protective backing from the screen protector taking care to handle it only by the edges and apply. I like to line up the center bottom and home button hole before setting it on the phone.  I hold the sheet slightly curled so the center touches first and when you let go it will adhere to the rest of the screen. If your screen is clean and edges are straight it should lay out with minimal bubbling that you can burnish out with the card. If an edge is not attaching the protector was probably not lined up straight. You can try removing and reapplying but you increase the chance of picking up stray dust on it and not being able to use it at all but it is worth a shot anyway.These are serviceable and cheap. I wouldn't buy them again simply because the extra hole does bother me. For the few times I need to apply every year full price doesn't break the bank.If these are seconds with manufacturing errors it should be included in the description so you know exactly what your getting.

A friend of mine bought a bottle of the Fee Brothers Gin Barrel-Aged Orange Bitters and kept telling me how amazing  they were. I hesitated at the price but finally caved and bought a bottle. He was right they are amazing. The undertone of gin flavor with the bitter orange is a perfect combination; even for me who is still not so fond of gin after a one to many martini lunch in my youth.It does make a killer old fashioned but I also love a few drops mixed with sparkling water or lemon-lime soda. Nummy.

I was surprised how large this monitor is; the face and footprint of the unit is 6.6" x 5". It has very large numbers and simple controls. After a reading the lights next to the systolic and diastolic measurement will be either green for normal range or amber for higher than the normal range.It comes with an A/C adapter and you can just plug it in and take a reading but if you want to use the date/time and save your measurement history you will need to install 4AA batteries.(not included)I have been using the Omron wrist blood pressure monitor for several years Omron 7 Series Wrist Blood Pressure Monitor and I love how easy it is to use but unfortunately it doesn't seem to be that accurate and always reads lower than my typical blood pressure. The readings from this 10 series monitor are much closer to my average so I am more confident in the accuracy.I had a lot of trouble with the cuff until it dawned on me I should slip my arm into and slide it up my arm instead of wrapping it around my arm. The instructions just say "apply the arm cuff to your left upper arm". The cuff does inflate to the point it is squeezing my arm quite firmly and because of that sometimes it seems to take forever to count down and release. Once it just took off and got up to 220 before I shut it off. I did have some broken capillaries on my arm from that.There is no case for it and unfortunately even the original box isn't suitable for storage or transport because it is open on two sides.

I have used Dawn for many years, but every now and then I try another brand and it never fails to dissapoint. I need  to use twice as much and still don't get the effective grease cutting I get from Dawn. I do love the refreshing green apple blossom scent too.This soap is antibacterial so it contains Triclosan.  If you want a great dish soap that is not anti-bacterial I'm a big fan of Dawn Hand Renewal, especially the Pomegranate Splash scent.Dawn Ultra Hand Renewal With Olay Beauty Pomegranate Splash Scent Dishwashing Liquid 44 Fl Oz

I have always wanted a touchless soap dispenser for my kitchen but they were all much too large to fit on the back of my sink. This compact model fits perfectly and looks great.I love that it is rechargeable so there is no bother and expense with replacing batteries.  It does come with just a USB cable for charging so if you want to charge it from a wall outlet you will need a USB wall charger.Universal US USB Wall Charger Plug In-door Power AC Adapter For iPhone 4 S 5 5G Galaxy S4 S3(White) I just used the one that came with my iPhone and it was fully charged in about 30 minutes.The top has a small charging/ low battery indicator light and a - and + button.  Adjusting the amount of soap dispensed is as easy as touching one of the buttons and it will retain that setting until you change it. I find the smallest amount works fine most of the time so if I need more soap I'll put my hand under the spout twice.  If you want to turn it off to prevent accidental dispensing it is as simple as pressing the - button for two seconds. The battery indicator light will blink red once to confirm the setting. To turn it on press the + for two seconds and the light will blink green to confirm.  It is quick and easy to fill from the flip up cover on top. The rear of the dispenser is clear plastic so you can easily check the soap level. The 2" long spout provides plenty of clearance for your hands and it dispenses the soap very quickly.It comes with a 3.5 oz. package of lavender scented simplehuman hand soap. I didn't try that because I don't like lavender scented products. I fill it with Caldrea liquid hand soap and it works just fine.This dispenser is a little spendy but it is well made, functional and nice looking. I love it and think it is worth it.Update 12/30/14 - One morning I found my soap dispenser repeatedly self dispensing. I went to the Simplehuman website support section and they state that there are two reasons this will happen; something has gotten on the sensor window or something in proximity trips the motion sensor. I knew I didn't have a proximity problem so I turned it off, cleaned off the sensor window and recharged the dispenser. That solved the problem and now I know to make sure I clean the sensor more frequently.
Replaces the junk miter that comes with your saws and routers. This thing is solid, stable, and accurate.

Small but mighty. I am using this to suck up exhaust from my power tools. While the planer fills this thing up quick its super easy to empty. The stock hose is junk but a 2 1/4(?) Shop-Vac hose I had laying around (also from Amazon) fit perfectly and kept up with the wood chips.

I eat it as porridge (1 to 1 - TVP to non-dairy milk). Add a little cinnamon, maple syrup, etc and you have a high protein vegan breakfast without firing up the stove. Sometimes I'll mix in oatmeal for a different texture. Also good in sauces, chilli, etc. This is a great price for how much you get.
Fits the Scanpan CTX 10 1/4 fry pan perfectly. You can fill the pan up and the lid does not touch the foot unlike all the other random pan and lid sets I've had over the years.

Plastic package it shipped in was real beat. I would not feel comfortable giving it as a gift in the condition I received it in. However for a cheap iOS testing device that you can easily jailbreak, this is perfect.
Flat, subtle, good connection. Using for all my drives and have had no issues so far.

Filling, good vegan protein, but a little salty. I like all of the flavors but will probably order just my favorite in the future (Black Pepper). Looks and chews as close to the real thing as you can get.
Fits my Razer Blade power brick snuggly. Wanted something smaller than the code it shipped with and this is perfect.

Great cookies. Vegan, higher protein, a little dry. That said instead of getting a sugar bomb off the shelf with all kinds of random junk in it these are a tiny bit better. I eat them for snack or after work out.
Brush heads were great but the packaging is the most wasteful thing I've ever seen. You'll be amazed at the size of this box!
Love the smell of this soap. It smells masculine not to be confused with a 15 year old teenagers idea of "manly". Animal friendly. It's a lot cheaper at the store with a target for a logo.
I got this to carry on me every day. Its smaller than I thought but has blown away my expectations. Its super handy, but I do wish the components locked into place.
This is a very good kettle and has all the right settings. Only complaint is that the lid is harder to open over time. I push, it sticks. I push 5 more times and it finally opens.
Brings my headphone jack closer to my head. Connected to my tower on the floor, routed up to my standing desk. Quality feels very good.
Perfect for the increasing prevalence and number of two factor types. I keep OTPs, connect work and personal, FIDO, etc.
I use this mostly for wood working. Its great for other random stuff or just banging hold fast, chisel, wood, etc. It dents over time but I am not worried about it holding up.

I love these bars. I was worried that cherry flavor would be fake or overwhelming but its actually very subtle. There is a lot of sugar in this entire line and I don't mind. I treat these more like a healthier candy bar.

Sound quality is good. Play/pause/mic work well on iPhone and Mac. I wasn't excited about the color but after using them for a while I have grown to like the whole package.Update: after about 3 months I've noticed a few annoyances. First the cord is coated in a sticky rubber. Getting them in and out of your pocket has more friction than I'd like. This also leads to the cord catching and tangling on itself often ending up in me fumbling or dropping my phone - something I've never done before using these headphones. Second issue, while the ear pieces are a great fit and stay snug the rubber pieces are low quality. Both have torn and become completely unusable. I've never had any of these issues with any other headphones of any kind.Bottom line - The sound quality and isolation qualities are good but these headphones just didn't hold up.

These have been the only bands I've ever bought. With that in mind, they meet my expectations but wish they'ed last a little longer. My most used band developed nicks after about 18 months. After tempting fate I decided to heed the manufacturers warning and get a new one. They come in any weight range you can imagine. I initially bought a pack of 5 or 6 but since replaced and bought individuals. I don't have the space for weights and I understand they'll never be the same but I love the portability and flexibility to do just about any weight lifting exercise.
I broke my elbow and wrist but the grass kept growing. I bought this to take the weight off my trimmer allowing me to control it entirely with one hand. The should pad is a must.

Michael McDowell fortunately hit the Seventies horror boom at just the right time when he left his Ph.D. program in literature at Brandeis so that his skills could find the right appreciative audience. Here he gets to wear his learning (lightly) in this deft exploration of many of the themes of American Victorian melodrama and the penny dreadful. There's everything here you might imagine from this clever re-imagining of the genres, from an upright and virginal heroine who can't pay the rent (but she must pay the rent!) and cares for her aging penniless mother; there's a heartless rich girl to disparage her clothing and marriage prospects; a handsome and wealthy suitor; a benevolent society woman; a helpless grandfather; the narrator making asides of the "Had they but known then..." variety; and even a murderous menacing family to bedevil the heroine. The last of these shows best McDowell's work in horror fiction; the terrible but fatally unimaginative Slapes--a father, his daughter, and her stepmother--are the most memorable characters in the book, and the daughter Katie is not only a psychopathic serial killer but also has mindreading and precognitive powers of which she makes fascinating use. Indeed, Katie is so formidable as to have even become the novel's eponymous character, though it shouldmore rightly have been called PHILOMENA after the resourceful heroine (who, in a nice twist, is not quite so forgiving or gentle as her 19th-century antecedent heroines). The novel is enormously helped by McDowell's extensive knowledge of 1870s America; he never shows off what he knows, but the depth and breadth of knowledge of the era is very apparent.

This may be the best of John Harwood's re-writings of Victorian ghost stories and sensation novels. It's a re-writing largely of THE WOMAN IN WHITE, and like Willkie Collins's most famous novel it makes much of multiple narrative voices and forms, surprises and reversals, and also involves all kinds of doubles and doppelgangers. In the 1880s, Georgina Ferrars wakes up in an insane asylum in Cornwall with the staff assuring her she put herself under voluntary incarceration with them under her actual name, Lucy Ashton; when she asks them to check with her uncle back in London to prove her identity, he assures them his niece Georgina is still living with him there. Things go on from there rounding most of the usual tropes of sensation novels from the High to late Victorian period, including hidden wills, falsified names, controlling parents, and crumbling old houses. It's a very fine and very gripping read, although it does not take the genre quite to another level as did Susan Waters' FINGERSMITH (which was also a re-writing of THE WOMAN IN WHITE, and which also like this novel brought out the homoerotic elements in the Collins novel more to the forefront).

Although THE GALTON CASE represents Ross Macdonald's breakthrough where he really found his voice as a crime novelist, his next Lew Archer book, THE WYCHERLY WOMAN, was a genuine setback. It starts out like most of Macdonald's Archer novels do, with his detective hero called in by a wealthy Californian to solve family trouble, but instead of dwelling on the lives and the psychology of the wealthy (as THE GALTON CASE and his other later mature novels do), THE WYCHERLY WOMAN gets drawn instead into an unconvincing, vaguely Chandleresque world of wiretappers, blackmailers, and sleazy hotels. It has a murder plot that's much too complex (again showing the influence of Raymond Chandler) and some inauthentic dialogue among lowlifes, and it becomes very hard to care about the characters. And it's also very hard to see why Archer, who gets so easily impatient with his clients in all the other books, would ever stay on Homer Wycherly's payroll given how unbelievably secretive and witholding the millionaire is (at several points in the novel he would have certainly at least threatened to quit the case had he been written fully in character).It's not until his next novel, THE ZEBRA-STRIPED HEARSE, that Macdonald seemed confident in the new direction in which he was moving and assumed full control of his mature style. No Lew Archer novel is unreadable, but this is not one of Macdonald's strongest books, and shows few of his genuine strengths as a mystery writer. (And what is up with that cover?)

NIGHT MOVES is often lauded as one of the best films of the Seventies, even though it didn't do very well at the box office during its initial release. A re-working of the classic private eye story, the story actually tries for more than that with its complex depiction of a seedy and dispirited America in the mid-Seventies. All of the locales look exceptionally seedy (not just the run-down motel in the Florida Keys where much of the action takes place, but also the homes of the very wealthy), and the film repeatedly makes reference to the various political tragedies of the decade previous (even the film's closing moments seem to evoke Chappaquiddick). The film also is a thoughtful exploration of the problems of American middle-class, middle-aged masculinity in a time of women's liberation and a rising divorce rate, and it has as its protagonist the greatest portraitist of middle-age white masculinity in the Seventies, Gene Hackman, in one of the best roles of his career as the football player turned second-rate private investigator Harry Moseby.Though Hackman is terrific as the morally compromised Moseby, he's let down repeatedly by his supporting cast. Both of his major love interests, Susan Clark and Elizabeth Warren, let him down: Clark is fatally uninteresting as his straying wife, and Warren is visually striking but has trouble sometimes with Allen Sharp's dialogue. (Though some of Sharp's conversations are brilliant, at times he seems to call too much attention to how clever he can be.) Viewers today are often excited to see Melanie Griffith and James Wood early in their careers in important roles here, but the truth is neither of them is very good. As the nymphet daughter at the center of Moseby's investigation, Griffith (who played a similar role the same year in another private eye film, THE DROWNING POOL, and who undresses at least four times before the camera) just doesn't pull off what's required of her. Much of the film's emotional weight depends on her ability to charm both Harry and the audience in its middle third, but Griffith just hadn't yet learned how to be endearing as well as irritating. Woods is repellent in a way that is partially his character but also largely him; he keeps trying to upstage Hackman (ineffectively). All the actors are also weighed down by the film's convoluted plot, which depends far too much on ridiculous coincidence and cheap cosmic irony.The film has eared a high reputation among film critics, but for all NIGHT MOVES accomplishes, it is very flawed.

David Thomson has seen more films (and written more about them) than most people alive, and this compendium serves best as a way to tag films you really ought to see but didn't know you should (my own copy is covered in Post-It flags for this reason). I've already been grateful since buying this for Thomson's recommendation of two terrific films noirs, THE PROWLER and ANGEL FACE, and he is especially fine on this genre, given his propensity for the dark and the perverse. (There are few writers alive who have better taste than he does on film noir or are more articulate on the subject: I can only think of Eddie Muller.) Accompanying his love for the twisted from the ordinary, however, is a distaste for an a bafflement by happiness and "normality," to which Thomson freely confesses in a review of THE TRIPLETS OF BELLEVILLE. This allows him to a certain critical blindness which sometimes mars his appreciation of certain films. In his review of Hitchcock's SHADOW OF A DOUBT, for example, Thomson wishes that Charlie Newton were written to be much darker, like her Uncle Charlie, and he confesses impatience with the careful depiction of Charlie's family other than her uncle--which in many ways misses the whole point of the movie.A greater flaw in the book is Thomson's writing. The high speed at which many of these reviews seem to be written lets him down, and though his knowledge of the film world is encyclopedic and his taste very interesting, his sometimes rushed prose style hampered my enjoyment of the book. His pursuit of unusual metaphors or other figures of speech is quite often jarring, and there are times when he lapses into mere description (as in his review of Sokurov's MOTHER AND SON) or embarrassing rhapsody (such as his concluding paragraphs on KISS ME DEADLY). Worst of all, Thomson keeps making stupid errors in his reviews. In his review of MEET ME IN ST. LOUIS, he claims, "LADY IN THE DARK--the most ambitious stage musical of recent years--flopped as a film," when it was actually the fourth highest moneymaking film of the year in 1944, and did even better than MEET ME IN ST. LOUIS. And in his review of THE SHINING, Thomson wonders at some length why the Colorado hotel where the film is set is useless in winter: "Why? Because it snows! DID NO ONE EVER TELL THEM ABOUT SKIING?" (It is carefully and explicitly explained in the opening minutes of the film that the hotel is unreachable by guests during most of the winter because of the heavy snows, and cannot function as a resort during that season.) A tough-minded revision would greatly enhance the worth of this flawed compendium.

A landmark motion picture, HARPER came about when producer Elliott Kastner and writer William Goldman decided to adapt one of Ross Macdonald's Lew Archer mysteries in order to create a new kind of Hollywood movie. One of the most popular and best mystery writers of the day, Macdonald's Archer novels had progressed by the 1960s from their very Chandleresque overtones to become very sophisticated studies of psychology and moral complexity; but this wasn't what Goldman and Kastner were after. They turned to adapting the first of the Archer mysteries, THE MOVING TARGET, to re-create the Hollywood detective thriller with a new emphasis on grittiness and machismo: thus the film features its detective (re-named "Lew Harper," for reasons that continue to be debated) moving in a very seedy milieu, involving drugs, illegal aliens, and torture, and uses language that was considered very edgy for its time (including, unfortunately, derogatory terms for gay men and for women that were not common in movies of the time).It's undeniable that HARPER, which was a huge success, was enormously influential and not only helped pave the way the next year for BONNIE AND CLYDE, which of course ushered in the so-called "Hollywood Renaissance" of the late 60s and early 70s. Moreover, its success had a huge influence on detective movies and shows of the coming era, with its particularly vicious thugs, its high-speed auto chase near the end (though the one in Steve McQueen's BULLITT was even more influential), and its hero's dodgy personal living situation (which must have been noticed by the creators of THE ROCKFORD FILES). But despite its popularity and the trends it set, it doesn't age very well, particularly in its attitude towards women. Almost every major female character in this film is extensively disparaged at some point for not being attractive enough, which seems a bit depressing given how much more complex Ross Macdonald's female characters, and the attitude towards them shown by his Lew Archer, had become by this time. There's a whole cavalcade of celebrity actors of the time playing minor roles, from Lauren Bacall, Shelley Winters, Janet Leigh, and Robert Wagner from the world of Hollywood to Julie Harris and Arthur Hill from Broadway. Bacall (whose presence winks back to THE BIG SLEEP) and Wagner fare the best, since they have the most fun with their parts, while Julie Harris makes a particularly unconvincing drug-addicted jazz chickie-baby (with exquisite stage diction). Although this was one of Paul Newman's most popular turns, he does little to convince himself as Harper, who here has annoying predilections for affecting terrible fake accents and for getting beaten up--he must get conked on the back of the head about three different times.

One of the best novels in Ross Macdonald's Lew Archer series, THE ZEBRA-STRIPED HEARSE may have as its only significant flaw its rococo title, which belies its elegance as a mystery novel. Once again his low-key and intensely likable shamus Archer is employed by a wealthy California family and winds up unearthing a series of buried murders; this time his case revolves around an heiress who is being wooed by a handsome artist. When the girl's martinet father hires Archer to uncover the truth about the artist's past, Archer finds that the artist has been operating under the identity of a murdered man--and that his previous wife was herself murdered as well, with the artist as the absconded main suspect. The case Archer builds (traveling to Mazatlan and then lake Tahoe) against the Lothario is so overwhelming that by the time he is apprehended halfway through the narrative its almost a disappointment that Archer finally believes him innocent. But who killed the artist's first wife and the other man? The story of how the victims were involved with the rest of the story begins to piece itself together through Archer's persistent questions...Macdonald loved writing about unhappy rich families and their wayward children; his novels owed much to  Raymond Chandler's THE BIG SLEEP (the glowering paterfamilias here is named Colonel Blackwood, as opposed to Chandler's General Sternwood), but perhaps even more to the dramas of Aeschylus and Sophocles. The rich layering of all the Blackwoods' lives, from father to daughter to mother to stepmother, and of the characters of all the  various people in orbit around them is one of the great pleasures of this novel; another is its fine mystery, which kept me guessing to the end. Despite Macdonald's great love for showing how the past determines the problems of the present, the novel's almost incidental portrait of a slightly menacing group of surfers (who ride around in the symbolic vehicle of the title) seems not only exactly up-to-date for the early 60s when it was published.

Just as the great hard-boiled writers Raymond Chandler and Ross Macdonald have been said to write the same story over and again, Jeph Loeb and Tim Sale, their descendants, recreated their first and highly successful Batman tale THE LONG HALLOWEEN, but made it even better, and found more of a voice for themselves. Again the story involves the early years of Batman and Commissioner Gordon in Gotham City (this story brings us up to the creation of Robin through the murder of Dick Grayson's parents by members of the mob), and again a serial killer strikes on holidays and is heavily involved with the Falcone crime family; but the mystery is more tightly plotted this time, and much more plausible. Tim Sale's artwork is also much stronger here; whereas in THE LONG HALLOWEEN the world of Bruce Wayne and Jim Gordon and organized crime was rendered more realistically, with the world of the encroaching "masks" (the classic Batman rogues gallery) was heavily stylized, here the two seem more blended together, with a stronger sense of expressionism dominating the renditions. The layouts are truly spectacular--this is some of the best Batman art I've ever seen.

This may be the best Batman story ever told; it has certainly been the most influential since the 1930s in terms of setting up a mythos and tone for the entire Batman series. Frank Miller wrote this 1989 four part story in his trademark noir style honed on "Daredevil" and "The Dark Knight Returns," but the series doesn't go in for the kind of baroque excess that Miller began to indulge in more and more since leaving "Daredevil." Undoubtedly it was the influence of the fantastic artist Dave Mazzuchelli (whose own work recalls Miller's earliest work for "Daredevil") that brings a kind of realism to this story. It follows an entire year in Gotham City as its favorite son, Bruce Wayne, returns from years abroad after his parents' murder, and a new police officer, Jim Gordon, is hired by the corrupt police commissioner Gillian Loeb; over the course of the year, Wayne will begin his new identity as the Batman, the vigilante obsessed with cleaning up crime, and set in motion a series of events that will result in the creation of the Catwoman, the kidnapping of Gordon's infant son, and the overthrow of Loeb's administration. The series also features heavily the Falcone crime family (and its boss, "The Roman") that figures so heavily into two of the later great Batman long stories, "The Long Halloween" and "Dark Victory."The emphasis on realism in this story (which Mazzuchelli comments upon and even questions in a smart little coda he draws for this edition) is its strong suit; its narrated alternately by both Gordon and Wayne, and the world they move in seems completely believable, despite the presence of a man dressed up as a bat who fights crime (and a prostitute who dresses up as a cat to steal). The art is some of the best I've ever seen in a Batman book, and certain panels (such as of the young Gordon trapped in traffic during a rainstorm) linger long in the memory. So much of what later happened with Batman in multiple media (including the new "Gotham" series on television) depends heavily on what Miller and Mazzuchelli established here; its almost indispensable if you're interested in the character and his various incarnations.

THE CHILL won Ross Macdonald the second of his Edgar Awards (the first was for THE WYCHERLY WOMAN the year before) and the Silver Dagger Award from the Crime Writers' Association (the next year would see him winning the Gold Dagger for THE FAR SIDE OF THE DOLLAR, which also won him the Edgar for the third time). By any standard this is a very fine Macdonald mystery, which means its one of the finest of crime novels. Although Ross Macdonald is most famous for his clean prose (at this point honed as sharp as it can be) and his psychological insights into his suspects and victims, this novel distinguishes itself by its superlative plotting. Although the solution to the novels multiple murders is very complex and involves many surprises, Macdonald eschews the messier expository models favored by Raymond Chandler (one of his heroes) for a narrative through-line so clean that the reader comes to the denouement feeling full command of the story. What makes this all the more remarkable is that Macdonald saves his big reveal for the final page-and-a-half of the novel--something that's almost impossible for most mystery writers to do convincingly. What's more, his final surprise caught me completely off-guard; the novel is a splendid work of misdirection to the very end.The plot involves some old Macdonald stay-bys, including wayward sons and wealthy families dominating local politics. What's so surprising, though, is how in this novel he plays with his story, so that when the novel starts with one mystery--a saddened husband hires Archer to find why his newlywed wife up and left him--but then moves in an entirely different direction. When the first body is found (of an attractive professor in a college town), we've already moved far beyond where we started. The case also involves two other murders, one from ten years ago and the other from twenty; though seemingly unrelated, the pleasure of the work is in seeing how they are indeed greatly related (and that there is a reason why Archer comes across both of them in his detective work).

Of all the writers among his fin-de-siecle cohort, Richard Marsh has most often been paired with Bram Stoker, mostly because of their competing best sellers from 1897 about foreign supernatural monsters wreaking havoc in England (THE BEETLE and DRACULA). THE JOSS shows Marsh writing in a line that might be more profitably compared to Robert Louis Stevenson or Joseph Conrad, however: its final quarter involves the romantic and disturbing tale of a father "gone native" (as the phrase of the time would have it) in the South Seas. Given that Conrad was not especially popular when this novel was written (1904), the comparison becomes all the more striking in this, the novel's best section. Because unlike THE BEETLE, Marsh's THE JOSS does not peter out toward its conclusion but rather gains narrative strength as it concludes; unfortunately, it must overcome some muddled structural problems near the text's beginning. As with THE BEETLE, THE JOSS is told severally by a series of narrators, a technique Marsh likely borrowed from Willkie Collins, the grand master of contemporary urban terror and horror (or sensation fiction) in Victorian England. But in this work the dissonances from one section to another seem quite jarring: the narrator of the initial telling, Mary(also called Polly), transforms utterly from the put-upon shopgirl of her own narrative to the completely fearless superheroine of her best friend Emily's narrative in the next section; then she disappears almost entirely from the story until the very last pages. Marsh is always much better with mystery and atmosphere than he is with character, but the inability for him to choose among his characters as to who is central seems more jarring here than it did in THE BEETLE (where the ghastly title character held everything together by its sheer malevolence). The descriptions of urban nightmare settings are again nicely done, and Mary/Polly's inherited decrepit house--overrun with both blackbeetles and rats--is memorably creepy.

Actually outselling DRACULA when they both came out in 1897, Richard Marsh's THE BEETLE was much talked about for years after its publication and even turned into a silent film. It's not as sustained as Bram Stoker's most famous novel and drags off a bit towards the end in a complicated railway chase, but sections of it are as frightening as anything Stoker ever wrote. Like DRACULA, Marsh's novel involves an Eastern invader with supernatural powers coming to England to attack a beautiful woman; it also invokes a whole series of tropes typical of the period, including gender confusion, fears of rampant unchecked sexual experimentation, imperialist concerns, and anxieties regarding the explosion of London's urban growth. The novel's central (and only really memorable) character is the titular Beetle, a monster from Egypt that can change its sex, its size, and its species: it comes to London to seek revenge against a politician who abandoned it decades ago in Cairo, and seeks to destroy him through his New Woman fiancÃ©e. The Beetle's presence in the novel is much more terrifying than its actual plans (which are never thoroughly explained); even so, it's quite a satisfyingly terrible monster. The novel's initial quarter, told from the view of a vagrant who sneaks into a London house for shelter in a storm only to find himself completely in the Beetle's mesmeric thrall, is outstanding in its hallucinatory detail and its evocation of sensory horror.Unlike DRACULA, the  THE BEETLE became almost forgotten within a generation. In just the last decade, however, multiple editions of it have appeared, not only because it speaks to much to the scholarship of critics in the fin de siecle (such as Elaine Showalter, Roger Luckhurst, and Sally Ledger) but also because it's such a rattling good read. This thoughtfully annotated edition from Valancourt, printed on beautiful paper and with the novel's original illustrations, may well be the best out there.

Over the course of a weekend, a rationalist sociology professor (Peter Wyngarde) discovers his wife (Janet Blair) has been practicing black magic to advance his career and protect him from bad juju in his department. After he forces her to burn all of her conjuring fetishes and charms, he returns to school on Monday to find his life has fallen to pieces. The source of this little-known British horror film was Fritz Lieber's novel CONJURE WIFE, a favorite of the screenwriters Richard Matheson and Charles Beaumont, about faculty wives practicing the dark arts to advance their husbands' careers. The best witch stories are often explorations into the darker forms of misogyny, and the hypercompetitive world of department politics (with suspicions faculty members on the rise were being helped illicitly by their wives) makes an interesting avenue for such a tale. Some of the film's best parts are at the beginning, when we begin to get a nasty taste of the department backstabbing at a bridge party; afterwards, the hostess's frantic search for what one of her guests may have left behind is one of the finest sequences in the film. It inspires the director, Sidney Hayers, into some of his most inventive camerawork (we see from the undersides of tables and sofas as Blair's fingers go exploring), that he also uses for some of the film's later showpieces, including Wyndgarde's frantic race in his car against a bus his wife is on, and the magical attack of a giant eagle near the film's end (which inspired its original title, NIGHT OF THE EAGLE).Unfortunately, Hayers is so focused on ratcheting up the film's intensity that he almost never gives the actors time to breathe, or even provide the exposition that could make more sense of what Blair and Wyngrade face together: some of the evil magic used against them seems to involve only hypnosis, and other times curses, and other times the actual transmutation of reality--but we never find out the rules to any of this. (This is the rare horror film where too much is left unexplained.) Wyngrade and Blair--both unusual choices for their roles--are also pushed a bit too hard; Wyngarde's magnetism allows him to fare better, but Blair seems too histrionic and one-note, as is Margaret Johnston as another faculty wife and also a colleague of Wyngarde's. The film isn't quite in the league of NIGHT OF THE DEMON, but compared to most other British horror films of its era, it's really worth watching.

Many British cultural critics consider Terence Davies likely their greatest living director, and much of that estimation rests on this, his loveliest film. An excursion into memory, THE LONG DAY CLOSES may evoke Fellini (in its visions of the past rendered larger than life, as in the famous ship sequence in AMARCORD) and Dennis Potter (in its use of popular music not just to romanticize the past but to show its inevitable dissonances with its realities) while all the time seeming very much its own special and distinct creation. The tableaux Davies evokes--from its opening shot of a poor Liverpool residential street drenched in a downpour, to its great closing shot of a mottled evening sky--almost stop the heart with their beauty. The story is a patchwork of memories of the childhood of Davies himself, here called "Bud": the youngest by far of four children, the film documents a year of his life (at age eleven) that roughly covers 1955 to 1956. No great dramatic incidents occur in the story: no one take seriously ill, or runs away, or gets married, or even fights. The film is in an assemblage of "spots of memory" wherein Bud usually stays at the margins (he is usually seen poised on a staircase or in a window), watching or listening to his family and the people around him. Although adored by his mother and elder siblings he is always an outsider; newly aware of his budding attraction to men, he can't join in in his brothers' attractions to the opposite sex (their fiancees are in the house nearly as much as the children themselves), and stays forever aloof. Family socializing is a wondrous time for Bud, although he is almost always the only youngster included. The only time he sees his age peers are at school, which is presented as a noisy painful place governed by adults who despise children. His great sources of solace are in the Catholic church, where he is a devout practitioner of his mother's Catholic faith, in the local movie palaces (of which he is an equally devout follower), and the radio: Davies uses the popular music of the time--Nat King Cole and Doris Day--not simply to enhance the beauty of Bud's surroundings but also to create a thread of mass culture to unite the ages and genders of Bud's community.The film could be a little much, especially in its treatment of Bud's loneliness: there are times when he veers dangerously close to Matt Lucas's "the only gay boy in the village" in his constant self-pity and sorrow. But the highly personal and subjective nature of the film renders all this allowable. Davies is so sure in his decisions and his tone that his romanticization of the past is ultimately proudly affirmed; what is more, he also even deftly deconstructs it as the film proceeds. Criterion's reissue of this film (with great sound and image restoration, and lovely extras) could not be more welcome.

The great British filmmaker of memory and loss Terence Davies made his first full documentary here with this 2008 collage film of "found footage" from the 1940s, 50s, 60s and 70s about his beloved home city of Liverpool. The footage and its editing are absolutely extraordinary: Davies (as in his great feature films DISTANT VOICES, STILL LIVES and THE LONG DAY CLOSES) is able to re-create a mid-century Liverpool that's both much more beautiful than you could have dreamed, and much more sordid than you could have feared. Anchored visually in its Edwardian heyday by the Great Liver Building (which also anchors the actual city docksides), the film documents not only the decay of the enormous darkened buildings of the Victorian and early 20th centuries, but also documents, with due alarm, the rise of horrible Council Estate tall buildings during the post-War period. The chosen footage also depicts (with an uncanny eye for visual beauty)  the beauty of the docks themselves, the trains, the beautiful electric signs of the cinemas, and the very human and lively city inhabitants, from children at play to adults retaining their dignity in decaying surroundings.For the eye, the film is something of a feast; but for the ear, the film just doesn't work. To accompany his matchless visual sense, Terence Davies also has quite an aural distinction for selecting lovely and evocative pieces of music (from Liszt to Peggy Lee) to accompany them; but he has something fo a tin ear for his own voice. His first mistake was to provide the film's narration in his hyperdramatic sonorous tones; his second mistake was to select a salad of super-familiar quotations (from Psalms to TS Eliot to Christopher Marlowe) that risk rendering his striking and singular images banal. Finally, he "comments" as he goes, making quite clear his crankiness towards the extravagance of the royal family, the musical unsophistication of rock music, his cynicism towards the Catholic church he so loved in his youth, and other fairly predictable and uninteresting biases and opinions. Instead of enhancing his visual feast, Davies's narration detracts from it.

The biographical subject of THE ORIENTALIST is an early twentieth-century Azerbaijani novelist and biographer named Lev Nussimbaum, who also published under the names of Essad Bey and (this book argues) Kurban Said, and who was almost forgotten in the West. because I was unfamiliar with him, I kept resisting reading this book until so many friends recommended it to me I had try it, and then I found it very difficult to put down. In Nussimbaum, Tom Reiss has found a subject on whom he can hang a grand tale of adventure, intrigue, and glamor in the war-torn worlds of Europe and central Asia from the beginning of the century until near the start of the second World War; its worlds reminded me of nothing so much as that of Sidney Reilly, the famous secret agent the United Kingdom employed in this same time frame to spy on the Germans and Russians and who was a major source for Ian Fleming's James Bond character. (I kept hearing the Shostakovich theme song to the Sam Neill series REILLY, ACE OF SPIES as I read this.) Nussimbaum started out in Baku as the son of a Jewish oil millionaire, then fled with his family during the Russian revolutionary period to Kyzyl-Su, Constantinople, Paris and Berlin, where they finally all finally settled with the enormous White Russian community headquartered there (along with the Nabokovs). Nussimbaum changed his identity to that of the Muslim-born fez-wearing Essad Bey to heighten his own glamor, began publishing bestsellers (including biographies of Stalin and Czar Nicholas II), married an heiress and became an international socialite before succumbing at a very young age to gangrene of the extremities.Reiss is less interested in Nussimbaum's writing than he is in his exciting experiences, which involved apparently one life-threatening escapade after another. Most of these events come from Nussimbaum's own autobiographical writings, the truth claims of which Reiss rightly questions frequently even though he seems to accept many of them despite their romantic nature. It;'s hard to know how rightly to take Reiss's judgment as to which stories are true and which are not since Reiss was here for the first time writing a biography of a then-dead subject. The best way to take this book is really on its own terms, and if you stop trying to evaluate the likelihood of the stories and just give into it as a series of rattling good tales it's an enormous amount of fun for its first half. (There's also lots of fascinating information about some of the less-known historical events of the period with which Nussimbaum was involved.) The narrative of the book involves Reiss's own tricky biographical enquiries into Nussimbaum's life and times, much along the lines of something like AJA Symons's THE QUEST FOR CORVO: Reiss does a fine job with this in the book's first half, but by the end of the book he seems to tripped up making his claims that Nussimbaum was the author of ALI AND NINO (which many other scholars have disputed) that it becomes hard to untangle the through-line of the narrative. (Reiss clearly expects readers of this biography to have read it in its original form as a long article in THE NEW YORKER -- a bizarre and unhelpful expectation.) Until the recounting of Nussimbaum's divorce (at which point the narrative falls apart), the biography is not only terrific but something I'd recommend to go out of their way to read.

Fragile, waiflike, and tentative, Mia Farrow was absolutely perfectly cast in ROSEMARY'S BABY, and spent much of the next ten years (until she met Woody Allen, who gave her more varied parts) playing the prey for Satanists, murderers, witches, and ghosts. In one of the more beautifully done of these victim stints, she plays Sarah, a woman who comes to live with her aunt and uncle and their daughter after she is blinded in a horse accident. Early in the this film, she returns from a day of riding to their beautifully appointed mansion in the autumnal English countryside: the utter silence in the house and the low camera angles suggest something is not right. The director, Richard Fleischer, takes him time as we watch Sarah navigate through the house's many halls and rooms, making coffee for herself in the kitchen; we see broken glass  (which she narrowly avoids stepping on, through pure luck) on the floors, but we still don't know what's wrong until she's in bed, and we see her beautiful cousin's corpse sprawled out unnaturally in the bed next to her. All the family have been slaughtered.This scene is so scary and carefully done that almost nothing could compare to it... and for  long time, nothing in the film does. Fleischer films everything beautifully, though, and scarily shows the killer (who wears star-embossed cowboy boots) only at a low level, so you don't find out who he is until the end of the film. Unlike WAIT UNTIL DARK (its clear direct inspiration), the film does not act to empower its blind heroine so much as to use her handicap as an opportunity by which she might be subjected to all sorts of nasty spills and mishaps: of course eventually she does step on that broken glass in the kitchen, and also runs through the wrong door leading into the cellar, rides a horse into a low-hanging branch, tumbles down a steep muddy hillside... it all gets to be a bit much. (The biggest suspense in this long middle section is actually whether the terrified Farrow will stumble in her panic into the many priceless vases and fragile objets d'art her relatives have somewhat tactlessly left on the side tables in all their long hallways.)
