The film does have a great final sequence, though, involving Farrow washing off in a bathroom.

John Williams's 1965 novel about a Missouri professor's life and career has been rediscovered in the last several years: it's become NYRB Classics' bestseller, it's attracted the attention of movie stars, and it's become some thing of a cult novel in Europe. It's pleasing to see that such a fine little forgotten book should enjoy such a fine second life, but it is somewhat bewildering, given what a dark tale it is. it's basically a story of one man's persecution through the years by the goddess Nemesis, who takes many forms: the foolish wife the young academic marries, who then turns against him; the department chair, who tries purposefully to humiliate him; the town gossip, which maliciously attacks him when he has some of the few happy months of his life in an affair with a young instructor; and finally cancer, which brings him to his grave. Watching William Stoner meet these persecutions with both stoicism and dignity is rather remarkable, and gives the novel its pleasures. In many ways it owes much to a tradition of realist literature coming straight out of Flaubert, although Emma Bovary meets life's obstacles in the reverse of the way Stoner does (and with none of his grace). STONER is a grim little book, but it well deserves its moment in the sun.

Though marketed as a standard horror film, the fact that this piece attracted actors with as much prestige as Imelda Staunton, Dominic West, and Rebecca Hall should be a clue that THE AWAKENING is not an ordinary ghost film, but something very special and moving. Set in 1921, the story involves a famous ghost-debunker (Hall) who is brought to a former country estate re-purposed as a boy's school to find how a little asthmatic student was frightened to death. The film really isn't very frightening, which is its worst flaw but perhaps still central to its aesthetic: it's structured less as a horror work and more as a mood and a character piece. The house (a combination of several different Scottish houses filmed from different angles) is itself a major character, and is gorgeously photographed. Although she plays a character who could not have existed in 1921 as she is depicted (the gender roles of the era are flouted too much here), Rebecca Hall brings a dose of good common sense and humor to her part; Dominic West is perfectly cast as her romantic interest, a Latin teacher recovering from wounds from the Great War. The film works best as a mystery story, one which doesn't cheat on its outcome.

It's very hard to keep a great television series going beyond four or five seasons: even such brilliant shows as MARY TYLER MOORE and THE SOPRANOS had trouble keeping their quality at a consistent level. Alas, this is also true for MAD MEN, one of the most beautifully accomplished series of the last ten years. In this, its sixth season, nothing seems as new or as interesting anymore for the writers, as story tricks that seemed tremendously inventive in seasons past (hallucinatory drug use, the central ad agency re-branding itself and going through a major personnel shift, etc.) recur here in mostly tired ways, and Don Draper (the series' antihero) seems caught in a pattern of marital infidelities we've of course seen before quite a bit. All this would seem forgivable if so many characters weren't by this point so sour and unpleasant. Certainly the contempt that ad men have for their clients' limitations and timidities has been a major theme in the series, but Don and Peggy by this point (initially at different agencies) seem so consistently condescending and irritable that it's hard to root for their campaigns very much or care whether they can score new clients. There are some interesting ideas this season, but not many. Despite the wonderful work of newcomer to the show Linda Cardellini as Don's new neighbor and mistress, this has been by far the series' weakest season.The DVD set of the sixth season is equally disappointing: there is not a single episode commentary, which makes buying the set mostly pointless because most episodes can be seen anyway on cable on-demand services anyway. Had I know this I would not have bought the set: getting to hear the actors' and especially the writers' ideas behind the series has been one of the most entertaining part of the DVD sets for this show previously. Omitting series creator's Matt Weiner's insightful commentaries, in particular, is something I do not understand.

HIGHLAND FLING is for the most part so accomplished that it's hard to believe it was Nancy Mitford's first novel: it shows already firmly  in place her tremendous gift with witty dialogue and her lifelong love of juxtaposing the differing mindsets of the upper classes. Although it shows some structural weakness (or naivete) in that it takes until the fifth chapter for Mitford to introduce her main character Jane Dacre, once Jane enters the picture and the action moves from London to Scotland it never stops being funny.The set-up involves two dizzy and constantly hard-up London socialities, Walter and Sally Monteath, being asked by Sally's titled aunt to care for her Scottish castle and their seasonal shooting guests where she and her husband the earl are out of the country. To make their stay (which will save them quite a bit of money) more palatable, Sally and Walter invite a few of their friends among the Bright Young Things, Jane and the surrealist painter Albert Gates, come with them. The humor depends on first glance on the generational differences between the elder shooting guests, Establishment monsters of conservativism addicted to hunting and fishing, and the Monteaths' friends, who are their mostly for gossip and aesthetic reasons (Albert, who has taken to calling himself Albert Memorial Gates, is so avant-garde that he has gone to the other extreme and become a devotee of Victoriana, of which the castle abounds but which was very much out-of-date among the Establishment by the time the novel was written). Much of the novel's humor depends on the clash between the aesthetics of the elder and younger generations, and the lengthy description of the "safe" bourgeois tastes of Lady Brenda Chadlington, the one figure who most floats between the two groups, won't be as funny unless you are firmly entrenched in the visual style of the period. HIGHLAND FLING goes beyond this, however, and like most of Mitford's novels engages with the political as well as the aesthetic: Albert's explicit denunciation of the Edwardian attitudes of the most aggressive of the elders, General Murgatroyd, that to the First World War makes this novel more than simply delicious froth.

Andrew Jarecki's 2010 crime film is "ripped from the headlines," as they say: although the names are changed, the parallels of this film's story to the mysteries surrounding New York real-estate heir Robert Durst are of course inescapable and intended. In 1982, Durst's wife, a medical student at Albert Einstein, disappeared and was never found again; the case was re-opened around the turn of the millenium, after which a young woman working on a book based on Kathleen Durst's disappearance was executed gangland style (the killer was never found), and Robert Durst, who hid from the public spotlight by moving to Galveston and dressing as a woman, was arrested for killing his neighbor and disposing of the body with a saw. (The killing was found by a jury to be in self-defense, although Durst was found guilty of improperly disposing of a body.) There's so much that was so strange in this heavily sensationalized story (Robert Durst also as a child witnessed  his mother commit suicide by throwing herself from the roof of their family mansion) that it might seem a natural for a great film, combining murder, mystery, money, and cross-dressing.To his credit, Andrew Jarecki (best known for his documentary CAPTURING THE FRIEDMANS) does recognize that his story is interesting mostly as an indictment of capitalism, and how great wealth makes even in its beneficiaries miserable. But we've seen this before in all kinds of American films based on true events, from CITIZEN KANE to REVERSAL OF FORTUNE, and this film doesn't have any of the great redemptive black humor of those other films. Nor does it have much of an air of tragedy about it, either: it just sort of sits there, unformed. It's worth watching only for the two performances at its center: although Ryan Gosling and Kirsten Dunst both start out doing exactly what we've seen them do multiple times--Gosling being twitchy and wounded, and Dunst being a golden sunshine girl--, as the film continues they do very new things. Dunst is phenomenal in several wordless shots where we see her misery sink in upon her, and as Gosling's character becomes more and more unhinged, he takes on a more hooded aspect to his character, making his motives and decisions much more mysterious.

Every Jane Campion film or television project is worth seeing because of her intelligence, her political commitments, and her remarkable visuals; every one of them also has major flaws compounded by Campion's heavy-handedness with her messages. This recent miniseries produced, co-written, and co-directed by Campion is no exception to either rule: set in her native New Zealand, it involves a stunningly dramatic and mysterious setting, a mystery centered upon an atrocity committed to a beautiful girl, a determined detective trying to root out the truth, and a community around the victim that is involved in far more horrors than the detective ever dreamed. The parallels to the Danish TV show FORBRYDELSEN (THE KILLING) and to TWIN PEAKS (which also inspired the Danish series) are inescapable, especially given in how both those earlier shows matters of gender and violence stood front and center. Campion, of course, is one of the most intriguing feminist film directors in the world, are her analysis of violence committed against women is even more front and center than in its predecessors. In this miniseries, a 12 year-old girl, Tui (Jacqueline Joe), is found trying to walk into a great lake on New Zealand's South Island, and when she is rescued, it is discovered she is pregnant, but she refuses to name the father to a detective (Elisabeth Moss); soon after, she disappears entirely. As the detective becomes obsessed with finding this young girl, she runs up against an odd mixture of the lake's inhabitants: the girl's father (Peter Mullan), a violent and self-pitying local criminal patriarch; his son, the detective's former boyfriend, who comes to care for her; and an odd New Age community of women led by an androgynous, taciturn guru (Holly Hunter).Campion's trademark gorgeous visuals and dreamy pacing kept me through the entire miniseries, and its really something to see, with the alien landscape of New Zealand's stark Lake Wakitupu and its nearby dramatic neighbor Mount Earnshaw. Some of the most remarkable shots are of helicopters, showing the landscape dwarfing the insectlike people crawling on it, or reducing the colorful stacked railroad cars of the New Age community to the scale of mere children's blocks. Whether the miniseries works as an actual narrative, however, is another matter. The mystery itself isn't very interesting and is fairly guessable, as is the big twist in the final episodes; there's also too much revenge fantasy, with nearly every rapist (the miniseries is fairly crawling with them) implausibly shot or maimed by story's end. Of the major actors, Moss and Mullan do the best work. As the detective Robin, Moss is very different here from anything we've seen her do before, and her quiet ability to assume command is nicely done. Mullan is ideally cast as a terrifyingly mercurial man who wallows in self-pit and who can be surprisingly tender before erupting into cruelty: one of the best (and scariest) bits in the show is a long sequence involving Mullan's tryst with one of the women (Robyn Malcolm, in a warm and fine turn) from the compound. Although Holly Hunter does excellent work as the guru GJ, and can strikingly evoke her character's air of electric quietude, she's burdened a bit by her own movie star aura (a less well-known actress would probably have suited the part more effectively). Jacqueline Joe has an unearthly beauty as Tui, but perhaps no child actor could have pulled the part off convincingly: the mirror of GJ at a different age (willowy, prophetic, and surprisingly tough), Tui has so much symbolic weight freighted onto her by Robin and the film alike that she struggles under the burden of it.

Bill Blakemore's beautifully crafted study of how people can become obsessed with their own interpretations centers on one of the most analyzed and re-watched movies of the 1980s, Stanley Kubrick's THE SHINING. In this documentary, multiple analysts talk you through their own readings of Kubrick's film, showing you how often the film refutes logical expectations and brings up puzzles worthy of interpretation: the hotel manager's office in the Kubrick film seems to be in the exact center of the hotel's main floor, for example, but it impossibly has a window looking out to the outdoors; the little boy at the center of the film takes three famous rides around the hotel on his Big Wheel where the first of the rides makes perfect sense but the latter two do not; an odd character is introduced near the beginning and stands around in several scenes but says nothing, and his purpose in the film is never overtly explained.Like all of Kubrick's films, THE SHINING is an interpretive labyrinth literalized in this film by the hedge maze outside the hotel (again, in an impossible location) and the maze-like patterns of the hotel carpets; like the three main characters in the film, the interpreters try as best as they can to get outside of the labyrinth but repeatedly find their ways blocked. Three major readings of the film emerge, but although all the interpreters repeatedly point out striking or unusual things to us, none of these three major readings (that the film is Kubrick's comment on the Holocaust; that it's about atrocities committed by the US government against Native Americans; that it's about the faking of the moon landings) is ultimately convincing. The film cleverly edits juxtapositions of the actual Kubrick film and other movies (from FAUST to CAPRICORN ONE) to make its points; it's a gorgeous overall piece of editing razzledazzle.

Vintage has been reissuing all of Nancy Mitford's hilarious novels, and two of the shorter ones, CHRISTMAS PUDDING and PIGEON PIE, have been paired in one binding most likely due to the fact that they're her shortest novels. They're both quite funny and about the kind of social milieu Mitford always deals in--the pampered upper classes--, although in tone they're fairly dissimilar, and could both be paired more aptly with two other longer novels that preceded each of them. CHRISTMAS PUDDING shares with its immediate predecessor HIGHLAND FLING several characters and a similar milieu (a country estate where a dissimilar group of aristocrats and their hangers-on has assembled), while PIGEON PIE is much more akin to the novel that came between it and CHRISTMAS PUDDING, WIGS ON THE GREEN, in its political theme and more slapstick Wodehousean humor.Each of the books is worth reading if you like Mitford in the first place, and PIGEON PIE is especially interesting for its treatment of the "Phony War" of 1939-1940 and its treatment of espionage, politics, and even murder. For the casual reader, however, CHRISTMAS PUDDING will probably be the more palatable: it's funnier than its companion in the volume (Mitford was much funnier when dealing with dialogue rather than with antic behavior), and treats marriage in a very different way than Jane Austen or Trollope did, and it has fewer period cultural references that might escape an audience not thoroughly versed in the details of the early war years. Mitford is so funny that it's a treat both books have been reissued, although these are not a patch on her two fictional masterpieces THE PURSUIT OF LOVE and LOVE IN A COLD CLIMATE.

In the four years between Will Hays' writing of the Motion Picture Production Code in 1930 and the actual enforcing of it, the major studios instead tried willfully to flout it as much as possible, producing some of the most interesting and exciting films of the Studio Era. This 1934 Warner Brothers film was one of the very last to slip in before the enforcement of the Hays Code, and was actually banned two months after its release by the Catholic League of Decency--and you'll know why when you see it.Based on a stage play by Leon Abrams and George Abbott that echoes in its mood and setting THE PETRIFIED FOREST, the film does little to move its actors away from their stagebound origins in and before a Mojave Desert rest-stop; fortunately, the director, Mervyn LeRoy, works against this by providing multiple pan shots across the desert, establishing the loneliness and eeriness of the setting. The rest-stop is run by two sisters, played by two of the finest actresses of the time, the emotive and huge-eyed Ann Dvorak, and the intensely likeable Aline MacMahon, for whom the studio treated the film as a big star-making vehicle. In those days, some of the most beloved stars in Hollywood (such as Wallace Beery and Marie Dressler) were of unusual ages or builds, so its not that surprising Warners' should have given this plum to MacMahon (who resembles Fanny Brice), though she rarely again got the kind of role she deserved. Here she's escaped from a bad relationship in Tulsa to raise her much younger sister (Dvorak) and act as the rest-stop's mechanic: the film involves the chance return of her old lover, Preston Foster, who hides from her the fact he's a murderous bank robber on the lam. All kinds of fine character actors turn up at the stop, too: Jane Darwell and Edgar Kennedy as a couple beaten by the heat; Muriel Evans as one of a pair of hitchhiking "tomatoes" who have their thighs pinched in the front seat by their professorial Good Samaritan; and Glenda Farrell and Ruth Donnelly as a pair of bickering friends who have been newly Reno-vated--and whose suitcases full of jewelry tempt the larcenous Foster and his partner (Lyle Talbot). Despite the staginess of the action, the film is mostly excellent thanks to MacMahon, who establishes real rapport with Dvorak and brings a true sense of complexity to her character.

Alan Moore is one of the three or four most important figures in the history of graphic novels, and FROM HELL is clearly his masterpiece, although it is also his most unsettling and upsetting work. The text is a recreation of the Whitechapel murders of 1888 attributed to Jack the Ripper, mostly from the point of view of the person Moore (and a few others before him--not very persuasively in any of the cases) proposes to be the Ripper, Sir William Gull, the personal physician to many members of the British Royal Family. The artwork by Eddie Campbell is absolutely perfect for the work--its sketchy and jumpy draftsmanship beautifully evokes the repressive paranoia Moore wishes to create, and Campbell's use of blackness is practically nonpareil. The book seems in the end to be more Moore's than Campbell's, however, given the former's extensive footnotes at the end of the text: they not only act to establish a kind of authority (though a somewhat questionable one, because most of the works in Moore's extensive bibliography are by amateur Ripperologists) but also make his seem like the final word on the entire matter.It's a difficult text in many ways, not simply because of its lengths and because its lettering is not always easy to decipher. Like many encyclopedic narratives (by Melville, Dickens, Joyce, and most analogously Bolano), it has its long boring stretches, where the obsession with detail overwhelms the sense of narrative drive. Its ethical implications are genuinely disturbing: you're not only asked to follow the Ripper as the text's antihero and view his horrible murders as the narrative highpoints, but you're also asked to see Queen Victoria (!!!) as the "prime instigator" (Moore's own phrase) of the entire murderous conspiracy, as if the misogyny of the Ripper's murders were not enough. And the damage wreaked upon actual historical events and real people's lives (it is almost impossible the actual Sir William Gull could have been the Ripper) is fairly extensive.What saves all this from ruining the work is Moore's awareness of all of these matters. In the superb coda to the text, "Dance of the Gull-Catchers," Moore mocks his own enterprise and shows how aware he is that the Ripper will never and can never be actually identified. He also shows his full awareness of the foolishness of playing with history to create his own narrative. And the book's most notorious section--the full serial number devoted to the Ripper's last and most horrific crime, the murder and then lengthy mutilation of Mary Kelly--is here presented in such detail and so graphically that we are dared to turn away, as if to suggest that not only are the writer and illustrator implicated in the Ripper's misogyny by re-presenting them to us but so are all readers, and indeed anyone interested in the most savage violence committed against women. Moore does not resolve these problems by signalling his awareness of hem but rather turns them out to us: why are so many people still so interested in these crimes? There's no denying how important and substantial this work is... or how troubling it also is.

At the time it was produced "Rome" was the most expensive TV series ever mounted, and by the second season it was clear it just couldn't continue for a third. Because the very strong first season has concerned itself with the dictatorship of Julius Caesar, from his victory in Gaul to his assassination in the Senate, it made sense to end the second series with the defeat of Caesar's assassins, Brutus and Cassius, and then the fall of his lover Cleopatra and his protege Mark Anthony. But the first season covered just five years, whereas the second comprehends twelve, and there's an awful lot to shoehorn into this given that the series is not just concerned with members of the imperial elite (i.e. Caesar's and brutus's family, Cicero, Antony, and Cleopatra), but also the fortunes of two of Caesar's former soldiers, the grimly pious Lucius Vorenus (Kevin McKidd) and the merry and bloodthirsty Titus Pullo (Ray Stevenson). This worked very well in the first season, since we got quite a bot of fascinating detail about Vorenus's family life and both men's exploits in the army. Unfortunately, since Vorenus's wife Niobe died last season, the second season involves her widower going berserk and becoming a bloody gangmaster on the Aventine, which does keep the violence quotient up but which doesn't tell us much interesting about Roman daily life (and which also made the series much too tediously akin to other roughly contemporaneous HBO dramas such as DEADWOOD and THE SOPRANOS).As for its portrayal of the elites, the second season starts very strongly in the immediate aftermath of the assassination conspiracy, with a panicked Atia (Polly Walker) and Antony (james Purefoy) trying to get out of town and stymied by the determination of Caesar's widow Calpurnia (Haydn Gwynne, excellent again in her smallish role) to do everything correctly and not be rushed. Though the major rivalry from last season between Atia and Brutus's mother Servilia (the superb Lindsay Duncan), and a new one between Antony and Octavian, also start well, once Brutus is defeated at Philippi everything in both cases runs out of steam: the Atia/Servilia rivalry has a disappointing go-nowhere ending that is not even true to history (well acted, however, by both women), and when Octavian comes back from Philippi played by Simon Woods rather than Max Pirkis something seems to be lost, especially when he marries Livia (who is portrayed here as a rich twit). The final episodes are especially disappointing because the entire romance between Antony and Cleopatra (Lynsey Marshal, not charismatic enough) is so rushed that the two seem fatally unsympathetic: you get tired of the debauchery and want Charmian to bring in that asp. The general sense of rush also means that major historical players in these events get excised from history altogether, including both Lucius and Gnaius Ahenobarbus, Octavian's first and second wives Clodia Pulcra and Scribonia, and Livia's husband Tiberius Claudius Nero. As before, the series is stunning to look at, with the visual climax, the Battle of Philippi, as spectacular as Caesar's triumph over Vercongetorix was the season before.

Peter Ackroyd has written many glorious and erudite works in his long career, but this is one of his most disappointing. Why this book could not have been a section within his long "biography" of the city of London (published several years ago) is not clear: its short and could have been even briefer given how much padding is in the writing. All kinds of fascinating facts about the networks of tunnels, ruins, and sewers under London are loosely strewn together here, joined by random quotations that often have nothing to do with London, or by what, I am sorry to say, is really just blather. "The idea of secret passages, of mysterious entrances and exits, of retreat and concealment, possesses an incurable charm," writes Ackroyd in one such instance, "Yet if we are not found in the game of hide-and-seek, what then? What if we are left alone in the darkness, our companions gone into the light?" (What then, indeed!) It's hard to reconcile such a drippy passage with the writer who crafted his magisterial Dickens and Blake biographies, or his beautiful early novels (like HAWKSMOOR). Peter Ackroyd has become a profitable cottage industry in his later years, where once he was a careful writer and scholar. It's been a disappointing change for what seemed in previous decades such a tremendous career.

Eleanor Catton won the Man Booker Prize with this novel in 2013, and in the process won all sorts of superlatives. Catton is the youngest novelist ever to win this prestige award, and THE LUMINARIES is the longest novel ever to take the prize. It may also well be the most enjoyably readable Booker prize winner since A. S. Byatt's POSSESSION in 1990, which (not coincidentally) was also in part a Victorian historical fiction and was also written in densely lush prose. Catton's novel echoes the sensation fictions of the decade in which it is set, the 1860s, but the scene here is New Zealand: in a boomtown near the famous gold fields, a large assortment of characters (including two Chinese men and one Maori) attempt to piece together the events that have led to a disappearance and to a death. Since sensation novels were predecessors of detective fiction, the reader must also figure out the determining narrative that involves gold smuggling, murder, prostitution, mutilation, opium addiction, and a very dramatic seance. Catton's larger point (revealed almost wholly in the novel's final fifty pages) is that mysteries and fates are often predetermined by parties outside our ken, as her complex plottings both narratological and astrological underline. Whether or not these tricks are ultimately mostly a lot of fuss and bother for diminished intellectual return, THE LUMINARIES is still a great deal of fun, with rich prose, fine characters, and an enjoyably complex plot.

Of all the different options there are for foil, the heavy duty is my favourite. It is sturdy, and actually lets you cook food in various ways. Great on the baking pan to prevent it from sticking. Perfect for lining the freezer, so that it's easy to remove when there are spills. For the cost, it's worth the extra couple of bucks to get the foil that's actually strong enough to do what you want it to do.

The mop head is the softest thing you've ever touched. I almost didn't want to clean. Almost.THE GOOD- Two separate chambers means that when you are cleaning up a wet spill, you can dunk the mop into the spinny chamber, let it loose, and rinse it off before giving it another spin. Great!- It's super duper soft, so you don't have to use it just for your floors. This would be great for those people who like their cars to be hand washed, but don't want to grab a ladder to reach the hard-to-reach spots. If you have delicate or finicky floors, this mop is your jam.- The mop spinning action is to pump the handle up and down. It takes a minute to learn to use, but once you have it, you're golden.THE BADAnd this is why I'm docking a star. No matter how good the design of the buckets, the overall beauty of the product, or the softness of the head--if the mop doesn't absorb water, we're going to have problems. There are times when I'm clumsy, and spill water on the floor. Rather than wasting a paper towel, I'll reach for a dry mop to sop up the spill.I don't expect the mop to get the floor bone dry. Quite the contrary. I just want the large majority of the water to be gone. Whether the mop was dry, or spun dry and merely a little damp, the water just doesn't come up as fast as other mops I've used in the past. Heck, I've taken to keeping an old cotton T-shirt around for this sort of thing, and that works pretty great!Were it not for the less than optimal absorbency, this would get the full 5 stars, because it really is a pleasure to use.

Here's the thing. The sound quality is superior to the earbuds that came with my iPhone. But then, that's like saying that an activity is more fun than watching paint dry. It's true, but it doesn't tell you very much, because so many MANY headphones are superior to the stock iPhone earbuds. I haven't owned terribly expensive headphones in the past, so I couldn't tell you whether or not these compare.I have owned a lot of middle-of-the-road headphones (between $30 - $75 a pair), and the sound quality on these is comparable to those for sure. Phone calls sound good, and the other party says they can hear me well. I like the pause and volume buttons on the remote control thing. Audio that sounds SSSSSSSOOOOO SSSSSSSIBILIANT and pierces my eardrums with the iPhone earbuds will turn into just sssssssslightly tinny on these. I'm emphasising the s because they sound ear-splitting with anything less than good headphones.If you're using these for anything except running, they're an utter waste. Why? The design of the wire that comes down one side makes it awkward for it to use when sitting down at a table (for example). The particular way that the band wraps around the back of your head makes it impossible to lie down with it. The reason I mention all this is because if I am spending this much on a pair of headphones, I'll want more than to be able to say that I can use them for one purpose alone: workouts.For comfort, these are terrible. In any configuration I put them on, they don't feel comfortable in my ears. After a fairly short amount of time, they grow painful to wear. I managed the first day to wear them for about an hour, with no problems. I'm not working out for an hour, but I wanted to wear one pair of headphones for the commute and for the session. After about an hour, my ears started to hurt from how hard the headphones were pressing against them. THAT SAID, they did not budge or fall off. That was probably because they had my head in a vice-like grip, but there you go.These aren't /bad/ headphones, but for what they cost, I'm not sure that it's a great purchase.

Great water bottle overall. It's got a straw in, so that you don't have to tilt it upwards to drink. It fits perfectly into the bottle holder compartment of my backpack. The carabiner on the lid makes it possible to clip onto a bag strap if needed. It looks pretty nice too. It also sits comfortably in my hand. There is a vent hole up on the top so that when you're drinking from the straw, pressure won't build up in the bottle. Unfortunately, it's not as effective as it could be, which means that after the first sip or so, it becomes more difficult to drink from. Otherwise, barring that minor issue, it's a perfect bottle.

I don't like to buy perfumes, because I find their scent to have things that I don't want in there. Most men's perfumes and colognes have this overwhelming musky undertone, which I hate. I find it harsh and unpleasant. And don't even get me started on Axe. Ew. I like to use essential oils to change up my scent (when I feel like wearing a scent at all, which is not a daily thing). So far, my favourites have been sandalwood and rose. A tiny bit behind the ears, and a tiny bit on my throat, and I'm good. I don't want the scent to be strong enough that you can smell it on me when I come near you. I want you to discover it if you come really close, and like whisper in my ear or something.What does all that amount to? I want the essential oil to have a strong scent, but it needs to smell like it's supposed to smell. Those ones with other things in the essential oil tend to turn me off, because the thing it should smell like only lasts a short time. Then the "other" smells take over and you're left with a scent you didn't sign up for. I also want the scent to be strong enough to last through the day. Colognes tend to fade with time, so I don't really bother using them that often.The scent should be strong, so that I can use the smallest amount possible. Everything else that I smell like should smell like me. It should enhance what I smell like normally, not mask it.That's the reason that this oil has my full 5 stars. It hits all my requirements quite nicely: it's strong, it's not overpowering, it smells like itself, and it lasts for a full day without having to reapply. A tiny bit goes a long way.

The colour is bright and vibrant. I have yet to bother with throwing it in the washing machine, because they don't seem to get that dirty that quickly. Why? They're not terribly absorbent. They'll clean off your mouth from BBQ sauce or something, but they're not going to do that well with mopping up big spills or something. A quick rinse under tap water, and they're clean. Then just hang them on the oven door or something and they dry pretty quickly. (It'll drip dry.) Rather nice feature to have.You /can/ put it in the dryer, but at low. I don't know about you, but I don't have a whole lot of clothes that do low setting drying (since I wear mostly cotton and things of that sort).

This laptop has some features that are excellent, and others that make it difficult to use.Touch ScreenPROS- Highly responsive overall.- Because of how good the touch screen is, I find myself using it quite frequently.CONS- Because of how much I use the touch screen, the screen looks horribly smudged all the time.Quality of 4K ScreenCONSI use a Macbook Pro retina, an iPad with retina, and the iPhone with retina. Websites looked terrible in the first few weeks of using the computer, because their images were all pixellated, and the layouts didn't quite have the same responsiveness that the websites of today have. On the XPS, however, the amount of pixels on the screen means that the entirety of the computer looks ridiculous.Websites have text that looks like ants on the screen. "Oh but you can zoom!" I can zoom on any computer that I own. I don't want to have to do that, because zooming the text breaks layouts of some websites, and overall just looks dumb. This same issue shows up on the start menu. You go to the start menu, and the icons are freakishly tiny.I have used Windows 8.1 on other computers with smaller monitors. This isn't an issue on there. This looks like it's partially a Windows issue, and partially a Dell issue. Why am I blaming Dell too? Because they have created software to add functionality to the trackpad (more on that in a moment). When you're charging over $2,000 for a laptop, it behooves you to take a look at something as basic as how things on the screen look to a user before you send it out, and create a thing to address that issue if indeed one exists.PROSMovies look gorgeous. Whether it's iTunes HD or other companies that offer HD moves on their site, the movies look absolutely stunning on the screen. Yes, I'm aware that I can hook up the computer to a flat screen TV, and really see it in all its beauty, but when I travel (frequently), it's nice to have a screen upon which anything with high resolution is going to look good.When you're in the middle of editing photos or videos, the extra pixels really help. You can see the whole thing on the screen, and have at it. The Adobe suite of products run on it just beautifully. Because of the sheer width of the screen, I can have my InDesign document sitting on one side of the screen, while I'm in the process of editing the images on a Photoshop window right next to it. My mac screen isn't nearly as wide as the Dell screen is. Also, because of the touch screen, I can very quickly organise windows or icons on the screen. This goes much faster than when I'm using the mouse. Why? Because the mouse is pretty awful.TouchpadHoly cow, this touchpad is awful to use. I've messed around with the sensitivity settings, and the speed settings until I'm blue in the face, and no luck. It's still horrible to use. If you're getting this computer to mostly use the touch screen, and use the mouse on the rare situations that you're doing businessy work, like a giant Excel spreadsheet or something, then this won't be an issue for you. When you're doing video or photo editing, you're probably better off using the touch screen in any case.However, for long-winded business style applications, you're going to be frustrated.When using the touch screen, I feel like the mouse doesn't want to respond to my moving it around. It's reason enough for me to hook up an external mouse. It was this usability issue and the squinting to see the screen that I docked a star.Startup SpeedThis is absolutely awful. Between the solid state drive, the masses of RAM, and the processor itself, the startup should be very quick. It's not. I've used Desktop computers with a fraction of the tech specs of this one, and with regular hard drives, and they start up faster. Don't know what's up, but it's a major issue.Battery LifeUnlike the mac, this one doesn't do too hot with having the lid closed. As I mentioned before, the startup from shutdown is really REALLY slow. To counteract this, the startup from sleep is freaky fast. You open the lid, and you're flying again immediately. Unfortunately, this sucks down battery. An average day of typing documents, checking email, organising my calendar (again, the touch screen makes this a pleasure to do), getting online for a spell, and even watching a movie for a bit, will give me a good solid 4 hours or so. Why?I tend to turn off the wifi when I don't need it. I'll also dim the screen as much as I can, and turn off the illumination from the keyboard. That way, I don't worry about the amount of power I need to do something frivolous, like play a movie or something. However, if I put the computer to sleep, it doesn't freeze the battery level like my mac does. It continues to take up battery life. Not as much as if I had the computer flipped open and was using it. It's definitely slower to drain the battery. But drain the battery it does. It's not good at standby.WeightThis thing is /heavy/. My similarly sized Dell 17" is heavier than this machine, because it's got an optical media drive, and is a few years older. However, this is heavier than my MacBook pro (which does weigh a ton too). If I'm going on a quick trip, I'll reach for my mac, because it's lighter. For longer haul trips, where I want the touch screen, or want to just watch movies, I'll reach for the Dell, because it's really good at playing my Blu Ray discs (on an external drive that I own).Overall, if you need a nice computer and aren't just using it for email, watching YouTube, and the occasional MS Office document, get this. It has the power to handle those resource heavy Adobe applications, and will keep up with your multitasking needs. If you need something highly portable, check out the 2015 Newest Model Dell XPS13 Ultrabook Computer - the World's First 13.3" FHD WLED Backlit Infinity Display, 5th Gen Intel Core i3-5010U Processor 2.1GHz / 4GB DDR3 / 128GB SSD / Windows 8.1 (Certified Refurbished)

Does not dissolve in water. When the weather is dry, or I'm taking a bath and really giving myself a thorough scrubbing down (like on those hot summer days when I feel all gross and sweaty and greasy from running around all day), my skin tends to feel particularly dry. I want a lotion that I can put on right after my bathing routine. This is ideal, because it's very rich and doesn't just turn to nothing on wet skin. Short of straight up coconut oil, I've yet to find another lotion that will behave itself when you jump out of the shower.I do ignore the instructions. I don't want to towel myself off right after putting on lotion. That'll end up with me having the lotion all over the towel, and having to use more. Instead, I'll lightly dry off the bulk of the water, and immediately moisturise afterwards. That gives me great results, and I end up with hydrated skin, and able to use much less than if I put it on when I'm still dripping wet.

This is not going to replace maple syrup for your pancakes. Don't expect it to. However, it will make your life easier on recipes that call for palm sugar. Generally, palm sugar comes in those giant lumps that are a huge pain in the neck to have to scrape bits off of, and add to a recipe. For example, when you're making a Thai curry, and it calls for a tablespoon of palm sugar, just throw a tablespoon of this stuff in, and it'll get you there with regards to flavour and sweetness. The taste is much more intense than brown sugar. Much more earthy, but sweeter than molasses. Definitely a neat option to have on hand if you like playing with different sweeteners in your recipes.I find it has too much flavour for things like iced tea or coffee. Unless it's a really bitter, strong coffee, the natural taste of the syrup interferes with the taste of coffee. All in all, a great product.

Cleans right down to the bone. OK, not literally. I'm exaggerating. I used these pads after doing some deep frying, and having my entire face feeling like a grease ball. The pad was disgusting to look at even after I washed my face with my usual face wash soap. Seriously gets down into the deep spots on your skin, and clears you right up. I tend to have oily skin, so this wasn't drying to my face at all.THAT SAID, I'm docking a star, because I haven't had hugely visible results. Yes, some of the very fine lines aren't as pronounced as before, but the wrinkles along the nasolabial folds, and the forehead are still crevices. Looks like I'll have to suck it up and deal with those, or go sort out a plastic surgeon, because they're stubborn.In other words, expect this product to clean really deep. Expect it to exfoliate a bit too, because the texture of the pads themselves is fairly rough. It's not as rough on your face as those face scrubs with giant honking chunks of stuff in them, but that's a good thing, because those things seem to take off layers of skin, and that's kind of concerning. Don't expect it to replace a round of filler or botox.

Colours are vivid and bright, even though it looks like pastel in theory. It's able to mark on really glossy paper without problems, which is great for making little notes in my textbooks or magazines. Does have a bit of the sharpie smell, but it's not as strong as the heavier markers, so less annoying that way. Another great marker from Sharpie!

It works on my iPad, and my iPhone. It lets me hook it up to a charger in the wall, next to my bed, and still play with whatever device is charging. This is excellent for when I've let the battery get too low (which is an almost daily occurrence, to be honest). There are differences between this cable and the ones bought via Apple. The one from Apple is more springy, whereas this one is more stiff feeling. The material coating the wires is not as soft. However, these are considerations that aren't that big a deal, because I wanted a cord long enough to reach from the wall to my pillow, but not so long that it gets all tangly. Best part is that the colour coding helps it stand out from the myriad iPhone cables at work. Everyone knows that the purple one is mine.

The paper is good quality, and has plenty of room for writing down quick notes. Each day, INCLUDING Saturday and Sunday have a full 1/4 page devoted to them. That means that you get 7 days on a 2-page spread, along with an extra box for notes. Solid. The tabs for the months are on both sides of the divider, meaning that you can see which months have passed, and which ones are coming up, regardless of where in the book you are. At the opening of each month, you have a full month view. In fact, as daily planners go, this one is a king amongst planners. So why the docked star?The spiral binding makes it difficult to finagle the front and back covers. When I fold the thing flat open on my table, it sits flat gorgeously. When I try to close it back up, the pages go back into configuration no problems. The cover, however, sticks. Pound for pound, this has ALL the features that I could hope for in a daily planner, but opening and closing it is a pain. If it weren't for that one major (it's not a minor annoyance when you're opening and closing the planner multiple times a day) annoyance, this would get 5 out of 5 stars. If it's not enough of an annoyance to you, because you just need one place to archive all your dates, you'll be fine.BONUS: If you use fountain pens, this will be a good choice for you. I used Noodler's Baystate Blue in a Platinum Preppy on this planner, and it didn't bleed through.

I could go on for ages on how much I love tea, but then you'll be bored. Suffice it to say that I will drink tea if it's on offer, especially when I'm wanting a bit of a relaxing moment during a busy day. However, when I'm at work, I don't have my little gong fu cha tea pot, or any of the other paraphernalia that I generally keep at home. This leaves me with two choices, both of which are terrible: bagged tea, or those Keurig tea pods. Bagged tea that's of quality will generally be good for one steeping, because the bag is barely 1/4 full. Basically, I've just spent a fortune on a single serving of tea. The Keurig stuff is terrible tasting, and also obscenely expensive.Why is this one different? Each tea bag is LOADED with tea. When you pour on hot water, the bag inflates to its full size, and the bag is crammed full with the tea leaves and rose petals. This is the same effect that I get when I make the Chinese tea at home. It means that I can steep quite a few times out of one amount of tea, and share it with my friends. Granted, this is not a tea I'd be sharing. It's too delicious.This is a decidedly floral tea. If that's not your bag, keep looking. The brand offers plenty of other choices. I actually really enjoy floral tea (Jasmine being a favourite), so this is right up my alley. THAT SAID, bear in mind that this is a flavoured tea. It's not for those who are tea purists, and need for their tea to be straight up tea leaves and nothing else. For me, it's a question of context. If I'm going to be with friends who enjoy a cup of tea, I'm going to break out the full shebang, and have a tea ceremony situation going on. If I'm on my own, and in the middle of a work day, I'll reach for these tea bags.The flavour of the green tea itself isn't too grassy. It's more of a mild green tea that's eminently drinkable. The rose comes through nice and clear. This needs no sweetener at all, because it's got a natural sweetness from the flowers in there. All in all, the product does everything right: plenty of tea for your bag, so that you can steep more than once, high quality ingredients, and convenience. The design of the pyramid shaped bag lets the tea bag get completely surrounded by the hot water, rather than having blind spots in between. Also, instead of floating on the top of your cup, this one sinks right down. It's costly, but compare the price of this to the price of a bag of garbage tea at a diner.

Clarissa is an engaging writer, and great storyteller. I used to watch her and Jennifer on Two Fat Ladies as a kid, and was intrigued about how Clarissa always had little snippets of knowledge about history and food. Especially if you're not a fan of your typical history books, this will be a great read for you, because there's plenty of little stories about individual people, and what they ate. Rest in peace, Jennifer.

My Hawkins was (SHOCK HORROR) not sealing properly, and I was getting steamed. Once I put the new gasket it, it's back to being the dream machine that it's always been. It fits my Futura perfectly. It keeps a nice tight seal, and hits full pressure in no time.

Very very cute little substitute for our Xmas tree, because we live in a tiny little room that won't fit anything larger. Also, his little head is so huge in comparison to his tiny little stick (hahahaah get it?) body. This is so great. Husband loves it too.
LOOK AT HIS STUPID FACE. IS IT NOT SO CUTE. OH MY GOODNESS. I AM SO HAPPY. WHY AM I SHOUTING? BECAUSE HE IS SO CUTE. SO. CUTE.

LOTS of power. So much power. My husband charged his android phone to 75% (because he then had to use the thing), I charged my iPhone 5S multiple times, and we're still on the first charging. It managed to charge overnight. I had my iPhone going at full tilt (Waze was running, as well as YouTube, and LTE turned on) on my trip on the bus. I was teetering on 20% battery life. In an hour, while using my phone with all the things running, I managed to get back up to 75% battery while plugged into the 2 amp side. The battery amount left over display is really helpful, because those freaking dots that other battery backups have don't tell you anything.We own a External Battery, New Trent iCarrier 12000mAh Portable Dual USB Port External Battery Charger/Power Pack for Smartphones, iPhone 6, Iphone 6 Plus, S5, Nexus 6, Note 4, Tablets, iPad Air 2, iPad mini 3, and more (Now w/Micro-USB charge port) that I've had for a couple of years now. Look at the price on that thing, and compare it to the price for the TSST one. It's night and day, isn't it? The amount of mAh on this one isn't that far behind the NewTrent one, but this one costs like half of the other one. Might as well buy two of these if you need that much battery charge.It is heavy though (like a pound or so), so if you're one of those people who hates carrying extra weight, then you'll be stuck with a lower capacity battery, because the amount of charging you get out of this sucker is very good. You can't have it all, can you? Either you sacrifice the amount of charge you get, or sacrifice having a heavy little brick in your bag.This is thicker and slightly larger than my iPhone, but it's small enough to fit into a regular sized handbag or backpack. It does fit into my pocket for those times that I want to talk on the phone while having the phone charge, and walk around (you'd be surprised how frequent that occurrence happens). When I do so in my pyjamas, it will bang against my leg, so I make sure to just slide the battery thingy into the pocket of my hoodie or something.For what you're paying for the unit, this is a very slick little device. It's got sensible features that you will find yourself wishing in all your other devices. It's also pretty enough that other people comment on it. Very much worth the money.

The pictures do NOT do these justice. If you could see how vibrant the colours are on the photo, you'd all be getting them. They are nicely absorbent (being cotton and all). You would be surprised at how nice they look on the table, especially when there's really not much else going on to decorate it. Generally, for a weeknight, I can't be fussed to deal with tablecloths, or other fripperies. I want dinner, and I want it now. Having a nice splash of colour really livens things up. I haven't run them through multiple washes yet, so I don't know how *fast* the dye is, but rest assured that I'll update as I know.For the price, these are well worth it.

I used another brand for years which had been recommended to me by a Nutritionist, and that brand was twice as expensive.  I actually feel this brand works better for me.  I haven't heard it used for weight loss until I read other reviews, it was recommended to me for stress and to help me sleep and that's what I use it for.  I seem to need it for a week or so every few months to 'reset' my sleep.

I thought I'd try this lotion for myself.  It met my new parameters of no phalates or parabens, no mineral oil, made in USA, fragrance free, no animal testing.  I just don't care for it.  I don't like the odor, it smells rancid to me - I am sure it is not, I just can't think of how else to describe the smell.  I don't like how it feels when rubbing it into my skin, it feels waxy.  I would recommend that someone try it - after all it's all personal preference.  Nothing bad happened to me while using it, I just prefer other brands.

I'm astonished at the good reviews for this piece of work.  Perhaps witchcraft was involved?  The characters are so flat, boring and immature it's amazing this ever got published.  Is it supposed to be YA?  That's the level of the character interactions, grumpy responses, glares, threats, staredowns from twilia twat and trigger or whatever the characters were named.  I read about 3 chapters thinking this has GOT to get better! It had so many great reviews!  Oh boy, it stinks like stink to the 10th power.

I like Anne Klein purses, so no surprise I ordered it and gave it 5 stars.  It has a very nice look with summer dresses.  Can easily be casual but with the patent band it's good for nicer outfits also.  2 separate pockets make up the bag which is nice for organizing things.  It has a zipper top, not a fold over flap.  A very nice purse.

What a fun doll to play with.  Dora is about 18" tall, nicely made vinyl doll.  She has a very easily identifiable, large button on her dress which when pressed plays a comment, command or song in both English and Spanish.  It's delightful.  Her little dog Perritto moves easily and is fun to watch.  My niece enjoys 'talking' with Dora.  Sometimes the Spanish is a little hard to grasp if you are unfamiliar with the language, but as everyone knows - with kids you'll hear it at least 500 times so I'm sure I'll catch on!  A very nice doll.  This is a special time toy with my neice as she's just about 3.

This book reads like a poorly written screen play for "The Big Chill".  The main character, a woman who impressed me so little I don't even recall her name is a whiny can't make up my supposedly adult, mind.  yawn.  What a bore.
I like it.  The tray is sturdy, the handles convenient and the rubber dots keep plates and glasses from slipping.  I wish it came in a larger size also.
I thought it was creative and it held my interest throughout the entire story.  Although written for children I enjoyed it, always interersting to have an animal as the main character.

A nice story about how being different can make a difference!  The Princess wants to be a warrior and she asks for a pony for her birthday.  She gets a sweet little roly poly pony that farts.  Undeterred by the pony's lack of abilities even after training, the Princess and her pony attend the great battle and.....well you'll have to read this charming book to find out what happens.
Very tasty, smells and tastes like cheesecake.  A nice change from nut and oat bars.  150 calories with 5 grams fiber, 10 grams of sugar.

I felt this was a thinly disguised story about 2 celebrities, one deeply involved with scientology and the other his now ex wife who arranged and executed a divorce without anyone knowing.  I expected a story something more along the lines of a Joan Collins hollywood themed juicy summer reading book.  This story is supposedly told from "Lizzie Peppers"  point of view.  How as a young woman she was romanced by a mega-star, fell for what she later found out were scripted lines, got married, found out more about his cult "One Cell"  and left.  I really didn't care.  I didn't connect with the character Lizzie and I didn't care what her motivations were.  It's true that I don't care about either person in real life, so their make-up life wasn't going to interest me either.  Promotional blurbs say the story is 'full of twists and turns and a breathless journes to the heights of Hollywood power....'  well perhaps that would be the case if you held your breath the entire time you were reading...I suppose that could render you breathless and if you've spent your life living under a rock I suppose you couldn't see what was coming.... what I'm saying is I felt no tension in the story at all.

I did enjoy the story.  There are some lol descriptions of feelings about your spouse when you've been married for a few decades.  The story centers around Lisa and Joe Stone, two very intelligent but by their choice small town lawyers, and their wacky client Lettie VanSandt.  Lettie is a regular ( almost weekly) client who often changes her will and wants to engage in all manner of lawsuits agains just about anyone for anything.  Joe isn't quite sure why he tolerates her the way he does. Lettie is also big on creating potions.  Low and behold one of them actually works and could be worth a fortune.  This part of the story takes off with Lettie's death, her nervous son Neal claiming her estate after Joe signs off on it and something fishy comes out.  This something involves a huge pharmaceutical and it's young magnate.  Interesting legal drama ensues.  However I didn't buy the actions of Lisa Stone - the decisions and actions she took to try to save the case when it looks as though the Pharmaceutical may win.  I don't believe anyone would do what she did and risk what she did, so that was a little off for me.There's a sub story about Lisa's discontent with her marriage, her actions and her constant - and somewhat annoying,  self recrimination and fear of discovery by Joe.  I had not heard of the author prior to reading this book.  I did enjoy reading it and felt it zipped along until Lisa's questionable actions...but that just bugged me.  You may be bothered.

Vinnie's Diner isn't your typical diner.  Apparently it appeared because the main character Allie needed a place to assess her life before moving on.  Allie has been in a life threatening auto accident.  She is helped to the diner by Vinnie and it is there where she reviews her life before making the ultimate choice of staying or moving on.  As with all of us, there are things that Allie would rather not 'replay' . There is a cast of characters in the diner, which serve no purpose and don't expand the storyline.  While talking with Vinne Allie reviews her life.  Ba'al also wants Allie, and shows her parts of her relatives lives she'd rather not know, but it's important. This story does have Christian themes of angels, Jesus and God, but I didn't feel overwhelmed by this and thought it was done very well.  Depending on your age, this could be a very thought provoking story.  If you really reflected back on your life, would you like what you see?  Would you take an opportunity to change?  Would you see that holding grudges has no meaning and could you let go?  Could you forgive so you could move on?  Would you change now, while you have life left and could make a difference in your life and others?  Interesting questions.  The story flows easily, I read it in two sessions by the pool.

I was skeptical about the sueded finish being any good but it did provide a pretty good grip on the yoga mat and it was a little sweat absorbent.  I prefer my hot yoga microfiber towel with the rubber bits on one side.  I never worry about that one slipping and it's more absorbent.  This one worked OK.

The chaise and table were delivered a couple days ago.  I finally made myself get up out of the chaise and write a review - the chaise is THAT comfortable!  Anyone who sits in it does not want to get up.  The items were packeged very well with no damage at all.  Heavy duty cardboard, foam sheeting around the arms and back of chair and the legs encased in bubble wrap.  Cushions in heavy duty plastic.  I'm not sure what 'assembly required' means to the manufacturer.  In this case it included tying the bottom cushion onto the back, cleaning the glass for the table and placing it on the table.  The set is made of plastic rattan which is nicely woven and smooth to the touch.  The cushions are a nice oatmeal shade, and the included lumbar or head pillow compliments it well, as does many other outdoor pillows I happen to have.  The set is supposed to e weatherproof, is intended for outdoor use and I may put it outdoors at some point.  After we unpacked the set it looked so nice in our great room we are just using it there.  The back of the chaise has 4 adjustable settings from fully upright to recline...and oh is it easy to fall asleep on this plush cushions!  The bottom pad is almost 6" thick.  It's really a great set.

This is a great work glove.  They arrived just in time for cleaning a gas grill in which a grease pan caught fire, leaving alot of baked on charred debri.  I used alot of soapy water, sponge and scrub brush and the grip from these gloves was great. No sliding or slipping.  Much easier to work with than my kitchen rubber gloves!  Also used with Roundup while spraying bug spray...usually not a problem but I felt better having my hands protected ( for once)  Again, firm grip, no slipping.  These were also used for repair on a bike chain and had great grip and allowed me to keep the dexterity.  I agree with other reviewers that you can reuse these gloves provided they are not filled with oil or yard chemicals.  I thought these were alot easier to put on than the Costco latex gloves I have been using.  Recommend.

I own a Weber Smokey Mountain smoker.  I thought the intro about various woods used in smoking, charcoal and the basic operating procedure were helpful for beginner smokers.  The Minion method of lighting the charcoal briquets is described, along with the comment to experiment with this method as there are a few variations. This is what we did- hey it's smoking, you're not building a nuclear reactor.  There are many ways to achieve the end result.  The food photographs are amazing, you'll want to tear the pages out and try to eat them.  Certainly an incentive to try the recipes!!  I didn't find the layout confusing as some others did, it was obvious that he was giving you the rub and barbeque sauce he used on the item he just gave the recipe for.  There are all kinds of recipes from basic smoked items such as pork butt, ribs, chicken etc to some more uncommon items like poppers ( several varities) and pizza.  The author also tells you how to use your smoker as a regular grill and there are several recipes for that - what he calls a high heat option.  Overall, I thought it was a great book and can't wait to try the recipes!

Works as advertised.  Once you download the Seek app, sign in etc...you simply attach the camera and go 'seeking'.  I had no connection issues, it worked immediately on a Samsung 5s and I did not have to remove my case.  I set it to see the temperature, and I had no idea how hot my modem or cable box got!  Both were close to 100 degrees F.  The color shades worked best for me from about 15-20 feet - very close and of course it wasjust the one color but also more blurry.  I was able to see someone walking around the house in the dark - my husband who volunteered.  That was pretty cool.  Take a picture quickly which would probably be useful if you had a problem and were talking to a contractor about it.  Took the camera to a few construction jobsites to check hot/cold spots.  Worked great.  I'd say if you had a real need for it in your job it would be very handy.

snappy design! sorry, couldn't resist adding another 'snap' pun.....however it is true, the blades snapped right on - no issues. quality construction. The blades have a curved design which hugs the windshield the blades do  help with sleet and snow removal and it seemed as though the buildup was less.  I like these better than the OEM blades on my Malibu.  I will update once and if winter ever ends regarding wear and tear. Recommend.

I've been using Neutrogena sunscreens for years as they were recommended by my dermatologist.  Neutrogena has a broad spectrum UVA and UVB protection which is marketed as 'helioplex'.  This is basically a combination of certain chemicals which when combined prevents the sunscreen from degrading rapidly, hence the 80 minute reapplication recommendation.  I used the cool dry sport 30 on a hot, humid Florida day. It's thick and when you apply it the whiteness of the sunscreen takes a few moments to fade as the product is absorbed into your skin.  It definately stayed put on my face and the perspiration came out through the suncreen.  It took several swipes from a towel before I felt like I had wiped off the sunscreen. So - it lasts.  I applied it, waited about 15 minutes ( sweat test) then went in the pool for a time.  When I came out I could still feel the lotion on me but less than when I went in, so it does last in the water.  That being said, I prefer the Neutrogena sport for face sunscreen and the Neutrogena Beach Defense sunscreens.  Although the cool dry sport sunscreen did preform well, it was not any different than the Neutrogena products I already use and like.  This sunscreen is just thicker than the beach defense.  This is personal preference.  This product did work well.

Not a criticism of the writing, I simply don't care for obscure organizations seeminly having control or vying for control of the world. In this case it's the "Fras".  Dopey name. Overworked storyline.  I thought the portion of the story which covered the Fras, a male dominated ( oh - aren't they ALL??)  society made up of some genetic whackos was so boring.  I skimmed all their meetings, plotting etc.  Boring.  The relationship between outspoken Abby and Hunter was fun and I really enjoyed that part.  I am a fan of Sherrilyn Kenyon, which is why I picked up the book, but won't go for another with this co-author.

Pros:  made in USA.  Duck is the first ingredient listed.  My dog eats these eagerly.  My dog pretty much eats everything eagerly :)Made without using corn, wheat, artificial flors or colors.....Cons:  why include the sugar alcohol sucralose when you are using cane molasses?  I just don't know why that's necessary.  I'd rather the vendor add more molasses if you want it sweeter.  I don't want to give my dog sucralose and won't buy these.  Also, isn't caramel color an artificial color?  I'm not sure on that one.  I also didn't like that it's recommended on the package to break these up when giving them to your dog.  Why?  are they a choking hazard because of the long thin shape?  If that's the case I sure don't want to buy them for my dog, what if someone else gives one to my dog and doesn't read the package and my dog chokes?

I used the product on 2 leather reliners.  One recliner is beige and about 10 yrs old with light use.  The cleaner immediately lifted the light "dirt" stains where your hands commonly rest on the arm rest.  Likewise light 'dirt' was lifted from the recliner portion where the feet rest.  I used the green bottle, cleaner and conditioner on this recliner.  The other reliner is taupe/grey, 3 yrs old and the leather color was already worn through on the recliner where your foot rests.  Also there were a few minor ink stains on the arms.  The spray on leather cleaner lifted the ink stains right off.  Didn't do much for the footrest where the color of the leather was missing.  Applied the conditioner and it immediately darkened ( naturally) and sealed the worn through areas so they are no longer obvious.  In all cases the product did not feel oily or greasy.  There was no real odor.  Now, the "leather scent" was hideous and got thrown in the trash right away.  There are pretty extreme warnings on all bottles, don't expose to skin, eyes, flush out eyes, don't inhale, give oxygen...I mean are these leather cleaners made of nuclear waste by products or what?  I went to their website to see list of ingredients and none is offered.  My opionion is that this leather cleaner was no different than another brand I used in the past, which also worked the same and actually listed the ingredients.  I wouldn't buy this as I think it's pricy but it did work well.
Bosch is known for quality blades and this is another.  Easy to install, fits well - Chevy Malibu '13 - I expect many years of service.No drag on windshield.

Cute dog treats, look like mini grilled burgers.  Strong liquid smoke flavoring smell.  Most ingredients seem fine but I question sacra lose in a dog treat.  I'm sure that's a sugar alcohol which can cause upset stomach in humans.  That being said, my dog didn't hesitate in gobbling these down with no reaction to the sucralose.
the quality is very good.  It has a hefty weight for a lock.  Nice finish and easy to install into door with existing deadbolt.  Works flawlessly.  Product recommended.

A collection of articles the author originally wrote for Wired Magazine, from 2006-2013.  The author's writing style is irreverent, quite readable and every article enjoyable, even for products I wasn't particularly interested in ( fix-a-flat)  Some articles have a 'backstory'The book is lighter in tone than I imagined it would be.  The information was interesting, for general knowledge.  Personally I don't and would not eat the majority of foods reviewed, but seeing that the same ingredients can be used in food as well as industrial application is interesting.  I'd probably bring up some of these things when just shootin' the breeze and eating snacks.!

quite a lovely shave cream!  Both my husband and I have used it and both thought it helped give a smooth shave.  We both enjoy the light fragrance and that it's more of a mild creamy lotion rather than a big foamy shaving cream.  It is  pricey at $28 a tube, which I think will probably last me 2 months.  I'm not factoring in husbands usage as I don't intend to let him have it back.  I would definately recommend.  I would purchase as I like the quality.
very easy to use with reliable measurements.  Handle folds in so you can easily keep in truck, or other work vehicle for quick use.  Numbers are very easy to read.  Recommend.
these work well in keeping your appliances shiny and fingerprint free.  Still have to buff out using a cloth, so it doesn't save any time over the spray cleaner - which I was hoping it would.

As some have noted, this bag is very small. To put it in perspective, I wear a size 11 and I can't even get a single shoe in it. For the right needs, this bag could be perfect.PROS- Compact size for compact needs- Durable materials and construction- MOLLE compatibility a big plus- Straps can be connected on top or sides (for shoulder or belt carry)CONS- Loose stitching needed to be trimmed- Zippers make way too much noise (I had to buy a pack of plastic zip pulls to replace these)

Not sure why Vacu Vin made this look like I'm holding a roll of duct tape but it works! It takes me a long time to drink my can of soda, usually 2-4 hours. My soda cans stay cold for about two hours longer with this nifty cooler. In some cases, it actually makes liquid colder for a short while, enough to form small ice crystals! Love it!

We use these to hold snow cones outside. The kids love being able to (1) put their snow cones down and (2) keep their hands from getting cold. So far they survived on summer by the pool; they should last quite a few years since I can't imagine the plastic cracking easily. I'll post an update if that does happen.

I bought this to place on my Platypus during paintball. It worked for the most part except when the cover fell off (which ended up on the ground in the middle of a match) and water started spilling everywhere!As others have noted, there are no instructions. That said, I think the installation is pretty intuitive. The problem is that when you reattach the hose to the tip, with the cover in between, you can't tell how far you've pushed it back in. If it's not attached deep enough, the cover doesn't stay shut. If it's too shallow, the tip can fall out. It basically must be perfectly reattached for neither of those to happen, which may take a little bit of trial and error.

These are the best snow cone cups I can find. We use these outside by the pool on super hot days and not once have these cups ever dripped, even after my kids get seconds from time to time. Seriously, not a single drop of anything after holding ice, slush, syrupy water, or any other time-lapsed snow cone.

I use this at home for filling small holes, this putty knife is perfect. When I have bigger jobs, I need a larger, more heavy-duty, knife. For the purposes this is meant for, this knife works extremely well. It bends when it's suppose to, it's stiff when you want it to be. Couldn't ask for more!

The idea is awesome but the execution it terrible. We bought these for our kids to use outside by the pool. They love being able use these to set down their ice pop or ice cream cone for few moments from time to time. They also love the colors and how novel it is to have a holder.That stated, the main reason why we, the parents, bought this is to not have a mess. From that perspective, this product fails. The treats still drip through the hole and the kids hands still get sticky.We'll continue to use these since the kids like them but we expect the mess to still be there.

It looks like it came right out of an episode of Leave It To Beaver but don't be fooled by this retro-looking nozzle. This feels great in my hand and functions way better than the plethora of nozzles I have tried in the past. The trigger has a real nice, snappy, feel to it.Unlike my other nozzles that are made from plastic, I actually think this will survive a winter outdoors in PA. The only thing I have to get used to is that the type of spray is determined by the pressure I apply on the trigger. Everything else about it is perfect.***Update*** (Aug 2014)After several months of use, this is starting to rust. Although I love this nozzle, it's apparent that I will have to replace this at some point. I get that zinc isn't the same as stainless steel but if a nozzle can't survive outside in the summer under the deck for more than a few months, I think something is missing. When is someone going to come up with a "outdoor" product that can survive the outdoors for more than one season? Sorry, had to take a star away from 5 to 4.

I run about 20 miles a week and have never gotten a blister until last week. I was about 3 miles into an 8 mile run and I literally felt a blister forming between my toes. When I got home, I knew I needed to do something about it; after a little due diligence, I bought these Injinji toesocks.They arrived 2 days later and couldn't wait to put them on. I ran 8 miles again that day and I couldn't feel my blister at all. It was as if the episode I had just 48 hours earlier never happened!Since these lightweight socks are relatively thin, I pray these will last a while.

Although I have a heater, the cost to use it in early Spring in the Northeast is way too high. When I opened the pool this season on May 8, the pool temp was 58 degrees. Within two days, it was up to 76! Granted we had warm weather and lots of sun those days but I was very impressed. I feel I can use the pool an additional month on both ends of the Summer now!PROS- Works great! Heats up the pool and keeps it warm at night- Easy to cut using a razor knife (I have a kidney-shaped pool)- Big enough for me to use on three sections (I have a main pool, a spa, and a sun deck)CONS- Can't use my robot cleaner while this is on- Heavy and hard to fold; takes me about 10 minutes to set up/take down- Must store in a shaded cool place; I stuff it in a deck box when not in useOverall, this was the biggest value I've gotten out of any purchase for my pool. Love it!

This compact adapter works fine but I was only able to get ONE out of three sets of holes to fit properly. I've tried every combination of different types of plugs into different holes and two of them just won't allow me to push them all the way in. Still works but looks sloppy and could potentially be dangerous since we use it by the bathroom sink.Ironically, it comes with instructions stating not to use this product unless plugs are all the way in flush.

We bought this picnic caddy and after several uses, we feel the product is OK but could be much better.PROS- Perfect height for plastic-ware so they don't fall out- Holds a decent amount (at least 25 pieces of plastic-ware in each small front section)- Back area has room for 20 napkins and 20 small paper plates- Made of durable plasticCONS- It could have looked good but there is a seam where the "wicker" wrap connects in the front. It is thick glue-like substance and hideous to look at. Why can't this be on the back?- If it was just an inch wider in the back, it could hold large paper plates as well! So close...

I run about 20 miles a week in a variety of conditions. I also am a bit of a sneaker/running shoe freak and own about 50 pairs. I can honestly state that these are my absolute favorite. As a result, I end up wearing many of my other shoes in casual settings but use my Puma Radius when I want to run a great time. Here's why:- Extremely comfortable. Seems to have just the right about of padding (not minimalist but not bulky) to make my feet happy.- Very breathable. Even in 90+ degrees, my feet don't feel stuffed up.- Incredibly durable. My Radius has been through about 100 miles and the only wear and tear visible are a few loose strings on the stripe.- Versatile usage. I can wear these in all temperatures and road conditions. I actually feel more comfortable in these than any of my trail shoes.- Good design. Looks nice with high socks, low socks, calf sleeves, etc. Also looks nice while wearing jeans or other casual wear.Overall, I love these. This includes all the other Pumas that I have as well. I plan on buying several more colors and hope Puma continues to make this version of the Radius for a few more years.

I've owned several pairs of Kinvara 3 and just started wearing Kinvara 4. I use them to run about 20 miles a week on paved roads and my feet thank me for it. These running shoes are extremely breathable and comfortable that I wear all year round except during the harshest part of winter.If you've never worn Saucony before, I suggest going up half a size. For example, I wear size 10 Nike but 10.5 Saucony. This applies to all my Saucony shoes.The only problem that I've had with any Saucony was that one of my Kinvara 3 shoes makes a snapping noise. This is not a problem when I'm running outdoors but no way I'd wear them at a mall or airport since it's incredibly embarrassing. I actually spoke with a Saucony rep and even shared a video but they were unwilling to swap the pair out with me unless I paid for shipping. Boooo! So far so good on my Kinvara 4 shoes.
