One senses Forsyth padding like mad to bring his book up to the required length, and not really sweating the relevance.Where Forsyth could be filling out his pages instead is in explaining how Martin manages to get where he does, how he beguiles his enemy into thinking he is one of them. This is where the suspense of the book lies, I think. Instead, Forsyth handles this issue in a breezy, backhanded way: "With his dark looks, full black beard and the repeated references to Allah of the truly devout, Martin convinced his host that he also was a true believer," is the sort of passage that crops up a lot and bespeaks laziness.The resolution of the story is where "The Afghan" fails most egregiously. It's a downbeat ending that accomplishes next-to-nothing, either on geopolitical terms or the book's own. The revelation of the nature of the al-Qaeda operation comes too late, is handled abstractly, and makes little sense after. The wind-up is clearly rushed as if Forsyth found he had reached a target word count and was in a hurry to get his manuscript out the door.The beginning of "The Afghan," involving the al-Qaeda finance officer, does pull you in; Forsyth also has the smart idea of bringing international shipping and piracy into the mix, and develops this with flair for a chapter or two. But the slackness in the overall narrative too quickly becomes contagious. Some reviewers fault those who would look behind the curtain rather than read what's on the page. But "The Afghan" is the kind of book that's all too easy to second-guess, given the apparent absence of any first-guessing.

This review is for the 1959 edition edited by Charles Neider.Mark Twain didn't exactly invent American fiction; rather he made it both marketable and respectable. It's a shame that life deprived him of the chance to do the same with his autobiography.Reviewing "The Autobiography Of Mark Twain" is a challenge. There are multiple versions out there, including two that predate Neider's edition and a fourth, three-volume set just recently published. Neider would seem to get the nod on the basis of digestibility (it isn't a stack of phone books like the three new volumes) and narrative flow (Neider reworked the book to follow a semblance of chronological order, which none of the others apparently do.)But it's scant pleasure reading. Some of this is on Twain, who was a sharp critic of cant and superstition and tended to harp on his bleaker views, especially late in life, where most of the material for this edition finds him."It has always been a peculiarity of the human race that it keeps two sets of morals in stock â the private and the real, and the public and the artificial," he notes.Twain had some outstanding successes in his life, enough so that he could justifiably refer to himself here as the most important American author of his time, yet he seems hellbent on accentuating the negative. He frequently dwells on people who let him down. It's fun reading about Twain's disgust with Bret Harte, a much-celebrated fellow author whom Twain describes as a narcissistic deadbeat. But Twain, at least here, offers little on other luminaries he knew, like Ambrose Bierce or William Dean Howells, apparently as he can't say anything nasty about them.Sentiment is reserved here for Twain's wife, Livy, and their three daughters, upon whom Twain dotes in print. The book become choked with anguish as it finds Twain near its end mourning the loss of three of these four women, which while interspersed over a period of 13 years comes at you in rat-tat-tat fashion here, as if Twain was in limbo between their deaths.Much of this is in fact on Neider, who seems to have struggled to find a way to link up what Twain wrote in non-chronological fashion, random observations for the most part jotted down as the mood hit. The result is a book that drably itemizes boyhood classmates, but spends no time on the writing of "The Adventures Of Huckleberry Finn" or "A Connecticut Yankee In King Arthur's Court."You do get some powerful passages, Twainâs thoughts on immortality and imperialism (each in the negative) and death (which he describes several times as lifeâs only gift). He discusses the import of humor: âHumor must not professedly teach and it must not professedly preach, but it must do both if it would live forever.â But there are long stretches of bracken between quotable sentiments.Twain wrote an autobiography on his own subjective terms; Neider deserves credit for trying to meet readers halfway. But in its final form, this is a frustrating read.

Tom Wolfe's "A Man In Full" is both an invigorating and disappointing read. Invigorating, because it brings Wolfe's gimlet eye and viscerally descriptive powers to bear on the modern American South. Disappointing, because it's less a novel than a series of clever vignettes cobbled together to create an unremarkable story.The "man" of the title may in fact be one of four characters, all of whom seek to attain some greater whole. They include a politically ambitious lawyer, a weaselly bank executive, a scrappy warehouse employee, and a good-old-boy real-estate tycoon who falls on hard times. The latter character, one Charlie Croker, a. k. a. "Cap'm Charlie," is the fulcrum of the story as it unfolds, deep in debt yet trying to keep his house, his plantation, his hot young wife, and his exalted place in Atlanta high society."It's a great life if you don't weaken," says the city's mayor near the novel's end. If there's a point to "A Man In Full," beyond showcasing Wolfe's justly legendary powers of description, I guess that would be about it. Croker may be an unreconstructed bigot and a self-interested scoundrel, but he is also a force of nature, a football legend in his youth known as "the Sixty-Minute Man" for playing both offense and defense, and as Wolfe gives us a sense of his struggle we are meant to pull for him as a "man in the arena" who doesnât know when to quit. I write "meant" because it's not an easy thing, not until late in the book where Wolfe introduces a literal deus ex machina in Charlie's world that may work for some more than it did for me.What works for me is the chance to see Wolfe practice his legendary "new journalism"-honed style on a new set of characters and settings, after the rousing show he made of his prior novel, "Bonfire Of The Vanities." If you enjoyed that novel's sensory swirl and anything-goes humor, crossed with such live-wire issues as race and sexual misconduct, well there's plenty more of the same to be found here.The best way to look at this novel is as a series of carefully-thought-out, scrupulously-researched snapshot examinations of American culture circa 1998, when "A Man In Full" was published. Each of the 32 chapters has its own point-of-view, its own focal points and takeaways. They don't cohere, and the whole thing gets out of hand by novel's end, with Wolfe even quoting extensively from a Stoic philosopher to explain irrational turns of plot and character. But the novel is fun most of the way through.I love how one character, the lawyer, processes such things as the gaudy "Pizza Grenade" neckties then favored by men in power, or how Croker ponders the overuse of the word "paradigm.""The damn word meant nothing at all, near as he could make out and yet it was always 'shifting,' whatever it was," Wolfe writes. "In fact, that was the only thing the 'paradigm' seemed to do."If you venerate Wolfe as one of American letters' true originals, and don't mind his brilliance put in service of a thinnish story, you will enjoy "A Man In Full" well enough to recommend. Just don't be expecting another masterwork.

The story of World War II is told through detailed overviews of more than 20 of the war's most singular and decisive battles in this lavishly illustrated, full-color book.Published in 1986, the book was designed to take advantage of then-novel advances in computer graphics, especially in regard to topography. As General Sir John Hackett points out in his introduction, a flat, two-dimensional map never tells the whole story when it comes to the challenges faced in particular battles.To this end, "Great Battles" features illustrations such as a representation of the steep, angular mountain in Cassino, Italy which Allied forces fought to capture for months in 1944. At Kursk, we see how German tanks went into battle in an axe-shaped "panzerkeile" formation, which maximized firing power instead of the speed favored in their earlier, better-known "blitzkrieg" attacks. At Kohima, near the India-Myanmar border, British troops found their hilly redoubt shrinking against repeated Japanese attack, yet managed to hold on despite losing the highest ground, a fact clear from seeing the topographical map in this book.The most notable technological devices employed in this book may well be watercolors and paintbrush. Each battle comes with at least one, sometimes two splashy illustrations of this kind showing forces in action at key moments. While no doubt compressed and somewhat romanticized (they look as exciting as they do brutal), the depictions (by Harry Clow, going by the credits) are the book's key takeaway and do give you a sense for how the battles might have went down.The narratives are a bit lacking when it comes to nuances. We learn something about the friction among the British high command during the Battle of Britain, though its only glanced upon. The chapter on Arnhem concentrates almost exclusively on that battle, between British paratroopers and German panzer forces, rather than the surrounding campaign, Operation Market-Garden.The book has a clear English focus, being a British publication, which isnât a problem at all. The British did fight through more of the war than the Americans or even the Russians, and figured prominently in a lot of different battles. The one pull-out four-page illustration in the book does depict Omaha Beach, however.There is an impressive range of conflict contained in this book, everything from convoy attacks in the North Atlantic to the defense of Malta to the battle in the skies over England, not to mention land battles around Moscow, Guadalcanal, and El Alamein. Each chapter (some of which detail more than one battle) includes a solid textual overview explaining what happened and why it was important. Also, there are sidebars on key leaders; on the tanks, planes, or ships involved; and such fascinating secondary subjects as the layout of Hitler's bunker during the final battle for Berlin and how a British biplane managed to sink Germany's greatest battleship.There may be a case for calling "Great Battles Of World War II" a fine book for 12-year-olds, but if so, I was a happy 12-year-old while reading it; learning once again, in a curiously immersive way, just how terrible a conflict World War II was and how magnificently brave were those who fought it.

Take one dead president, add three historically-inaccurate but politically-correct protagonists, a couple of Bondian super-villains, throw in a lot of half-baked plots and counterplots, and stir until all is an impenetrable mess.This is the recipe for Timothy L. O'Brien's history-mystery novel set in the days after the American Civil War and the killing of President Abraham Lincoln. Temple McFadden is a Washington, D. C. police detective, haunted by a grim Irish childhood among other things, who interrupts a deadly assault at the B & O Railroad station. He takes custody of a package containing two diaries, one kept by Lincoln's widow and the other by his killer. He also takes on a bevy of deadly and ruthless operators who want the diaries. Can McFadden, his devoted wife Fiona, and their friend Augustus solve Lincoln's murder?After finishing the novel, I can't say I know the answer. I know how the book ended, but I'm not at all clear on what happened or why. Things happen in "The Lincoln Conspiracy" less for reason than for effect.A number of historical figures make their way into the pages of the book, including the famous detective Allan Pinkerton; photographer Alexander Gardner; and Edwin Stanton, Lincoln's secretary of war oft-speculated to have played a role in Lincoln's death. Unfortunately, they are cardboard caricatures seemingly plucked from their Wikipedia entries rather than developed as human beings of depth and feeling.Without revealing too much, Temple discovers that Lincoln was a victim not of desperate terrorist fury but corporate greed. This doesn't make sense considering Lincoln's pro-wealth economic policies (which O'Brien acknowledges), nor especially when the chief villain is finally revealed at the book's end. I suspect O'Brien meant the conclusion as a parody of the Lincoln-as-vampire-killer subgenre making the rounds, but it doesn't come off either for laughs or for raw excitement. It just feels wrong.Characters speak in clichÃ©. Temple is warned: "You're putting yourself in a very perilous and untenable place." Later, when he has a chance of killing one of the bad guys, Augustus cautions: "Don't turn yourself into him. Don't turn yourself into a murderer."Much dialogue consists of clumsy exposition designed to showcase O'Brien's research, rather than life being lived either then or now. The political correctness of Fiona, a liberated doctor who sees through the ignorance of her chauvinistic colleagues; and Augustus, a black scholar and codebreaker who points out such injustices as the White House being constructed by slave labor, too obviously cater to 21st-century sensibilities.There are many clams in O'Brien's storycraft, too. Pocketa Queep, in a November 2013 review, points out a couple of egregious ones, but there are many to confuse and befuddle. One Union soldier killed in the opening battle turns up later so he can be killed again. The many shifting alliances get out of hand, as do the ridiculous coincidences and mistakes that help Temple and his friends stay ahead of the odds.âLincoln Conspiracyâ left me feeling not just disappointed but cheated.

A 14-year-old orphan's chance at enjoying a rare carefree summer at a boys' camp comes horribly undone in this 1989 suspense novel.All Leo Joaquim wants at Camp Friend-Indeed is a chance to belong. But his awkward background combined with bad luck quickly land him on the wrong side of most of the others in the Jeremiah cabin, including counselor Reece Hartsig. Others find things to like about Leo, including cabinmate Tiger Abernathy. Can Leo find his way into the good graces of Friend-Indeed's social order, or will the highly-competitive atmosphere keep him on the outs?âDonât screw up,â is how one of the other campers puts it to Leo. âWe donât want any more spuds in Jeremiah.âWhile likely written with younger readers in mind, "The Night Of The Moonbow" will resonate with adults who recognize in Leoâs experience their own adolescent difficulties fitting in to a demanding environment. As Leo tries to find his way around camp, Tryon employs details from the sleepaway camp experience of a bygone era, such as snipe hunts and talent shows, and draws from them moments of compelling angst and crisis.Leo is a protagonist you canât help but root for, especially as Tryon presents him in such an empathetic and subjective way. Thereâs tragedy in his story, with a strain of black humor, too. Just about everything the kid tries to improve his stock among his fellows backfires.Hartsig, nicknamed "Heartless" by the campers (though seldom to his face), makes for a marvelous heavy, so caught up in his cabin winning a trophy that he can't see Leo as anything other than a millstone. Reece has a slick manner and knows how to impress the people who run Friend-Indeed (having a rich father whoâs a camp benefactor doesn't hurt), yet there is a darker element to his personality he either can't or won't contain. His dealings with Leo give "Night Of The Moonbow" much of its power.There are some minor missteps. At several points, Tryon draws tangents between certain characters and the rise of Nazi Germany, which may be true to the time (there was such a thing in the United States as the German-American Bund), but deprives the narrative of some needed subtlety. The characters are pretty squarely drawn in the main, registering more as types than as people.But Tryon brings Camp Friend-Indeed to life by alternately lighting upon particular characters and camp locations in a way that creates a sense of a symbiotic whole. In some way, the camp itself may be the most compelling character in the book. It is a place of bucolic beauty, which Tryon limns with touches of nostalgia and warmth in his smooth-flowing prose. Yet it proves a cruel testing ground.Childhood canât help but summon rosy memories, but for those who recall the thorns, âNight Of The Moonbowâ is a novel that will connect on multiple levels.

The fact that William Shakespeare's already got one of the most formidable bodies of work in literature doesn't stop people from wanting to add to it. Charles Hamilton uses his background as a handwriting expert, as well as his deep interest in the Bard, to advance his case for Shakespeare's authorship of a 1611 play called "The Second Maiden's Tragedy." My short take: It doesn't wash.The play, included in full along with various scholarly essays by Hamilton, is a bizarre story about an usurper named "Tyrant" who tries to win the love of a woman named "Lady" even though she prefers to stay with the man from whom Tyrant took the throne. Tyrant's machinations run from bribing her father to sending a force of desperadoes to abduct her back to his palace. Meanwhile, a subplot presents a man who distrusts his wife and charges his friend to prove her unfaithful.Shakespeare was guilty of a few dodgy plots, but none sink near the level of "The Second Maiden's Tragedy," which is really more of in the line of Jacobean Grand Guignol than anything one might consider classical. The most memorable dramatic moment involves a lengthy love scene between Tyrant and a corpse. Killing is the main order of business; only three of the 11 main characters live to see the end of the play.Admittedly, this makes "Second Maiden's Tragedy" sound like perverse fun. Take it from someone who liked "Titus Andronicus;" it's not. The play unfolds in an artless, clumsy style. Characters change personalities on a dime. The language is rude and plain, not like Shakespeare at all, like when Tyrant, secure on his throne, bemoans the lack of the woman he loves."There's the kingdom/Within yon valley fixed, while I stand here/Kissing false hopes upon a frozen mountain."Hamilton's essays draw a link between the play and a rumored lost play of Shakespeare's, "Cardenio," taken from a story found in Cervantes' "Don Quixote." Even though the play is not at all like the Cardenio story, Hamilton draws some tortured parallels in explaining how "The Second Maiden's Tragedy" uses "Cardenio" as a jumping-off point.To a matter more at the center of disbelieving a Shakespeare connection, "The Second Maiden's Tragedy" is really, really bad. Hamilton offers a feeble excuse: "Certainly, 'Cardenio' is a rough tumbling from the high peak of 'The Tempest,' only a year or so earlier and one of Shakespeare's sublimest plays. Perhaps 'The Tempest' was the brilliant flare of the candle just before it gutted."Or perhaps "The Second Maiden's Tragedy" is just what nearly every other scholar of the period says it is, a crude sex tragedy written by Thomas Middleton in the kind of tawdry, cynical style with which he is commonly associated and which Shakespeare wouldn't have touched with a bargepole.Even when Hamilton goes to his area of greatest expertise and shows how handwriting from the "Second Maiden's Tragedy" manuscript matches writing in Shakespeare's will, it's impossible not to think of some other possibility, like a common scribe. The play itself is just too poor a work, lacking even the faintest echoes of humor, tragedy, and/or subtlety to suggest the work of the Bard.

Frank Sinatra wanted people to love him, but those who got too close could get burned. This 1976 biography takes stock of Sinatra's problem personality from one who experienced both the good and bad Frank yet couldn't help but care about him, warts and all.A longtime Manhattan nightlife columnist, Earl Wilson saw Sinatra when he was just starting out, singing at New York City's Paramount Theater with Tommy Dorsey's band in 1940. Wilson recalls Dorsey's road manager describing Sinatra: "He's smart. He's human. He's a sweetheart, but he's also got a temper."That he did, as Wilson quickly discovered. With success, Sinatra became quite demanding and high-handed. Yet he could also be generous and kind. For a time, Earl was one of Sinatra's favorite members of the press, a recipient of Sinatra scoops and gifts. Then came a sudden falling out, over something Wilson says he never understood.What he did understand was Sinatra's hard-nosed mindset, which didn't do apologies. Taking stock, âSinatraâ is less bio than character study, largely ignoring the music to focus on the personality and the people around him, including, when Sinatra would have him, Wilson himself."Yes, Frank, unable to forget all the hurts he suffered in his down period, had developed a defiance of society that reinforced his childhood thinking and influenced the rest of his life," Wilson writes. "He would forever after be the little guy fighting the system.""Sinatra" is a decent early examination of the title subject when he was still alive and making headlines. Except when it gets to situations involving Wilson himself, itâs not very compelling. Wilson's gossip-columnist writing style drops a lot of famous names and clever quips, which gives you some feeling for the world Sinatra moved in. It's interesting stuff, if shallow.Wilson does better work recalling Sinatra's famous romance with the tempestuous Ava Gardner. Both she and Sinatra spoke freely to Wilson about their relationship. At one point, he puts you in a hotel room with the couple circa 1953 as they cheerfully discuss Frank's prospects for a big comeback in the movie "From Here To Eternity," Ava barefooted and Frank "docile and under complete control." Just a short while later, Frank and Ava were splitsville.Wilson's own issues with Sinatra occurred much later, in 1967, when he wrote about the latest of many Sinatra altercations in a way the singer did not like. Wilson owns up to being hurt about the cold shoulder he got as a result, which lasted the next few years. While others in the press liked to ding Sinatra; Wilson presents himself as an earnest champion, the sort of observer ready to take Sinatra's side whenever others accuse him of Mafia ties or a poor attitude.Even on the outs, Wilson makes clear here he sees Sinatra as a noble man, if brutish. In that way, "Sinatra" offers something of a counterweight to the more lurid bios that push Sinatra's darker side, even if it doesn't quite convince you to see the singer in the same forgiving way."He has more likability than anybody I ever met," Wilson writes. "If there's such a word as 'unlikability,' he has that, too, but when he turns on his likability, you think you must have been wrong about him ever being unpleasant."

One of the foundational writers for spy fiction, Eric Ambler still can grab you. This 1940 novel showcases his well-regarded strengths in establishing mood and building suspense around a deer-in-the-headlights protagonist.Graham is an easy-going English ballistics expert who finds his career in armaments on the upswing as war settles in over Europe in 1939. While on assignment in Turkey, he discovers himself at the center of international intrigue. Turkish agents desire to keep him alive. German agents wish otherwise. Can Graham make it back home on a clanky steamer amid a suspicious lot of fellow passengers?The opening chapter demonstrates just how good Ambler was at establishing character and setting. We see Graham in his opening moments aboard the Sestri Levante as it cruises along the Black Sea. A lengthy flashback leisurely introduces his situation, including the mystery woman he met at a nightclub and a bullet wound in his hand. "All that had happened to him was that he had discovered the fear of death," Ambler writes.This offhanded tone becomes one of "Journey Into Fear's" most characteristic features. Whether it is a Turkish ally, a German adversary, or a potential love interest, Graham's situation is met at every turn with a kind of jaded indifference that actually adds to the suspense of the situation. Ambler builds interest in Graham without much apparent effort, expending more obvious energy on detailing the people around him aboard the steamer. They are a colorful lot.Mathis is a Frenchman with socialist sympathies and a shrewish wife. JosÃ© and Josette are a couple of apparent convenience, with Josette seemingly the fairest and friendliest face to the married-but-still-interested Graham. Haller is an old German scholar who is stoic and surprisingly understanding at the hostility his nationality provokes from other passengers. Kuvetli is a Turk with a noticeable interest in showing Graham around. Mavrodopoulos is a sullen, menacing character who perversely smells of roses.At bottom, the story presents Graham as a kind of everyman thrust into a dangerous situation much like everyone else would be with the coming of World War II. "Journey Into Fear" appeared just a year into the war, the product of a time after Germany invaded Poland but before it had invaded France. There was still a notion that World War II might not be as violent as the prior world war, but Ambler seems to have known better. In Graham, he presents us with a case study for the fragility of life to come."He had to die sooner or later, and a bullet through the base of the skull now would be better than months of illness when he was old," Ambler has Graham reflect late in the book. "Forty years was not a bad lifetime to have lived. There were many young men in Europe at that moment who would regard the attainment of such an age as an enviable achievement."The book also holds its value as a suspense story, even if it is more in keeping with a locked-door Dame Agatha mystery than the sort of spy fiction presented in cinemas today. Every chapter leaves you impatient to start the next, with Graham's difficult situation seemingly becoming more hopeless by the minute. Yet there is a shaded humor around the edges of the book that keep matters from becoming too grim, whether it be the gruff ally Colonel Haki or the Mathis' stateroom arguments Graham hears behind a thin wall.The ending of the book comes with surprisingly suddenness; it felt almost too sudden. Perhaps that was because I was enjoying the story too much to want it to end. Regardless, I was disappointed by it, particularly a couple of loose ends. But it was a fun journey getting there, one I'd take again and thoroughly recommend. Spy fiction has changed a lot in 75 years, but "Journey Into Fear" remains an enjoyable hallmark.

In the 1980s, Thomas Boswell was one of baseball's most important scribes, capturing with wit and grace the sport as it underwent a Wild-West-style makeover of growing revenue, outsized personalities, and expensive free agents. Why then is "The Heart Of The Order" such a disappointment?Published in 1989 and collecting pieces Boswell wrote for the Washington Post and others from 1983 to 1988, "The Heart Of The Order" gives you close-ups of some of baseball's biggest stars and situations during the decade which introduced the sport to cocaine trials, collusion, and lights at Wrigley Field. For this, and other things, the book should be more fun than it is.An autumnal quality is apparent immediately and runs through the pages of this book. The first item, an interview with the man known at the time as "baseball's greatest living ballplayer," Joe DiMaggio, offers little substance beyond the fact that the Yankee Clipper is surprisingly modest about his long-ago accomplishments and finally content to enjoy them in public, more or less. Later pieces, particularly those in the second half of the book, spotlight other ballplayers as they get ready to say goodbye to the game after lengthy, successful runs. Some cry. Others play golf. Age claims them all.A series of short profiles on established stars and a quintet of longer pieces that sum up each season from 1984 to 1988 make up most of the rest of this book. The profiles are engaging if surprisingly shallow, testament more to Boswell's predilection for front-runners and underscoring his own relationships with them than his ability at getting something revealing.The season summaries vary in quality, with some spotlighting ephemeral social trends over the game milestones of a particular season. His 1984 write up skips over that year's World Series, for example, to question whether we have seen the end of "a decade of romantic good luck," which he spends most of the piece elaborating upon.The 1988 write-up does give you some of Boswell at his best. Writing about Kirk Gibson's famous home-run in Game One of that year's World Series, Boswell notes its growing mythic quality, such as whether Gibson really hit it with one hand and how far it travelled: "There's a palm tree, about 500 feet from home plate. If it ever dies, folks here will swear Gibson killed it."Boswell can be fun like that, sometimes for long stretches. His famous list of 99 reasons baseball is better than football is still a hoot, even if it is outdated in places. I really enjoyed his prescient reporting on the 1986 Boston Red Sox and the heartbreak he knew was coming (he even correctly identifies from where) as well as a profile on Doyle Alexander that shows Boswell smartly dealing with a more hostile interview situation than was apparently normal for him.But overall, I was too burdened down by somber retirements, painful deaths, and an absorption for left-field trivia like newfangled exercise machines and cricket. Maybe Boswell wanted to showcase his softer, sentimental side, but I found "Heart Of The Order" surprisingly hard to bear.

It is the summer of 2011. A crushing debt crisis is about to engulf America. The brightest minds on both sides gather come together to answer the question on everyone's mind: Who gets blamed?Presenting the story of the Great American Budget Battle of 2011 even before the dust cleared, Bob Woodward provides a highly-detailed, minute-by-minute account. While impartial in most key respects, this 2012 account is notable among Woodward's many inside-the-Beltway books for its tone of incredulity, as reflected in the title.Could Republicans really have stiffed an opportunity at long-desired tax reform because they didn't want to raise income-tax rates on the upper class? Were they more willing to stick it to the poor by cutting Social Security and Medicare benefits? Why didn't Speaker of the House John Boehner take an 11th-hour call from President Barack Obama if he was sincere about making a deal?Could President Obama really have thrown away a chance at a "grand bargain" out of a last-minute whim to make Boehner tack on $400 billion more in new revenue? Why did he go to the mattresses without a "Plan B" when Boehner pushed for another deal to prevent default? And why did Democratic Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid say he was willing to work on a package with the Republicans they could then take to the President if he really wasnât?The fact that everyone is party to some epic mindflusters is the ongoing theme of the book. As a series of profiles of the politically powerful, presented in stark contrast as they clash and argue, "The Price Of Politics" makes for an vivid read. As a case study in how government works, or doesn't work, it both infuriates and frustrates. Infuriates, because you see these people across the spectrum more concerned with scoring points off each other than accomplishing anything substantial and risk offending their bases. Frustrates, because Woodward himself is more caught up in detailing the ego games than the underlying issue of a nation hurtling toward bankruptcy. He doesn't really tell a story so much as summarize meetings and off-line discussions.The text gets crowded with the jargon of the moment: "decoupling," "unbalanced trigger," "firewall," "OCO," and "bonus depreciation." Woodward enjoyed access to key players on both sides, and shares their thoughts with us liberally, but a sense of context is missing. How close were the two sides, really? What was the final cost of their failure, beyond bruised egos?âThese Washington leaders were risk adverse,â Woodward sums up after 380 pages. âThere was so much effort, most of it sincere, but so little result.â I canât say I learned much more in the end than that.As usual, Woodward is writing history's first draft here. A useful exercise, but as Woodward drills down to the passions of passing moments, more ephemeral than it could or should have been.

The two best-known works by one of American fiction's least-known masters, "Miss Lonelyhearts" & "The Day Of The Locust" present a double-barreled portrait of life in a budding media age. If they put cancer-warning labels on cigarette cartons, they should put suicide-warning labels on books like this.On the East Coast, a nameless New York City newspaperman finds himself falling into a pit of despair as a "Miss Lonelyhearts" columnist, trying to offer pearls of consoling wisdom but coming up with only stones. "He had given his readers many stones; so many, in fact, that he had only one left - the stone that had formed in his gut." Trying to remove this stone with booze, sex, and Christianity only drives it deeper.On the West Coast, Tod Hackett is a scenic artist in Hollywood's dream factory, but the only dream inspiring him is his lust for a 17-year-old bit actress. She doesn't want him because he's neither rich nor powerful nor handsome, but he is persistent, and immersed enough in his sordid surroundings to mistake his rape fantasies for genuine concern.As a one-two punch, it's hard to beat this compact collection of two short novels. The one thing I might change is that they are in the wrong order. Even though "Miss Lonelyhearts" was published in 1933, and the much longer "The Day Of The Locust" six years later, I'd actually read them in reverse order. Both carry the same bleak punch, but "The Day Of The Locust" reads more like a conventional novel, with recognizable characters, settings, and a plot. "Miss Lonelyhearts" is more of a surreal depiction of philosophical despair, harder to read in many ways but somewhat prefigured by the crazed riot of people in pain that overtake "Locust" in its final chapter.I found "Miss Lonelyhearts" bracing, often powerful, yet ultimately confusing, as much in tone as in anything else; probably because I read it first."The Day Of The Locust" is the brighter gem. It presents us with Hollywood in its Golden Age, but focuses on the dregs: prostitutes, con artists, bookies, pimps, and crooked layabouts. It's a riveting read, in part for the way it refuses to give us anyone to root for and in part for its merciless depiction of Hollywood as a kind of wreck-filled ocean: "Just as that imaginary body of water was a history of civilization in the form of a marine junkyard, the studio lot was one in the form of a dream dump." Yet West's real target throughout this book is the human heart, the source of these lurid, unrealistic dreams that drive people to ruin.You want to tell yourself while reading that West was just a nattering nabob of negativism, that life can be a place of goodness and hope. Yet while you are under his singular power, you cannot quite convince yourself of this. As nihilistic probings into the heart of humanity, you can't go much deeper than these books. Or, perhaps, want to.

Edgar Rice Burroughs must have been recharging his batteries when he offered up this tired, by-the-numbers effort at jungle fantasy in the midst of his run of Tarzan novels. Tarzan is remembered for the ages. Thandar, hero of this novel, is not one to remember four minutes after finishing this.He starts out one Waldo Emerson Smith-Jones, a sickly young man sporting white ducks and a hacking cough. Marooned on an island civilization forgot, he connects with a beautiful native woman, gets tough, and finds new life as a panther-killing he-man. Can he adapt to his primitive jungleland, beat off savage adversaries, and lead his beloved back to his Massachusetts home?Actually a pair of linked novellas, "The Cave Girl" (1913) and "The Cave Man" (1917) read more like rough outlines than the more fully-formed work Burroughs made of Tarzan and John Carter. Instead of putting us in a setting rich in detail and character, "The Cave Girl" sticks us on this lush but empty-feeling island where the only humans other than Thandar and his beloved, Nadara, are nasty Neanderthals who kill on sight and utter little other than boasts and threats. Burroughs doesn't care about them; why should you?The book starts out with left-field promise. Waldo, we are told right off, is no man of brawn or action: "He had been reared among surroundings of culture plus and ultra-intellectuality in the exclusive Back Bay home of his ancestors." When Nadara first brings him to her village, to fight her burly, unwelcome suitors to the death, Waldo's understandable reaction is to run away, fast and far. It has the makings of a mildly fun Monty Python sketch.But then Waldo feels shame, and undertakes a six-month physical self-improvement regimen. "It was too much to expect, he told himself, that a man should be entirely metamorphosed in a brief half year," Burroughs writes. But thatâs what happens. No longer Waldo, he becomes Thandar, who kills easily and often, levelling all adversaries like a Conan in tattered white trousers.The book is rife with conveniences like this, such as Waldo and Nadara overcoming their language barrier in a few paragraphs, and having detailed conversations thereafter. Or the way the only protective member of Nadara's tribe stays alive just long enough to impart valuable information about the girl to Thandar; information, it turns out, that reveals her to be as white as he, and thus okay for him to love."The Cave Girl" is dated like that, and in other ways, but I was mostly put off by the formulaic aspects. You feel the scene-shifting apparatus clinking into place with each fresh chapter. Worse, what happens to Thandar and Nadara doesnât thrill. Mostly it is a repetitious series of killings, broken up by an earthquake and a pirate abduction. It's the kind of book where, when the heroine is spirited off-island, the hero sails off after her with no idea where to go, gets lost at sea, scooped up by a hurricane, and dumped on an island that, as it turns out, is exactly where he needs to be.There was a moment in the middle of the second book where it seemed the story might pick up. Thandar takes command of a tribe, and introduces the concept of ruling by consent. But this is abandoned for another cheap abduction ploy, and the tribe is effectively thrown away thereafter through another of the book's many odd, cruel twists.Burroughs never excited me, or made me care. I don't think he cared, either, and wonder whatever possessed him to come back to this Waldo and his dull environs a second time, when he was doing so well with the rest of his fiction.

A disappointing continuation of the best-selling "Killing" series of popular history books co-authored by Bill O'Reilly, 2014's "Killing Patton" suggests that the series, profiling famous historical personages and their legendary deaths, may have run its course.George S. Patton was the hard-charging commander of the U. S. Third Army as it rolled through Western Europe and helped speed Adolf Hitler's Third Reich to its doom. His style of leadership impressed some but bothered others, especially when he groused about his superiors or his Soviet "allies." So when he was fatally injured in a freak accident after the war, shortly before he would have gone home to civilian life, it had the makings of a suspiciously convenient death. At least that's the contention of this book."The two-and-a-half-ton GMC army truck that collided with the general's touring car suddenly and inexplicably veered from the opposite lane and into Patton's â as if intentionally trying to injure the general," O'Reilly and co-author Martin Dugard write. "Both the man driving the truck and his two passengers quickly vanished after the incident. No criminal charges were ever filed. No accountability was ever recorded."Was it murder? O'Reilly and Dugard suggest so, with some hedging. In addition to bringing up the famous killing methods of Soviet premier Joseph Stalin and his subordinates, they also spend quality time on the founder of the American Central Intelligence Agency, Wild Bill Donovan, who reportedly signed off on Patton's killing according a decorated war veteran who claimed to be the trigger man in a report published in the 1970s.I wasn't convinced. Worse, I was bored. The thinness of the facts presented is exceeded only by their lack of connection and the failure of the authors to present any clear, compelling reason for anyone to order the killing of a soon-to-be ex-general, however outspoken.It would be somewhat unfair to criticize wholly "Killing Patton" for floating the idea of Patton's assassination, since it doesn't spend a lot of time on the topic. This is odd since it supplies the book's title. Instead, the authors detail the last year of World War II in Europe, from Patton's perspective as well as a slew of other people, including Stalin, Winston Churchill, and Erwin Rommel. So much time is spent on Adolf Hitler I wondered whether the book started out being "Killing Hitler" before someone realized how a portrait of Hitler with OâReillyâs name over it might play on MSNBC.In earlier "Killing" books, there is a fair amount of rambling, but also a unique take on the subjects involved, call it "spin," that makes each engaging in its own way, especially âKilling Jesus.â At their best, the "Killing" books cover a lot of territory in a sharp, breezy way that grips you like a good airport read, going down easy while giving you a sense of history's sweep in motion.Here, the book pings back and forth between cock-eyed conspiracy mongering and various pieces of war narrative that never cohere, everything from Hitlerâs bunker accommodations to Eisenhowerâs mistress to Franklin Rooseveltâs famous last headache. By the end, it gets like reading Wikipedia on a tequila bender. Patton himself never emerges from beyond the famous film character played by George C. Scott; he even seems to be quoting several times from the "Patton" movie script.I wanted to like this book, if only to annoy the right people. But I couldn't. If there was a point to "Killing Patton," other than selling merchandise to a ready audience, it is not apparent.

Having focused on perpetual outcasts in earlier Albany novels, William Kennedy in his 2002 novel "Roscoe" introduces us to a powerful figure in the city establishment. Roscoe Conway has never held elective office, but very little in Albany, New York happens without his okay.Kennedy's Albany circa 1945 is a city crammed with incident. There are police shootings, bordello busts, cockfights, blackmail, bondage and all kind of corruption which Conway in his unruffled way must sort out and keep from upsetting the gravy train Albany has become for him and his Democratic Party apparatchiks. When his best friend suddenly turns up dead, an apparent suicide, Conway must work out why it happened and what it could mean for the friend's wife, whom Conway has always loved and who is locked in a custody battle for the boy she raised as her son."Roscoe" is wholly sympathetic to Roscoe's outlook no matter the graft he collects or elections he steals. Basically, we are meant to see him as a good man, "Falstaffian" as he is described on the dust jacket. Sure, he lies like the devil, but as presented by Kennedy he's on the side of the angels, or as close to the angels as it is possible to be on this earth."A lie, after all, is only another way of affirming the desirable," Conway affirms near the end of the novel. "A live lie is better than a dead truth, and there is no ultimate wall that the creative individual cannot breach through deceit."Or as he puts it earlier: "Life without gravy is not life."I wanted to like this novel more than I did. Alas, it has a few strikes against it. One is it's less self-contained than earlier Kennedy novels like "Ironweed." Much of the backstory requires knowledge of Kennedy's other Albany novels, particularly "Legs," which dealt with the life and death of 1920s gangster Jack "Legs" Diamond and who pops up here basically as a flashback device.Another, the biggest as I see it, is the story goes too far along various tangents, like the threat of investigation from state Republicans, brothers whose feud over cockfight chicanery threatens the power structure, and two police officers who have a bloody falling out. There are a slew of other minor characters who make "Roscoe" as crowded as a Dickens novel. Kennedy can't help but entertain you with all the balls he keeps in the air, but all that you really need here in the way of story is Conway's investigation of his friend's apparent suicide, Conway's working out of his feelings about the friend's widow, and his handling of the custody case of the widow's son.When Kennedy is focused on one or more of these three things, he's brilliant, amusing, and romantic, sometimes all at once. When he's filling out another corner of his Albany portrait, he's less on point.One problem that may not be a problem is the way Kennedy embraces Conway's lifestyle of "wretched excess," suggesting it is a life well-lived because it is being lived on his terms. Kennedy brings us around to Conway's way of thinking through stream-of-consciousness narratives, including a brief dream sequence that opens every chapter. You come to see Conway's point of view, even as you wonder if an author less sympathetic to it might do more to challenge it and force Conway to confront some unpleasant realities rather than reward him for his clever lies.

The final book in Bob Woodward's four-volume account of President George W. Bush's wars in the Middle East is the most disappointing, both for the story it tells and for Woodward's way of telling it.The book opens in 2006. The U. S. invasion of Iraq is going badly. More than simply kicking up a hornet's nest of terrorists, the invasion has unleashed long-festering sectarian strife, particularly between the Iran-enabled Shia and the once-dominant Sunni peoples. Years of trying to get the two sides to play nice and help beat the terrorists have resulted in more bloodshed and confusion as to what the United States wants, even within the Pentagon and the State Department. Rejecting advice to pull out, Bush opts to send more forces in for one last attempt to stabilize Iraq."I'm not a textbook player, I'm a gut player," Woodward quotes Bush saying, more than once.If there's a message in this book, and it's certainly there and all-but-underlined, it's that working from the gut is a bad idea, and sticking with that gut even worse.Woodward enjoyed decent access to Bush, which resumed in 2008 after Bush declined interviews for Woodward's prior volume. Others participated, too; many off the record. The result is a minute-by-minute recounting of key meetings, off-line discussions, and occasional heated confrontations. The idea of a surge, initially pushed by a former Democratic senator, Charles Robb, faces huge opposition not only from Congress but the military, who describe Iraq's combat-ridden capital, Baghdad, as "a troop sump" and counsel against committing what reserves they have left. But Bush takes to the idea, and drives it against fierce resistance.The story Woodward tells isn't about the surge, or its overall success. It's the process that interests him: How did decisions get made, and why weren't adjustments quicker in coming? This was the same tack he took in the prior Bush book, "State Of Denial," where it was much more effective as an indictment of overall groupthink. Here he focuses on the meetings, and the disagreements. When the surge begins to succeed, it's not so much explained as acknowledged, with caveats.What "The War Within" needs, and doesn't get, is a view from the ground in Iraq. The only time we see anything happen there is when Bush officials visit for a dunning session with Iraq Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki, and National Security Adviser Condoleezza Rice warns his fate may be "hanging from a lamppost" if he doesn't get serious. But why did the surge, basically the insertion of five combat brigades, succeed after everything tried before failed?Woodward wants to emphasize as much as he can the basic wrongness of the initial decision to go in, and Bush's failure to recognize it as such. It's hard to argue with the point of view, especially as the undeniable success of the surge in placating Iraq's sectarian strife has proven temporary. But the book doesn't really work with the open editorial slant Woodward chooses to take. It's not his style, and it shows.The result is a somewhat unsatisfying conclusion to what remains one of the most useful multi-volume examinations of a U. S. presidential administration going through "interesting times." Long after the verdict of history has been rendered, Woodward's books on Bush will provide an engaging, illuminating and sobering take on one of America's most divisive presidencies.

I know reading Shakespeare isn't supposed to be easy, but this was ridiculous.Dense Elizabethan wordplay, obscure classical references (many in Latin), a small cast of largely indistinguishable characters, and a thin plot that ends with unfunny historical-comic soliloquies and a left-field bolt of sadness, "Love's Labour's Lost" presents more labor than love, and left me lost.In medieval Navarre, King Ferdinand and three of his lords take a vow to self-improvement for three years, through study, fasting, and the avoidance of sleep and especially women. Just then a princess from France arrives with three ladies-in-waiting. Upon learning of the king's vow, the women opt to lay waste to the men's plans by making them fall in love and abandon their vow. Hijinks become more pronounced as the men undertake to hide their feelings from each other.The Signet Classics edition includes an introduction by John Arthos calling this "one of Shakespeare's earliest and happiest comedies." I get the earliest part, as it apparently was written between 1588 and 1594 and preceded only by "A Comedy Of Errors" in the output of the young Bard. But "happiest"? It's not just a downbeat ending, but the stubborn obscurity and sense of Shakespeare as a young man showing off his dexterity with verbiage rather than involving himself more viscerally in the situations of his characters.It's hard not to concur with that famous Shakespearean scholar, Roger Ebert, who in reviewing a rare film adaptation back in 2000, called this "probably the weakest of Shakespeare's plays" and concluded: "It's not about anything." More friendly scholars have noted a revue-show quality to the way the play works, its various scenes designed chiefly to amuse like âSaturday Night Liveâ blackout sketches while kicking the can of the plot a few feet further. This could be okay; the dense rhyme schemes and pleasant scene-setting offer brilliance in composition if not in structure. There are wonderful lines, like when one of the lords, Berowne, extemporizes on love late in Act IV to bring his comrades to their collective senses."It is religion to be thus forsworn/For charity itself fulfils the law,/And who can sever love from charity?"Alas, what follows in the next act makes a hash of all the good that came before. Act V, taking up nearly half the entire play, is basically where Shakespeare spins his wheels and tortures all the good will he developed, with a lot of silly word play, role reversals, and a sudden tonal shift that leads to a surprising downbeat ending where the women decide to put off the men for a year and a day to test their worthiness as mates.As one character puts it, breaking the fourth wall: "That's too long for a play!" Especially when it's now Act V, scene ii.Shakespeare wasnât always at his best in the final act; arguably âThe Tempestâ presents the biggest such letdown in his canon. This time itâs hard to be so put out given how uninteresting the storylines are. Except for Berowne and a Spanish lord Armado who makes for the butt of some good jokes early on, none of these characters make an impression. The women serve no driving purpose other than infecting their would-be mates with desire and then leaving them flat. The whole point of romantic comedy, at least this time around, seems to be giving Shakespeare excuse for bawdy jokes largely obscured by the mists of time and some high-toned ruminations about mortality that feel more labored than heartfelt, especially when used as an excuse to deny the audience a happy ending.I get that some people find this play compelling, though more for subtext than what's on the page directly. The problem is the business on the page repels all but the most ardent student from giving it the kind of chance it needs to get that subtext across. This is one play of Shakespeare's that seems unlikely to have reached us had another writer's name been on the title page.

The return in 1981 of spy fiction's biggest hero was a cause for rejoicing. But was James Bond ready for the eighties? John Gardner took a stab at updating 007, and it kinda, sorta sometimes works.The new Bond drives a SAAB, drinks Perrier, and jogs before missions. Instead of bantering with his armorer, Bond sleeps with her. His license to kill is suspended, but his old boss M makes clear he wants Bond as lethal as ever as he takes on a Scottish laird with a dangerous sideline in nuclear fission."License Renewed" was published in early 1981, just as Roger Moore had settled into the role of Bond on screen. That Bond's influence is visible here. Unlike the literary Bond Ian Fleming developed in the 1950s and 1960s, and more like Moore, this Bond is heavy on the wisecracks and getting busy with the ladies, even when locked in a cell with one. Gardner pushes technology to the forefront, like in a seduction scene where Bond's lover employs an erotic hologram to set the mood.As a story, it's less gripping than satisfying. While Gardner introduces his villains effectively at a posh horse race, there's no mystery for Bond to plum. The laird, Anton Murik, basically lays his plot out for Bond and the readers; the challenge becoming whether Bond can alert his superiors to the details of the threat."Government agencies have tried, again and again, to muzzle people like me," Murik tells Bond. "Now they deserve a lesson."To supply the suspense, Gardner gets a bit too cute. Bond has a device to signal for immediate help, so naturally loses it at the critical moment. When he goes to a phone booth, one of Murik's henchmen happens upon him just as he is about to make contact. Bond's on his own, as he should be, but more from his own incompetence. Bond's entire strategy seems to involve being captured and told what the villain is planning from the villain himself, then affecting a left-field escape or two.The pluses of "License Renewed" include Gardner's facility with the subtleties of Bond's character. His Bond is as enjoyably fetishistic about his pleasures and hidebound in his worldview as Fleming wrote him. Like Fleming, Gardner takes some engaging descriptive detours, especially when writing about the southern French city of Perpignan where Bond finds himself on the run. At times during this part of the story, the book's highlight along with the horse race, you recall that famous "Fleming Sweep," where action, real suspense, and description blend masterfully together.But the story peters out fast after that. You know that Dr. Evil line about never just shooting the hero when you can lecture him instead about the all the nuances of your diabolical plot? Well, in this case the villain even arranges for Bond to have a ringside seat. Maybe Gardner was doing his own parody?This is better than a couple of Bonds Fleming wrote, namely "Doctor No" and "The Man With The Golden Gun." The update is fun, and Bond is reintroduced effectively. The weaknesses are there, and strong enough at times to cancel some of the good feelings, but "License Renewed" has its pleasures, and like the Fleming Bonds, serves as an entertaining time capsule all its own.

In an era where organized religion is often reflexively frowned upon, it's uplifting to read a novel presenting a priest in as positive a light as "The Keys Of The Kingdom." But a heroic protagonist can also be a dull one, and too often that is the case here.From a Scottish fishing town, Francis Chisholm journeys to a Spanish seminary and then the hinterlands of China, imbued with the call of his Catholic faith and employing a non-doctrinaire approach that often draws the scorn of his church superiors."Like a blade thrust into the warmth of his life came a dread, a shrinking from that word 'religion,' a chill bewilderment that men could hate each other for worshipping the same God with different words," author A. J. Cronin writes of Chisholm.That dialectic between actively practicing a faith, and converting others to the same, while simultaneously avoiding excess zeal and arrogance, makes for the key struggle of this 1941 novel. Cronin finds in Chisholm a vessel for exploring his theme of humanist ecumenicism, and it is certainly a worthwhile subject...for a while.Then the reader wants for something of an engaging plot. What one gets instead is a series of incidents, capturing Chisholm at various points in his journey. He struggles with doubt, and with people who are at best sordid or base, and at worst outright villains with no redeemable characteristics. There are plenty of points of action, starting with a strange accident that deprives Chisholm of his parents, but the novel lacks for a compelling interior story to match it. Chisholm believes, because that's the way he is, taking terrible setbacks as welcome tests of faith. One seeking a bridge of understanding to who he is and what he's about will find it hard, even if they share his faith. All-too-often, he's too good to be true.Cronin's writing style lacks for engagement. It's very dry, reminding me a lot of Hermann Hesse on the other side of the theological divide, except of course Hesse is only readable to me via translation, where you have to allow for an etiolated quality. Cronin's prose feels like a translation in its flattish way, coming to life only when he describes scenes of natural wonder. Fortunately this happens fairly often, whether our hero is tending a garden or enduring the impact of a hellacious flood.At the midpoint of the novel, Chisholm arrives in China. Here, the story kicks into a higher gear. There's infighting with a proud German nun, and real fighting with a robber baron terrorizing the countryside. Chisholm struggles with one rich-living bishop, a childhood acquaintance named Anselm who lords over his professed superiority. Chisholm finds himself on better terms with an atheist doctor who joins him in serving a plague-infested village, and later by a Protestant couple who are as sincere in their faith as Chisholm is in his. This will go down well with modern readers, surely, but the question of why Chisholm still hangs in there as a Catholic is something for which we don't get the same type of compelling insight.It's a worthwhile novel, with an admirable message, but something seemed to be lacking for me. Maybe the various episodes described felt too much like set-pieces, like New Testament parables rather than recognizable steps on an immersive journey.

Late in this biography of Frank Sinatra's early life and career, arranger Nelson Riddle discusses his method for recording Sinatra in the studio."First, find the peak of the song and build the whole arrangement to that peak, pacing it as he paces himself vocally. Second, when he's moving, get the hell out of the way."This was good advice for everyone dealing with Frank Sinatra. As James Kaplan makes clear in this 2010 account of the singer's first 39 years, which takes you from Sinatra's birth to capping one of show biz's biggest comebacks with his 1954 Oscar win, Sinatra was less a man than a force of nature, made callous both by the circumstances of his upbringing and an unquenchable desire for the spotlight and for love on his own terms.Kaplan's thesis is that Sinatra, while honorable in intent and too sensitive for his own good, didn't really care about anyone other than himself. Even the great love of his life, Ava Gardner, whose marriage to Sinatra dominates this bio's second half, was equal parts sexual narcotic and ego sop with whom true happiness was impossible. Underneath it all, it seemed, lay Sinatra's unresolved issues with his equally vital but much nastier mother, Dolly.This reeks a bit to me of dime-store Freud, which Kaplan doubles-down on by ascribing a compulsive need for projecting toughness to his henpecked father. There are times when Kaplan gets too reductive in this way, pushing oft-told anecdotes to fit his set conclusions, and even injecting some novelistic mind-reading at points in the narrative where Sinatra clearly wasn't sharing his feelings for the record.But the pluses of this book are much stronger. For one, it's a brilliant read, sweeping you off your feet from the moment you read of Sinatra's bloody birth all the way to his Oscar-night reverie. Other reviewers note a tendency toward Kitty Kelley dirt-dishing, and they are right, but Kaplan really likes his subject, too, even with his overarching thesis being what it is. The biggest negative for me is too much Ava, although Kaplan may be just reflecting the bias of his subject.With other problem personalities, it's just a matter of it being easier to ask forgiveness than permission. But Frank didn't even do apologies."When Frank felt humiliated, his first reaction was to bark commands," Kaplan writes. "If others were humiliated in the process, all the better."I'm not quite sold on Kaplan's thesis, but it does focus the narrative quite well. The thesis of Sinatra the narcissistic user meshes with the way his career continually reinvented itself, such as the way he shed arranger Axel Stordahl - who gave the young crooner a touch of class in the 1940s but whose violin-heavy style Kaplan labels "somnolent" - for Riddle in the 1950s, who knew how to make Frank swing.This is a great book for someone laid up with a cold, and not for an insomniac, as it has the enviable but annoying habit of keeping you reading. Even the footnotes are like potato chips, as Kaplan drops fact nuggets like the fact his birth certificate has him down as "Frank," not "Francis," the latter apparently being Ava's idea. I had fun reading it, and think you will, too.

While Allied troops were landing in France in June, 1944, partaking in the greatest amphibious assault ever known, a key German unit was held up by French resistance forces and their English commando supporters. Max Hastings' 1981 account shines a light on that fight, and its terrible aftermath.The 2nd SS Panzer division, known as "Das Reich," was one of the most fearsome units ever put into combat. After years of hard fighting on the Eastern Front, where no quarter was asked or given, nor civilians respected, their officers were put out when they found themselves relieving a besieged German garrison in Tulle, a town far from Normandy. There German soldiers and French Milice collaborators had been killed by communist French partisans, the FTP. Das Reich retaliated after the town was recaptured by hanging 99 men, all but one non-combatants.Later, after one of their senior officers was captured by another group of partisans, soldiers of Das Reich moved into the village of Oradour-sur-Glane and killed every man, woman, and child they found, 642 in all, most forced to die in a church set afire.Hastings doesn't try to excuse the Germans, but he does seek to understand the motives behind these and other killings committed, many against civilians like those at Oradour and Tulle who had nothing to do with the Resistance. War is never kind; after all, Hastings asks, how could the slayers of thousands at Dresden judge those who similarly burned just hundreds in France? Das Reich was battle-hardened by war in Russia and led by men who goaded others to show as much zeal as they did. Zeal was one thing the SS never had in short supply.Finally, it was an effective means of curtailing resistance. After Oradour, the Germans didn't have to fight through the rest of France to get to the battlefield. "Painful though it may be for humanitarians to accept, a policy of unlimited repression can be formidably effective."Yet also ridiculously wasteful. One of the points Hastings raises is however much the French uprisings slowed Das Reich down, it was that same policy of unlimited repression that cost the Germans where it most counted; at the front lines in Normandy. Division elements took nearly a month getting to the front lines; Hastings' book reveals how the blade of war can cut both ways when wielded improperly."Das Reich" offers a vivid portrayal of the French side of the conflict especially, noting myth and reality where the Resistance is concerned. The book shines brightest in delineating the tensions between the communist FTP and Gaullist forces, as well as the varying levels of activity during different points of the German occupation. Much attention is also paid to the interaction by these and other rÃ©sisants with British special forces, where larger-than-life personalities weighed heavily on the success or failure of a mission.The book doesn't cohere as well as I'd like; the path of Das Reich especially is not well described. For long sections of the narrative, its progress is left untracked. Published in 1981, when Hastings had access to several SS survivors, he admits to not pressing them too hard on who was responsible for the fates of Tulle and Oradour. Understandably, he says, they weren't that forthcoming.Were the Germans wrong for doing what they did? Hastings suggests they were, if for the logistical holdup if nothing else. Looking for a more definitive moral judgment, it's a frustrating experience that way. So, I'm sure Hastings would argue, is war.

If life is a game where those who meet the most interesting people win, Dan Jenkins has been running up the score for some time. One of the most unique and recognized writers of American sports, Jenkins looks back over the decades in this 2014 memoir, telling tales that often amuse though fall short on insight.The early part of "His Ownself" is the best; writing about growing up in Texas during the Depression, a product of a broken home. Jenkins didn't suffer much, he notes, raised as he was by an extended family that included a bickering aunt and grandmother. Jenkins presents an amusing transcript of one of their conversations, complete with stage directions."If you don't like football and golf growing up in Texas, they drown you at an early age," Jenkins writes. As it turned out, those were the two sports that interested Jenkins most as a writer, becoming his main beats when he wrote for Sports Illustrated.Jenkins was one of the few writers who could talk to golf great Ben Hogan, a tough Texan if ever there was one. Jenkins devotes a couple of chapters of "His Ownself" explaining how the public misread Hogan's shyness for arrogance, and the facts behind Hogan's mythic comeback from a devastating auto accident in 1949.The negative on Hogan may have been that he spoiled golf for Jenkins when it came to anyone else. Arnold Palmer and Jack Nicklaus get positive if less starry-eyed treatments. By the time Jenkins gets to Tiger Woods, he's quite withering about golf's first rock-star celebrity, taking him to task for a phony marriage and eating Fruit Loops when depressed.Jenkins doesn't have much use for today's sports heroes, and "His Ownself" is less fun the more he dwells upon that fact. He also blasts political correctness, unleashing a few salvos in the direction of various minority groups that made for more fun when channeled through third parties in one of his Billy Clyde Puckett novels, when it could be laughed off as good-ole-boy mimicry. Here it comes across too often as a lack of caring about anyone's feelings but his own.The biggest turnoff of "His Ownself" was the feeling Jenkins, for all his access to the world of sports at its highest level, lacked for curiosity. Most sports are turnoffs for him, to be dismissed with a one-liner. He didn't even like football, at least at the professional level, saying it lacks for the passion of the sport at the college level. His short takes on various Super Bowls showcases a writer limited by his own casual attitudes, even as his humor and talent for pungent observation keep you reading.The last third of the book is the worst part, as Jenkins self-consciously drops a lot of names and quotes himself saying funny things that probably were a lot funnier the first time. He does talk about his dedication to the craft of writing, even dismissing the "casual" tag as applied to him by one Sports Illustrated editor. But "His Ownself" doesn't do a lot to buttress his claim. A good memoir provides context and a sense of personal development. Reading "His Ownself," you get the sense that Jenkins sprang from the womb with a lit cigarette and a martini in hand, asking when the next foursome teed off.I was amused, but disappointed. I suspect Jenkins fans will enjoy it, but like me will be left wanting for more.

Like a fine wine, "Proof" requires patience to appreciate.It's no thrill ride. It takes its time spinning a rather involved case. Younger readers may find it plodding, with reason, but if you are on the other side of life like me, you may find rather stirring the perspective of a middle-aged man widower who finds in a strange case involving counterfeit booze a chance for a new lease on life, even if he has to die in the process.Those expecting another journey into the lethal world of the horse-racing set when they pick up this Dick Francis novel, be advised: There's murder in "Proof," and horses, too, but the plot centers on a man with a haunted past whose involvement in a mysterious case is driven more by internal issues than anything else. Published in 1985, just after Francis had fully emerged as one of the tentpoles of his genre, it shows him willing to work away from his usual format.When we meet liquor merchant Tony Beach, he is catering at a garden party for a racehorse trainer and his wife that suddenly turns deadly from an apparent accident involving a trailer. Helping victims as best as he can, he meets a detective who eventually recruits him for help solving a case. Someone's stealing cheap whiskey from trucks, and apparently reselling it as mislabeled single-malts and premium brands. Beach knows the business, and has an educated palate. Could he help?"It's on the very edge of consultancy, and maybe beyond," the detective admits. This turns out a classic bit of British understatement.Francis works hard to bring out Beach's character, making it a story as much about him as about the case. It never becomes too closed-in, but it's more intimate than I expected. Beach's self-isolation, we learn early on, is not only the product of a lost love but a troubled childhood, of finding himself lacking in comparison to the war heroes and horse-riding legends in his family. Beach has grown up thinking himself a coward by comparison."Any son, I supposed, was loved when small, before he grew up a disappointment," Beach tells us.This basically becomes Beach's excuse for involving himself in a case that is really none of his concern. It seems to work for the story. At least it works for me.The case itself is certainly different. Francis takes us into a world of bootleg booze, where inquiries lead to out-of-the-way establishments and racetrack caterers. It's set up well, both in terms of novelty and credibility. Most important, you are rooting for Beach all the way, and enjoy looking on as he uses his observational talents to help find leads.There is suspense, and some moments of deadly action, but for the most part "Proof" is a quiet mystery. Like I said, this may not be for everyone, but it worked for me. What didn't work so well is the criminal element. They are a trifle too dastardly and thick to really work in concert with the realistic structure Francis builds around them. The chief heavy employs plaster-of-Paris in Auric Goldfinger-style.But such things bothered me more after I finished. Francis wrote his books to be read in a gallop, not a canter, and that holds true even with this gentler, less-quadruped-focused entry. I think it's a fine read, an engaging mystery, and a character study to be remembered long after the whodunit part is forgotten.

The movie "Metropolitan" has a scene where a college kid explains to someone with whom he is discussing classic literature how he never reads the actual novels. Rather, he reads commentaries about them. "That way I get the views of the novelist and the commentator," he explains.I thought a lot about that reading this 1988 examination of history's most famous execution before Christ. Make no mistake: "The Trial Of Socrates" covers the title story in depth, but the philosophy Stone draws upon, for better and worse, is most often his own.Part of the problem, as Stone points out early in the book, is no one can be exactly sure where Socrates stood, philosophically speaking. He died in Athens in 399 BC, well before the era of mass communication as Tim Rice would say, and no writings of his survive. Those second-hand accounts that do are often contradictory. Stone nevertheless comes down strongly on the idea that Socrates was an elitist enemy of democracy, and thus earned prosecution for attacking civilization's earliest exemplar of such a political order."The dominant Greek view gave dignity to the common man," Stone writes. "The Socratic view demeaned him. This was an irreconcilable divergence."While Stone doesn't come out and hail the decision to put Socrates to death ("When Athens prosecuted Socrates, it was untrue to itself" he avers), Stone nevertheless finds creative ways to blame the victim, noting for example his apparent sarcasm at trial. He even suggests Socrates tricked the Athenians into executing him because he hated their society so much he wanted to embarrass them.It all reads a bit like piling on, especially as the historical record on Socrates is not only unclear but sometimes contradictory. Some say he was an elitist, while others point to him as a champion of the common man. Both sides may have a point; playing with contradictions is the essence of a Socratic dialogue, after all. Besides, what comes across as anti-democratic two and a half millennia later might have been rather liberal then. Finally, if you are being put to death by citizens of what was then championed as a free and liberal society, maybe a little sarcasm is in order.What Stone does well in the book is use his argument against Socrates as a means of drawing you into the world of classic Greek culture. He tells a good story, from multiple angles, however fixed the perspective. I wish he had taken some time to present the basic facts of Socrates life and what is known in a detached, neutral way before jumping into the prosecution, but that wasn't Stone's approach to writing. He pushed arguments, and in a book about ideas, it's a useful means of going about it. Stone takes his point of view pretty far at times, even denouncing Plato's "Gorgias" as "poisonous nonsense." Yet he's never intemperate, and despite what some reviewers say here, doesn't push any then-modern political points into the equation.That was something that surprised me, actually, that Stone took the side of the state in one of history's most infamous prosecutions, given he was something of an underdog champion in his career. The book offers much food for thought that way, which is fine, provided you don't mind thinking about Stone's ideas at least as much if not more than you do those of the guy who actually drank the hemlock.

Marvel Comics' Conan the Barbarian character had always rested on the impact of fantastic visual presentations. This, the ninth collection of stories from Marvel's "Savage Sword Of Conan" magazine, offers some sumptuous eye-feasts but also reveals too much of a good thing can be bad for even the mightiest Cimmerian.Michael Fleisher was in his third year writing "Savage Sword" by the time these issues were originally published, November 1983-July 1984, and his once-original take on Conan was getting tired. Though Vol. 9 shows signs of fresh perspective, it also continues Fleisher's overreliance on superhero tropes and magic, not to mention convoluted storylines. Much of Conan's comic greatness had rested in the pencils of lead artist John Buscema, and four of Vol. 9's main stories include Buscema on the script side of the equation for the first time, providing plots Fleisher fleshed out into fuller stories.The Buscema-plotted stories not surprising employ brilliant visuals, like seaweed-choked ships adrift in a foggy sea, a giant vivified idol pulverizing the jungle temple where it is worshipped, and lust-filled revelers at a palace orgy presided over by an evil, nearly naked queen. With splash pages like these, you want to forgive Fleisher's tendency to lose Conan's vitality and grounded personality and lapse into goofiness.The first story, "Death Dwarves Of Stygia," presents Conan with the challenge of saving his latest woman from the clutches of an island enchantress by taking on the title characters, three dwarves that by sitting on each other's shoulders transform into a hulking djin, as well as a second magic-user who can will himself to take possession of other people's bodies. Like too many of Fleisher's stories, there's nothing organic to the story, just random encounters designed to make full use of Buscema's pen. When Conan and his woman need to be shipwrecked, why settle for a simple storm when a kraken attack will do instead?"Night Of The Rat" employs an exotic, quasi-Asian setting to good effect, and there are some good story moments mixed in that reveal Fleisher's high imagination. Here as elsewhere, the story elements often don't cohere, and there are some head-scratchers. Why would a king agree to rule under a system that places him in constant fear of sudden death, and why would a kingdom put its ruler under such constraints before he could even produce an heir?You try not to sweat stuff like that and enjoy the ride. But it adds up.There's also the reintroduction of Wrarrl, the soul-sucking humanoid with the bat-winged helm introduced in one of the issues featured in Vol. 8, back for a second crack at his least-favorite "manling." Wrarrl's a great visual but a pretty dull character, pretty much just defined by his lust for vengeance and his hunger for souls.
