As a physician, I've always enjoyed reading about the journeys that people take to become doctors. Sacks, the author of Awakenings, has written a book unlike his others. This book doesn't deal so much with his patients as it does his own life. As you can see by the man sitting on the motorcycle on the cover, his story isn't what you may expect. His recent announcement that he has terminal cancer makes the book all-the-more affecting and eye-opening.Sacks vividly describes his younger years, before medical school, where he rode his bike through California valleys, tried various drugs, and struggled with his mother's issues with his homosexuality. The scenes are brilliantly described and, at times, painfully poignant. Often lonely and nomadic, the young Sacks displays the introspective and sympathetic traits that would ultimately (I believe) push him to become a ground-breaking physician, but also damage his psyche in ways I had never realized. He struggled with being falsely accused of having inappropriate relations with patients, causing him to be celibate for 35 years, and feels slighted by peers for not supporting his writing.Overall, "On the Move" is a fascinating autobiography by one of the greatest physician authors of our time.  If this book interests you, then I highly recommend two other books by physicians. Anthony Youn's In Stitches is a riveting memoir about medical school, at times hilarious, touching, and inspired. Sampson Davis's Living and Dying in Brick City: Stories from the Front Lines of an Inner-City E.R. is a fascinating look at medical care in the inner city.
Helped clear my skin. I used it a couple times a week.

They are an interesting combination, but one that mixes well. Tony's voice has never been my favorite (too gravelly, I am more into Dean Martin) and Lady Gaga's better suited for pop music, but overall an enjoyable listen.
My kids loved it. Great progression of story and stays true to the books (mostly!)

Many of us have been there. "If I don't get into this school I will not be able to be a ----." My parents raised me this way, as have many of yours, I assume. That is the subject of New York Times columnist Frank Bruni. But does getting into that prestigious, Ivy League school really make a difference in who you will be? Will not getting into that school prevent you from reaching your dreams and potential? Too many parents (and young adults) have believed in this faulty premise, resulting in unnecessary stress, heartache, and psychological trauma.Bruni tells the stories of many young men and women who, despite graduating from 'middle-of-the-road' schools like Arizona State University, become extremely successful adults, both personally, socially, and professionally. Story after story supports the idea that you don't have to get into 'that school' to achieve your dreams. He supports this with admissions statistics and surveys and also tackles the subject of the importance of athletics and athletics scholarships in molding a young person's future. This book roundly disproves that belief that Amy Chua's parenting style in Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother is necessary to make your child successful. Far from it.I recommend this book strongly to parents of school-age children and high schoolers who are trying to decide what to do with your lives. It just may change the way you think. Reading this book made me think about Dr. Anthony Youn's In Stitches a memoir of a young man who goes through college and medical school 'mania' to become a doctor. An eye-opening and enjoyable read, especially for people interested in this subject.

This collection of essays and short stories runs the gamut from laugh-out-loud hilarious to touching to exhilarating. If you are looking for a quick, light read that will get you chuckling and spitting up your drink, this is it.My favorite chapter is called "The Original Catfish," and details how he decided to get back at some kids who kept making fun of him. At one point he's so upset at their teasing that, "I ran to the bathroom and locked myself in the stall. I cried for a good ten minutes and then took a s***. There's nothing more depressing than crying while you are smelling your own s***."Shane decides to get them back, by posing as a woman online who is interested in them. Hijinks ensue, and young Shane is then, for once, given the power to shut them down.Shane covers so many funny stories from his life, including his first kiss (at age 21 to a girl), his three year job as a salesman at a weight loss center(!), and even his experiences with astral projection.  His writing is witty, irreverent, sometimes filthy, and always inspired. I especially loved all his pop culture references, from Saved by the Bell to Gary Busey to 7th Heaven to even Sizzler and Nutter Butters.Throughout his stories, his rampant self-deprecation all-but-covers-up his underlying issues with self-image and self-esteem.  Reading "I Hate Myselfie" made me remember another book that's also about a young man who struggled with being considered different. Wade Rouse's At Least in the City Someone Would Hear Me Scream: Misadventures in Search of the Simple Life is quick, fun, hilarious, and, at times, touching read. It's worth a look if you like Shane.

I hadnât heard about Dr. Joseph Mercola until I was encouraged to read his newest book to read by another physician. For those of you who donât know, Dr. Mercola is a family physician and founder of the wellness website Mercola.com. Heâs been in the forefront of wellness medicine for years, and has written this book as a summary of his beliefs on how to be healthy. He gives nine simple rules for causing your body to heal better, age slower, and lead a healthier and happier life.Some of his rules include: getting more direct sunlight to combat Vitamin D deficiency, drinking more pure water (and avoiding sugary drinks), exercising in short bursts vs. long cardio marathons, eating more vegetables in all its forms, and eating more high quality fats (like lean meats and olives). The rules are simple, easy to follow, and (for the most part) have a scientific basis.  It truly is amazing how the foods we eat and the drugs we take can have a profound impact on our physiological well-being. However, if I had one (tiny) complaint about the book, itâs that some of the recommendations are actually too simple (like laughing).For those of you who are looking for an easy-to-read guide to living a healthy life, while limiting the use of prescription medications and avoiding environmental toxins, this is a good book for you.

Jauhar is the author of Intern: A Doctor's Initiation, a classic memoir about residency in a big-city hospital. In his latest memoir, Doctored, Jauhar is now an attending cardiologist. He quickly learns that the actual practice of medicine in today's society is nothing like he (or we) imagined that it was, should be, and could be. The issues of practicing medicine in today's rapidly evolving climate are neither simple nor have obvious answers.Physician income issues are prominent in this book. Doctors are paid less than they were paid ten years ago, causing many to even moonlight to make ends meet. The incredible advances in medical technology, which save countless more lives today than 50 years ago, also are a part of the rapid increase in health care expenditure. The reliance that today's physicians have on testing has caused many of them to lose the art of being a physician, the laying of hands to diagnose.Throughout this book Jauhar wrestles with the various complicated issues that today's doctors face in the practice of medicine like those above. With the massive overhauling of the health care system today, his book comes at a very appropriate time. Medicine is changing, whether physicians like it or not. As a practicing physician, I highly recommend this book for medical students and physicians, in addition to anyone interested in today's medicine and medical memoirs.Two other recent medical memoirs to check out are Dr. Danielle Ofri's fantastic Singular Intimacies: Becoming a Doctor at Bellevue and Dr. Sampson Davis' affecting Living and Dying in Brick City: Stories from the Front Lines of an Inner-City E.R.. They will also open your eyes to the psyche of today's doctors.

First time author Peter Levin has written an enjoyable, thoroughly engrossing novel that spans continents, generations, and major worldwide historical events.  Beginning with the murder of Franz Ferdinand and his wife Sophie, Levin exposes us to a story of intrigue, lost love, and mystery.  True events are melded with fictional ones to create a story that I found informative, fun, and interesting.  It was obviously a 'labor of love' by the author, and surprising that a book of its caliber wasn't published by a major publishing house.  But I suppose the readers are the real winners here, as the Kindle book is a real bargain.  Fans of Tom Clancy, Eric Larson, and Laura Hillenbrand will enjoy this one.  I look forward to Levin's next book!

I began watching "Breaking Bad" recently, after hearing all the praise lavished on it.  After watching the first season (short, only a handful of episodes), I'm not quite hooked but interested.  I'm interested to see how this one plays out.  I hear it gets better with each season, so I'm withholding complete judgment for at least another season. Overall, worth checking out.
No problem with this.  Put in batteries and go.  I will be using this for a long time!  Or at least until I give up my laptop for a tablet.

Is back pain all in your head?  Dr. Sarno thinks it is.  I've had back pain for years, went to chiropractor and even treated myself (I'm a physician).  Nothing has worked consistently.  Dr. Sarno wrote in this interesting book that back pain is often a physical manifestation of emotional issues, like stress.  Once you realize this, then you can start visualizing and telling your body to stop the process.  It's worked for many people.  I've been using his recommendations for many months and it seems to be working for me, too.  Fingers crossed.

"Good Talk, Dad" is a very well written book (composed in a inquire-and-respond style, like letters or emails back-and-forth) that covers many topics between father and son Bill and Willie Geist, both TV hosts and best-selling authors.  These topics range from summer camp, sex, sports, food, religion, and even (one of my favorite subjects) professional wrestling.  I found myself laughing out loud at many of the funny details of their family stories.  As both a father and son these stories really struck a chord in me.  It made me think of my own father, who lives quite far from me now.But, like life, it's not all laughs and fun.  The book does get serious and quite poignant when Bill (the father) reveals he has Parkinson's.  His tales about Vietnam were quite sobering as well, but effectively balanced out the lighter stories from Willie.  Even if you haven't seen either of the Geists on TV, this is a great book to buy for your Dad for Father's Day.  One small warning: there are a few mild off-color jokes, so be aware.This book follows in the footsteps of one of my other favorite father-son books, Sh*t My Dad Says. If you haven't read this, it's a riot.  A short, quick read, it will have you laughing within minutes.

In this book, Dr. Scott Rivkees' describes his many experiences as a resident at Mass General Hospital, possibly the most famous (and intense) hospitals in the country.  Throughout his narrative, he introduces us to many of the patients who touched him and taught him how to be an empathetic, caring physician.  It's basically The House of God for today and a great read for anyone considering becoming a doctor.  Whereas many medical memoirs are overly serious and refuse to see the light side of medicine, Rivkees deftly balances humor and seriousness, just like medicine in real life.  I really enjoyed this book and found it very hard to put down.

Dr. David Agus, a professor of medicine and engineering at USC, is also the author of the best-selling but controversial book The End of Illness.  His latest, "A Short Guide To A Long Life," is best-described as an easy-to-read, cliff-notes version of his recommendations for improving your health.  A pioneer in cancer research, his tips have a heavy bent towards preventing cancer, but also cover general wellness.  If you've read his first book but found it a bit dense, then you will gobble this book up.As a physician, I agree with most of his recommendations.  While some of his tips may be controversial, for the most part Agus stays in line with current medical thought.  Most of his recommendations aren't ground-breaking but make sense.  Drink a glass of wine with dinner. Eat cold water fish at least 3 times a week.  Practice good hygiene. Get a dog. Avoid sunburns.  Smile.  That being said, some of his recommendations regarding medications (like fat-reducing statins) should be discussed with your doctor first.Like Dr. Oz on TV (and his books), Agus does a fantastic job presenting medical advice in a fashion that is easy for any reader to understand and appreciate.  That is where this book really shines.  I plan to have copies in my waiting room for my patients to digest since it's such a quick, easy read.Another quick and extremely enjoyable read by a physician is Dr. Anthony Youn's In Stitches. This memoir shows what it's like to go through medical school and become a doctor, in eye-opening detail.  I highly recommend it for anyone interested in medicine and health.
My kids loved it.  The songs are current, and will purchase from this company again. Lyrics match songs well and kids could follow them closely.

Before watching this one, pick up the first season.  As long as you aren't grossed out by (fake) gore, the Walking Dead series are great.  Acting is superb, and you never know what happens next.  Props to the producers for not being afraid of killing off main characters.
I recently bought a karaoke machine and purchased some discs for my kids.  They really liked this one since it has some very recent hit songs.
I recently bought a karaoke machine and purchased this disc.  It has a wide range of songs that the kids enjoyed.  Recommended.

I was always a fan of Jimmy Connors when growing up.  Jimmy was, as he titles his book, the consummate Outsider.  After reading the memoirs of both Andre Agassi and John McEnroe, both of which didn't present Connors in the best light, I was very interested to read Jimmy's side of it.  This book doesn't disappoint in that Jimmy lays it all out there.  He describes his thoughts during various matches, both big and small, and his opinions of players such as Agassi, McEnroe, and Lendl.  He doesn't pull any punches, and even explains why he was the only person in the locker room who didn't clap for Agassi after his last match.  If I have one complaint about this book, it's that the writing (I assume by a ghostwriter) isn't the smoothest.  It's full of clichÃ©s and choppy sentences.  That being written, if you are a fan of tennis in the 80s and 90s, you will enjoy this book immensely.

As a physician, I'm always interested in reading books by other doctors.  Dr. Jessica Wu is a prominent celebrity dermatologist based in Beverly Hills.  I've seen her on several television programs, and thought I'd pick up this book.  Dr. Wu basically gives a very detailed description of how you can look younger, healthier, and improve your skin by changing what you eat.  She explains the glycemic index, and how eating foods too high in sugar can result in inflammation, leading to acne, dry skin, and wrinkles.  Throughout the book she includes celebrity stories, and how certain celebs have improved their complexion and appearance by following certain dietary guidelines.This book is complete, well-written, entertaining, and chock-full of useful information with a scientific basis.  I thoroughly enjoyed reading it and am going to rethink how I eat as I continue to get older.If you enjoy this book, I recommend that you consider 7 Years Younger: The Revolutionary 7-Week Anti-Aging Plan, a recent best-seller by the editors of Good Housekeeping.  It's an information-packed reference full of tips to look younger, be healthier, and reduce aging.  It's very easy to read, and a great resource.I also recommend Dr. Jennifer Ashton's Your Body Beautiful: Clockstopping Secrets to Staying Healthy, Strong, and Sexy in Your 30s, 40s, and Beyond.  It's a great guide for my women patients to be healthier, look better, and reduce their risk of age-related medical problems.  Very well-written, scientifically and medically supported information.

I was really excited to read this book, given my recent interest in The Walking Dead: The Complete Third Season.  So I tore into World War Z with a lot of interest, buying it on my Kindle and reading it on a vacation.  The first part was definitely interesting and kept my attention.  It covered the beginning of the Zombie plague, with scores of interviews from people who experienced it, in their words.  Then I kept reading and reading.The book is a collection of interviews, all about different people and how they witnessed parts of the Zombie apocalypse.  As I read on, I figured out that the entire book is interviews.  There is a distinct lack of continuity because of this.  It basically feels like watching dozens of small news interviews, where people tell their side of the story.  Because of this, it's very difficult to actually connect or care about the people in the book.  There are so many characters, that don't return, that it almost felt like reading a bunch of news reports.It got old so I quit reading.  If he had written a coherent narrative, with recurring characters, I bet I would have really enjoyed it.  Instead, I think I'll try The Walking Dead:  Compendium One.  I know the character development there is really good.  Looking forward to the World War Z movie, though.

I'm a big fan of Dan Brown's The Da Vinci Code.  I've enjoyed reading books that incorporate Christian history with adventure and mystery.  Hence, I was interested in reading Blood Gospel.  The book starts out well, with a good amount of action and suspense.  The story begins right away, with the history of Masada and the hiding of a secret gospel.  Fast forward to the present, with archaeologists and military personnel, earthquakes and priests.  Things were chugging along, very interesting and entertaining.Then came the outlandish stuff.  Hyena-people, werewolves, and priests that grow fangs.  It was too out-there for me.  Too much fantasy.  I'm ok to suspend disbelief for a while, but this wasn't what I was looking for.  If you are interested in a book that combines some historical and Biblical stories with fantasy, then this book may be for you.  I was looking for something more believable.

"Parenting: Illustrated With Crappy Pictures" is an absolute blast of a read.  For those of you new to Amber Dusick, she's a mom who writes and illustrates the wildly popular Crappy Pictures website, where she shares candid, pull-no-punches, funny stories about parenthood, complete with crude drawings.  She's taken about 30% of the classic old material from her site and combined it with 70% new material for this book.  And let me tell you: It's a hoot.I devoured this book in one sitting.  As a parent myself, the stories made me laugh-out-loud and remember those times when it seemed that poo, pee, and feeding were the three most important things in the world.  As parents it seemed our entire lives revolved around them.  I believe Dusick's stories will resonate with parents everywhere, with subjects like trying to juggle feeding an infant while eating your own dinner, sleepless nights with nursing children and snoring husbands, and trying to regain some intimacy with the kids nearby.The drawings are crude, even by South Park standards, but enhance the stories since it's obvious that the person who experienced the story is actually drawing it.  Interestingly, the drawings and stories can each stand on their own, but create such a better hilarious portrait when combined.  If you'd like to get a preview of what her style is, I strongly suggest that you check out her blog online.  You just might get hooked and keep coming back for more.Let's Pretend This Never Happened, written by the Bloggess Jenny Lawson, is another book worth looking at.  This best-seller is also based on a wildly popular blog and is a fun, fast read.  Fans of Crappy Pictures will probably enjoy this one too.

I'm a physician who's read Dr. Parnia's other book What Happens When We Die with great interest.  Dr. Parnia is the director of the Awake study, an intriguing and ground-breaking study of Near Death Experiences.  Basically, he sets up posterboards pointing upward toward the ceiling in patient rooms to find out if the people who claim to have an out-of-body experience can recall what was on the posterboards.  The idea is that some people claim to float upwards as they see themselves being worked on by the doctors and nurses, and even claim to recall actual events while they were being resuscitated.  So it makes sense then, that if this really occurred they's be able to recall what was on the posterboards pointing up at them, right?His previous book was disappointing because he was so early in the study that they didn't have results.  It was filled with filler about NDE's and various people's experiences with them.  So it was with great interest that I picked up this book, written several years later with a plethora of findings, right?? Wrong!Spoiler alert!  Although he put up 1000 posterboards in various hospitals across the country they had ZERO patients who had an out-of-body experience in one of the rooms.  Zip.  Nada.  So I felt the book was basically filled with filler about CPR, NDE's, and his personal experiences.Nothing groundbreaking here.  I'd like my money back.

Charlie Leduff is a former New York Times reporter who decided to move back home to Detroit, Michigan and become a writer for the ailing Detroit News.  This book follows his journey back to the city he grew up in, and exposes so many of the terrible things happening in the Motor City.  LeDuff follows several threads, including the city's neglect of their fire department, the Kwame Kilpatrick scandal, the Monica Conyers scandal, the killing of a local imam believed (erroneously?) to be a terrorist, and many, many sad stories of poverty and hopelessness in the city.  Throughout he intersperses personal stories and his family history.  While the stories are indeed heartbreaking, they don't come across as exploitive.  Also, LeDuff doesn't get on his high horse and pretend he has the answers.  Overall, this is a very well-written book by a reporter to reports what he sees in Detroit.  And it ain't pretty.  A must read.If you read this book, check out Andrew Moore: Detroit Disassembled for a photographic view of this broken down city.

"The Heart and the Fist" is an interesting memoir by a Navy Seal and self-described humanitarian.  It tells his story about growing up, progresses to college, then military training, and finally war.  The unique thing about this book is that he focuses on his belief that proper compassion sometimes must include use of might.  Overall, I'd say I agree with his beliefs.  The writing is crisp, yet somewhat simple and easy to read.  It's a worthwhile read for anyone interested in the military, especially the Navy.If you enjoy this book, I also recommend No Easy Day: The Firsthand Account of the Mission That Killed Osama Bin Laden, the memoir about one of the Navy Seals involved in the Osama Bin Laden raid and killing.  It's also a quick, easy-to-read book that should interest anyone interested in the military.  A more gritty read is Sebastian Junger's WAR, a journalist's view of the war on terror as fought in Afghanistan.  Both of these books are worthwhile reads.

"Living and Dying in Brick City" is an eye-opening book by Dr. Sampson Davis, previously best known for co-writing "The Pact."  In "The Pact," Dr. Davis described the bond that he made with two other kids with whom he grew up in the inner city.  They decided that they would all rise out of their difficult surroundings and become physicians, and all three have lived up to that promise.  In "Living and Dying" Dr. Davis returns back home to Newark as an Emergency Room attending physician, where he works in Beth Israel Hospital, a tough inner city hospital that sees its share of drama and tragedies.  He tells the gritty and affecting stories of many of his memorable patients.  Their stories are at times uplifting and at times sad reminders of how our society sometimes fails its least fortunate.One fascinating story involved a young man who arrived in the ER with critical gunshot wounds.  He was transported to the ICU where he died.  Dr. Davis recognized his name on the patient list as a kid who accompanied him when they committed an armed robbery at the age of 17.  Unlike Dr. Davis, who went on to success as a physician, this young man went in a completely different direction.  It's stories like these that make one realize the small forks in the road that can determine our lives.Unlike most other medical memoirs, this book also gives practical advice to people who are trapped in the difficult situations of many of the patients in his stories.  It's a wake-up call for people to learn about the difficulties and failings of health care in major urban settings.  I really enjoyed it.This book is the latest in what I consider a recent renaissance of medical memoirs.Twelve Patients by Dr. Eric Manheimer tells the stories of patients at the famed Bellevue Hospital, written by the former medical director there.  The author pulls no punches in describing these affecting and often unusual patients in sometimes terrifying detail.  Very recommended.

I watched the first season of "Falling Skies" and was hoping to watch a series that would grip my attention like "Lost" did.  Unfortunately, I was disappointed.  While the idea of the show is interesting, a post-apocalyptic world where aliens take over the earth, the execution of the story isn't necessarily riveting.  The acting is OK, scripts are OK, which combines to a so-so show.  I recommend that you catch it on free On Demand if you want to try it.Instead, try checking out The Walking Dead: The Complete First Season.  It'll grip you on the first episode and won't let you go.

Ever since the series "Lost" concluded several years ago, I've searched for another show that could grasp my attention and interest in the same intense fashion.  Until now, no series I've watched has held a candle to that classic show.  "V", "Flash Forward," "Terra Nova," and most recently "Revolution" have all failed to live up to (any) hype.  Then came "The Walking Dead."  Out of nowhere this series grips you from the first episode and doesn't let up.  It's suspenseful, harrowing, emotional, and absolutely riveting.  I can't stop watching.If you buy the first season, be warned that it's only several episodes long.  Do yourself a favor and purchase The Walking Dead: The Complete Second Season too.  You will watch these episodes back-to-back!

Written as a work of fiction, "Total Frat Move" tells the story of Townes Prescott III, from his arriving to college as a freshman and moving into his dorm room, through pledging and rush, and then becoming a college senior and fraternity star.  It's based on the wildly popular website which bears the same name.  TFM can be best-described as the newest entry of fratire, a genre most well-known by the Tucker Max book I Hope They Serve Beer In Hell (movie tie-in): with 16 page photo insert.  Fans of Tucker will most definitely enjoy this one.  It's full of drinking, womanizing, debauchery, and other pursuits that may be offensive to the timid, but a blast to read for others.  Fans of "Animal House" will also enjoy it, as it is a modern re-telling of the tale of college fraternity life.I never lived the insane lifestyle depicted here, but always envied the fraternity studs like Prescott becomes.  For that reason, I've really enjoyed books like TFM, since it opens up a world of male debauchery that I've never really experienced.  The action begins in the first chapter, where Prescott, literally six hours into his college experience, get loaded on Keystone beers and shots, then is blindfolded and brought to a massive toga party.  The chapter includes sex, drugs, and even the cops, in a story that is every college male freshman's dream (but not often the reality). Each chapter also includes anonymous hilarious photos of college kids involved in the same activities of that chapter.The writing in this book is fast, easy-to-read, and does contain a good amount of cursing.  Be warned.  Overall it's a fun read and worth picking up for anyone who's been through the college fraternity experience or wishes they would have.If you like books like TFM, I would also recommend one other that is a great companion.  Neil Strauss wrote The Game: Penetrating the Secret Society of Pickup Artists, which tells the absolutely fascinating story of how he went from being a loser with women to the ultimate pick-up artist.  It's a classic, especially for guys like me who could never figure out how certain guys are so successful with attracting women.  This one holds the key.

As a fan of Marvel comics, I was very excited to read this book.  I read most of my comics back in the 80's and have lost track with what's happened in the Marvel universe since then.  This book was helpful in informing me on major storylines, but does not give the reader insightful knowledge of the actual events in the Marvel universe. It more covers the behind-the-scenes stuff, like writers or artists coming or going.  That being said, it is a beautiful book that is great for a coffee table or to display.  As long as you don't use it to get re-acquainted with the Marvel universe, it's a great buy.I bought this book with Marvel Encyclopedia, another large, hardcover book that is great for the coffee table.  My kids really like that one.

This is a book I bought for my wife last year.  It's a great resource and coffee table-type book for people who like to travel.  Although I can say I've been to a few of these places, the vast majority of them will likely not feel my footsteps, since the locations are scattered throughout the world.  I highly recommend this book for any adventurers who are compiling their "Bucket List."  I took a few suggestions from this book to add to mine.

I purchased this so I could watch TV and scribble around on my laptop at the same time.  It has a space for a mouse, making scrolling much, much easier.  A very nice buy.  Make sure to pick up a wireless mouse with it.

I was a big comics reader when I was younger.  Although I don't read them all that often anymore, my interest in Marvel Comics has persisted into my adult years.  For this reason, I was interested in reading this book.  I remember many of the old names, not just Stan Lee and Jack Kirby.  There are significant sections on Jim Shooter, John Romita, and John Buscema, among many, many others.  The author is so complete with his research, that my only critique is that the book is quite long and maybe even over-detailed.  He mentions many of the personal issues that certain writers and artists had back in the day, and other details that may have been left out.This is a great read for the big fan of Marvel Comics.  I'm not so sure it would appeal to a casual reader, though.  If you were a big fan of Marvel comics and would like to reread some of the old books, I highly recommend that you check out some of the Omnibuses that Marvel has put out.  Here are some good ones: Uncanny X-Men Omnibus (v. 1) The Amazing Spider-Man Omnibus - Volume 2 . The Omnibuses, unlike the old "Essential" series, are in color on nice paper.  Well-worth the price.

Erio Weiner is a 'seeker.'  Although he was born into a Jewish family, he never really considered himself having a relationship with the divine.  After a minor illness lands him in the hospital, a nurse asked him, "Have you found your God yet?"  This drove him onto a journey to discover other faiths, as a way to find 'his' God.  Suffering from a deep depression, Weiner travelled throughout the globe to learn about other religions, hoping that one just might 'stick.'He commits a chapter to each of several religions, including Sufism, Buddhism, and even the obsure Raelism.  While I believe that much of his journeys are serious spiritual quests, he never hesitates to insert his self-deprecating humor into it.  Overall, I found the book to be light, interesting, but ultimately unsatisfying.  I wish he would have delved more seriously into some controversial arenas like fundamental Islam.  But the aim of the book is more entertainment than education, I suppose.If you are a seeker, I recommend that you consider reading Rob Bell's Velvet Elvis.  It's a groundbreaking book about the new directions today's Christian churches are taking.  It'll make you think.

As a physician, I often get people ask me about whether certain products they use are good for them.  Today's age of Dr. Oz remedies have caused many people to reassess whether the shampoo they use, or the toothpaste they use, can cause certain unknown problems down the line.  I picked up this book after seeing the author on a television show.  It's a fun, small tome that answers many everyday questions about beauty and health products.  There's nothing earth-shattering here, but it does answer some questions for the curious (like me).  I recommend it.

"Food, Inc." is a very interesting documentary that examines the current state of mass-produced food in today's society.  We eat every day, but do we really know where our food comes from?  This movie explores how government supported mass-produced food is making us all less healthy, in addition to negatively impacting our environment and the animals that become our hamburgers, sandwiches, and steaks.  It's an exhaustive (but not exhausting) documentary that should be viewed by everyone.  My only complaint is that the movie could have been edited a little bit, as it got a tad long in the end.If you enjoy this movie, I strongly recommend that you read Fast Food Nation.  This fascinating book details how today's fast food marketplace is corrupt and destroying people's lives, in more ways than you may know.  McDonald's is the main culprit here.  Strongly recommended.

I'm not sure what all the fuss is about.  All the nurses at the hospital love this book.  It was all the talk in the hospital for weeks.  So my wife read it and couldn't finish it.  I thought I'd pick it up, and it definitely wasn't for me.  The writing isn't polished, and I'm not into the S&M stuff.I do give her props though.  In a very difficult book-selling world, she has sold a ton of books and helped keep my local bookstore in business.  That definitely means something!

"On Call" is a very good memoir about residency by Dr. Emily Transue.  As a physician myself, I found that it faithfully depicts the world of the resident with meaning, empathy, and compassion.  The patient stories are interesting, including both good and bad medical decision making.  The reason why I don't give this book five stars, is that it seemed to be missing something. It's a solid read, but not an instant classic, like some others of the genre.  I give this book a good recommendation for anyone who is considering becoming a doctor.If you are considering buying this book, I would also highly recommend two others that do have that extra special 'something.'  Complications by Dr. Atul Gawande is a classic set of essays by one of the best medical essayists ever.  It's a must read for anyone interested in the surgical profession.God's Hotel: A Doctor, a Hospital, and a Pilgrimage to the Heart of Medicine is also a very worthwhile read for anyone interested in the medical profession.  It's poignant, heart-breaking, and gives a sense of what medicine was and could have been.  A great read.

I read this book on the advice of a friend.  Now, I'm a happily married professional, but had heard that this book was fun.  I bought it used off Amazon, since I didn't want to spend the money on a faux-leather version of it.  I found the book to be a very interesting read.  It tells the story of Neil Strauss, a ghostwriter and magazine writer, who never had a way with women.  He decided to look into the underground world of pickup artists, and eventually transformed himself into Style, one of the best pickup artists in the world.  He gives the juicy details behind his encounters with normal women and celebs like Courtney Love and Britney Spears.  I wish I would have had a book like this when I was much younger.  It gives pointers on how to talk with women and meet them in bars.Overall, though, it's an eye-opening look at how well-educated men can use tactics of manipulation to get women to sleep with them.  You may not like what they do, but apparently it works.  Not that I would know.If you enjoy the Game, then I recommend that you read Tucker Max's I Hope They Serve Beer In Hell (movie tie-in): with 16 page photo insert.  He's a womanizer like Strauss, but never realized that there is more than just the hook-up.

PHI is a wonderful book by Giulio Tononi that explores our consciousness.  Told as a story with Galileo as the main character, PHI reveals the secrets behind our consciousness, as if exploring unknown worlds.  Along the way, Galileo meets many wise people who explain to him the origin of consciousness, how our conscious mind works, what happens to our consciousness while we sleep, and even explores the question of whether animals have conscious minds like humans.The biggest surprise in this book is the multitude of gorgeous painting, photos, and images spread throughout.  These images really make the book stand out from anything I've read recently.  As a physician, the anatomy lessons brought me back to my neuroscience course in medical school, and the many paintings harkened back to my art history classes back in college.  This book was an education and an absolute gem.  I highly recommend it for anyone interested in how our brain works and the origin of our consciousness.

I'm not a financial person.  I handle the finances of my family and am a medical professional.  Since Lewis is the author of The Blind Side (Movie Tie-in Edition) and Moneyball, I thought I'd be able to follow and enjoy this book.  Instead, I found myself confused.  The Big Short deals with mortgage bonds, credit default swaps, CDO's and many other financial terms that I had never quite understood.  Although I understand them better, I had a hard time getting through this book.  In fact, I stopped at page 181 and gave up.Maybe I'm not as smart as most of the people who read this.  Maybe it's just that I'm not in the financial industry.  I wouldn't recommend this book for anyone who's a layperson when it comes to Wall Street and the financial markets.

The Magic Treehouse series is a series of books that each focus on a specific historical or mythological subject.  It's been great at teaching my kids to read and also instill a love of learning new subjects.  Through the Magic Treehouse series, my kids have learned about Abraham Lincoln, Leonardo Da Vinci, and Thomas Edison.  It's all put together in easy-to-read stories with suspenseful chapters.My kids liked this one, although it's probably not as great as some other ones, including Magic Tree House #35: Night of the New Magicians (A Stepping Stone Book(TM)), which was my favorite.  Already looking forward to the next one!

I'm a big fan of Saturday Night Live, especially the era when I grew up in the 80's and early 90's with Dana Carvey, Jon Lovitz, Phil Hartman, Adam Sandler, and Chris Farley.  I really enjoyed a lot of the insights in this book about all the backstage goings-on at this amazing show.  This book was written as a series of quotes from various performers and writers involved with the program.  Because of this, the narrative was somewhat disjointed, and never achieved a level where I just couldn't stop reading.  I found myself skipping sections from writers whom I had no idea who they were.There is a lot of good information here, but like shopping at T.J. Maxx, you have to sift through the unnecessary stuff to find the occasional gem.This book reminded me of the very similarly written book by former NBC President Warren Littlefield Top of the Rock: Inside the Rise and Fall of Must See TV.  Both are written as a series of quotes from many interviews, and suffer similar faults (in my opinion).  However, if you are into the backstage dealings behind these shows, then these books are decent reads.

I was very interested to read Zuckoff's "Lost in Shangri-La."  I'm a sucker for non-fiction accounts about people doing things or surviving experiences that are foreign to me.  For this reason, I picked up this book with a great deal of excitement.  I was sorely disappointed.I was looking forward to reading about how a group of plane crash survivors braved through a foreign jungle, fighting animals and cannibals, to eventually make their way back to civilization.  The reviews and book jacket made it read like a thrilling adventure in the heart of the jungle, with lots of action and suspense.  What I got was something much different.Spoiler alert!  Do not read on if you don't want some of the book spoiled for you!The survivors don't have to trek that far before they make it to a clearing. They basically stay there until they are rescued.  The natives are not restless, nor all that cannibalistic.  Basically, they are simple, kind people who take an interest in helping the survivors.  They are eventually rescued by a daring glider-related escape.  This was one of the only truly entertaining parts of the book for me.TThere was also too much background information on people that didn't need to be told.  We didn't need to know all the background info (birthplace, former jobs, marital status, etc.) on the press corps that covered the story, or other characters that weren't survivors.  I ended up skipping through much of it to get to the end.If you are really into true-life adventure stories, I highly recommend that you check out Jon Krakauer's books Into Thin Air (Turtleback School & Library Binding Edition) and Into the Wild.  They are gripping, tightly told, and exhilarating reads.  Another interesting read is The Lost City of Z: A Tale of Deadly Obsession in the Amazon, about a man who journeys into the Amazon.  I recommend these much more than Zuckoff's book.

Monkey Mind is a memoir written from a person who suffers terrible anxiety.  Although I'm not a really anxious person, I'm a physician who treats many anxious patients.  Reading this book gave me some insight into how some people really suffer from anxiety.  The inability to react calmly in situations that others might just blow off was eye-opening to me.  Overall, a well-written book filled with self-deprecating humor.I enjoy reading books where people can poke fun at themselves.  For this reason, Drop Dead Healthy: One Man's Humble Quest for Bodily Perfection is a great companion to this book.  Man Made: A Stupid Quest for Masculinity is another recent funny one.  Stein, a writer for TIME, may be the best writer today at self-deprecating male humor.

"Twelve Patients" is an engrossing book written by the former medical director of Bellevue Hospital, one of the most famous (and oldest) public hospitals in the country. Manheimer details the lives of several of his most interesting patients, in often lurid and terrifying detail.  He pulls no punches in his descriptions of these patients, and doesn't flinch in his portrayal of the often depressing social situations involved.  Many of these patients have tragic background stories that have lead them through the doors at Bellevue, sometimes their only refuge from horrific circumstances.  Through these stories, Manheimer also tackles the subjects of hospital politics and our country's broken healthcare system.As a physician I found his book fascinating and truthful.  Those of us in the medical field all have our own stories of patients who've left their marks on us, some good and some bad.  Manheimer's great strength is that he doesn't try to sugarcoat the stories or his feelings about his patients.  One patient was described as "evil."  How often have you read a book by a physician that described a patient this way?Medical memoirs appear to be in a renaissance.  Manheimer's book joins several recent physician memoirs that I've really enjoyed.  The most recent one, God's Hotel: A Doctor, a Hospital, and a Pilgrimage to the Heart of Medicine is a fine read that really gets to the heart and soul of medicine.  It's touching and thought-provoking.Confessions of a Surgeon: The Good, the Bad, and the Complicated...Life Behind the O.R. Doors is a controversial book where a surgeon reveals his true feelings about his field, good and bad.  After reading this book, you may not like the doctor, but you'll see his point of view.  I highly recommend all these books for anyone interested in medical memoirs.

I just finished reading Ready Player One and absolutely loved it. The book is a definite departure from anything I've read, probably since Cormac McCarthy's The Road (Oprah's Book Club). I really enjoyed both of these immensely.Ready Player One follows the story of Wade, aka his avatar Parzival, a video game playing nerd who spends most of his life in the Oasis, a virtual world of the future. Young Wade, like many of his peers, spends more time in the Oasis than in real life, since in the Oasis he's not an unpopular and poor nerd, but a somewhat powerful virtual being.Parzival then undergoes a quest for treasure, that takes him on many twists and turns, including falling in love with another avatar whom he's never actually met in real life. The book contains tons of references to movies, video games, computers, and television shows from years ago. Some of these had previously been lost in the back reaches of my memory, like the old Ultraman Japanese TV show.If you were a computer and video-game playing nerd like me, then you will love this book. It's a fast, fun read that is completely unexpected. I look forward to a movie adaptation.

The Tarascon Pocket Pharacopoeia is a must buy for all medical students and residents.  It is a guide to all the major medications on the market today, and a great quick reference for both trade and generic names.  I bought this as an intern and used it virtually every day.  It's very easy to look up any medication to see the dosing, other names, and category it fits into.  As a practicing physician, I use it every day even now.  Very highly recommended.The other handbook that I recommend, that fits great in your pocket is The Sanford Guide to Antimicrobial Therapy 2012 (Guide to Antimicrobial Therapy (Sanford)).  This is a great guide to antibiotic dosing and choice.  I have used this nearly every day both as a resident and practicing physician.

These sunglasses are super cute and unbelievably lightweight. When you open them, you'll definitely have a hard time believing that they are wooden because of their look, feel and texture. They have that classic 1985 look that all the hipsters will love. They'll go great for just about any outfit and have lenses that are dark enough to block out not only the sun but the haters too. I'd definitely recommend this to any of my friends to purchase to complete their retro style and make them look simply fabulous.Lightweight, comfortable and cute! What more could you ask for?I purchased this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review and opinion.

This thing looks like a space alien but it runs like a dream so I named it Magic Mike and it has it's own compartment in my vanity now. It's made of see through, soft jelly like latex for ease of use and is a good job for toy beginners or old pros. It's just for the G-spot, so don't throw away King Kong just yet, you're going to need that later. This bad boy is completely waterproof (as I would imagine it would have to be) so you can take it in the shower with you. This massager takes one AA battery and the bottom screws onto it where you can switch it on and off. It's pretty flexible and works great, but don't over do it or the next thing you know your old man is writing reviews on it warning men to ration your usage. Just sayin'.I purchased this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review and opinion.

I have style A. First of all, for a dildo, this thing has some pretty bitchin' bling on it so my handsome new friend gets an A+ for presentation. It's a pretty typical rabbit, with the clitoral stimulators at the bottom and a rotating beads on the inside for a double your pleasure free for all. It's made of silicone so it's waterproof EXCEPT for at the bottom - that 36 frequency switch will not take immersion of any kind, and since it charges by USB port for convenient internet porn viewing, it's probably not a good idea to get it too juicy or you might get a vibration you won't enjoy.I purchased this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review and opinion.

For a seven inch toy, this thing is a classy little beast. It came in a nice box to start with and didn't have a rubbery odor when I opened it. It's not veiny and gross like some vibrators that I've seen. It's nice and smooth and conforms nicely, but the shape can be slightly intimidating although the soft casing is a plus. The bottom piece snaps off easy and the vibrator takes 2 AAA batteries. I like that it's quiet, but some of the settings are louder than others. The power button is on the end so it's really easy to switch modes. Overall it's a good piece, and definitely something I would give to a lover as a gift or buy for myself in a store.I purchased this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review and opinion.

This is a great product for hands free use while travelling. It's easy to setup and use. I'd recommend this product for anyone who spends a lot of time in their vehicle while also making lots of phone calls. This will keep you safer out there while driving and taking care of phone calls.I purchased this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review.

I like this temperature probe because it's easy to use and the display is easy to read. It has a simple, four button interface with temperatures reaching up to 527 degrees Fahrenheit, so it is a suitable thermometer for high temp projects like making candy. It has a control switch from Fahrenheit to Celsius and a "hold" button, as well as button for controlling the minimum and maximum temperature that the thermometer needs to reach. The probe comes with full battery and a lifetime guarantee, as well as a simple case to keep it from getting banged around in the drawer.I purchased this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review and opinion; these thoughts are completely my own. No compensation was given for writing this review or providing a rating.

My a-hole cat gets litter everywhere and while I suspect he's doing it on purpose, I hadn't found a good way to stop him till this bad boy showed up. The mat is huge - about 36x24 so it fit very well leading up to the covered box with the lip just underneath.The Ultimate Large Cat Litter Mat went right under the box and immediately in the box went the cat. He sprayed his litter out of the box and anything that landed on the mat was trapped right away. He scratched at the litter on the mat and got upset when the litter stayed so he pissed on it and I had to take it out to clean it. It was easy to clean, I just hosed it off and it didn't hold the spray odor. When I replaced the mat by the litter box, the cat tried to paw the mat away from the box and couldn't because of the heavy rubber backing that's on it. After hours of scratching at the mat he finally gave up and went away, and the problem has been solved!I purchased this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review and opinion; these thoughts are completely my own. No compensation was given for writing this review or providing a rating.

SUPER CUTE! I wanted all of the designs but I only got these. They're a bit hot right now, considering that Florida is not participating in Fall, but I strapped them on underneath a mini skirt and off I went. They did not distort or become misshapen like I thought they would and they were of good quality material. I love the thigh high look without all of the pain in the neck rolling down.I purchased this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review and opinion; these thoughts are completely my own. No compensation was given for writing this review or providing a rating.

This is a great toy. The controls are a bit difficult to get used to, and it would behoove you to learn to fly it before you decide to take it out anywhere. It has a good range on it, 30-50 meters and it didn't take too long to charge, although the longer I have it, the more time it takes to charge and the less time it will spend in the air before it starts to droop. Once you get used to the controls however the real fun begins and you can teach the drone to do tricks and flips.I purchased this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review and opinion; these thoughts are completely my own. No compensation was given for writing this review or providing a rating.

These flashcards came right on time! My child is currently studying multiplication and it's been a long haul to get the little one's memory to retain it all. We went through them once and separated the unknown answers from the ones that were well recited and put them on the two rings. After a couple of nights of drills, the answers started to sink in and things are looking up! I like that they are covered in plastic, and the rings make them easy to use.I purchased this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review and opinion; these thoughts are completely my own. No compensation was given for writing this review or providing a rating.

This is a pack of assorted temporary tattoo arm sleeves. They are easy to put on and will be a great addition to the kids costumes this year for Halloween. I may even wear them to work just to see if anyone says anything or notices, lmao.I purchased this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review and opinion.

This is going to make the perfect present. It's actually larger than what I was expecting and is soft and cushy.This product cracks me up really and is pretty hilarious in its self. A happy pile of poop. haha this will for sure be a great way to tell some one what you think of them or that they are full of poop. Imagine receiving this as a present on your birthday, or maybe on your anniversary. Would you laugh or be mad? I can't wait to see the look on my daughters face when she opens this for Christmas!I purchased this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review and opinion.

This selfie stick is great for capturing those moments of self that no one else seems to be good at getting. I gave this to my daughter who said that she liked it but the connector was not recognized by her device so that made it difficult for her to use it. She ended up putting the camera on voice recognition and it seems to be serving its purpose.I purchased this product at a discount in exchange for my honest review and opinion.

This is a very nice cell phone case and wallet. It has a professional look and feel to it that gives you and your phone a touch of class while also being practical in its usage. The Dansk Lenox Dipping Bowls have me seeking an Around the Table Dinnerware set at a reasonable price. One creamer tub definitely isn't enough, your personal preference will tell if 4 is too many. You'll need more than one to savor the seasonal goodness of Pumpkin Spice. Your taste buds will definitely tell you "more IS more".  I enjoy Coffee-Mate's various flavors, especially those that don't require refrigeration. This flavor is my seasonal favorite. Although pleasant, it's not one I enjoy year-round. This  is great for the cold weather and melds beautifully with the traditional Fall season aromas.It makes my cup of coffee very satisfying  without needing a slice of pumpkin pie with oodles of whipped cream and the calories. It screams THANKSGIVING to me. I just prefer the pump version to minimize shipping leakage and sticky messes.Psst... I use 2 - 3 tub in a 10 ounce cup of medium roast coffee.

This manufacturer's products reminds me of home remedies my granny would concoct. They're readily available, effective, easy to have on-hand and give with the kid-sized syringe. Many brand name cold formulas are re-formulated to decrease/eliminate ingredients in liver damage or minimize addictions. Things I thought were perfect for my babies, kids and adults weren't. It's difficult to feel comfortable with BIG companies' brand name cough and cold meds that have changed, been removed from store shelves or placed behind the druggist' counters because of ingredients that can cause side effects.When I think of my reliance on those popular brand name cough and cold formulas during my kids' childhood, I'm wondering what their future holds in their later adult years. I feel more comfortable for this generation of parents having broader access to homeopathic options that are effective for the kids, comfortable results and the peace of mind for all involved.

Pleasant sheet set for a few reasons: * Softer and nicer than expected for a 200 thread count, * Elegant, yet hip, neutral color for a stylish inviting bedroom, * Deep pockets to accommodate thicker mattresses and mattresses with toppers, * Similar to the cotton poly-blend sheets I grew up with that were handled gently in the washer and dryer to extend the life of the sheets and minimize pilling due to broken threads - double-digit years of enjoyment IS possible.

The fragrance is off-putting. I've resorted to using this for my hands as I put them in my gloves. It does soften my hands, makes the backs look better than usual, but they're not glowing. The LÃ³real quality is there but I'm not about to put it on my face and smell it contiually.

These small, round, tasteless, softgel capsules are easy to swallow,  and cause no tummy upset. These help me keep my Vitamin D levels up after being on prescription strength at 50,000 IU for 12 weeks. A bone density test showed I have the precursor to osteoporosis, called osteopenia. Besides a calcium rich diet, strength bearing exercise - walking 20 - 30 minutes daily and my D3 supplements, I'm expecting to be in great shape at my next physical.Although increased use of sunscreens on a daily basis via cosmetics and skincare products is a suspected cause for low vitamin D levels, I still use them because I've had a skin cancer removed and must use SPF daily year-round.

This calms the baby's cough and allows them to rest and get well. It's not a magic bullet for those that believe an antibiotic is the only thing for a cold. This cough syrup seems to let baby's own body weather the cough and cold that's a precursor to ones that will come through their lifetimes.

Absorbent and great for cleaning, washing, drying items without shedding lint. I've been using these mostly in the kitchen because the color blends with current accessories.  They do a good job and are much better than my old-fashioned style ones.

I've been experimenting like many others searching for something other than medication-combos the doctor prescribes to make peace with my digestive tract. I've had many of these same issues since childhood even when we ate few meat products and items from our family gardens. I've been trying different food combinations, eliminating foods etc to find a solution. Now I'm looking to probiotics to allow my body to do what it was created to do properly.  There are many available from various manufacturers, Viva Labs version has done me well without stomach upset or issues.My digestion has improved from top-to-bottom. I imagine little colonies of gut flora flourishing as I continue including these probiotics in my regimen to treat the root cause of my digestion issues vs. symptoms does better for me.

Portable, well tolerated, easy to prepare and feed infant cereal. It can be mixed with breast milk, formula or suitable liquid you choose. The apple ingredient appeals to the little ones and saves blending in applesauce.

I've used Hefty's smaller-sized freezer bags with excellent results, including washing and reusing without the seal or slider failing after 2-3 washes/ re-uses. The stomach distress and frequent bathroom trips did help me jumpstart my weight loss. It's made me food adverse and on the lookout for restrooms. If you want to try this, I'd do it on a SLOW weekend so the side effects don't ruin anything you planned accomplishing.

Soft as a favorite cotton tee shirt, almost as comfy as when your little one nestles on your chest; just without your heartbeat and warmth. Washes well and doesn't break the bank.

The author began one of the most honest dialogues about the work and family lives of superwomen; those women who dream/work toward having careers, marriage and families in a magazine article. That article triggered social media conversations, barrages of sharing and discussions in AND out of the workplace for men AND women. These undies fit well whether I'm on an exercise OR eating binge. They are soft, comfortable and hold up well to either hand washing or the gentle/delicate washer cycle. I treat them well like my Victoria's Secret undies without being tangled up with regular laundry loads; shortening their lifespan & mangling the elastic. These razors do their job very well. The lubricating strip, triple blades, and curved handle with rubber hand grips do deliver closer shaves without many nicks. The only thing I'd suggest is a pivoting head that hugs the curves of my legs and knobby knees better than most fixed head razors. All the same qualities outlined with the addition of the floating head would get a 5 star rating.The cost for the eight pack with the smooth, comfortable shave will keep me away from the bargain packs in the men's aisle at my local stores.

After telling a nurse at at my doctors office I'd been using pure aloe gel followed by CeraVe moisturizing cream to soothe dry irritated areas, she let me try a bit of her Jason's lotion. I was happy I could get the creamy, soothing results with the convenience in ONE step from a tube I can keep in my backpack or purse  without having to wait until I get home to apply my version of a soothing remedy.She warned pricing could be steep so look around at local health food stores and some supermarkets for it and the sales. However I came to trusty Amazon and saw the 3-pack cheaper than any local or online sales.  I'm super glad I did!

Completely assembled on arrival, ready to go, generates enough comfortable heating for the 600 square foot open studio with high ceilings. The wheels allow easy movement to areas of the studio. This easily replaces the usual space heaters that seem as though they'll tip over when bumped. With rambunctious pets around, this is a sturdy and safe alternative.Temperature precision isn't high on my list of priorities, feeling warm and comfortable is!  It looks nice and meets my needs. There's even a remote control when my couch potato vibe takes over.

Newest addition to the family, Pappy, is a rescued stray older Papillion recovering from significant dental surgery provided by the Humane Society. The brand name food samples provided by the local shelter were his recent diet there and highly recommended. He wasn't impressed and I was distressed because he wasn't eating and losing weight. His mouth was still tender and refused to let anyone near it.I fed him home cooked food, wet food and wet food mixed with kibbles to get him to eat and regain some of the weight he lost since dental surgery.  I jumped at the chance to try the 4 pound sample of  Wellness CORE Natural Grain-Free Dry Food. It's made in the USA, has an excellent positive record without recalls which put my mind at ease.The vet recommended keeping kibble in Pappy's diet despite the number of teeth removed to preserve the few remaining ones. She recommended the same brand name food the shelter uses that Pappy doesn't like. This made trialing a sample a win:win for us both. Pappy LOVES these kibbles dry or mixed with wet food. He eats heartily without digestive issues, his demeanor is upbeat as he regains his health. I can't ask for much more than that.UPDATE: I really like the small triangular kibbles. I use them as training rewards as well as hiding a few in his toy box to keep things interesting. Pappy is having fun too :)

Too often the clothes for husky boys and girls make them look like a sack of potatoes. I'm happy to say these fit nicely and the waist with it's elastic inside doesn't embarrass the kid like the full elastic waist clothes usually made for husky kids. The stylish loose fit and dark indigo wash without the visible full elastic waist was a hit. I'm officially a fan of these jeans!

THIS Lightening wire seems more reinforced at each end than the standard Apple item that came with our iPhones. We seem to be rough on these cables and they're usually shorted out or fritzy needing a duck tape bandage (#CableShame) within 6 weeks. Resorting to the cheap replacements that are equally as short-lived is no remedy. Only problem is when we DO get a sturdy one we can't remember where we got it.  Our motto is "you can't have too many iPhone lightening wires for car, home etc..."So far so good, I'll keep you posted if this cable is wearing a duck tape bandage and my #CableShame is eliminated.

I really do enjoy seeing the little ones interacting with LeapFrog books and technology. I consider it an interesting add-on to supplement regular pen & pencil learning and training NOT a replacement for it. WHY? I 'm a former teacher and retired corporate technical manager. I can see  the difference between the kids who are Think AND Do-ers vs. Thinkers; it rarely changes as they become adults.  The ability to think, imagine, understand, analyze, problem-solve and think critically are essential for kids' longterm success.That being said I think the LeapFrog products in general, this one in particular are entertaining, enjoyable, educational. I only hope parents don't take the easy way out but include these items in a well rounded educational experience filled with various activities. I do use the Leapfrog products with the little nieces & nephews to stimulate interest when the not so fun parts of real reading and writing are upon us. They notice a difference at the library when the books are not LeapFrog and their brain is working a wee bit harder. Yippee!

Reasonably priced item that does it's job, doesn't appear flimsy compared to many surge protectors on the market. I use surge protectors to protect and control various bundles of tech equipment and/or appliances. I can shut each surge protector down when the items are not in use in fell swoop per surge protector. Take that you vampire electric blood suckers!It can be a pain restarting some equipment, yet I do see some small energy reductions that make me more mindful of utility usage and costs. It's worth it to my budget.

Wonderful option for personalizing  tags for upcoming flea markets, tag sales and holiday celebrations; Useful with inkjet, laser printers or old-fashioned handwriting. With the pre-punched holes, adding your own flair couldn't be easier with your  own style/colors of twine, ribbon, wire etc. Sure beats my old trial-n-error (emphasis on error) method of using blank index cards to complete the deed without a template etc.

Sooner or later most of us gals have urine leakage concerns as we age, have surgeries or after we have kids. We look for alternatives that solve the problem, fit our lifestyles and improve our quality of life too. This product can be an option. However there are some background concerns to understand BEFORE you even venture into determining IF Poise Bladder Supports are an option or this sizing kit is for you.1. ONLY for urine leakage due to stress urinary incontinence - your oopsies occur when you laugh, cough, sneeze, dance, exercise2. NOT for urine leakage due to sudden need OR rush to urinate - called urge urinary incontinence.3. NOT recommended if you have BOTH urine leakage concerns.IF stress urinary incontinence is your only concern - item 1 above THEN you may want to try this sizing kit. * Do note that the supports can be used only EIGHT hours of each 24 hours. figuring out how to cover the other 16 hours with pads or special undies is still a concern for me. * The Poise Bladder Supports are inserted into the vagina like a tampon via a plastic applicator. This sizing kit provides an opportunity to find your size on your own. Pretty easy to begin with the Low, move to the Medium or High until you find your comfort level as needed * There are a slew of concerns and medical conditions under which usage is discouraged. I'd recommend discussing this product with a doctor to explore the options available that address your concerns, fit your lifestyle and improve your quality of life *

Reminiscent of earlier times when brown paper wrap was the norm for wrapping packages that were processed by hand at local post offices. These tags make me smile with nostalgia as they now get used for tag sales aka yard sales and garage sales.  I prefer the pre-wire convenience over  the stringed version.

Great as a lap pad for babies, kitties and puppies. These pads are the new improved version the old-fashioned ones had the waterproof layer exposed without the thin soft quilted layer for comfort. The baby isn't in direct contact with the waterproof layer. The thinness makes it an easy to wash and quick dry item. What's not to like?

I really like and appreciate re-positionable "stickies" that don't mar the surfaces where placed. No matter how much I plan before placing them, I always find another place or two that seem better.
