"Beyond No Mean Soldier" by Peter McAleese (Oct. 2015), paperback, nice high-quality glossy 287 pgs; publ. by "Helion & Co. Ltd." and "GG Books UK" in England. In a note apparently from the publishers, this book is a "completely revised and expanded edition" of his 1993 classic "No Mean Soldier".  This book is essentially the author's biography with many photos of himself in various military-attire settings.The author was born  on 7 Sept. 1942 in Glasgow, Scotland..  At 17, the author joined a Parachute Regiment in March 1960 for a nine-year hitch.  Two years later he joined the SAS (Special Air Service) and went for jungle training in Malaya, and later trained with U.S. Special Forces at Ft. Bragg, NC for HALO training.  During that service he was off-and-on stationed in Aden, Cyprus, Borneo, & Guyana, and provides interesting insights into his tribulations in becoming an exceptional paratrooper.After retiring from the British Army, in 1977 the author joined the Rhodesian army, and in 1980 the South African army.  The author discusses his reasons in fighting for these white-minority regimes:  to oppose the communist-oriented groups interested in taking over these countries.During his African service, he recounts his military shootouts with FRELIMO, ZIPRA and ZANLA units.  He provides MANY very descriptive details of his engagements, which are not for the faint-of-heart.Leaving the South African army in late 1981, the author joined a private-security firm, engaging in protective services in that country.  The author provides many informative insights as to how South Africa's lifestyle changed as white-rule there transferred to a black-majority democracy.The author provides a very bull-dogged recovery story after a May 1984 a parachute jump left him with broken bones throughout his body -- it took several years for him to recover well.The author provides a very informative look at a private-security job in Columbia to attack a drug cartel in Casa Verde in late 1988, but the mission was cancelled.  Several months later, he returned Cali, Columbia to hunt down the drug king: Pablo Escobar (chapter 12).  The author goes into great detail in explaining his preparations in attacking Escobar's well-guarded villa, but while flying in on the initial assault, the pilot of his helicopter flew it into a fog-drenched mountain; again, the author suffered more broken bones, and the mission had to be cancelled.  The author displayed grime determination in making another long recovery to walk and work again.In 1991 the author published first book: "No Mean Soldier".  A couple of years later, the author landed a job with a Russian private-security firm, where he recounts what it was like trying to avoid encroaching on Russian Mafia businesses.You have seen many biographies with wide margins and large type with much spacing between sentences.  Well, in this book, there are almost 500 words on EVERY page!A most impressive read; I highly recommend this book to anyone interested in military adventure -- especially the harrowing life of a "soldier of fortune" as was the author's.

"PT 109" by William Doyle, (Oct. 2015), 330 pgs.This book immediately conjures up a comparison with "PT 109" (220 pages) written by Robert Donovan in late 1961.I remember reading that book in 1966 and wrote to Mr. Donovan in my search to learn whether or not he had addresses of several of the individuals involved with either the sinking of PT 109 or the rescue of its crew members: Cpt. K. Yamashiro (senior officer aboard the Amagiri that crushed PT 109), Cpt. T. Hara (captain of the Shigure and who directed machine-gun firing at the sinking PT 109), coast-watcher Reg Evans, and islanders Biuku Gasa and Eroni Kumana (who located Kennedy and suggested that he write a rescue-needed message on a coconut husk) -- all of whom I eventually contacted and receive autographed letters or photographs from (including a 9-page account written by Kumana about his discovery of Lt. John F. Kennedy).Doyle describes well the basic story of PT 109's sinking, Kennedy's swimming in search of help, his encounter with the islanders, and the writing of the coconut message -- all covered well already by Donovan in his earlier book.However, Doyle is able to provide additional details about the ship's sinking and rescue by his recent discovery of several after-actions reports written by Kennedy and others -- that were not known to Donovan.  A reader might ask:  "Heck, after an event as minor as a PT boat being crushed by a destroyer during WWII, what more could be learned from this six-day trial of sea survival?"  Well, as the book's dustcover noted: "Drawing on original interviews with the last living links to the events, previously untapped Japanese wartime archives, and a wealth of archival documents from the Kennedy Library, including a lost first-hand account by JFK himself" author Doyle has enhanced our knowledge of this harrowing military adventure.  Specifically, the author conducted new interviews with Kennedy's shipmates, and the author had his Japanese-speaking wife research and translate a couple of Japanese newspapers that reported on this "battle", as well as translate a couple of Japanese naval documents relating to this naval engagement.  More interesting tidbits, but they don't change the "basic picture."Doyle notes that Kennedy was upset that no search-and-rescue operations were not immediately initiated --except "Several New Zealand P-40 fighter aircraft flew in search of PT 109... spotted boat wreckage, but no survivors were visible" (p. 134).  And his superior, Commander Warfield, believing that all crew members had been killed during the sinking, decided not to send out a search mission that might jeopardize the lives of other PT rescuers (p. 132).Besides recounting how Kennedy joined the navy, became a PT boat commander, was injured during his ship's destruction, and swam in search of help, Doyle expand's upon Donovan's work by noting in more detail how Kennedy used his "war hero" survival story to strengthen his bid in campaigning for his future political wins as a congressman, senator and finally President.Although Doyle's book highlights the bravery of Kennedy in trying to organize the survival of his crew after his ship's sinking, Doyle does present some criticism by those who question Kennedy's judgement in idling his boat's engines to quiet them to hear better in his search for Japanese ships.After winning his congressional race, Kennedy tried to contact Cpt. K. Hanami (who had ordered his ship to ram Kennedy's) during a trip to Japan in Nov. 1951, but wasn't successful -- due to perhaps a bout with Addison's disease (p. 218) -- which he tried to keep hidden from the public as he felt it might hurt his political career.While there is no specific "Bibliography" section, Doyle has a "Notes and Sources" section, whereby he cites his sources.  Doyle also explains that he found new accounts to draw upon to expand our knowledge of the basic event (p. xvi-xvii).If you've already read Donovan's book or Wikipedia articles, you know the basics of Kennedy's PT 109 story.  Nonetheless, while not changing the basic story, Doyle offers new details, but more importantly, provides a most informative analysis how that sinking contributed significantly in developing and furthering Kennedy's political career -- and how his father (Joe Sr.) and his brother (Robert) cajoled others to write "war hero" stories to enhance John's political career.

"The Politics of Social Change in the Middle East and Northern Africa" by Manfred Halpern, (1963), 431 pages; a Rand Corporation report, w/ fold-out map.From the Rand Corp. about this [pre-1964] book:  "An attempt to analyze the cause and character of a profound revolution taking place from Morocco to Pakistan. This Report examines the forces, groups, ideas, and institutions now in motion and estimates the direction which politics may take in the future in the area. While the transformation here under study embraces both the pervasive nationalist revolution and the ensuing "revolution of rising expectations," its sources and ramifications are broader and run deeper than nationalism and its discontents: (1) a way of life 1,300 years old is being destroyed by challenges for which it was almost entirely unprepared; (2) a social system with new values is taking the place of traditional society; (3) a different range of ideological choices has opened up for a new kind of elite; (4) new political instruments are at the elite's disposal; (5) the fact that new men are using new means to attain new ends in their attempts to deal with the politics of social change entails widespread revolutionary consequences."Table of Contents:Part I: The Legacy of the Past and the Claims of the PresentChapter 1: The Inheritance of the Islamic CommunityChapter 2: The Challenge of the Modern Age to IslamPart II : The Changing Structure of SocietyChapter 3: Kings, Landlords, and the Traditional Bourgeoisie: The Declining EliteChapter 4: The New Middle Class as the Principal Revolutionary and Stabilizing ForceChapter 5: Peasants: The Silent Majority at the Threshold of PoliticsChapter 6: Workers: The Growing Tide of the Unskilled and UnemployedPart III: The Range of Political ChoicesChapter 7: Amending the Past: Reformist IslamChapter 8: Resurrecting the Past: Neo-Islamic TotalitarianismChapter 9: Toward a New Age of Certainty: Communist TotalitarianismChapter 10: From Unorganized Insecurity to Organized Insecurity: NationalismChapter 11: Transforming the Present: The Quest for Freedom and AuthorityChapter 12: Transforming the Present: Socialism for the Few, for the Many, or for the Aggrandizement of the State?Part IV: Instruments of Political ModernizationChapter 13: The ArmyChapter 14: Political PartiesChapter 15: Trade UnionsChapter 16: The Civil BureaucracyPart V: The Cost and Consequences of Middle Eastern Choices Domestically, Regionally, and InternationallyChapter 17: The Price of Political StabilityChapter 18: Regional Rivalry and the Prospects for UnityChapter 19: The International Orientation of the Middle EastCritique:  This book pretty well discusses all of the Middle East countries, including Pakistan, in the above chapters.  My disenchantment here is that I believe it would have been better had the author wrote chapters classified by country, and then broken down my the above section-chapters.  For instance, if you wanted to analyze the problems of a specific country, you need to read each of the above chapters and parse out your country-specific interests.The author tries to tie in many countries into one chapter, such as "Chapter 13: The Army".  While some countries, such as Egypt, Jordan and Syria tried some limited cooperation, not all of the other Arab countries really united their countries militaries into a united force.  This chapter is nice in bring many issues relating to "The Army" for comparison between the countries. and while it works on this topic -- I find other chapters seem to "stretch out" in a search for joint comparisons.A lot of "background" information prior to 1963, and the author writes very well -- I'd say even "majestically" as a professional, knowledgeable story-telling researcher -- a fine, talented word-smith.

"The Politics of Terror: An Essential Hamas Lexicon" by Guy Aviad (2014), no index.  This book's title perhaps should have been more direct like "Hamas Lexicon" or "Who's Who in Hamas".Of the 716 pages in this medium-size paperback, sadly, only a paltry 5% (33 pages) are devoted in explaining the development of Hamas between 1987-2012.6% reprint the Hamas' Charter, while 79% (567 pgs) is a "Who's Who" of those involved in the Hamas movement: some 300 biographies of Hamas followers who have committed some militant act (stabbing, killing, bombing or suicide-mission) against Israelis.  After reading about 15 such bios, they begin to blend together: some dude (primarily named Muhammad) infiltrated into Israel to stab or shoot some Israeli.The Hamas bios very in length from a half-page to maybe two pages.  The author provides a few tidbits about each member: name, where born, and what seemed to motivate the Hamas hedonist: he became enraged when back during the 1948 war some battle forced some relative to flee Israel (or he/she got roughed up a bit by an Israeli soldier while throwing stones at the apartheid occupiers), and the Hamas member wants to do his/her part in trying to destroy the Zionist state by committing some relatively small (and usually inconsequential) terrorist attack.  [Inconsequential only in the sense that the attack did not result in some "decisive" policy change by Israel.]So, who is really going to enjoy "reading" this factoid-name tome?  There is no really great "operational strategy" Hamas-attack plan revealed here -- outside of generally individual, one-on-one attacks.  Some policy analyzer could study each bio to see which particular background "slight" enraged a Hamas fighter.Appendix C: is a 14-page "List of Major Attacks by Hamas", detailing dates, attack method, where committed, and the number of victims killed.Mini-theme pages that are not included in the Contents page are: Hamas founding fathers; Bereaved (Palestinian) Parents; Prison inmates; Prisoners released in the Gilad Shalit deal; University grates by country of study; a list of Palestinian Legislative Council members and short lists of Hamas military squads; Kidnapped Israeli soldiers, Marj al-Zohour deportees,  Hamas explosives experts, Hamas suicide bombers, and major terrorist attacks.Not a captivating or exciting read, but if you want to know the 300 major players in Hamas before 2012, this is your book.

"The Red Circle" by Brandon Webb.  I read several of the 2-star and 3-star reviews, many of which thought that this book was too long, and/or covered too much of the author's teenage angst years with his father -- who didn't seem to have very great parenting skills in communicating-fathering with this son.  I thought that the author's recounting of his youth years was just about right; they were relevant in understanding his growing up along the California coast and diving -- all of which contributed in preparing him for his Navy SEAL career.Others thought that were would be more shoot-'em-up stories about the Afghan/Iraq wars; he recounted primarily his own battles -- and some involving his buddies or students.  This was the first SEAL book that I have read -- so I found almost very paragraph of interest.  Some reviewers thought that the author spent too much time in explaining his training, the training methods, and the reforms that he hade at the Navy SEAL Sniper Corps -- I found all of this very informative.The author recounts some of the sad antics of his instructors or superiors whose goal seemed to be in trying to purposely flunk training candidates, rather than trying to make them better.  I highly recommend this book to all!

Partial comments by Joel Singer in the Fall 2015 "The Middle East Quarterly":"Hirschfeld tells the fascinating story of how, together with a handful of colleagues, he served from 1978 through 2014 as a private "foreign ministry" for Yossi Beilin and Shimon Peres both before, during, and after they served as Israeli deputy foreign minister and foreign minister, respectively. During that time, Hirschfeld assisted them in track-two diplomacy and exploring new ideas and models of resolving the Israeli-Palestinian dispute through informal discussions with Palestinians and others....."Hirschfeld has been committed to track-two diplomacy, mostly related to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, for more than thirty-five years, concurrently wearing several hats in the process: academic, think tank, and political...."Because history books are normally written by track-one players, this book provides a unique inside view of the intensive and continuous track-two activity that is hidden from the public eye. It offers a wealth of information that has not yet been covered by any other publication on the Middle East peace process."

Partial comments by Wolfgang Schwanitz from the Fall 2015 "The Middle East Quarterly":"Ethnographer ÃzyÃ¼rek, born and raised in Turkey and now living in America, explores Muslim life in Germany. She investigates Muslim immigrants and post-1989 East German converts. Her key thesis is highly controversial: that the search by German and other European-born converts for a purified Islam can best be understood in a climate of increasing xenophobia and hostility to Islam. The reader might ask if that hostility is indeed increasing, and, if in a less heated climate, would there be no search for a "true Islam?""Religious minorities, ÃzyÃ¼rek posits, cannot fully embrace their minority position, nor entirely abandon it, nor cause it to disappear completely. Politicians insist that Muslims can live in Germany as citizens, but their religion or Islamic identity is often not accepted. In turn, they try to respond to this challenge by showing that one can be, for instance, a conservative Muslim and a good German citizen at the same time. Thus, they willingly let their ethnic identities as Arabs, Turks, Bosnians, or Indians slip into the background, says the author....."Her field work from 2006 to 2011 included studying lectures and social activities for converts in eight mosques operating mainly in the German language. Additionally, ÃzyÃ¼rek conducted interviews with sixty-six converts and fourteen born-Muslims; these form the most vibrant section of her book....."Surprisingly, she finds that, for East Germans, becoming Muslim is "a way of escaping their East German identity" (although many East Germans Muslims still have a proud identity as participants in the overthrow of a totalitarian regime). Born Muslims, on the other hand, promote a more de-culturalized Islam as a way for them to integrate."In terms of field research, this book is a trail-blazer. Although not free of stereotypes, including those regarding East Germans, it offers quality food for thought on many of the main issues of Muslim integration and non-integration in Germany, and constitutes a solid base to compare results with other parts of Europe."

Partial comments by Wolfgang Schwanitz  in the Fall 2015 "The Middle East Quarterly":"ElsÃ¤sser of the Christian-Albrechts-University in Kiel offers a detailed account of the status of Coptic Christians under Husni Mubarak's regime (1981-2011). The author defines the "Coptic question" as a complex of issues ranging from the struggles of daily life to constitutional questions to the problem of political participation."The author argues that, in the Mubarak era, human rights and civil society groups saw Coptic concerns within the framework of authoritarianism and human rights violations though the rise of public discussion of these issues marked a breakthrough for Coptic grievances. Unlike in previous discourses on national unity and religious patriotism, the debates on citizenship provided a widely accepted conceptual framework in which different problems such as legal and administrative discrimination or human rights violations against the Copts could properly be addressed....."The author finds that Muslim and Christian religious revivalism appeared simultaneously and share similar ideas and social bases (the educated middle class). He posits that Coptic revivalists have little political ideology, certainly nothing remotely comparable to their Muslim rivals such as the Islamist Sayyid Qutb. Christian revivalism, also, focuses on increased spiritual interest or renewal of the life of the church."ElsÃ¤sser sees the current volatile state of Muslim-Christian affairs and rising sectarian tensions as the legacy of the Mubarak era. But the 2014 Egyptian constitution for the first time offers a "democratic system," and article three allows Christians and Jews "their Shari'as" as the main source of civil legislation to "regulate their respective personal status, religious affairs, and selection of spiritual leaders."

Partial comments by Steven Rosen in the Fall 2015 "The Middle East Quarterly":"This thorough and authoritative account assembles the definitive record of Israel's policy toward the Palestinian refugee issue in the early years of the state. Tovy of the Herzl Institute at the University of Haifa examines the origins of Israel's policy toward repatriation, resettlement, compensation, blocked bank accounts, internal refugees, and family reunification, drawing on declassified archives from government meetings, Knesset committees, and files of the prime minister's advisor on Arab affairs.Tovy illustrates how, beginning with Israel's creation in 1949, its first prime minister, David Ben-Gurion, came under great pressure to accept the return of large numbers of Arabs displaced during Israel's war of independence. At home, the second largest party in the Knesset, Mapam, a Marxist-Zionist party allied with the Soviet Union, advocated for full repatriation of all Arab refugees. Abroad, the Truman administration initially called upon Israel to accept repatriation of 200,000-250,000 Arab refugees, a number that would have raised the Arab minority in the fledgling state from 13 to 30 percent and created staggering political, economic, and security problems."The author examines how Ben-Gurion deflected the pressure with a policy that was adroit rather than confrontational....  Ben-Gurion did not, however, declare absolute opposition to the great powers. Instead, he deflated the issue by saying it should be resolved at a peace conference with Israel's Arab neighbors, at which time an appropriate balance between resettlement, compensation, and repatriation would be negotiated. This put the burden on the United States and Britain to bring the Arabs to the table for a realistic dialogue, something the Arabs would not accept."In Tovy's opinion, Ben-Gurion's approach worked. In just a few months, U.S. policy shifted from pressure on Israel to accept repatriation, to various proposals for an economic solution, to resettlement through regional cooperation. However, this has left the refugee problem unresolved...."

Partial comments by Michael Rubin in the Fall 2015 "The Middle East Quarterly":"The author provides a narrative, both readable and substantive, tracking the major trends in Iran over the past century..... In separate chapters, she explores the major ideological trends that have dominated the Iranian political landscape: communism, "revolutionarism," and ideological Islam."Shirali displays an impressive ability to describe the big picture and illustrate salient trends, but her consideration of the clergy makes The Mystery of Contemporary Iran path-breaking. Many authors include them among Iran's engines of change. Shirali argues, however, that both liberalism and political reform frightened the clergy, setting the stage for increasingly reactionary behavior not only in the aftermath of the constitutional revolution but also against the backdrop of Mosaddiq's agrarian reforms and the shah's modernization drive of the 1960s and 1970s. One of her most startling contributions is evidence showing how clerical intransigence evolved into support for terrorism decades before Ayatollah Khomeini's revolution took the world by surprise."With so much new academic work in Iranian studies blighted by arcane theory, apologetics, and a narrow, irrelevant focus, Shirali's work is a breath of fresh air, offering a masterful and must-read combination of political and intellectual history."

Partial comments from a review by Stephen Schwartx in the Fall 2015 "The Middle East Quarterly":"Haider's volume is by no means an introduction to the Shiite tradition in Islam. Rather, it is the author's analysis of features of Shiism that have drawn his attention, emphasizing details that for a reader little acquainted with the sect will likely be difficult to follow and of little interest.....Thus, while discussing the transformation over time of the Khoja Shiites and their absorption into Niza'ri Isma'ilism, the reader is forced to suffer through rather predictable but, nonetheless, lamentable quotations from leftist sociologist Frantz Fanon and Palestinian apologist Edward Said, culminating in a sharp critique of the movement's current leader, Aga Khan, IV, for what Haider calls his "modernist" ideas and attachment to capitalism.For the author, the "collective memory" of Shiites, focused on the legitimacy of Muhammad's son-in-law Ali as successor to the Muslim prophet, his assassination in 661 C.E., and the subsequent battle of Karbala, in which Ali's son Hussein was slain, recede into the background. They serve merely as markers to distinguish between the main Shiite traditions: the Twelvers, the Isma'ilis, and the Zaydis. Comparison of the differences in narratives of Karbala among these groupsâwhich focus on a cosmic significance in the martyrdom of Hussein among the Twelvers and Isma'ilis, and a less spiritual protest over the break in Muhammad's lineage for the Zaydisâprovides a simple reference for scholars.For those who have some acquaintance with Shiism, this volume may prove a useful handbook in sorting out differences within the sect. For most newcomers to the subject, it will likely prove confusing and a waste of time."

Partial comments by Alex Joffe from his review in the Fall 2015 "Middle East Quarterly Review":"From the creation of the Palestinian Student Association at the University of Cairo in 1944 to that of the General Union of Palestinian Students (GUPS) in 1959, student organizations have been at the forefront of political activism and have provided cadres of leadership to various Palestinian factions. As successive waves of political fervor washed over Arab society, student politics followed suit: revolutionary leftism, pan-Arabism, and Islamism have been prominent themes. Zelkovitz details how Palestinian students, particularly those living far from the Middle East, tended to be more radical and routinely pushed against compromises that could bring peace. GUPS, for example, not only reached out to leftists in Europe throughout the 1960s but provided support to Palestinian terrorists there and in the Middle East."Zelkovitz provides a wealth of detail regarding student movements, their constant in-fighting, and the ways they were both vied over and, in turn, influenced by political movements. Universities were not only an arena for activism against Israel but also a place for each faction to demonstrate its ability to lead Palestinians."Universities have also been vital for nationalizing Palestinian society, especially after 1967, when the first such institutions were established in the West Bank and Gaza. According to Zelkovitz, inept Israeli efforts to control them, their staff, and curricula, backfired badly. This helped bolster various nationalist visions on campus, first Fatah's and then Hamas's."Zelkovitz notes that Palestinian student radicalism now propels North American universities too: Uncompromising opposition to Israel, the baseline of Arab and Muslim student politics, has also become the touchstone there for leftist university politics."

The author of the 47-page-long "Jihad in the Qur'an and Sunna" is "Sheik Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Humaid" who was the Chief Justice of Saudi Arabia (c. 1390 A.H./1975 A.D.). Briefly, this eminent Muslim justice wrote that "holy fighting" (al-Jihad) is `obligatory' for all Muslims to `fight against all the Mushrikun as well as against the people of the Scriptures (Jews and Christians) if they do not embrace Islam, till they pay the Jizya (a tax levied on the non-Muslims who do not embrace Islam...) with willing submission and feel themselves subdued (as it is revealed in the Verse 9:29)' (p. 9-10). The author cites other verses (ayats) from either the Koran or the sunna commentaries about how militant jihad is `the best thing that one can volunteer for. All the Muslim religious scholars unanimously agree that Jihad is superior to Hajj and Umra..." (p. 24). This booklet can be downloaded from "islamworld" net. Peaceniks living in denial of the war traditions of the Prophet Mohammad would label this jurist Islamophobic, but devotees of the Robert Spencer School of Islam would most likely call him an Islamorealist.

"A Funny Things Happened To Me on the Way to Tel Aviv -- Gamal Abdel Nasser -- A Mad History of the Arab-Israeli Campaign"; by Paul Laikin (author); Joe Simon (editor?); 66 pages (1967); English with some Hebrew.  This photo "comic book" is a fictional account of Egyptian Pres. Nasser's "after action" report of his June 1967 almost-invasion of Israel -- the pun being in the comic-book's title.This is 66 pages of real photographs of various Israeli, Egyptian & Israeli political and military leaders.  However, fake "talking or dialogue"  balloons have been posted onto the photos to make the personality look foolish in making some fake, humorous, slap-stick commentary about the "Six Day War".One can see this on the comic's cover: it shows Egyptian Pres. Nasser and nine apparatchiks all wearing a one-eye patch similar to the one worn by wounded Israeli general Dayan --- the humor here being that if the Egyptians would just wear an eye-patch then the Egyptians could win a war, too.  A type of photo-comic-book that was in style during the 1960s.  Arabs probably won't find much humor with the fake commentaries.

"A Funny Things Happened To Me on the Way to Tel Aviv -- Gamal Abdel Nasser -- A Mad History of the Arab-Israeli Campaign"; by Paul Laikin (author); Joe Simon (editor?); 66 pages (1967); English with some Hebrew.  This photo "comic book" is a fictional account of Egyptian Pres. Nasser's "after action" report of his June 1967 almost-invasion of Israel -- the pun being in the comic-book's title.This is 66 pages of real photographs of various Israeli, Egyptian & Israeli political and military leaders.  However, fake "talking or dialogue"  balloons have been posted onto the photos to make the personality look foolish in making some fake, humorous, slap-stick commentary about the "Six Day War".One can see this on the comic's cover: it shows Egyptian Pres. Nasser and nine apparatchiks all wearing a one-eye patch similar to the one worn by wounded Israeli general Dayan --- the humor here being that if the Egyptians would just wear an eye-patch then the Egyptians could win a war, too.  A type of photo-comic-book that was in style during the 1960s.  Arabs probably won't find much humor with the fake commentaries.

"With Paulus at Stalingrad" by German Col. Wilhelm Adam & Otto Ruhle; translated by Tony Le Tissier; Pen & Sword Books; published in the UK, with 287 pages in English, no index; includes 4 pages of maps, but only 8 pages of glossy photographs; Sept. 2015.Co-author Otto Ruhle, a former soldier and a friend of the author who assisted in the author's research, in "close working association assisted in the publication of this book"; originally in the German language in Nov. 1965.Col. W. Adam was senior aide-de-camp to German Colonel-general (later Fieldmarshall) Friedrich Paulus during the German 6th Army's ill-fated attempted capture of the Russian city of Stalingrad around Sept. 1942 - late Jan. 1943.After capturing much of Stalingrad, the German army was surrounded by the Russians -- which effectively caused the starving Germans to surrender in Jan. 1943. Following the surrender, the author remained in captivity until Sept. 1948, when he chose to settle in communist East Germany. There he converted to becoming a communist apparatchik -- along with a number of other German officers, including Paulus. Adam eventually rose to become a general in the East Germany army, and after retiring in 1958 began to write this book -- which was first published as "Der schwere Entschluss" in East Germany in Nov. 1965.This book is Col. Adam's account of his combat service with Lt. Gen. Paulus after the later became commander-in-chief of the 6th Army in late Jan. 1942 on the Eastern Front, until their joint surrender just a year later in Stalingrad to the Russians.  As Paulus never got around to writing his own account, Adam's book here is the only one I know of that was written by someone on Paulus' staff.  Yes, when you read a typical book about "Fortress Stalingrad" you read the same accounts of the final surrender -- this book provides more details.At the time of this review (1 Sept. 2015), there is no "Look Inside" feature to this book (I'm sure one will be provided soon). Hence, a brief listing of the chapters and a few limited sub-topics:Chapter 1: Marching to the Volga [Jan. - Aug. 1942] - (Gen. Paulus' assumption of command; discussions with Gen. Keitel; Hitler's attack aims for 1942; Filed Marshal von Bock has to go; Thrust over the Don) {48 pages long}.Chapter 2: The Shattered Attack on the City [Sept. -Nov. 1942] (The 'Land Bridge' between the Don and the Volga; Gen. von Wietersheim is relieved; Gumrak main dressing station; Little success with great losses; The enemy has grown; The tragi-comedy of winter clothing) (40 pages}.Chapter 3: Counteroffensive and Encirclement [Nov. - Dec. 1942] (The storm breaks; Paulus and Schmidt fly into the cauldron {Stalingrad}; Defence without heavy weapons) {25 pgs}.Chapter 4: Between Hope and Destruction [Dec. 1942] (I fly into the cauldron; Breakout forbidden; 'Fortress Stalingrad'; Goring's lie about air supply; Christmas in the cauldron) {55 pgs}.Chapter 5: An End to the Horrors [Jan. 1943] (Fantastic breakout plans; The tragedy of the wounded; the decision to surrender) {45 pgs}.Chapter 6: New Shores [Feb. 1943 - 1958] (Meeting the Russian victors; Discussion about the National Committee 'Free Germany'; Going over to the National Committee's side' Field Marshal Paulus turns against Hitler; the war's end; Nuremburg; Returning home to the New East Germany) {62 pgs}.Chapter 7: For the New Germany (reflections) {5 pgs}.So, what personality/moral traits can we learn about Col Adam?  Well, by serving in the German military during WWII he supported German dictator Adolf Hitler and his destructive goals, and the author seemed to struggle somewhat before converting to support another dictatorial system: Stalin's communist rule -- rather than moving to the democracy-driven West Germany.  We can surmise that he saw a better income in serving in the East German military, whereas as  "turn-coat" he probably would have had a difficult time in re-joining the W. German army.As the translator noted: "Adam's [book] is noticeable for the complete lack of any criticism or adverse comment about the Soviets."The author, having served on Paulus' staff inside "The Cauldron" of encirculed Stalingrad, provides very detailed accounts of the discussions of the staff in how best to defend "Fortress Stalingrad" from Russian attack, as well as their analysis leading to the decision to surrender.I'm not going to recount how Paulus made some decision to transfer some unit to some other sector, instead, I'd like to provide some unusual tidbits:Regarding the wounded Adam noted they were "wrapped in blankets and bits of tent, with sacks and bandages on their frozen feet instead of boots.  They were hardly soldiers any more.  They were a broken, disarmed mob"  (p. 149).One might ask: "What influenced the author to turn his back on Hitler, his country, his Germany army, to support the Soviet effort in enticing other German soldiers to defect to the Russians.  Addressing this issue would take some time, but it started as the author began reading Soviet propaganda leaflets that had been dropped into Stalingrad  and that urged German soldiers to desert for a safer life (p. 178).In reviewing this book, one needs to contemplate whether or not Adam's conversion to communism influenced his revelations in this book.  I'll let others muse this topic-- but one must be aware of such influence.  Such influences are not blatant: "Germans bad; Russians good."  It took about 6 months in captivity, and reading various communist tracts, before the author began to turn against Hitler and develop agreement with his communist handlers.Adam doesn't relate many "personal" stories of witnessing some German soldier losing a leg after stepping on a landmine, he wrote more generalized descriptions of witnessing some pack of soldiers freezing along some road.The author explained that he and Gen. Paulus (and most generals) were "apolitical", in that they "followed their orders".  The author said that he and Paulus didn't really contemplate how the policies of Fuhrer Hitler were hurting German civilians.After their surrender, German communists were able to slowly develop a (for the lack of a better word) "guilt complex" amongst some of the generals by pointing out how Hitler really didn't care about the suffering of German soldiers and civilians -- essentially, what was the purpose of the war?After evaluating that Hitler's regime was not only "bad" for the Germans, but also "evil", the author, Paulus and other German officers joined a movement to publicly call for the over through of Hitler to prevent further destruction of Germany.I don't know why it took so long for this book to be released in English -- maybe due to some copyright issues.  But it certainly is one that is a "must" read for understanding the thinking of Paulus' staff during their long refusal to surrender after being surrounded by the Russians.Very BRIEF discussion of his post-war activities in the E. German government.

"Stalingrad: The City that Defeated the Third Reich" by Jochen Hellbeck (April 2014), [originally published in German in Oct. 2012 as "Die Stalingrad Protokolle"].  There are many photographs sprinkled throughout this book.Essentially, this book is a collection of hundreds of excerpted statements from various Russian sources regarding the horrific battle (Aug. 1942 - Feb. 1943) between Russian and German armies over a Russian city: Stalingrad.  [Its importance was more psychological than strategic: the Germans wanted to capture a city named in honor of the Russian oligarch, while the Russians wanted to defend it for the same reason.]Amazingly, in looking at the "Look Inside" option, it appears that the entire book has been made available for reading on-line (so much for trying to protect the contents of this book from free reading).Besides being merely a listing of selected excerpts, the author provides an introduction and analysis of each chapter topic.  Given the readily available "Look Inside" feature, there is no need for me to list all of the Table of Contents or themes here.To me, what I found of particular interest, was the section from Chapter 2 regarding "The Capture of Field Marshal Paulus" (pages 222-261).  I've previously read several accounts of Paulus' surrender, but I found much new information here.  So it was interesting to learn how many of the different Russian participants commented on how "dirty" they found the German rooms to be -- apparently, few Germans were brave enough to try to toss out their human waste while Russian shells were raining down outside.The Russian accounts ring true with my other readings of Paulus' surrender: he was pallid, disheveled, almost totally out-of-focus regarding the conduct of the battle, and almost seemingly uncaring about his appearance or the well-being of his troops.In this book though are the first accounts I have read of Russians killing Germans after their surrender:  "Prisoners were being brought out with frostbitten feet, bandaged heads...But I did use my pistol to finish off their wounded in the basements" (p.256) and an account: "You'd often hear them [Germans] saying that our [Russian] success at Stalingrad was all due to chance...Our commandant grabbed one of them by the sleeve, dragged him off, and shot him" (p.257).Besides the excerpted comments of Russians who participated in the battle, excerpts from German publications are also provided to portray the experiences of how Germans suffered following their surrender.  I believe fewer than 10% survived to successfully return to Germany after their eventual release in 1956.There will be those who contend that some/much of this book is merely Soviet propaganda, I'll let others debate the validity of the readings -- I'm not an expert in this field.I like reading accounts of "I Was There" events -- I like learning of the original observations rather than summarized opinions.  As such, I am very pleased with so many first-hand accounts regarding this battle -- I highly recommend this book.  {As a companion book, I suggest: "Survivors of Stalingrad: Eyewitness Accounts" by Reinhold Busch, Oc.t 2014}

"Panzer Operations: Germany's Panzer Group 3 during the Invasion of Russia, 1941" by Gen. Hermann Hoth (April 2015), which was originally published in German in 1956.  As the subtitle of this book states, the battlefield scope of this book focuses on Panzer Group 3 during its invasion of Russia between June-Oct. 1941, although the author does review the "Big Picture" of the overall invasion..Although this book totals 215 pages, 10% of the book is devoted to appendices & bibliography.  The author devotes 6 pages to his thoughts regarding the viability of tanks during a possible nuclear war in Europe -- which really don't add much to this book.  Fortunately,  16 pages are of nice campaign maps.  The author spends several pages analyzing the differences between "operational" versus "strategic" goals versus "tactics" (p.28) and how such thoughts were contemplated by Clausewitz versus Scharnhorst, and how such thoughts influenced the German military mind during the 1870s, WWI, and Hitler.As the author noted: "This book does not purport to be a definitive account of the military history of the Russian campaign" (p.7) ... "In the first few months of the Russian campaign, [the author's] Panzer Group 3 was the middlemost of the three northern German panzer groups".The author noted: "The pros and cons of an attack against Russia are thoroughly described elsewhere" (p,39), but he does devote a couple of pages reviewing how the German campaigns against England (Operation Sealord), and in the Balkans, influenced Hitler's time-schedule in invading Russia (Operation Barbarossa).Hence, with all of the author's prior-to-battle analysis, his discussion regarding his actual invasion and initial battles inside Russia are reduced to barely 80 pages -- but the author's prior-to-battle reflection is still very useful in understanding some of the battle-preparation thoughts of Hitler's staff as they developed the Russia-invasion plans -- and how they debated how much initial emphasis should be devoted to destroying Russian military units before turning attention to capturing political targets (Moscow vs. Leningrad).As a graduate of the U.S. Army's "Command & General Staff College" myself, it was insightful that the author high-lighted some of the invasion problems:  roads were more paved in northwestern Russia than in the south, different terrains (forests versus marshlands) constricted armour-column traffic routes, could bridges be secured before the Russians could destroy them?, where were Russian military units deployed?, how many Russian units were mech verses horse-drawn?, how soon would new and stronger Russian tanks replace weaker under-armed tanks?, how the lack of railroad lines impeded troop advancement?,  etc.The author noted how German generals debated whether or not to allow panzer units to rapidly advance -- as slower-moving supporting units might have to be left behind and play a slow catch-up (p.73).No need here to recount how the author, Gen. Hoth, maneuvered his Panzer Group 3 during the invasion, except to note that he provided nice details as to how he conducted his maneuvers in advancing and encircling Russian units.  He noted disputes between German military commanders, as how some Russian units escaped (temporarily) when Gen. Guderian decided to capture terrain heights to deprive them from the enemy (p.113).  Gen. Hoth also discussed how campaigns changed (usually for the worse) as Hitler changed his mind as to how his units should be deployed within Russia -- even by mid-July (barely 30 days into the invasion).  Besides discussing his own maneuvers, Gen. Hoth also describes how adjacent units were also affected by changes from Hitler's directives.Gen. Hoth limits his book to essentially operational issues, he doesn't comment upon whether or not any of his units assisted in the rounding up of Jews or punishment of captured Russian guerrilla-partisans.I highly recommend this very informative book.[A companion book regarding the harsh treatment of captured Jews and partisans during the 1941 invasion by the German XXXXIII Corps is: "A German General on the Eastern Front" by Johannnes Hurter -- being a limited history of German Gen. Gotthard Heinrici between 1941-42.]

"Cathedral of the Wild" by Boyd Varty, March 2014; 281 pages.  This is a story written by a 29-year-old male of his experiences growing up c. 1979 on an South African game preserve since the age of 5.He had many close encounters in being killed (let alone being merely badly injured) by the local wildlife (either elephant, rhino, croc or by one of a multitude of venomous snakes) but survived -- despite either his father or uncle who led him into a never ending-series of potentially deadly encounters with ever-hungry wildlife.While he enjoyed growing up in the game preserve, in his early twenties he grew restless and wanted to see more of the world -- so he headed off to India and traveled through that expansive land.Nonetheless, the feelings for his family finally pulled him back to South Africa -- at a time when it was struggling to shove off its white apartheid heritage in favor of, essentially, emancipation for its black majority.One unsolved mystery that tormented the author's soul was the on-going lawsuit between several investors in the game preserve -- the author mentioned it infrequently, but frequently enough to pike a reader's interest, but by the end of the book their is no resolution to the lawsuit: the reader is just left twisting in the wind wondering what was the out come of the lawsuit -- and its impact upon the management of the game preserve.While reading this book, while one admires the author's dad in introducing him to the raw nature of an "eat or be eaten" world, at times one is aghast in learning how irresponsible the author's father seemed to be in putting his son in harm's way.For those who enjoy a read that puts them in a sweat in wondering how the author is going to survive some dangerous encounter with "what big teeth you have" wildlife -- then this book is for you!

[Partial comments by Jeremy Sigler in the 23 March 2015  on-line "Tablet Magazine"]:..." A big bunch of Polaroids (over a thousand) that the artist Balthus never intended to show to the world are now ...printed in a book .... And while these rare jewels are being showcased for a few, there is a significant effort being made to keep these pictures out of the hands of the general public."Balthus ...  went to his grave without ever declaring these Polaroids or anything made with emulsion and light-sensitive paper to be his art, while those of us who have been lucky enough to see these Polaroids now find ourselves reacting to this new unauthorized addition to the artistâ oeuvreâunsure if we are thrilled to be informed or if we are burdened by this new and incriminating visual evidence...."I had not intended to review these Polaroids....Balthusâ photographs are a very soft-core form of, um, well, âkiddy appreciation.â Right on the line of inappropriateness, they could be called âultra softâ core, like the toilet paper. They feel perfectly safe, and perfectly friendly, and are not the least bit seedy."In this context of epic transgression, Balthus would be thought of as totally harmless. ....Balthus, in other words, was getting in touch with his inner extended puberty.  I like to refer to this as the âeternal coming-of-age story,â and we all have the capacity to live this life......."The story has it that between 1990 and 2000, Annaâthe youngest daughter of Balthusâ doctorâwas recruited to be Balthusâ model. She began the ritual of coming to the chalet to pose when she was merely 8, and the dance continued every Wednesday afternoon until she was 16!"The critic Ingrid Sischy, who reviewed the Polaroids in their debut show at Gagosianâs New York gallery in 2013, describes the scene well: âAnna is dressed in either a tartan or a white dress when she is younger, typically posing in an armchair, but as time goes on she moves to a chaise lounge and wears a brocade robe that sometimes falls open, so sheâs partially nude.â"And I would add my own observation that the knee of the back leg is usually up and the front leg is usually bent downâextending off the edge of the daybed into the foreground and out of the frame. Thus the picture is open and inviting, but also cozy and nurturing. With each repeating close-up (often completely out of focus), the artist attempts to lock in and stabilize the figure. The back arm is often thrown up over the modelâs head, while the front arm is usually down and relaxed. The geometry formed by the slanted arms and legs is frequently that of the running man symbol or swastika."One excellent feature of the Steidl book is a short text written by Anna Wahli......."Now, due to the Polaroids, we get to leave the artistâs primary medium of painting and drawing behind, maybe for the first time ever. We get to âgo it aloneâ without the marriage of his beloved medium. We get to see what he saw (or didnât see; ironically). These Polaroids are suddenly activated by our gaze on the muse and the museâs performance for usânot for Balthus...."By reacting so strongly and with such pleasure to the Polaroids arenât I validating them and thus undermining the artistâs intentions to âsay itâ in paint? And yet, I feel like these Polaroids may be among his greatest achievement, and I am glad that they were put out in the world."

"The Lives of Muhammad" by Kecia Ali (2014).[Partial comments from a review by Robert Spencer in the Spring 2015 "Middle East Quarterly"]:"Ali's work evaluates and compares biographies of Muhammad, ancient and modern, favorable and unfavorable, arguing that the emphases of these life histories reflect the concerns of the age in which they were written. ..."However, Ali's book is guilty of a grave defect: She is generally disdainful of biographies that are critical of Muhammad while dismissing legitimate concerns about the examples that stories about him set for contemporary Muslims. Her chief complaint, for example, about this author's [Robert Spencer] own biography, "The Truth about Muhammad", is that while it provides "reasonably accurate information," it is "framed and interpreted in relentlessly negative ways." Conversely, she characterizes authors of positive biographies such as Karen Armstrong and Tariq Ramadan as "public intellectuals"; this author [Robert Spencer], on the other hand, is described as a "professional polemicist" and the "grand pooh-bah of the legion of American Islamophobes.""Similarly, Ali's use of the propaganda neologism "Islamophobe" to tar Muhammad's critics mars the academic value of her work. Her preference for admirers of Muhammad frequently clouds her ability to evaluate the data. ...."The premise of The Lives of Muhammad is intriguing, and it contains a good deal of useful information. It is, however, marred by the author's failure to take seriously the numerous reasons why Muhammad is so deeply problematic a figure for non-Muslims and secular Muslims alike. "

"The Lost Spring: U.S. Policy in the Middle East & Catastrophes to Avoid" by Walid Phares, 2014.When I ordered this book, I had really hoped that I would like learning much from Mr. Phares' observations.  I had hoped that it would be better than a speech that I had listened to his about two years ago in Woodinville, WA -- where he spoke about the "Arab Spring" revolutions that were then underway in the Middle East.  Sadly, it was a rather disjointed speech, rambling between various topics without really tying them together.This book is a little better, at least he, or his editor, tried to keep each chapter focused.  Sadly, the entire book is overly verbose:  many words were written, but repeatedly repeated.  I believe that this book could have easily been condensed by half or more.I appreciate what the author is trying to do:  alert the public to the anti-democratic philosophy of the Islamists, whether of the Muslim Brotherhood or al-Qaeda ilk.But who is Mr. Walid Phares? While he has a brief bio on the inside of the book's book-jacket -- it is too short to give any credence as to who he is in giving us his thoughts.  In his "Acknowledgments" he notes dozens of names that he has discussed his ideas with, but informs us of few of the ideas coming from those conversations.It seemed like in the first quarter of this book the author bemoans that few are interested in heeding his warnings about how either the revolutions were ready to emerge throughout the Middle East in the early 2010s, and he fears that now that the revolutions have broken out, how few are willing to head his concerns as to how the Pres. Obama administration is stifling the pro-democracy revolutionaries in favor of the Muslim Brotherhood that will stifle those yearning to live free of the harsh Islamist oppression.  He wants to heard as a modern-day Paul Revere -- but fears being viewed as more of a William Dawes -- sounding the same alarm as Mr. Robert Spencer (Jihad Watch), but few listening, or worse, remembering him.The author reviews how the revolutions developed throughout the Middle East, but then re-examines  and re-tells us the same descriptions over and over again.  Brevity would have been better, but more importantly, more "meat" about those revolutions needed to be documented -- far too many generalizations as to what happened, and too few names of groups and specific details as to how the revolutionaries organized their demonstrations.After trying to stay awake in reading the first 160 pages of this book, I finally came upon what I believe is the best part of this book: Chapter Eleven, where the author analyzed how Pres. Obama essentially ignored the pro-democracy revolutionaries to support instead the anti-democratic Muslim Brotherhood.The author downplays the significance of the split between the Sunni and Shia sects, instead, he seems to believe that "moderate" Muslims are somehow going to coalesce in debunking the Islamists.  Too much wordiness and lack of substance in this book.  His heart and mind are in the right, just wish he could be more effective in exposing it in print.

"Through Bolshevik Russia" by (Viscount Philip) Mrs. Ethel  Snowden; 1920, 190 pgs.  This book developed from an investigation that she participated in between April-June 1920, at the behest of the British Labor Party.  It is her travelogue of her 6-week trip through a small area of the newly emerging Bolshevik Russia.  Her journey was in part in an attempt to entice the Russian communist government to enter into peace talks with Poland, which had attempted to seize a small section of Russia, as well as entice the British government to end its blockage of Russia -- which was curtailing the importation of goods for Russia's poor.This is not a profound, investigative-journalism account of life under the post-Czar USSR.  However, the author wrote a sympathetic view of the poor Russians that she encountered.  She was "happy" for the revolution overthrowing the Czars, but she was dismissive of the Bolshevik coup d'Ã©tat in installing a  non-elective, minority-ruling government.At the time of my review, there was no "look inside" feature.  Hence, following is the  Table of Contents:IntroductionChapter 1: A Starving People ["Besides the lack of food there is an almost entire lack of medicines, anesthetics, linen for bandages, disinfectants and soap" (p.18)]2: Making Our Plans3: Ghosts [when visiting private properties that had been confiscated by the communists, she wondered what had happened to their previous owners; "When we rode in the czar's motor-car, I did not feel the presence of my fellow-delegates, but the ghosts of the new dead unhappy, little man and his family" (p.38)]4: Investigating on Propaganda5: The Communists6: The Artists Life of Russia7: The Military Power of Russia8: Education and Religion9: Off to Moscow10: An Interview with Lenin  [from her 1.5 hours interview with Lenin, she wrote "He impressed me with his fanaticism.  This is surely the source of his driving power" (p.127).]11: Talks with Communists and Others12: The Dictatorship of the Communists13: The Suppression of Liberty14: Down the Volga15: The Future of RussiaThis book is known for his sharp, critical condemnation of the communist regime.  A brief, yet informative look at 1920 Russia -- at a time when many pro-communist-oriented publications in Europe were glossing over the heavy handiness of the new communist dictatorship.

"Farsi (Persian) Phrasebook & Dictionary" by Yavar Dehghani, Lonely Planet Publ.,  (3rd ed. Nov. 2014), 260 pages; ISBN 978-1-74179-1341 (printed in China).  I am unsure how much revision has occurred from the last Apr. 2001 ed., but this 3rd ed. has a new and different ISBN.Unfortunately, Amazon gives no "look inside" feature.  Hence, following are this ed.'s chapters:1:Intro; 2: Pronunciation; 3:Grammar; 4:Meeting People; 5:Getting Around; 6:Accommodation (hotels, renting); 7:Around Town; 8: Going Out; 9:Family; 10:Interests (cinema & theatre, music, sport, hobbies, etc.); 11:Social Issues (politics, environment, social issues); 12:Shopping; 13:Food; 14:In the country (camping, hiking, geographical terms, fauna); 15:Health; 16:Specific Needs (disabled travelers; looking for a job; pilgrimage & religion, on business): 17:Time, dates & festivals; 18:Numbers & Amounts; 19:Emergencies; 20:English-Farsi Dictionary (35 pages); 21:Farsi-English Dictionary (30 pages); Index; Finder; Sustainable Travel.This small-pocket size paperback notes: "Throughout this book you'll see coloured phrases on each page.  They're phonetic guides to help you pronounce the language.  Start with them to get a feel for how the language sounds.  The Pronunciation chapter will explain more, but you can be confident that if you can read the coloured phrase, you'll be understood."Hence, EVERY ENGLISH WORD in this book also has the green "how to pronounce in Farsi" transliteration, as well as the Arabic(Farsi)-script; hence:  glass/shishe/(sorry can't reproduce the Arabic-Farsi script here).  For about $10, you're getting a fine buy.

"Leaves from an Autumn of Emergencies: Selections from the Wartime Diaries of Ordinary Japanese" by Samuel Hideo Yamashita, (2005), 331 pages.  The author has read numerous diaries written by Japanese civilians and soldiers during World War II, and from them has selected eight of them for reduction to only 20-30 pages each.  The author undertook this reduction to highlight various insights and experiences of these civilians.Most of these "how I survived the war" diary entries discuss the difficulty of obtaining extra food, as the rations provided by the government were so meager -- more than just hunger pangs: some suffered outright starvation.Other quotations are about how some believed that Japan was still going to win the war, even as they saw more and more of the cities around them being firebombed into near obliteration.  Others doubted that their air-force could actually sink 20 American warships during a single battle.  Some discussed their doubts about the sincerity of their politicians in being honest in reporting on the outcome of various battles  -- as more and more American airplanes appeared overhead, and how the battle-lines of the war-front continually shrank as Japanese forces were overrun.As at the time of this review there was no "view inside" feature, following are the book's chapter titles:"Chapter One: Introduction: The Pacific War and Ordinary Japanese": a review as to how the author make his selections from various war diaries [48 pages]."Chapter Two: The Diary of a Navy Special-Attack Pilot": selections from the diary of a kamikaze (tai-atari) pilot who after training to become a suicide dive-bomber had to wait over a year before finally crashing into an American warship.  Hard to believe that this guy so badly wanted to die for his country -- especially after so many of his co-pilots had met a fiery death.  [30 pages]."Chapter Three: Bittersweet: The Wartime and Postwar Diary of an Ordinary Kyoto Person": details of growing disillusioned with the war effort [50 pages]."Chapter Four: The Diary of a Defeated Japanese Soldier": a disillusioned Japanese soldier on Okinawa doesn't learn about the end of the War until 30 days later -- he surrenders, but feels ashamed.  His daily comments as to how he held out in small caves while American soldiers searched for him and other stragglers. [30 pages]  {My father, a cook in the U.S. Army on Okinawa during 1945-46, would ask Japanese POWs to help in the U.S. mess halls; the POWs would agree to obtain additional food.}"Chapter Five: From the Start of the War" [30 pages]."Chapter Six: Until the War Ended" [30 pages]."Chapter Seven: The Diary of a Labor Service Corps Girl"  [14 pages]."Chapter Eight: The Diary of an Evacuated Schoolboy" [31 pages]."Chapter Nine: The Diary of an Evacuated Schoolgirl" [40 pages]."Glossary" [6  pages].  Bibliography & Index w/ map of Japan.Usually not exciting reading, but one of the few books that details the thoughts of war-weary Japanese civilians.  (Also see:  "Japan At War" by Cook.)

"The Dogs Are Eating Them Now: Our War In Afghanistan" by Graeme Smith, Jan. 2015.  The author covered the Afghan war from 2005 through 2009 for a British newspaper, then returned in June 2011 for an update to this book he was writing.  The author is to be commended for his bravery in traveling throughout southern Afghanistan for several years -- primarily in Kandahar.  While embedded with Canadian forces, he meet with many NGOs, local Afghans, Paks and a handful of Taliban spokesmen.  Fearing being kidnapped by the Taliban, he recruited  a couple of his interpreters to meet with Taliban spokesmen to arrange live telephone interviews.The author used interpreters since he did not speak Dari or other Afghan/Pak languages himself -- this, he acknowledged, limited him in not fully understanding some of the nuances of a message being conveyed to him by the various speakers.  Nonetheless, with his many interviews and long time in researching the area, he developed some fine insights as to what was motivating young men to join the Taliban movement, as well as evaluate the strengths, weaknesses and failures of the NATO campaign in southern Afghanistan.The author noted that he had to finally leave in late 2009 as he was being threatened by various groups for his uncovering how numerous government officials were raking in revenue from their illegal participation in the illegal opium-drug trade.  Outside of a handful of names, and some very loose data, this book isn't a great expose of the illegal drug trade.The author recounts how he scored a media scoop by reporting that some/many Taliban (and some innocent suspects) captured by Canadian/NATO troops were being beaten/tortured by Afghan officials, after being turned over to them.The author noted that at one time more than 800 international military bases were once scattered throughout the country, and that more money had been spent to rehabilitate Afghanistan than what had been spent through the Marshall Plan throughout all of Europe after WWII.The author opined: "The insurgents were not defeated.  We killed thousands of them, but their movement would not die" (p. 1) ... NATO was "relying on counter-insurgency theories that suggested American soldiers could walk into the world's most conservative villages, make friends, hunt their enemies, and build a better society.  None of that proved successful.  Perhaps it wasn't ever possible, after all."The author revealed that so many of the local government officials were either underpaid or not paid at all, which caused them to become lackadaisical and/or disinterested in supporting NATO's rehabilitation agenda.  Graft was a bad drug.Despite his 4-5 years reporting from Afghanistan, and almost 300 pages in this book, the author really doesn't reveal a whole lot of interesting battle activity.  Perhaps he saved his more interesting items for his newspaper.  This is not an account of the author surviving dozens of road ambushes, although he encountered many warlord "checkpoints" where he had to pay a road-tax to proceed.From his reporting, the author concluded that the Afghan war:"Is a family feud""Air strikes pushed people to join the insurgency""Destroying poppy fields makes things worse", and"Taliban nationalism leaves room to negotiate."In trying to understand why the Taliban continued their attacks against the popularly elected government, the author recorded one Taliban spokesman as saying: "When anyone doesn't want to accept the Koran as our constitution, we want to cut their necks ... The northern Afghanistan people, the Kabul people, they don't want our [sharia] constitution and that's why we were fighting against them" (p. 273).  The author really didn't dive into much research or reporting on the theological Islamic underpinnings of the Taliban.Although the author noted: "Afghanistan was an unsuccessful laboratory for ideas about how to fix a ruined country", rather than supporting a cut-and-run solution, the author still asked for "a plea for continued engagement" (p. 283) -- but didn't provide a 7-point list in how to find peace within Afghanistan.For all the time that the author spent there, I was hoping for a little more "meat on the bone" within this book.  But a good book by one of the few correspondents who stuck around the area, instead of being just a one-night-stand reporter.
